description: Students read a selection from Joy Hakim’s book Newton at the Center, which traces the shift from a geocentric model to a heliocentric model of the Universe. The reading helps to contextualize this scientific advancement through the lens of politics, culture, and economics.

title: Planetary Motion and Models of the Universe
description: This test requires students to demonstrate their mathematical understanding of Kepler’s three laws of planetary motion, sidereal and solar days, seasons, and evidence for the geocentric and heliocentric models.

title: Art, Anatomy, and Observation
description: Working collaboratively with the other core courses, students are led through an investigation of selected images from the notebooks of Leonardo da Vinci, Andreas Vesalius, and Juan Valverde de Amusco. Students examine the nature of the sketches in terms of detail, complexity, and likeness to the real subject. Students research the contributions of those artist-scientists to science.

title: The Illuminated Body
description: Students are given a set of guiding questions to respond to based on the images provided in the previous assignment. Using the questions, students trace the scientific advances that were taking place in this period of time in terms of information sharing, techniques, and advances in understanding through comparative studies. Students also research the contributions of Galen and William Harvey to the understanding of circulation.

title: Leonardo: The Artist and the Scientist
description: Through readings, discussions, and analysis of Leonardo’s sketches, students discover that his approach to both art and science was primarily visual and based on careful thought about how to observe.

title: A Closer Examination of Leonardo’s Architectural and Mechanical Drawings
description: This exercise complements students’ work in their Visual Arts class. Students examine the architectural problems that Leonardo addresses as an engineer and process his ability to analyze patterns, spatial organization, and flow as a means to seeing new forms of design. Students are shown how his work foreshadows the study of fractals today.

title: Leonardo and His Ways of Seeing
description: Students discover Leonardo’s work in optics and linear perspective, based on experimentation and his discussion with mathematician Fazio Cardano. Students recreate a series of experiments in which Leonardo mapped the perceived size of objects as the distance from the viewer changed. Additionally, they explore his concepts of perspectives of color, disappearance, shadows, and aerial effects. They ultimately apply this knowledge in their sketches of animal dissections later in the unit and build on this knowledge in their Mathematics and Visual Arts studies during the Renaissance Perspective Drawing integrated project.

title: Leonardo’s Anatomical Sketches
description: Students learn about Leonardo’s earliest anatomical drawings based on dissections, which helped to reveal the mechanics of organ and system functions within a living organism. Students appreciate how Leonardo’s mechanical studies and propensity for invention helped him to think about the body through a mechanistic lens.

title: Organs and Systems, and Form and Function
description: Through lectures, labs, simulations, and discussions, students learn about the chemical nature of life at both macroscopic and microscopic levels, the structure of cells and the role of cell organelles, and the role body systems play as mechanisms for providing life’s needs at the cellular level. Students focus particular attention on the digestive, circulatory, respiratory, and excretory systems in terms of how form implies functions.

title: Quizzes: Digestive System and Circulatory System
description: Students identify the organs in the human digestive and circulatory systems and describe how they function. These quizzes serve as formative assessments to check student understanding before beginning the Renaissance Dissection Project.

title: Test: Life, Cells, and Digestion
description: Before students begin the integrated project entitled the Renaissance Dissection Project in which they will be challenged to complete vertebrate dissections, they display their knowledge about the related life systems. The test includes multiple-choice, short-answer, and labeling questions.

title: Dissection Virtual Notebook Presentation
description: Students produce a Virtual Notebook or a website, documenting their work on the Renaissance Dissection Project. The goal of the notebook is to allow viewers to learn about the dissection itself and understand the student’s experience during the project.

title: Constant Velocity and Acceleration
description: Students are challenged to use their prior knowledge to solve problems using the formulas for constant velocity and acceleration. Students analyze the given information to isolate variables and solve for the unknown.

title: Motion Equations
description: Students solve motion problems that involve nonaccelerated, accelerated, and free-fall motion of objects.

title: Quiz: Kinematics
description: Students’ knowledge of kinematics is assessed through a series of self-paced quizzes.

title: Galileo’s Plane Experiment
description: Students recreate Galileo’s inclined plane experiment to determine whether the equations for accelerated motion are validated.

title: Laboratory Report: Galileo’s Plane Experiment
description: Based on the data they obtained, students present and analyze their findings in both graphic and written form. As part of their report, students contextualize Galileo’s work in the time period.

title: Vectors
description: Students participate in a discussion about physical quantities that require both magnitude and direction for their description, then complete a series of related problem sets.

title: Newton’s First Law of Motion
description: Students are introduced to the concept of inductive reasoning as a way to examine Newton’s laws of motion, and through readings they explore the climate of the time and the role Galileo and Newton played in changing the way the physical world is perceived.

title: Acceleration Experiments
description: Students conduct an exploration of Newton’s Second Law of Motion with a series of investigations in which they empirically examine the relationship between acceleration, mass, and force.

title: Laboratory Report: Acceleration Experiments
description: Students write a laboratory report that describes the results of their acceleration experiments.

title: Test: Kinematics, Vectors, and Inertia
description: Students apply and synthesize their knowledge of the concepts of kinematics, vectors, and inertia by responding to a series of multiple-choice and short-answer questions.

title: Newton’s Second Law
description: Students discuss the components of Newton’s Second Law of Motion, including the forces involved and the use of force diagrams.

title: Newton’s Third Law
description: Students discuss Newton’s Third Law of Motion, dealing with action and reaction forces, and complete a related problem set.

title: Notebook Check
description: Students have been documenting their learning through notes, written reflections and observations, diagrams, and laboratory reports. Students’ notebooks are checked to assess and address any gaps in their overall understanding.

title: Test: Newton’s Laws
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of Newton’s laws of motion as they synthesize the concepts studied through a series of applied problems and short-answer questions.

title: Projectile Motion
description: Students examine both the vertical and horizontal components of projectile motion, applying their understanding of kinematics to the process.

title: Hit the Cup Experiment
description: Students apply the laws of projectile motion to predict how far away a cup must be placed on the floor so that a ball rolling along a laboratory bench at a known speed falls directly into a cup. Students analyze the data collected during the investigation, prepare a laboratory report, and use the data as evidence to respond to a series of questions.

title: History of Conservation Laws (Descartes, Leibnitz, Newton)
description: Students trace the contributions of Descartes, Leibniz, and Newton to the development of conservation laws and also investigate through hands-on explorations how hunches about the nature of phenomena can lead to great discoveries.

title: Introduction to Momentum: An Exploratory Study of Motion
description: Students review the thread of motion throughout the year’s curriculum and then conduct three hands-on exploratory investigations related to momentum.

title: Momentum, Impulse, and the Conservation of Momentum
description: The concepts of impulse and momentum are discussed in relation to Newton’s Second Law of Motion, and then students complete a short problem set.

title: Energy
description: Students discuss the abstract concept of energy and concepts related to it and then perform two investigations related to power and the conservation of energy. They also research Leonardo da Vinci’s machines.

title: Circular Motion
description: Through a series of lecture-discussions, students explore different kinds of circular motion and the forces associated with it, then relate this motion to its mathematical representation by completing a series of problems.

title: Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation
description: Students discuss the concept of an orbit as the combination of centripetal force and a tangential velocity that exactly compensates for the fall due to gravitational pull. This discussion leads to the introduction of the law of universal gravitation, in which students derive acceleration due to gravity (g) as a constant from the universal law, and ponder the implications of every object attracting every other object in the Universe.

title: Final Reading: “Fame Finds Newton”
description: Students read a selection from Newton at the Center by Joy Hakim, titled “Fame Finds Newton,” which outlines Newton’s major contributions to the field of science and his role in shaping the Royal Society into a powerful think tank that helped transform ways of thinking about the natural world and the Universe.

title: Test: Newtonian Mechanics
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts studied in this unit through a series of short-answer questions and problem-solving scenarios on this final test.

title: Leonardo da Vinci: A History in Art
description: Students watch a film, read histories, and discuss concepts to place the quintessential Renaissance man in context.

title: Perspective in Renaissance Art
description: Students display their ability to draw a three-dimensional image on a two-dimensional space by using one- and two-point perspectives.

title: Sketching of Dissected Animal
description: Students learn how to use various shading techniques to create realistic anatomical sketches.

title: Renaissance Drawing Techniques
description: Techniques are introduced to students through examples in Renaissance art, as well as through demonstration and practice. Students create drawings using foreshortening, cross-hatching, memory and observation, and contour drawing.

title: Leonardo Sketchbook Presentation
description: Students learn how to bind the pages of their Leonardo Sketchbook, as well as how to create a cover for it. They present the final sketchbook to peers and teachers through a formal discussion.

title: Introduction to Shakespearean Stage
description: This lecture and subsequent discussion introduce students to the world and language of Shakespeare.

title: Rehearsing and Critiquing the Scene
description: Students are assigned scenes in which they read, dissect, and rehearse to ultimately perform in a readers theater format.

title: Shakespeare Readers Theater Presentations
description: Students perform scenes from Macbeth for one another and offer critiques.

title: Compare and Contrast Shakespearean Film
description: Watching versions of “The Scottish Play” (Macbeth) allows students the opportunity to discover how others have interpreted it.

title: Performing Shakespeare’s Macbeth Test
description: Students draw upon their experiences with reading, discussing, performing, and critiquing Macbeth in order to complete this written assessment.

title: Self-Portrait
description: Students draw self-portraits and list their artistic goals for the coming school year. The self-portraits and goals are placed in students’ portfolios for review in Unit 3 at the end of the school year.

title: Sketchbooks
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. Students review and discuss their sketchbook work at the end of each learning experience to monitor their own progress, challenges, and accomplishments.

title: Colors of the Rainbow
description: Through readings and discussion, students learn the basics of color. Then, students experiment with a light source and a prism to observe the relationship between color and light. After their experimentation, students illustrate their findings in their sketchbooks. At this time, in the second grade course, prisms are used in both Visual Arts and Science discussions so that students connect the concepts of color and light in both contexts.

title: Color Theory
description: By completing a series of experiments inspired by the work of Josef Albers, students discover that the appearance of any individual color is dependent on all the other colors that surround it. Students gain an understanding of color theory and the influence of color and perception in the visual arts.

title: Color and Mood
description: Students explore how artists use color to express mood and emotion, and then students apply this concept to create their own artwork. As part of their exploration of color and mood, students study the paintings of Pablo Picasso’s Blue Period and respond to these paintings through discussion and writing in their sketchbook.

title: Warm and Cool Colors
description: Students explore the relationship between color and emotion further by discovering the way warm and cool colors effect the expressive qualities in works of art. Students research and view the work of photographer Eliot Porter and describe how color adds an important element of expression to his artwork.

title: Constructing the Solar System
description: As students learn about individual planets in Cultural History, they use their knowledge of the planets and the solar system to create a planet, Moon, Sun, or asteroid in three-dimensional using papier-mâché.

title: Exploding Colors
description: Students examine the concept of working together as a system by creating one large painting of the Big Bang. Students explore mixed media techniques and apply their prior knowledge of color theory to complete the collaborative painting.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: At the end of the unit, students’ progress, challenges, and achievement during all of the learning experiences and projects in the unit is evaluated with a unit-specific rubric.

title: Read-Alouds
description: Students begin the unit with three read-alouds, including Chameleon’s Colors, by Chisato Tashiro; A Color Of His Own, by Leo Lionni; and The Mixed-Up Chameleon, by Eric Carle. During each read-aloud, students observe how each illustrator creates color and texture using different techniques. Then, students complete a Venn diagram to compare and contrast the work of each artist.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. Students review this sketchbook at the end of each learning experience to monitor their progress, challenges, and accomplishments as an artist.

title: Eric Carle/Textured Paper, Collage, and Poetry
description: Students study the work of author and illustrator Eric Carle. They explore his textured paper technique by creating a variety of colors and painting their own sheets of tissue paper. Students then use their painted textured paper to depict an assigned animal in collage.

title: Textured Landforms
description: Students view images of Van Gogh’s landscape drawings and experiment with using repetitive lines and patterns to show texture in two dimensions. Then, using a variety of art media, such as black crayons, black markers, and pencils, students draw an irregular layered pattern, illustrating the sedimentary layers of Earth.

title: Optical Illusions/3-D Hands
description: Students examine topographical maps and artworks by optical artists Ludwig Wilding, Victor Vasarely, and Josef Albers to discover how artist create the illusion of three dimensions on a flat surface. To recreate the illusion for themselves, students trace their hands with markers using parallel, straight, and curved line patterns.

title: Plate Tectonics in Clay
description: To extend their learning of Earth Systems from Cultural History, students create clay models to depict the movement of tectonic plates. Each student is given two pieces of clay to depict three different movements of plate tectonics: divergent, transform, and convergent. Each student sculpts one clay maquette for each movement.

title: Pangaea Puzzle in Clay
description: As part of an integrated project, students create a clay puzzle of Pangaea. With the technology teacher, students use the clay puzzle pieces to create a stop-motion-animated film that depicts the movement of the tectonic plates that occurred to break apart the supercontinent.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: At the end of the unit, students and the teacher review sketchbooks and discuss each student’s progress, challenges, and accomplishments.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. Students review and discuss their sketchbook work at the end of each learning experience to monitor their own progress, challenges, and accomplishments.

title: Primary Colors/My Color Recipe
description: After listening to the book All the Colors of the Earth, students learn the vocabulary words hue, tint, shade, primary color, secondary color, and tertiary color. They use primary paint colors to create a variety of secondary and tertiary colors, as well as tints and shades. Students invent a new color and write their own color recipe.

title: Monochromatic Painting Using Tints
description: Students use their knowledge of tints to create a progressively lighter grid of 12 tints of a hue. They use these tints to create a color gradient background for a landscape painting of a deciduous tree or an animal from a deciduous forest.

title: Andy Goldsworthy
description: Students examine the work of Andy Goldsworthy, an artist who creates works of art using natural objects in their surrounding environment. Students discuss and reflect on the challenges of creating environmental art, such as the work of Andy Goldsworthy.

title: A Walk in the Woods
description: After learning about environmental artist Andy Goldsworthy in the previous learning experience, the class visits a deciduous forest. They create a temporary artwork in the style of Goldsworthy, which the teacher photographs. Students collect natural materials to bring back to the classroom to examine and use as natural painting implements.

title: Painting Tools, Not Just Brushes
description: Students experiment with a variety of tools to create texture and patterns on colored paper. They also paint with natural materials collected on their visit to the deciduous forest.

title: Ecosystem Mural
description: As a culminating piece for this unit, the class collaborates to create a large mural of the temperate forest ecosystem. Students create a color palette of colors found in nature. They use various painting tools, as well as the natural materials collected during their field trip, to create the paintings of the plants and fauna for the mural. Students apply their knowledge of color, texture, painting tools, and ecosystems to complete the project.

title: Color and Collage and Self-Portrait
description: Student and teacher review the student’s work on the collaborative ecosystem mural and the other unit projects. They also discuss the student’s participation and learning throughout the unit. Each student creates a self-portrait to compare to the self-portrait they created in Unit 1. Students note which goals they achieved and use their self-portraits to help evaluate their progress over the year.

title: Beginnings
description: For this end-of-year, theatrical Integrated Project, the class works to create costumes and/or backdrops for their grade-level thematic presentation.

title: Course Introduction
description: Students review key concepts of the Spiral Curriculum and consider the relevance of the Arithmetic Mentality today.

title: Exploring the Past and What Makes Humans Human
description: This is the first of several activities designed to have students look at human ancestors and the Paleolithic era and understand the nature of the archaeological work that pieces together this historical record.

title: “Last of the Neanderthals” Quiz
description: Students take a quiz and take part in a discussion after reading the National Geographic article “Last of the Neanderthals.”

title: Paleolithic Culture
description: In this learning experience, students listen to a lecture, discuss Paleolithic culture, and read an article about the Ice Age.

title: “New Women of the Ice Age” Quiz
description: In this formative assessment, students respond to questions about an article on the role of women in the Paleolithic era.

title: Big Boned
description: Through lecture, discussion, and partner activities led by a visiting Mathematics teacher, students learn about early numeracy.

title: Göbekli Tepe: The World’s First Temple
description: Students watch, respond to, and discuss a documentary about what scientists have called the world’s first temple, found at the archaeological site of Göbekli Tepe in Turkey.

title: Art and Life in the Early Agrarian Era
description: Students respond to a guided reading examining visual sources from Çatalhöyük, an early Neolithic settlement.

title: The Emergence of Civilization
description: In lecture and discussion format, students learn about the transition from early agricultural societies to riverine civilizations.

title: The Code of Hammurabi
description: In this activity, students work in teams with the Code of Hammurabi, one of the oldest surviving law codes, to understand the characteristics of early civilizations.

title: Arithmetic Mentality
description: Students reflect on and communicate what they have learned in each domain about the evolution of consciousness and culture in the Arithmetic Mentality.

title: “Poets and Psalmists: Goddesses and Theologians”
description: Students read and respond in writing and formal discussion to a text about the rise of patriarchy in Ancient Sumer.

title: Overview of the Geometric Mentality
description: This overview lecture contextualizes the unit’s key concepts, including the transition from a riverine to a transcontinental cultural ecology and the search for understanding that results in the wisdom traditions of this era.

title: The Gathas of Zarathustra
description: This reading and response is designed to introduce students to a period of ancient Classical culture in which moral orders arose in conjunction with expanding empires.

title: Prophets, Philosophers, and Universalizing Religions
description: Students investigate a specific religion or philosophical tradition originating in this time period and prepare peer-teaching presentations.

title: Pythagoras and the Geometric Mentality
description: In this presentation by a visiting Mathematics teacher, students learn about pre-Socratic philosophy via Pythagoras.

title: Performing Arts: Music and Pythagoras
description: This lecture by a visiting Performing Arts teacher discusses Pythagoras’s discoveries relating to music.

title: Reflection on Prophets, Philosophers, and Universalizing Religions Reflection
description: In this summative assessment, students compare and contrast three of the religious and philosophical traditions studied and presented in the Prophets, Philosophers, and Universalizing Religions assignment.

title: Universalizing Empires
description: Through reading, lecture, and discussion, students learn about the development and growth of universalizing empires.

title: Cities and States of the Classical Era
description: Students respond to a reading on cities and states in the Classical period.

title: The Geometric Mentality
description: For this final summative assessment, students write an essay synthesizing what they have learned in the unit.

title: Setting the Stage for the Algebraic Mentality
description: This overview learning experience sets the context for the Algebraic Mentality by reviewing the decline of classical civilizations and the expansion of transcontinental and intercontinental exchange in the first millennium CE.

title: The Rise of Islam
description: In this learning experience, students watch and respond to an excerpt from the PBS film Islam: Empire of Faith.

title: Islamic Culture
description: Through a slide presentation, reading, and discussion, students review the beliefs, spread, and cultural influence of Islam and the shift to the Algebraic Mentality.

title: Voices of Islam
description: In this formative assessment, students analyze and respond to excerpts from primary texts of Islam.

title: Science and the Golden Age of Islam
description: After watching excerpts from the BBC film Science and Islam: Empire of Reason, students write short answers to questions about the film.

title: Reason Versus Revelation in Islamic Learning
description: Students read and respond to several primary documents about the relationship between philosophy and religion in Islam, including the mysticism of the Sufis.

title: Medieval Europe
description: This lecture and discussion of primary source documents provides background for the study of medieval Europe.

title: Building the Great Cathedrals
description: After watching a PBS film about the architecture and art of medieval cathedrals, students answer questions about the film and discuss their ideas.

title: Saint Thomas Aquinas’s Summa Theologica
description: Students read, respond to, and discuss excerpts from this exemplary text of medieval Scholasticism.

title: Medieval Allegory—The Bestiary
description: In connection with their studies in English and allegory, students examine the Medieval Bestiary.

title: Meeting God
description: In this learning experience, students listen and respond to podcasts about the Holy Thorn Reliquary and the Icon of the Triumph of Orthodoxy, from the British Museum’s History of the World in 100 Objects.

title: Crusades and Cultural Interaction
description: Students read and respond to primary source documents with perspectives on the Crusades— one from Pope Urban II, the other from a Muslim warrior and courtier.

title: Algebraic Mentality Essay
description: For this summative assessment, students respond to a prompt about the depiction of the sacred and spiritual in the medieval period.

title: Shia and Sunni
description: Through video, readings, and discussion, students examine the meaning and origins of the Shia and Sunni sects within Islam.

title: Setting the Stage for the Dynamical Mentality
description: This learning experience contextualizes the unit’s setting and concludes with reading and discussion comparing Medieval and Renaissance Europe.

title: The Voyages of Zheng He
description: Following an introductory lecture, students examine primary and secondary documents about the voyages of Zheng He during China’s Ming Dynasty.

title: Consequences of Trans-Atlantic Linkages
description: Students read and discuss primary source documents related to the expansion of Europe to the Americas and Africa.

title: Exploitation or Opportunity in the Peruvian Andes?
description: Students read and respond, in writing, to contrasting views of the Spanish in South America.

title: State Building in the Early Modern Era
description: Students read and discuss primary sources related to state building in China, India, the Ottoman Empire, and France in the early modern era.

title: Martin Luther—The Reluctant Revolutionary
description: Students watch and respond to questions about the PBS film Martin Luther: the Reluctant Revolutionary.

title: Documents of the Scientific Revolution
description: Students read and discuss excerpts from a variety of primary sources related to scientific developments in early modern Europe.

title: New Science and Enlightenment
description: Students read documents from scientific and philosophical thinkers of early modern Europe and compose an essay responding to one of two prompts.

title: Mercantilism and Early Modern Capitalism
description: Students read and respond to documents on trade in the early modern period.

title: The Spread of the Enlightenment
description: Students read and discuss two primary texts related to the spread of the Enlightenment beyond the intellectual circles of Europe.

title: Politics and Romanticism
description: Students read about the French Revolution and watch a film about the Romantic reaction to Enlightenment ideals.

title: Slavery and the Slave Trade
description: Students read and discuss documents related to slavery and the slave trade in the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: Rights and Revolution
description: Students read and discuss documents from the French Revolution and other revolutions influenced by it.

title: Industrialization
description: Students participate in a lecture and discussion of the Industrial Revolution and read primary source documents about socialist responses.

title: Introduction to the Unit
description: This overview lecture contextualizes the unit’s setting and key concepts.

title: Imperialists and Imperialism
description: Students recall their grade 11 study of the New Imperialism by reading and responding to primary document excerpts from southern Africa, India, Mexico, and Japan.

title: Civilization and Its Discontents
description: Students read and peer-teach about the modern consciousness, and then they respond in writing to an excerpt from Sigmund Freud’s Civilization and Its Discontents.

title: Challenging the Western Model
description: Students read background information about the two world wars and the Great Depression and read and respond to four primary documents from writers reflecting challenges to the Western model.

title: Constructing a Postwar World
description: Students read and respond to information and two different viewpoints about the United Nations.

title: The Planetization of Mankind
description: Students read and respond to an essay by Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, “A Great Event Foreshadowed,” from The Future of Man.

title: A Bipolar World
description: Students participate in a lecture and discussion about the Cold War and compose written responses to primary documents related to its origins.

title: The Kitchen Debate
description: Students role-play the famous “Kitchen Debate” between U.S. Vice President Richard Nixon and Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev and then discuss the debaters’ points.

title: The Emergence of a “Third World”
description: Students participate in a lecture and discussion about decolonization and then read and respond to a primary source from the Bandung Conference of 1955.

title: The Non-Aligned Movement
description: Students read and analyze primary sources related to the non-aligned movement.

title: Clouds Over Cuba
description: Students watch a series of short videos about the Cuban Missile Crisis, responding to guiding questions as they go.

title: Countercultures and Cultural Transformation
description: Students read texts by Gary Snyder, Peter Benenson, and Rachel Carson to understand concepts related to countercultural responses to prevailing trends of the early postwar decades.

title: Into the 21st Century
description: Students read and respond to a textbook chapter and contemporary writings about economic globalization, women’s rights, religious fundamentalism, and the environmental movement.

title: Globalization or Planetization?
description: Students write a thesis-driven essay responding to a prompt about globalization versus planetization.

title: Introduction to the Course
description: Students receive the framework for the course. They look generally at the relationship between Cultural Ecologies and Mathematical Mentalities and explicitly at the attributes of the Arithmetic Mentality.

title: Ends at the Beginning: The Fall as Mythic Root in Creation Stories
description: Students explore a collection of narratives containing the same mythological root in order to approach mythology within the framework of the Ross Spiral Curriculum.

title: Wisdom and Love: Two Myths of Inanna
description: Students read and discuss “Inanna and the God of Wisdom” and “The Courtship of Inanna and Dumuzi” as formative literary examples of the Arithmetic Mentality.

title: The Descent of Inanna to the Underworld
description: Students examine “The Descent of Inanna” as a dominant literary example of the Arithmetic Mentality that portrays multifaceted religious rituals.

title: Inanna and the Huluppu-Tree
description: In this final Inanna myth, students explore a narrative in which Inanna is portrayed in a weak light.

title: The Epic of Gilgamesh
description: As students read The Epic of Gilgamesh, they explore the tension between matristic and patriarchal systems of authority during the Arithmetic Mentality.

title: The Epic of Gilgamesh Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students complete quizzes to demonstrate their comprehension of The Epic of Gilgamesh.

title: The Myth of Isis and Osiris
description: Students read the Egyptian myth of Isis and Osiris as a representation of the transition from matristic villages to patriarchal cities of civilization.

title: Lao-Tzu’s Tao Te Ching and the Attempt to Retrieve the Eternal Feminine
description: Students examine the Tao Te Ching as a swan song for the anarchic, prestate values of the Eternal Feminine and the creative and generative power of the Tao.

title: Engaging with the Tao Te Ching
description: Students read and annotate the Tao Te Ching. They then show their personal understanding of the text in chosen forms.

title: A Final Look at the Arithmetic Mentality
description: Students revisit their understanding of the Arithmetic Mentality, connecting its attributes to literature read during the unit.

title: Samson and Delilah: The Shift from the Arithmetic to Geometric Mentality
description: Students read the Old Testament story of Samson and Delilah to examine a narrative about a threatened people on the cusp of a bifurcation of mentalities.

title: Enuma Elish: The Babylonian Creation Story
description: After having read the story of Samson and Delilah in the previous learning experience, students read Enuma Elish as a formative literary milestone of the Geometric Mentality.

title: Examining Homer’s The Iliad and Tales Surrounding the Trojan War
description: Students revisit storylines concerning the Trojan War and examine themes of love and death in Homer’s epic, The Iliad.

title: Evolution of Athenian Society: Aeschylus’s Agamemnon
description: While placing the play and playwright in the proper historical context, students engage in a close reading of the first play of Aeschylus’s Oresteia trilogy.

title: Development of Tragedy: Aeschylus’s Choephori (Libation Bearers)
description: Students continue their study of the Oresteia with an examination of the Choephori and the development of theater in classical Athens.

title: Justice in the Theater: Aeschylus’s Eumenides (Furies)
description: In the final play of the Oresteia trilogy, students examine how the social and moral dilemmas presented in the earlier two plays are resolved.

title: Classical Greece and the Geometric Mentality Research Paper
description: After reading the Oresteia, students complete integrative research concerning aspects of the trilogy and its historical and cultural context. They ultimately craft a five-page essay on one or more themes.

title: Plato’s Timaeus: Bringing Structure to the World
description: Students read and discuss the famous dialogue in which Plato establishes the idea of perfect forms.

title: The Chinese: Introduction to The Book of Songs
description: Students examine poetry from The Book of Songs that reflects Chinese cultural values during the time of Confucius.

title: Exploring China's Past Through The Book of Songs
description: Students read poems from The Book of Songs, annotating and providing titles for each.

title: Confucius’s The Analects
description: Students annotate and discuss their interpretations of The Analects in order to make inferences about the Confucian belief system.

title: Confucius’s The Analects Short Paper
description: Students write a short essay drawing on the rules of personal and political conduct that originate in The Analects.

title: The Revelation of Muhammad: Exploring the Qur’an
description: Students explore the creation of the Qur’an, including its revelations and calligraphic code, as a formative work of the Algebraic Mentality and read several suras as an introduction to this religious text.

title: Gorgani’s Vis and Ramin
description: This Persian romance, nostalgic for the Pre-Islamic rule, sets benchmarks for chivalric and courteous lovers.

title: Vis and Ramin Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students complete short-answer quizzes to access their essential understanding of the plot of Vis and Ramin.

title: Vis and Ramin Thoughts on Romantic Love Essay
description: Drawing on their reading and discussion of the text, student compose persuasive essays in which they explore the strengths and weaknesses inherent in romantic love.

title: Nizami’s Story of Layla and Majnun
description: Students read an abridgement of Nizami’s romance of mad love, noting Gorgani’s influence, as well as its importance to later European texts.

title: Tristan and Isolde: Once More with Feeling
description: Students trace many components of Vis and Ramin in this tale, and examine the ending of the narrative for significance.

title: The Rise of Troubadour Poetry
description: Students read exemplars of this form that originates in southern France and was influenced by earlier Islamic romances.

title: Le Morte Arthur
description: Romantic love becomes an allegorical code in this telling of the illicit love of Guinevere and Lancelot and the death of King Arthur.

title: Le Morte Arthur Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students complete short-answer quizzes to access their essential understanding of the Arthurian legend’s plot.

title: Essay on Courtly Love and Marie de France’s “Laüstic”
description: Students cite specific examples of courtly love in one of the poems of Marie de France.

title: Dante’s Vita Nuova and Divine Comedy: Cosmic Allegory
description: By reading his “Letter to Can Grande” and reexamining the Divine Comedy, students explore how Dante completes the shift from courtly romantance to cosmic love.

title: The Advent of the Picaresque Novel
description: Students reacquaint themselves with picaresque fiction by reading and discussing examples of the form.

title: Descartes’s A Discourse on the Method: A Picaresque Philosophy
description: Students apply their knowledge of the picaresque narrative as they read and interpret Descartes’s intellectual search for truth.

title: Melville’s Moby-Dick: Introduction, Characters, and Setting
description: Students are reintroduced to the literary form of the novel and get acquainted with Melville’s Moby-Dick.

title: Melville’s Moby-Dick: Captains, Crew, and Quest
description: Character roles and motivations become central to students’ study of Moby-Dick.

title: "The Whiteness of the Whale" Assessment
description: This written assessment addresses Ishmael’s meditations on the many meanings of the term “white,” among other key ideas in Chapter 42 of Moby-Dick.

title: Moby-Dick Oral Presentations
description: In formal presentations, students present about select chapters of Melville’s masterpiece to one another, focusing on philosophical and factual content.

title: Melville’s Moby-Dick: Pursuits of Whaling
description: Students continue their reading of Moby-Dick, focusing on the conflicting views of Starbuck and Ahab over the purpose of the voyage, among other topics.

title: Melville’s Moby-Dick: The Final Journey
description: Students complete their reading of Moby-Dick and examine contemporary connections to the work.

title: Modern Writing Styles: The Shift from Hypotaxis to Parataxis
description: Students learn that the shift of popular writing styles from controlled to spontaneous coincides with the arts’ increasing allowance for interpretation.

title: Imagism and Ezra Pound’s “In a Station of the Metro”
description: Students examine the complexity of one of Pound’s short poems to determine how Imagism works.

title: Introduction to Ezra Pound’s The Cantos
description: By applying Pound’s use of overlaying texts, students explore the opening Canto (and related influences) of Pound’s masterwork.

title: Modernist Poets: Gertrude Stein and T.S. Eliot
description: After studying Pound, students examine how two more modern poets manipulate sources and styles to reinvent them.

title: T. S. Eliot’s The Waste Land: “The Burial of the Dead”
description: Students are introduced to Eliot’s masterpiece through a close reading of the opening section.

title: Presenting The Waste Land
description: Students continue their study of The Waste Land through a presentation of the remaining sections.

title: Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Part One: The Overlords Arrive
description: To examine the shift from national to planetary cultures and the fear of total annihilation due to the nuclear bomb, students begin reading Arthur C. Clarke’s science fiction classic Childhood’s End.

title: Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Part Two: Establishing a Utopia
description: Students continue their reading of the science fiction classic Childhood’s End, ruminating on the inherent possibilities and consequences of establishing utopias.

title: Childhood’s End Alien Impact Essay
description: Students synthesize their thoughts about the first two parts of Childhood’s End in writing.

title: Arthur C. Clarke’s Childhood’s End, Part Three: New Athens, the Overmind, and the End
description: Students complete their reading of Childhood’s End, using guiding questions to support their comprehension.

title: Childhood’s End Formal Discussion
description: As a final assessment of Arthur C. Clarke’s novel, students deliberate on themes in the last section through a formal discussion.

title: Sylvia Plath’s The Bell Jar: Electricity, Food, and Fertility
description: Students examine the Cold War, the execution of the Rosenbergs as spies, and the McCarthy era through the lens of a sensitive teenage girl in The Bell Jar.

title: Sylvia Plath’s The Bell Jar: Nonconformity and Electroshock Treatment
description: Students go deeper into Sylvia Plath’s novel, exploring the lengths society will go to in order to stamp out nonconformity.

title: The Bell Jar Final Essay
description: Students write a paper in which they analyze an image cluster of their choice in The Bell Jar.

title: Ginsberg’s “Howl” and the Beat Movement
description: Students read and discuss the landmark poem “Howl” while learning about the causes and impact of the Beat movement.

title: Tarkovsky’s Solaris
description: Students watch Solaris, a 1972 Russian film about materialistic astronauts dealing with the possibility of a sentient planet.

title: Uncanny X-Men: A Path to Planetization
description: Through the reading of selected issues of The X-Men, students track how the comic follows and addresses important themes of the Complex Dynamical Mentality.

title: Lília Momplé's Neighbours: The Story of a Murder
description: Students read this novel, which is set in Mozambique, as a literary example of an emerging people after the dwindling of the Portuguese empire.

title: Neighbours: The Story of a Murder Letter
description: Students write in the voice of one of the characters from Neighbours to show the complexity of competing cultures and the context in which the text was written.

title: Elizabeth Kolbert’s The Sixth Extinction
description: Students read an excerpt from Kolbert’s book to learn about the variety of ways humans have manipulated nature and the subsequent possibility of an extinction event.

title: Welcome to the Anthropocene: The Sixth Extinction Mapped
description: Students present and collectively map the various contemporary and historical problems addressed throughout the chapters of Kolbert’s book.

title: World War Z, Snowpiercer, and the Problem with Tragedy
description: Through the examination of zombie and apocalyptic films, students explore whether or not the structure of tragedy retards social or planetary action.

title: Human Narratives of Origins and the Big Bang
description: Students learn about the Big Bang Theory as a story about the history of the universe and are given an overview of the timescales and distances involved in modern cosmology.

title: Scientific Evidence for the Big Bang Theory
description: Students examine evidence for the Big Bang Theory. Students learn about Hubble’s Law and how it is used to describe the distances and velocities of galaxies in the Universe. Cosmic background radiation is discussed as evidence for the Big Bang.

title: Photocopy Big Bang Cosmology Lab
description: Students engage in a hands-on exploration of the linear property of Hubble’s Law using photocopy enlargement as an analog of cosmic expansion.

title: The History and Emergence of Structure in the Cosmos
description: Students explore the large-scale structure of the Universe. Students learn that the motions of galaxies are governed by Newton’s laws of motion on a very large scale. The Hertzsprung-Russell diagram is introduced as a method for categorizing stars by their characteristics. Students use Earth’s Solar System as a model for the development of a planetary system orbiting a star.

title: Dark Matter and Dark Energy
description: Students learn about the concepts of dark matter and dark energy as they relate to the structure of the Universe.

title: Microcosmos: The Very Early Universe
description: Students imagine the Universe in the time after the Big Bang, when the Universe was young and hot, and describe what was happening on an atomic level.

title: Fundamental Physics and the Standard Model
description: Students develop a basic overview of the particles and forces that make up the modern Standard Model of particle physics, and they address some of the unanswered questions that continue to drive the field.

title: The Anthropic Principle and Unanswered Cosmic Questions
description: Students explore the limits of science to answer questions that ask about reasons for the structure of the Universe, and then turn to philosophical considerations about what sorts of explanations are meaningful and useful.

title: The Limits of Science and Reductionism
description: Students confront the underlying assumptions of science, and they address the question of whether or not the process of science has limitations. Students reflect on their own philosophical biases, and they explore their own beliefs about the meaning of scientific theories.

title: Cosmos Unit Test
description: Students complete a written examination that probes their understanding of Big Bang cosmology and associated issues.

title: The Chemical Basis of Life
description: Students review the organic chemical underpinnings of life as we know it on Earth. Students develop and refine a working vocabulary of terms that will enable them to discuss various theories about the origin of life.

title: The Second Law of Thermodynamics
description: Students review the second law of thermodynamics and discuss its application to living organisms. Students transition from a physics-centered approach to talking about the cosmos to a more biological approach.

title: The Idea of Emergence in Complex Systems
description: Students explore the concepts of emergence and self-organization through examples of simple systems that give rise to novel and complex behaviors.

title: The Origins of Life’s Chemical Building Blocks
description: Students examine the work of Urey and Miller as they attempted to recreate some of the conditions and early chemistry of life on a pre-biotic Earth.

title: Models of the Origin of Life: Chemical Self-Organization
description: Students are introduced to ideas about spontaneous self-organization that might bridge the apparent chasm between chemistry and biology. Students look at simple models that try to explain chemical self-organization.

title: From RNA World to the First Cells
description: Students examine one currently popular model that attempts to address the shortcomings of replicator-first and metabolism-first accounts of the origin of life and how the first self-replicating DNA molecule arose.

title: The History of Life on Earth: Major Transitions
description: Students brainstorm the major turning points in the evolution of life on Earth. Students consider the factors that contributed to the big picture and how they affected the development of life on Earth.

title: Natural Selection and Mechanisms of Evolution
description: Students review the basic precepts of natural selection and evolution from a historical perspective and from a modern standpoint.

title: Life Unit Exam
description: Students take a short exam covering concepts from the first part of this unit.

title: The Evolution of Humans: The Big Picture
description: Students brainstorm uniquely human qualities and learn about our knowledge of early pre-hominids and the rough timescales for innovations, such as bipedalism, tool use, domestication of fire, and changes in cranial capacity over time.

title: The Human Evolution Lab
description: Students explore the evolutionary changes in one particular part of hominid anatomy—the skull—as a microcosm of evolution and a narrow lens through which to examine human evolution in particular.

title: What Makes the Primate Brain Special?
description: Students learn about the relationship between brain and behavior to understand how and why primates in particular, as a group, were well positioned to make the evolutionary leaps that led to the unique qualities of the human brain and human consciousness. They explore a variety of theories that seek to explain how, why, and when the human brain evolved its special characteristics, and what makes the human brain and mind different form the brains of other primates.

title: What Makes Humans Special? Biocultural Evolution
description: Students begin an exploration of the human brain and human consciousness. Students explicitly outline the path from prehominid ancestors to fully-modern humans, not in anatomical terms, but in cultural ones.

title: Neuron Structure and Function
description: In this learning experience, students investigate the structure and function of neurons at an overview level. They develop an understanding of the basic vocabulary for talking about neural connectivity and signaling in the brain.

title: Neural Networks and Artificial Models of Brain Function
description: In this learning experience, students investigate the idea of neural networks at an introductory level. They explore both biological and artificial networks.

title: Structure and Function in the Human Brain
description: In this learning experience, students complete an introductory exploration of some basic brain anatomy and are introduced to the idea of functional localization within the brain.

title: Modern Tools for Exploring Brain Anatomy and Function
description: Students learn about some of the technology used to explore brain structure and function.

title: Unanswered Questions and Current Directions in Brain Research
description: Students identify and discuss some of the most pressing unanswered questions about the brain and human consciousness in this open-ended discussion of the current state of brain research.

title: Unit Exam
description: Students demonstrate their understanding and level of mastery on the structure and function of the brain by completing this unit assessment.

title: Nationalism as Political Ideology
description: Students read and discuss an excerpt from The World Since 1500: A Global History by Lefton Stavrianos and spiral back to grade 10 Cultural History content on the development of nationalism as a political ideology.

title: Understanding Nationalism
description: Students compose written responses to questions from their first reading on nationalism as distributed in the learning experience above.

title: National and Cultural Identities
description: Students read excerpts from several scholarly works about nationalism—nation, state and nation-state—and write responses to specific questions using a rubric for guidance.

title: National and Cultural Identities: Mazzini and Bismarck
description: Students read and complete the “Mazzini and Bismarck Project” with the “Mazzini and Bismarck Project Rubric” to develop an understanding of the differences between a nation, state, and nation-state and the concept of imagined community among the Italian and German peoples of the 19th century.

title: Sectionalism as Nationalism?
description: Using their understanding of nationalism, students explore differences that led to “sectionalism” in the United States during the Antebellum Period. They form opinions on national identity gleaned from excerpts on southern nationalism and slavery and discuss how these led to secession and the Civil War.

title: Civil War Letters
description: Students examine letters from James McPherson’s For Cause and Comrades: Why Men Fought in the Civil War. Students respond with reflective paragraphs comparing Northern and Southern soldiers’ attitudes and motivations for enlisting and fighting.

title: Nationalism Quiz
description: Students view a film about nationalism in the 20th century and compare it to what they have learned about nationalism in the 19th century to prepare for the “Nationalism Quiz.”

title: The Effects of Colonization in the New Imperialism
description: Students read excerpts from The Earth and Its Peoples, Volume II: Since 1500 and consider the concept of Social Darwinism when exploring the projection of Western society’s culture and conventions around the world as part of the New Imperialism in the mid-19th to early 20th centuries.

title: Responses to New Imperialism: Asia and Africa
description: Students form teams to develop written strategies of Asian and African resistance to Western intrusion and share these strategies with other teams for peer review.

title: New Imperialism Quiz
description: Students take a quiz covering lessons from the second portion of this unit and use this time to prepare for the upcoming Integrated Project: “The Visionary Leaders Trial Project.”

title: Tradition and Modernity in Britain—and Around the World
description: Students explore the concepts of modern and modernization by discussing a debate over traditional practices in the British House of Lords before researching and writing about the concepts of tradition and modernization in a culture of their choosing.

title: The Modern Consciousness
description: Reflecting on a reading, students answer questions about late 19th- and early 20th-century intellectual and artistic trends.

title: From Traditional to Modern
description: Students compare characteristics of traditional (premodern) and modern life, revisiting content learned in grades 9 and 10 and discussing the dynamics of modernization in Europe.

title: Tradition and Modernity in Kyrgyzstan
description: After reading a short article on the tensions between traditional and modern life in contemporary Kyrgyzstan, students answer questions.

title: Achievements of Modernity—Paris, Modern City par Excellence
description: Students consider the shift from the Dynamical Mentality to the Complex Dynamical Mentality by looking at the achievements and contradictions of modernity through the experience of everyday life in Baron Haussmann’s redesigned Paris—the modern city par excellence. They are also introduced to the Modernity Project, which is the culminating project for this unit.

title: Modernity and Everyday Life—Marx
description: Students read excerpts on socialism and answer questions with short written work.

title: Modernity and Everyday Life—Zola
description: Students reflect on the dark side of modernity following a viewing of the first 25 minutes of the film Germinal.

title: Modernity in Philosophy: Nietzsche, Einstein, and Freud
description: Students explore modern secularism and philosophy in discussing the decline of religiosity in the 19th century and Nietzsche’s notion that “God is dead.”

title: Modernity—Reflections
description: Students have an opportunity to process modernity as discussed to date in a whole-class discussion for which they must prepare reflections.

title: Modernity and World War I
description: Students study World War I as the opening of a great gap between what Europeans expected from modernity and what actually happened. Readings and discussion focus on the disillusionment and devastation of Western society’s view of itself and offer an opportunity for revision to their thinking about modernity for their Modernity Project.

title: The Trauma of the Trenches
description: Students inspect advertisements, posters, cartoons, and paintings of the period 1914–1922 in order to identify and discuss the salient themes and motifs.

title: Self-Determination and the Peace Process
description: The unit begins with a role-playing activity that enables students to explore the post-World War I settlement worked out at the Paris Peace Conference.

title: The Middle East After World War I
description: Students apply what they have learned about self-determination following World War I by responding to primary documents related to the collision of great power goals and nationalist aspirations in the Middle East.

title: Self-Determination and Anti-Colonialism
description: Through studying Gandhi’s independence movement in India, students assess their understanding of self-determination as an internationalist principle.

title: Self-Interest and Economic Excess: Predictive Analysis
description: In this learning experience, students examine the world market economy as another example of increasing global self-consciousness.

title: Excesses of Nationalism: Fascism, Hyper-Nationalism, and Totalitarianism
description: Teams of students work to role-play journalists reporting on political events of the 1930s.

title: Divided We Fall
description: In this learning experience, students confront the brutality of war through film, readings, and discussions and reflect on their personal response to an atrocity or human rights violation.

title: Globalization and the Dynamics of Cultural Transformation
description: Students spend the first week acquiring an overview of the themes they will explore the remainder of the year, including the difference between globalization and planetization .

title: Modeling World Order
description: Students study the post-World War II shift in international diplomacy from a security to a rights framework by examining the original structure of the United Nations as a manifestation of the interest in collective security. After exploring the broadening definition of human rights promoted by the UN, which furthered the development of global consciousness, they propose structural reforms to the UN that would better support the latter framework.

title: Class, Free Markets, and the Cold War
description: Students compare the Soviet and U.S. perspectives on the war and the postwar world to analyze the origins of the Cold War.

title: Orthodoxy and Dissent in the Cold War
description: Students read speeches by Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin to get a deeper understanding of Cold War conflicts and then explore the conformity and conflict of American and Soviet culture in the 1950s, as American and Soviet values become rigidified into ideologies of mutual opposition and self-promotion. They then create original visual products reflecting their view of the “American Way” or the “Soviet Way” and role-play a conformist or nonconformist who critiques these works from a particular point of view.

title: Introduction to Playwriting Elements
description: Students are introduced to the basic elements of writing a play through reading, discussion, and an informal presentation of the Anton Chekhov play, A Jubilee.

title: Synopsis of Chekhov’s A Jubilee
description: By means of a detailed plot synopsis of Chekhov’s A Jubilee, students demonstrate understanding of playwriting elements.

title: Group Storytelling Exercise
description: Students invent and sustain the telling of a story by engaging in collaborative story creation both orally and in written dialogue.

title: Writing a Conflict Script
description: Using photographs of two anonymous people, students create characters and backstories upon which they base a two- to three-page script, incorporating elements learned through their study of A Jubilee and their group storytelling exercise.

title: Writing a Trial Scene
description: Students work in teams to draft and revise a script that incorporates historical understanding and elements of playwriting.

title: Rehearsing the Scene
description: Students learn, practice, and employ effective sight-reading and acting techniques in preparation for performing their Trial Project play.

title: Visionary Leaders’ Trial Project Performance
description: As performers and peer teachers, students present their plays to classmates who render a verdict on whether this revolutionary leader should be found guilty or innocent of the alleged crime(s).

title: Critiquing Performances
description: In a supportive atmosphere of constructive criticism, students watch video recordings of their own and others’ Trial Project Performances. They reflect on how and why performances were well done or could have been improved.

title: Cities of Early Modern Europe
description: Students engage in brief readings of historical texts dealing with life in London and Paris in early modern Europe to provide context for understanding the Glorious Revolution.

title: The Tudors, the Stuarts, and the Glorious Revolution
description: To better understand the factors that led to the Glorious Revolution in Great Britain, students take and revise notes on a presentation about the Tudors, the Stuarts, and the Glorious Revolution.

title: The Glorious Revolution and the Rise of Constitutionalism
description: Based on the presentation they viewed and on readings, students work in small groups to create and give presentations on the factors that led to the Glorious Revolution, its details, and its effects on English society.

title: The Glorious Revolution Assignment
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of key vocabulary terms and events.

title: Paraphrasing the English Bill of Rights
description: By rewriting a historical text in their own language, students’ understanding of the English Bill of Rights can be assessed.

title: The Philosophies of Locke and Hobbes
description: Students focus on the conflicting philosophies of Thomas Hobbes and John Locke and why they were the two most important thinkers of the 17th century.

title: Hobbes and Locke Vocabulary
description: The vocabulary assessment provides students with opportunities to demonstrate their understanding of vocabulary used by Hobbes and Locke.

title: Europe Before Transatlantic Slavery
description: Students discover the early history of slavery in Europe. By looking at the major slave-trading countries, students understand slavery through global trade and conquest during an age of expansion.

title: The Move to Africa
description: In this learning experience, students discuss the transition to African slavery and the slave markets. By looking at African slave narratives, students begin to understand the larger picture behind slavery.

title: Slavery: The Terrible Transformation
description: Students discover how the use of enslaved labor in the colonies allowed parent countries to build wealth.

title: Leaders in Resistance
description: Students learn about iconic leaders in the slave resistance. By studying Nat Turner, Denmark Vesey, and Olaudah Equiano students are able to understand how the ideas of the Enlightenment began to affect enslavement in the colonies.

title: Reflective Essay: Effects of Slavery
description: Students write a reflection answering several questions addressing the effects of slavery on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: The Enlightenment: An Introduction
description: Students use their readings, including an essay by Emanuel Kant, to create their own definitions of Enlightenment.

title: Isaac Newton’s Contributions to Modern Science
description: In this learning experience, students learn about Isaac Newton’s accomplishments in the fields of mathematics, motion, and optics. They study how he helped create the modern understanding of the universe and how his understanding of the natural world helped lead to the development of the Enlightenment.

title: Enlightening the Despots
description: After reading Introducing the Enlightenment, by Lloyd Spencer, students complete a quiz to demonstrate their understanding of the text.

title: Ridicule Quiz
description: Students watch the film Ridicule in order to deepen their understanding of salon culture and the concept of Enlightenment values. They then take a quiz on what they have learned.

title: The Encyclopedia Project
description: Students mimic Diderot and D’Alembert’s work as they create a compendium of information for selected words based on their understanding of the meaning and organization of knowledge.

title: Benjamin Franklin as a Model of Enlightenment
description: This learning experience emphasizes how Franklin stands as a model of the Enlightenment through his scientific, cultural, and political activities.

title: The Seven Years’ War
description: Integrating with their reading of Candide, students research why and to what extent specific participants were involved in the Seven Years’ War and the war’s effects on them and their global position.

title: Background to Mercantilism
description: This learning experience introduces students to the concept of mercantilism and provides another connection of this unit to the novella Candide.

title: Mapping Candide and Beyond Project
description: In the first part of the project, students devise a method to map the travels of the novella’s main character. In the second part, more broadly based, they research and write about any particular place connected to this grade’s curriculum.

title: Mercantilism Quiz
description: This assessment gauges student understanding of the Seven Years’ War, mercantilism, and the connection that each has to the novella Candide.

title: Mercantilism Game
description: Students debate principles and practices of mercantilism through this game.

title: The Proclamation of 1763
description: This learning experience introduces students to the Royal Proclamation of 1763 as they consider the document from the viewpoint of the British, the colonists, and the Native Americans.

title: Taxes and the Road to Revolution
description: Students create their own study guides to identify the events and actions that caused the American Revolution.

title: The Uses of Rhetoric in the Revolutionary Period
description: Students investigate the use of rhetorical devices in 18th-century writing in favor of and in opposition to the American Revolution.

title: Point-of-View Project
description: While studying the ways in which Enlightenment ideals crossed the Atlantic, students learn how the rhetoric of freedom can be used to support a wide variety of opinions. Assuming the viewpoint of a member of a group affected by the upcoming American Revolution, students write letters in favor of or against the war and respond to letters written by fellow students.

title: U.S. Constitutionalism Salon
description: Students are introduced to the Bill of Rights by writing paraphrases of each amendment. To extend their understanding of the individual rights, they read about contemporary issues involving those rights and discuss the issues in a seminar setting.

title: The Ancien Régime
description: This introductory learning experience sets the stage for a study of the remnants of the feudal system and the rise of absolute monarchy.

title: Analyzing French Political Cartoons
description: Students analyze political cartoons to determine how they reflect the relationship between the three estates in French society during the ancien régime.

title: Society in the Ancien Régime Quiz
description: Students answer comprehensive and interpretive questions to demonstrate their understanding of the roles in society at this time.

title: Absolute Power in France
description: This learning experience introduces students to the concept of absolutism and the development of the modern state.

title: Louis XIV’s Absolute Reign
description: Students read primary and secondary sources to investigate Louis XIV’s reign and analyze the effects of his rule.

title: The Legacy of Louis XIV’s Absolute Reign
description: To demonstrate their understanding of absolutism and the reign of Louis XIV, students take part in a formalized class discussion around the question “What was the legacy of Louis XIV?”

title: The French Revolution
description: This learning experience begins students’ exploration of the French Revolution through reading and film study.

title: The “Reign of Terror” Project
description: In this research project, students investigate the social and political conflicts that lead to the Reign of Terror. The research culminates in a presentation.

title: The Haitian and South American Revolutions
description: Students learn how the French Revolution gave support to other revolutions around the world.

title: Romanticism: Literature, Music, and Art
description: Students begin this unit by studying the aftermath of the French Revolution. They then review a biographical study of Napoleon Bonaparte, a figure representing not only charismatic individualism but also the rise of nationalism and the trend toward territorial expansion in European politics.

title: Napoleon Bonaparte: Romantic Hero
description: In this assessment, students analyze portraits of Napoleon Bonaparte and explain how the portraits illustrate Napoleon at the start of his reign and near his fall from power.

title: William Blake and the Industrial Revolution
description: Study of William Blake features his critiques of the Enlightenment and longing for humanity’s lost connection with an agricultural world. It helps illuminate the transition between the Enlightenment and the Industrial Revolution. This learning experience begins with an examination of his monotype “Newton” and continues with an analysis of Blake’s beliefs about science.

title: Introduction to Thomas Malthus
description: Students learn about the celebrated economist and thinker Thomas Robert Malthus. They research his assertions on the societal implications of population growth and issues of sustainability as an introduction to the Malthus Integrated Project.

title: The Industrial Revolution
description: This learning experience provides students with a foundation for researching the Industrial Revolution. It centers on the reading of an essay that describes the characteristics that helped Great Britain emerge as an industrial giant.

title: En Plein Aire Day
description: The En Plein Aire Day field trip is an outdoor visual art and poetry experience focusing on the study of Romanticism. In order to better experience the Romantics’ intimate connection to nature, students spend the day at a local park creating art using various media.

title: Charles Dickens and the Victorian Novel
description: Charles Dickens was a sharp critic of the Industrial Revolution. This learning experience introduces students to several of his works that describe such grim industrial realities as child labor, the rise of machines, and overpopulation.

title: Workers’ Rights in the Industrial Revolution
description: Students examine Chartism and the Peterloo Massacre in order to understand workers’ reactions to Industrialism.

title: The Push for Reform: Women’s Rights
description: Students address the beginnings of feminism by analyzing and discussion texts on women’s rights.

title: The Push for Reform: The U.S. Abolitionist Movement
description: Students examine the U.S. abolitionist movement and figures and events that led to the Emancipation Proclamation.

title: The Industrial Revolution Sows the Seeds of Climate Change
description: Students read the essay “Industrial Britain” and research the impact of the Industrial Revolution on England, addressing the development of the modern state, the rise of the factory system, and consequent social, economic, and environmental problems.

title: Karl Marx’s Critique of Capitalism
description: Students read a selection of excerpts from The Communist Manifesto, by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, dealing with the bourgeoisie, the proletariat, and the authors’ historical method. A lecture on “Marxism 101” follows.

title: The Crystal Palace Exhibition: Zenith of Industrialism
description: Students contrast the extravagance of this exhibition with the lifestyles of those who built it and those who ran the machines that created the products on display.

title: The Wonder of Symbols
description: While students are actively problem solving during each subsequent learning experience, the teacher circulates around the room and records evidence of student progress on the Performances of Understanding note-taking sheet.

title: Signs and Symbols Around Us
description: Students begin the year exploring signs and symbols that are familiar to them; for example, weather symbol for snow, a stop sign, a crosswalk sign, and the handicap parking symbol. They learn that signs and symbols are used to make sense of the world around them.

title: Reading Symbols
description: Students identify symbols in the classroom and their meanings. As symbols from the list of Symbol Signs are displayed, students read the symbols by telling what they mean. Students discuss the kinds of information that symbols provide.

title: Symbols in the Classroom
description: Students begin to apply their understanding of how symbols order their lives. They create symbols to label classroom activities and places, such as shapes for the calendar, job chart, supply bins, and learning centers. Students then begin to use the new symbols while executing their classroom responsibilities.

title: Reading Signs
description: Students read the book I Read Signs by Tana Hoban, which is a collection of familiar signs students are likely to recognize before they learn sound-symbol correspondences; for example, playground, stop, and exit. Students create community service signs and symbols to reinforce the unit goal of understanding that people use signs and symbols as a form of communication.

title: Unfolding Symbols: Alphabet
description: Students explore the alphabet and learn that each letter of the alphabet represents one or more sounds and the written letter is a symbol (picture) for the sound. They create an alphabet book and practice writing letters.

title: Unfolding Symbols: Mathematics
description: Students investigate numbers and explore the concept that the written numeral is a symbol (picture) that represents a certain amount. Students count out the number of objects represented on number cards.

title: Creating a Classroom Community
description: As classroom rituals and routines are being established, students are introduced to symbols they will use throughout the school year. These pictures/words and gestures help students communicate and build a classroom community. Students take digital photographs of one another acting out or pointing to symbols.

title: Creating Treasure Maps
description: Students study mapping symbols and create their own treasure map. They give the map to another class, which follows the map to the treasure.

title: Origins of Life, Creation Myths, and Birth Stories
description: While students are actively problem solving during each learning experience and assessment in this unit, the teacher circulates the room and records evidence of student progress on the “Performances of Understanding” note-taking sheet.

title: Let’s Begin
description: Students begin the unit by discussing the questions, “What happens at the beginning of a day?”, “What do you see?, “What do you do?”, and “What is a beginning?” Students share stories of their day and complete a sentence starter about beginnings.

title: Reading The Everything Seed: A Story of Beginnings
description: Students participate in a shared reading of The Everything Seed: A Story of Beginnings, which is a creation myth that focuses on the simple magic of one tiny seed. After the shared reading, students discuss guiding questions and act out how a seed grows.

title: Write a Poem
description: As a group, students write a poem entitled “What Is a Beginning?” Students record the lines of the poem. When everyone is satisfied with the  final version, the poem is copied onto a large sheet of poster board. Students decorate it with drawings that depict beginnings. This learning experience is sequenced after students brainstorm ideas in the related World Languages and Literature: English, Learning Experience: Shared Writing with Illustrations (WL-EN_GK_U2_03_LE).

title: Create “Everything Seeds”
description: Students are asked to imagine everything in the world came from an “everything seed.” Students draw or paint representations of their own imagined “everything seed” and answer guiding questions about their seed.

title: Planting Seeds
description: Students respond to the essential question “What is change?” by planting sunflower seeds and observing plant growth. Then they complete plant growth sequence storyboards to record the process. They complete a worksheet to explain the elements needed for plant growth and survival.

title: Journey of a Monarch Butterfly
description: Students observe monarch butterflies in the environment or classroom and observe the butterfly’s journey of change. They document the process of growth and changes on a worksheet and discuss their observations. Students create a storyboard and perform the metamorphosis of the monarch butterfly.

title: Creation Myths
description: Through shared read-alouds, students encounter a variety of creation myths from around the world, for example, The Fire Children by Eric Maddern, The Star-Bearer: A Creation Myth from Ancient Egypt by Dianne Hofmeyr, or Sun Mother Wakes the World by Diane Wolkstein (see Unit Texts and Resources).
