Students discuss differences between fiction and nonfiction as a lead in to the idea that all cultures use fiction to help explain the real world. Students outline and discuss ideas for their own creation stories, which they will write in their World Languages and Literature: English Writing Workshop.

title: Creating a Slideshow
description: Students collaborate to choose photos and write captions for a Creation, Birth, and Change Slideshow. They present the slideshow to parents and other classes and then reflect on their unit learning in their Cultural History journals.

title: Seasonal Migrations
description: While students are actively problem solving during each learning experience and assessment in this unit, the teacher circulates the room and records evidence of student progress on the Performances of Understanding note-taking sheet.

title: Weather Watch
description: Students explore the guiding question, “What is seasonal change?” They share several nonfiction books about seasons, update and examine the class calendar, and reflect on changes in weather. As a connection to their study of mathematics, students use a weather graph to compare changing temperatures.

title: When Winter Comes: Plants
description: Students investigate plant life and gather specimens around the school grounds. They document their findings through photographs and illustrations and present their observations with the help of a sentence starter.

title: When Winter Comes: Humans and Animals
description: Students explore animal behavior in the winter, considering how different animals cope with cold weather and lack of food (for example, migration and hibernation). Students share their observations of animals in the local area. Together students complete a large Venn diagram that compares how humans and animals prepare for winter.

title: Migration
description: This learning experience addresses the third essential question, “How does seasonal change cause movement?” Students read the book How Do Birds Find Their Way? by Roma Gans. They recall how they observed monarch butterflies and followed the butterflies’ journey of change. They further explore the concept of migration by looking at the flight patterns of birds.

title: A Winter’s Rest: Hibernation
description: Students watch a video called Frozen Turtles and participate in read-alouds of books about hibernation. They identify animals that hibernate, such as bears, woodchucks, skunks, and wasps, realizing that not all animals migrate. Students act out hibernation and compare the concept with migration.

title: Cozy Winter Activities
description: After a read-aloud of Winter Is the Warmest Season by Lauren Stringer, students discuss the warmth and coziness people share during wintry weather. They discuss the fact that many people are fortunate to live in houses with ready sources of heat, while animals and plants must adapt to the cold outdoors. Students use a flannel board to create a winter scene. They draw their own winter activity scene and write a sentence about it on their worksheet.

title: Seasonal Migrations: Winter Mural Project
description: Students reflect on how winter weather affects both animals and themselves. As a culminating activity, students collaborate to create a winter mural that shows the effects of winter weather.

title: Elemental Forces
description: While students are actively problem solving during each learning experience and assessment in this unit, the teacher circulates the room and records evidence of student progress on the “Performances of Understanding” note-taking sheet.

title: Earth: Soil and Sand Exploration
description: Students begin an exploration of Earth by comparing and contrasting soil and sand. They weigh and measure sand and soil samples and create a chart. A discussion about what organisms need soil to grow completes the activity.

title: Earth/Soil
description: Students are introduced to resources about soil, including Dirt: The Scoop on Soil by Natalie M. Rosinsky. As they learn about and explore the components of soil, students draw and label pictures of organisms found in soil and dirt. They make comparisons between their reading and their hands-on exploration of soil.

title: Earth/Seeds
description: In autumn, students investigate seeds. In spring, students ready the soil, plant the seeds, and document the growth of seeds and the relationships of the seeds to the soil and other elemental forces. They compare bulbs to seeds and record observations of their growth.

title: Fire and Light/Sun
description: Students explore why the Sun shines, reading books from the classroom library. As they research the relationship of the Sun to the Moon, students write facts on sentence strips. They participate in a movement activity to simulate the orbit of Earth around the Sun and the Moon around Earth.

title: Fire and Light/Day and Night
description: Students examine the opposite forces of light and dark and day and night by creating and using stick puppets to investigate formation of shadows. For a Nighttime Mural, students create pictures and descriptions of images they might see at night. They participate in shadow dances to demonstrate opposites.

title: Fire and Light/Solar Ovens
description: Students research solar ovens, using classroom and library resources. They discuss the importance of solar ovens and then make solar ovens. After they use the ovens to make a simple food, they watch a conventional oven in use and compare the cooking methods.

title: Air/Breathing
description: Listening to a read-aloud of Air Is All Around You by Franklyn Branley (see Resources), students are introduced to the elemental force of air. They try experiments from the book to “see” air and feel it move.

title: Air/Investigations
description: Students explore the mechanics of breathing, blowing up balloons to see evidence of air moving from their lungs into the balloon. As their balloon expands, students feel the movement of their diaphragm. They read classroom resources to learn how fish breathe underwater and then investigate air pressure by participating in an experiment.

title: Air/Migrations
description: Students make connections with Seasonal Migrations (Cultural History Kindergarten Unit 3). They listen to Eric Carle’s The Tiny Seed, which focuses on a seed that travels with the wind, survives perils, germinates, and grows into a flower, producing more seeds. On a springtime walk, students observe green shoots, buds, and flowers. They discuss the critical role of air in the cycle of growth and renewal.

title: Water/Water on Earth
description: Students begin the study of water by investigating how Earth obtains its water in a read-aloud of A Drop Around the World by Barbara McKinney. After reading about the journey of a raindrop, students discuss the importance of the water cycle and its connection to life on Earth.

title: Water/Salt Water vs. Freshwater
description: Students conduct experiments with fresh water and salt water, record observations, and discuss them. They read classroom books and take a field trip to a freshwater and a saltwater habitat. With the specimens they collected on their field trip, they set up two classroom tanks (one with fresh water and one with salt water).

title: Water/Necessary to Sustain Life
description: To better understand how water nourishes other organisms, students investigate water transportation in plants. They use dyed water to color flowers and then document their learning on a sectioned sheet of drawing paper.

title: Water/For Drinking
description: Students participate in read-alouds of stories about the scarcity of water, such as The Water Hole by Graeme Base and Tiddalick the Thirsty Frog retold by Mark Carthew. While reflecting on their reading, students discuss the need for mindful water use and take a walk to record ways that water is used around the school.

title: Creating Fairy Houses
description: As an integrative cumulative activity, students review elemental forces and symbols. They create houses for fairies using their new knowledge of essential needs, scale, and symbols.

title: Introduction to the Maya
description: This learning experience places the Maya civilization geographically, introduces archaeological study of the Maya, and provides a general description and overview of Classical Maya culture.

title: Maya Glyph Exercise
description: Students learn about the Maya system of writing, watch a video about interpreting the glyphs, and create their own glyphs.

title: Popol Vuh: Maya Origin Myth
description: Students read the Popul Vuh, the Maya origin myth. They discuss each episode and the nature of origin myths. They conceptualize links between the story and what they have learned about Maya culture, while using the story to make additional inferences about the Maya.

title: Art and Artifact Analysis of Maya Cups
description: Students analyze images found on cacao cups of the ancient Maya. They use a worksheet to organize their thinking about the Maya cups, such as the cups’ value to the ancient Maya, the artistic expression they embody, and the stories they tell.

title: Classical Maya Chiefdoms and Adaptation to the Environment: Agriculture, Food, and Nutrition
description: Students learn about the major crops of the Maya and the way non-complex societies weave religious belief into their subsistence activities. Topics include Maya agriculture of the Three Sisters, symbiosis as a biological process, and Maya diet and nutrition.

title: Maya Gods, Goddesses, Religion, and Agriculture
description: Students consider the ideological contrast between nature and culture with regard to the ancient Maya. As a homework assignment, they write a one-page essay about the contrast between nature and culture in their own landscape.

title: Maya Ballgame
description: Students explore the Maya Ballgame through an interactive website. They learn about various aspects of the sport and watch a reenactment of the game. Students consider how details of the ballgame reflect important characteristics of Maya culture.

title: Architecture of the Ancient Maya
description: Students explore ancient Maya structures that still remain today, with a focus on the ceremonial temples and observatories, especially the tomb of the Maya King Pacal.

title: Quiz: The Maya Calendar
description: Students explore the complexities of the Maya calendar and its relationship to Mathematics and astronomy. They take notes and create their own quizzes about the Maya calendar.

title: Maya Music
description: Students reinforce their learning about the music of the ancient Maya from their Performing Arts: Music class through a teacher presentation. The presentation includes both descriptions and images of various instruments played by the Maya, as well as other information about Maya music and its role in Maya religion, culture, and society. Students create their own instruments based on the ones they have learned about.

title: Bonampak Murals
description: A teacher-led presentation introduces students to the mural art of the Maya of the late classical period. Students analyze the murals, applying information they have learned about the history, society, and the political and economic structures of Maya culture.

title: The Collapse of the Maya
description: Students read about the collapse of the ancient Maya. They then evaluate and debate the theories presented in the readings.

title: Maya Research Paper, Creative Project, and Oral Presentation
description: Students write research papers, complete independent hands-on projects, and give oral presentations of their projects.

title: Test: Maya Unit Final
description: The Maya Unit Final includes questions concerning the geography, culture and politics, religion and sacrifice, art, and architecture of the Maya, as well as arguments about the collapse of the society.

title: Maya Day Celebration
description: As a culmination of the unit, students play the Maya ballgame, perform skits, and display and present their independent projects. They also provide Maya-style decorations and food for the school.

title: Build Background: Alexander the Great: An Introduction
description: Students discuss the following questions: What is culture? How do we recognize it? What kinds of artifacts does a culture leave behind? What is Persia? They then listen and take notes on a presentation regarding the importance of Alexander and Hellenism.

title: Hellenistic Greece Reading and Class Discussions
description: Students read and take notes on Alexander the Great and Ancient Greece by Miriam Greenblatt. They summarize orally and paraphrase in writing to reflect their knowledge of the text.

title: Current Events
description: Throughout the weeks, students report on and discuss current events in Mediterranean Europe and Asia, the conquered lands of Alexander’s empire. Reports are in both written and oral form and structured around the standard news questions: Who? What? When? Where? Why? How?

title: Alexander the Great Monologue Project
description: Students create and perform their own monologues from the point of view of a person in the life of Alexander the Great.

title: The Geography of Alexander’s Route
description: Students trace the geography of Alexander the Great’s route in a mapping activity using the Internet and Google Earth.

title: Alexander Travelogue Project
description: Students do research and create presentations about places of interest on Alexander the Great’s route.

title: Alexander Unit Test
description: Students take a written test to assess their understanding of Alexander the Great and their ability to map points of interest on Alexander’s route.

title: The Silk Road—Context, History, and Geography
description: Students read a novel about the Silk Road. Each student keeps a reading journal and participates in discussions about cultural fusion along the Silk Road.

title: Research and Oral Presentations on the Silk Road
description: Students conduct research on two topics inspired by their reading journals. Emphasis is on using questions to guide their research. They use their research to create and give short oral presentations.

title: Quiz: The Silk Road in Fiction
description: This is an open-book quiz that assesses students’ ability to use their annotations to answer short-essay questions about the unit novel.

title: Current Events: The Mediterranean World
description: Throughout the unit, students give weekly written and oral reports on current events. They practice reading news articles and being concise by answering who, what, where, when, why, and how questions in one or two sentences.

title: Silk Road Essay Writing Project
description: Students write three, one-page expository essays on topics related to their study of the Silk Road. Each essay is organized around a thesis statement and is accompanied by a relevant illustration.

title: Test: The Silk Road
description: The unit test assesses students’ knowledge of the Silk Road, including the Han Dynasty, cultural fusion, goods traded, and the challenges faced by the Silk Road travelers.

title: Silk Day
description: Silk Day is a celebration of Chinese culture. It includes a Chinese-themed lunch and a display of student art and writing projects.

title: An Introduction to Foundations of Early Rome
description: Students listen to a lecture and view images about the Etruscans and their contributions to Roman life and culture. To learn about the early forms of Roman government, students read, discuss, and take notes on essays in classroom texts.

title: Quiz: The Etruscans
description: This quiz assesses students’ knowledge of ancient Etruscan culture and its influence on later Roman civilization.

title: Daily Life in Ancient Rome: Research Project
description: Students research topics on ancient Roman culture and then share their findings in class presentations.

title: The Rise and Expansion of the Roman Empire
description: In this weeklong learning experience, students learn about the expansion of the Roman Empire by conducting research about the provinces and by reading about several leaders of resistance movements.

title: Pompeii and Herculaneum Research and Creative Project
description: After reading Pliny’s account of the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, students use class time and homework time to read, take notes, write essays, and create projects based on the houses uncovered in Pompeii and Herculaneum.

title: Cleopatra and Roman Egypt
description: Through reading, discussion, and writing, students learn about the role of women in the ancient world and the strategies used by Cleopatra to maneuver a treacherous political environment.

title: Quiz: Cleopatra and Roman Egypt
description: This quiz assesses students’ completion and comprehension of the unit novel about Cleopatra.

title: Cleopatra In-Class Compositions
description: In Cultural History and World Language and Literature: English classes, students write essays based on their annotations in the unit novel about Cleopatra.

title: Roman Architecture and the City
description: In this weeklong learning experience, students view presentations on Roman architecture, and they learn to draw two-point perspective in connection with their studies of Vitruvius.

title: Mapping Imperial Rome and the Collapse of the Roman Empire
description: Students map the major monuments in Imperial Rome that reflect the growth of the empire and the chronology of its rulers. Students then examine the explanations for the collapse of the Roman Empire.

title: Test: Rome Unit
description: The Rome unit test assesses students’ knowledge of the development of Republican Rome, the emergence and climax of Imperial Rome, and the collapse of the Roman Empire.

title: Introduction to Early Christianity in the Roman Empire
description: Through reading and discussion, students learn how Christianity helped to unite people of various cultures over vast geographic expanses.

title: Persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire
description: To examine Roman domination and Christian persecution, students read and annotateThe Bronze Bow and a selection excerpted from Perpetua’s prison journal.

title: The Bronze Bow Journal and Essay Assignment
description: Upon completion of reading The Bronze Bow, each student writes a reflective essay, developing an original thesis statement about or inspired by the book. The essay, completed in Cultural History and World Languages and Literature: English classes, helps assess students’ grasp of the content and historical time period presented in the novel.

title: Paul and the Spread of Christianity
description: Through classroom texts and maps, students discover the important role that Paul of Tarsus played in the spread of Christianity.

title: Test: Christianity Unit
description: The Christianity unit test assesses students’ comprehension of key concepts studied.

title: Ashoka and the Spread of Buddhism
description: In this learning experience, students read and discuss essays about Ashoka and his role in the spread of Buddhism.

title: An Age of Change
description: After briefly reviewing the evolution of consciousness in the spiral curriculum, students analyze the inventions of the Gilded Age (electric lights, horseless carriages, flying machines, etc.), and consider how much has changed in the world during the more than one hundred years since that era.

title: The Gilded Age: Carnegie, Rockefeller, and Baum
description: Students read, discuss, and take notes on essays about Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller, and L. Frank Baum. They also consider the United States’ economic system, describing what they know about how the system works and who regulates it.

title: Progressives and Muckrakers
description: Students analyze the Progressive Movement and its beginnings as a response to the problems caused by rapid industrialization and urbanization. They identify the leaders and issues of the Progressive Era and the muckracers who brought these issues to light.

title: Immigration and Jacob Riis
description: Students examine the living and working conditions of immigrants in American cities and how the exposure of their experiences changed the face of the nation’s cities. They learn about Jacob Riis, a social reformer who used photography to expose the wretched living conditions of New York City’s poor.

title: Theodore Roosevelt and Empire Building
description: Students examine Theodore Roosevelt both as an “empire builder,” with his advocacy of the Spanish-American War and as a progressive reformer with his trust-busting, regulation of industry and conservation.

title: Political Cartoons
description: Students analyze and interpret political cartoons, learning how serious economic, social, and political issues can be expressed visually and comically.

title: Unit Test
description: Students complete the Gilded Age Unit Test, which assesses their understanding of vocabulary and important ideas regarding journalism, living conditions, immigration, Theodore Roosevelt, the Progressive Era, and the economic system of the Gilded Age.

title: Final Exam
description: In this Final Exam, students respond to short answer questions that assess their knowledge of each of the grade 7 units. They also answer essay questions that assess their ability to discuss the themes of empire expansion and universalizing religions.

title: Introductions and Louis XIV’s Emblem Poem
description: As an icebreaker and introduction to Louis XIV, a focus of study in Cultural History, students read Louis XIV’s emblem poem and write their own.

title: Overview and Orientation to Reading Literature
description: Students are introduced to the course and unit. They are then given three diagnostic assessments—a literary terms quiz, a summer reading essay, and a summer reading creative response assignment—to gauge their literary analysis and reading comprehension skills.

title: Daniel Defoe’s Robinson Crusoe
description: This learning experience introduces students to the novel through two activities: Predicting the Plot and Role Play. This multilevel experience is designed to engage students in the story through previews of the plot and characters.

title: Charting Crusoe’s Voyages
description: While students begin tracking Crusoe’s voyages on maps, they consider the contemporary equivalents of “going to sea” and the motivation for this type of adventure. They also choose a cultural history topic to trace throughout the novel.

title: Rise of the Novel
description: As students continue reading and tracing Crusoe’s voyages, they learn about the cultural factors that contributed to the rise of the novel and understand why Robinson Crusoe is often considered to be the first English novel.

title: Survival and Civilization
description: Students continue to discuss Robinson Crusoe, focusing on Crusoe’s experiences on the island and what they believe are the necessities of survival. This learning experience ends with a discussion on the value of working with one’s hands.

title: Hints of Hobbes and Locke
description: Students identify and discuss aspects of Robinson Crusoe that suggest Defoe was influenced by Thomas Hobbes and John Locke.

title: Quizzes on Robinson Crusoe
description: These quizzes, taken by students throughout the unit, assess reading preparation and comprehension as well as vocabulary mastery.

title: Crusoe’s Toleration
description: Students continue discussing the novel, with emphasis on the island as a reflection of Locke’s ideas. They apply their understanding of literary devices to enrich their understanding of the text.

title: Voltaire and the Enlightenment
description: As an introduction to Voltaire’s Candide, which students will read in the next unit, students listen to lectures about Voltaire’s life and works. They then read several of his Philosophical Letters.

title: Coffee Houses and the Exchange of Ideas
description: Students learn about 18th-century England coffee house culture and make comparisons to modern coffee shops.

title: Voltaire’s Candide: The Nature of Satire
description: Students identify the elements of satire and how it is used to critique society, using Candide as a basis for their study.

title: Using Satire to Respond to School Culture
description: Students apply their understanding of satire by critiquing an aspect of school culture using a medium of their choice.

title: Leibnizian/Panglossian Optimism and Its Deterrents
description: Students read and discuss the first six chapters of Candide, focusing on satirical elements and the idea of optimism.

title: The Comedy of Reversals
description: In this learning experience, students read and discuss chapters 7–13 of Candide and respond to the text through tableau or miming.

title: Jesuit Missions and the “Noble Savage”
description: Students read chapters 15–18 of Candide, discuss the Jesuit mission, and present visual representations of two utopias in the novella.

title: Pessimism, Corruption, and the Cultivation of One’s Garden
description: In this learning experience, students finish reading Candide and participate in group discussions on a variety of themes throughout the text, including pessimism and corruption.

title: Franklin’s Autobiography
description: Through the study of various autobiographies, specifically those of Benjamin Franklin and Jean-Jacques Rousseau, students explore the rise of the individual and liberation of the middle class.

title: Readings and Writings on Rhetoric
description: Students prepare for the Cultural History Point of View Project on the American Revolution by studying elements of rhetoric and applying what they have learned to a reading of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Rousseau’s The Social Contract and Émile
description: Students examine Rousseau’s work to understand his perceptions of the individual’s place in society.

title: Rousseau’s Confessions
description: Students continue reading Rousseau’s autobiography and then write a comparison between his work and Franklin’s Autobiography.

title: Phillis Wheatley’s Life and Poetry
description: In this learning experience, students learn about Phillis Wheatley’s life, poetry, and significance in American history during the time of the American Revolution.

title: Toussaint L’Ouverture: Slavery and Revolution in Haiti
description: Students examine the impact of Toussaint L’Ouverture and his writings, which were instrumental in leading to the Haitian revolution for independence.

title: Goethe’s The Sorrows of Young Werther
description: During this learning experience, students begin reading Goethe’s The Sorrows of Young Werther to examine the Romantics’ preoccupation with authenticity and analyze Goethe’s crucial relationship to the Romantic movement.

title: Kant and Goethe
description: Students are introduced to philosopher Immanuel Kant and his concept of authenticity. They apply this idea in their examination of motifs as they complete their reading of Goethe’s novel.

title: Romantic Poetry and the Ideas of the Time
description: In this learning experience, students are introduced to Romanticism in British poetry.

title: William Wordsworth and Lyrical Ballads
description: Students investigate Wordsworth’s poetic theory and his use of poetic techniques in several poems.

title: William Blake as Visionary Poet
description: Students become acquainted with Blake’s origins and his participation in radical circles. They read a selection of his poetry in order to understand his view of the Industrial Revolution.

title: Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein
description: This learning experience begins with an introduction to Mary Shelley and continues with a focus on Gothic motifs in her novel Frankenstein. Students write an essay examining Shelley’s use of the doppelgänger in this novel.

title: Walt Whitman’s Leaves of Grass
description: In this learning experience, students are introduced to Whitman’s use of Romantic elements in his free verse and the American sense of Romanticism.

title: What Do I Want to Know About Fossils?
description: Students revisit their learning about Earth systems from grade 2 by creating a KWL chart. Using the chart and information from a read-aloud about fossils, students work collaboratively to develop questions that will guide their learning as they begin their exploration of evolution in this unit.

title: Unit Summaries/Questions
description: Students create summaries of big ideas from the unit on index cards to capture their understandings and they create inquiry question cards to identify areas of understanding that need clarification. As questions change to understandings, students create big-idea summary cards to match. The cards help identify where and how to support individual students.

title: Reading Research on Bacteria
description: Students conduct online research about a specific type of bacteria, trace its evolution from origin to present day, and present their findings to the class.

title: Making Connections with Early Forms of Plant Life
description: Combining information gleaned from Cultural History learning experiences focused on early plants with information gathered from their own research, students create informational books on one of the specific plants studied in this integrated learning experience.

title: Fossil Read-Aloud
description: After participating in a read-aloud of The Fossil Factory: A Kid’s Guide to Digging Up Dinosaurs, Exploring Evolution, and Finding Fossils, students discuss how the study of fossils and rocks helps to determine Earth’s history. After a whole-group discussion, students collaborate to create a timeline that shows how biology and geology are coevolving systems.

title: Reading/Writing with Big Old Bones
description: Students take notes during a second reading of Digging Up Dinosaurs to gather specific details to use when writing an answer to the question: “Do you think it is difficult for archaeologists, geologists, and paleontologists to know exactly what happened in the past?”

title: Poetry and Living Fossils
description: Using Ubiquitous: Celebrating Nature’s Survivors as a mentor text, student create a variety of poems about animals and plants that have lived through the ages, such as beetles, geckos, sharks, crows, and dandelions.

title: Dinosaur Tree
description: After listening to Dinosaur Tree in Cultural History, students rewrite the story from the tree’s perspective, tracing its evolution journey over millions of years.

title: Dinosaur Research Project
description: As part of an integrated project that will be shared with the community at the Evolving Planet Museum (CH_G3_U1_18_AS), students glean information about the specific dinosaurs they are researching by listening to a read-aloud of The Magic School Bus in the Time of Dinosaurs.

title: Research Presentation
description: Each small group research team presents its dinosaur research project to parents, other students, and community members at the Evolving Planet Museum (CH_G3_U1_18_AS).

title: Making Mammal Connections
description: Students organize and connect concepts to each other and a larger knowledge framework by creating mind maps. Beginning with mammalians, they branch out to encompass evolution, adaptation, and the Cenozoic era and continue branching to capture and connect all concepts, reflecting a thorough understanding of the topics developed.

title: Journal Editing and Revisions
description: During Writing Workshop, students edit and revise their Cultural History journal entries explaining and describing the evolution of life from planetary origins to 10,000 BCE using information from texts and demonstrating correct grammar and spelling strategies.

title: Mammoths in Reading Workshop
description: As students learn about the woolly mammoth in Science, they explore nonfiction books about woolly mammoths in varied reading groups using different reading techniques before discussing their books with their partners.

title: Research Study and Book
description: To launch their study of mammalian evolution, students choose a mammal to investigate, tracing its lineage from prehistoric ancestors to its modern descendant. They explore a variety of texts and websites to collect and organize information before working in small groups to write, peer edit, and revise the text for each page of an accordion book about the mammal’s evolution.

title: Adaptation: Writing Workshop
description: For Writing Workshop, students write and illustrate a poem to express the hypothesis they drew from their research findings on how adaptation might have led to their prehistoric mammal’s survival.

title: Mammals and Size
description: Students compare the size of the different prehistoric mammals to each other and to themselves and write about it in any genre: fiction, nonfiction, or poetry.

title: Mammalian Creation
description: Students apply all that they have learned about early mammalian evolution by discussing and writing about their imaginary mammal. Data assembled in this assessment may serve as background for imaginary animal activities in cultural history and visual arts.

title: Early Humans: Reading/Vocabulary
description: Using the book Early Humans, this learning experience gives students the opportunity to gain knowledge of the world of early humans and learn vocabulary that describes that world. The introduction and discussion of vocabulary terms helps students understand the text.

title: Early Human Research
description: Using the Internet, students search for, explore, and classify information about the discoveries of early humans.

title: Early Human Compare/Contrast
description: In this learning experience, students create a diagram, such as a Venn diagram or a T-chart, to compare and contrast hominids and apes. They incorporate their compare/contrast data and additional information to create teaching books about early humans and apes.

title: Early Human Essay Writing
description: Students work independently to write an essay about early humans and use facts to support predictions about human survival.

title: Timeline of Human Evolution
description: As a summative assessment of unit content, students create a timeline depicting the evolution of humans.

title: Questioning Human Evolution
description: Students create a KWL chart to connect what they know about the evolution of the natural world to questions they have about the evolution of culture, and then create mind maps to conceptualize research they will focus on throughout this unit of study.

title: Human Survival Read-Aloud
description: After reading and listening to texts that describe human necessities for survival, students create webs that reflect and organize the survival information in preparation for a diagnostic assessment in their Cultural History class.

title: Early Human Dwellings Sketch Journals
description: Students create labeled sketches of the Dolni Vestonice and Terra Amata settlements and compare them to other early human dwellings in preparation for creating their own settlement dwelling structures in cultural history class.

title: Lascaux Reading Using Visualization
description: After being introduced to visualization and using it to infer meaning through a read-aloud, students apply the strategy when rereading a text about the caves of Lascaux.

title: Early Human “Creative Museum” Project
description: Using all available resources from the unit, students work in groups to create backgrounds, write scripts, and give live presentations of their wax museum living dioramas.

title: Numbers with Music
description: In this learning experience, students explore the power of naming numbers through investigating the numbers and names of musical ensembles in Zin! Zin! A Violin! They write addition number sentences to model “one more” musician joining the musical ensemble in the story and discuss number-related words such as solo, duo, and trio and their corresponding values. They conclude the learning experience by performing counting songs in groups representative of the small ensembles in the story.

title: What’s My Number?
description: Students begin first grade by playing games with a partner that demonstrate their prior number sense. They also participate in a one-on-one diagnostic assessment with the teacher showcasing their understanding of the numbers 1 to 20 and the connections between numbers.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students record their observations and reflections in the form of drawings and written words. Specifically, they work with words, numbers, diagrams, drawings, and other visual representations to identify mathematical concepts and symbols.

title: Naming and Comparing Periods of Time
description: In this learning experience, students connect the names of the months of the year to their placement within a calendar year. They discover how a clock represents specific times of day and how they can use terms such as morning, noon, and night to differentiate between two seemingly equivalent times.

title: Counting and Modeling Two-Digit Numbers
description: In this learning experience, students collect small objects found in nature and use strategies to count them. They begin to develop an understanding of place value through exploring groupings of tens and how they correspond to the tens digit in two-digit numbers.

title: Naming “Decades”: Number Families of Tens
description: In this learning experience, students collaboratively fill in a blank hundred chart and track how often each digit is used. They look for patterns in how each of the digits is used and use these patterns to help them understand the order of numbers in the chart.

title: Naming and Classifying Plane Shapes
description: In this learning experience, students demonstrate their understanding of two-dimensional plane shapes by identifying, naming, drawing, and labeling triangles, rectangles, squares, circles, and so on. They sort the shapes and create categories to organize them. Then they make a packing list for an assorted two-dimensional shape kit.

title: Numbers 1 to 10 on the Soroban
description: Students continue to develop their understanding of numbers to ten by using the soroban. They also solve addition and subtraction sentences, as well as simple word problems using the soroban.

title: Naming Sums and Differences
description: In this formative assessment, students demonstrate their knowledge of addition and subtraction sentences by using manipulatives and creating story problems. They also write explanations on how to solve for sums and differences.

title: Numbers in Other Languages
description: Students extend their understanding of naming numbers by learning and recognizing numbers up to ten in different languages. They also identify number patterns to use numbers in other languages more fluently and frequently.

title: Custom Design Kits
description: To conclude this unit, students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts developed by creating a design with two-dimensional shapes. They use 30 to 40 shape pieces from pattern blocks, attribute kits, and other two-dimensional kits to create a colorful design and a packing list for others to re-create the design.

title: What’s a Repeating Pattern?
description: Students start the unit by completing a one-on-one diagnostic assessment. They also work in groups to create linear patterns and discuss the rule for each pattern. Students record their observations and knowledge about patterns on chart paper for future reference.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical concepts, mathematical practices, and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals.

title: Repeating Patterns and Predictions
description: Students create and analyze their own repeating patterns of shapes using pattern blocks, connecting cubes, and computer drawing tools.

title: Repeating Patterns and Tessellations
description: Students apply what they have learned about repeating patterns to connect to their search for natural tessellations and other patterns in Cultural History in order to create their own tessellations.

title: Symmetrical Patterns
description: Students use their prior knowledge of symmetry to create symmetrical patterns.

title: Patterns and Place Value in Number Names
description: Students examine the numbers 1 to 100 written as numerals and as words, identify and discuss patterns, learn to write word names for numbers, and practice counting aloud.

title: What’s a Growing Pattern?
description: Students explore growing patterns with shapes, numbers represented with cubes and dots, and numerals. They complete a Venn diagram to compare and contrast growing and repeating patterns and connect the patterns to their study of natural patterns in Cultural History and Science.

title: Growing Number Patterns
description: Students connect growing patterns to arithmetic sequences by modeling growing patterns with connecting cubes and by playing a “name the missing number” game.

title: Number Patterns and Skip-Counting
description: In this learning experience, students investigate skip-counting number patterns and the number relationships inherent to the hundred chart and number lines through a series of activities.

title: What’s the Rule?
description: Students identify a pattern for a given set of numbers, write a pattern rule, and use the rule to extend the pattern.

title: Composition of Numbers and Addition Table Patterns
description: In this learning experience, students explore the numeric patterns on an addition table. They use manipulatives, such as connecting cubes and the soroban, to model basic facts to identify sums and complete the table.

title: Digits and Place Value Groups
description: Students begin to develop an understanding of the base-ten system using their fingers and base-ten blocks. They associate values with both the tens and the ones digits in two-digit numbers.

title: Temperature and Reading Thermometers
description: Students apply their understanding of tens and skip counting to thermometers as they read and represent temperatures to the nearest ten degrees.

title: Add and Subtract from Two-Digit Numbers
description: In this learning experience, students develop a variety of strategies to add two-digit and one-digit numbers and subtract one-digit numbers from two-digit numbers. They use manipulatives, such as ten frames, base-ten blocks, and the soroban to add and subtract with and without regrouping.

title: Color by My Numbers
description: In this assessment, students display their understanding of addition and subtraction by designing a color-by-number quilt block pattern.

title: Calendar, Time, and Sequence Words
description: Students complete a diagnostic assessment to gauge prior knowledge about calendars, time, and sequence words. They also create a timeline of holidays and events for the year and discuss other sequences of events, such as those that happen at different times of the day.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students continue to build on their knowledge and document it through drawings and writings in journals. They also contemplate and write reflections based on their observations and learning experiences.

title: Holidays for Each Season and Month of the Year
description: Students sing songs and investigate literature in order to master the names and order of the days of the week and the months of the year. They conduct further research on holidays and use calendars to determine when they occur along a monthly timeline.

title: The Winter Holiday Season and Number Lines
description: Students use a number line to identify, compare, and order numbers from 1 to 100. They create a number line depicting holidays and customs during the winter holiday season and practice moving forward and backward along a number line to mimic addition and subtraction.

title: Adding and Subtracting on Number Lines
description: Students perform mathematical operations using a number line to develop their understanding of the relative magnitudes of numbers and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

title: Sharing with Even and Odd Amounts
description: Students investigate the relationship between even and odd numbers. They play a game of spin-the-dreidel to explore the significance of even and odd numbers in relation to halves.

title: Reading and Writing Time
description: Students learn to read and write times on both analog and digital clocks to the hour and half hour. They play Telling Time Bingo and discuss specific times relating to holiday traditions and stories.

title: Time for the Holidays
description: Students work in small groups to make a fact sheet poster for a selected holiday. The poster includes the date(s) of the holiday, the length in hours, days, and so forth. of any celebrations, and any significant times during the celebrations in the form of a timeline.

title: A Math Toolbox
description: In this learning experience, students learn about the concept of mental math tools and the understandings and strategies that help them calculate and solve problems more efficiently. They compare physical scientific tools with mathematical tools and then explain how using tools makes work easier.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical tools, mathematical practices, and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals.

title: Adding and Subtracting with Zero
description: In this learning experience, students rotate through centers to investigate adding and subtracting zero. They practice modeling addition and subtraction sentences on the soroban and continue to fill in their addition tables.

title: Seeing Doubles
description: Students investigate doubles and add more mathematical tools to their toolbox. They continue to fill in their addition tables and identify patterns on the tables.

title: Doubles Plus or Minus One
description: Students use the mental mathematical tool of doubles plus or minus one to identify sums and differences. They continue to fill in their addition table as they work through solving number sentences.

title: Adding and Subtracting Tens
description: In this learning experience, students investigate the place value system to add and subtract tens and multiples of ten from two-digit numbers. They continue to fill in their addition table and add to their mathematical toolbox.

title: Measuring Length with Repeating Units
description: Students order objects and themselves from shortest to tallest and work in pairs or small groups to explore length and linear measurements using nonstandard units of measurement.

title: Inches, Centimeters, and Rulers
description: Students apply what they have learned about measuring with nonstandard units to measuring the length of objects using inches and centimeters. They estimate, compare, and measure the lengths of several classroom objects and discuss the importance of using labels when recording measurements.

title: The Shapes We See
description: During this assessment, students display their knowledge of two-dimensional shapes and their attributes.

title: Making Shapes from Shapes
description: Students compose and decompose a variety of polygons and three-dimensional figures to develop familiarity with the attributes of two- and three-dimensional shapes.

title: Identifying Congruent Shapes
description: Students develop an understanding of congruency by exploring the sides and angles within a given shape such as a square or rectangle. They also explore whether or not two figures are congruent based on their shape and size.

title: Measurements for Making Tools
description: Students estimate and measure the dimensions of the tool from Cultural History Unit 2 assessment Designing and Making Tools (CH_G1_U2_10_AS) and they explain how the shape and size of the tool and its parts relate to its intended purpose and use.

title: What Can We Measure?
description: Students start the unit by brainstorming different measurable attributes. They show their prior knowledge of measurement by rotating through centers and describing how to measure different states of water.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit and the year, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical practices and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals.

title: Comparison Symbols
description: Students begin to explore the inequality symbols and expressions for less than (<) and greater than (>). They play games and complete activities to reinforce their use of appropriate mathematical language and the correct use of symbols to compare the relationship between two numerical values.

title: Measuring and Comparing Weight
description: Students begin to develop their understanding of standard weight measurement units by weighing a variety of objects using several different types of scales. They compare the weight of the objects using inequality symbols and relate the weight to the size and shape of each object.

title: Measuring and Comparing Capacity
description: In this learning experience, students integrate with their water-measuring activities in cultural history to measure the capacity of containers using standard whole units. They explore different containers with equivalent capacities and investigate the concept of conservation.

title: Lemonade Recipes
description: In this formative assessment, students follow a recipe with exact measurements. They then modify the recipe to create their own recipe and compare the two recipes.

title: Patterns with Measurements
description: In this learning experience, students move around the classroom to several different stations where they begin to formulate an understanding of how size and shape affect the weight of an object. They also discover how to distinguish weight from capacity.

title: Equivalent Forms of the Same Number
description: Students reinforce their understanding of the composition of numbers by investigating equivalent addition and subtraction expressions.

title: Halves, Thirds, and Fourths of a Whole
description: Students build on their knowledge of halves as they explore the meaning of other common unit fractions, focusing on one third and one fourth.

title: Unit Fractions of a Set
description: Students explore the meaning of fractional parts of a set as they share groups of objects equally.

title: Probability and Fractions
description: Students connect their experience with fractions to expressing probability as they perform probability experiments using a spinner.

title: Water Posters
description: To conclude this unit, students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts developed by creating a water information poster. They use a given water amount, such as 1 gallon = 16 cups or 2 liters = 20 deciliters, and describe how the water can be used throughout the day. They decompose the given amount in three different mathematical ways.

title: Characteristics of Coins
description: Students start the unit by completing a one-on-one diagnostic assessment. They also work in groups to identify attributes that can be used to sort the coins they have been given. They choose an attribute, sort the coins, and showcase the comparison on chart paper.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical practices and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals.

title: Coin Values and Shopping
description: Students learn about coin values, using the cent symbol, and adding, subtracting, and comparing money amounts through playing games and participating in a shopping scenario.

title: Bottle Deposits, Recycling, and Skip Counting
description: Students continue to work with money amounts as they explore the topics of bottle deposits and recycling. They skip count forward and backward to keep track of bottle deposits and returns as they role-play bottle deposit return scenarios.

title: Pennies, Dimes, Dollars, and Place Values
description: Students play a variety of games to reinforce their understanding of money and place value concepts.

title: Speedy Coin Counting
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of money concepts by analyzing coin pictograms and identifying a faster and more efficient method of counting the values of the coins.

title: The Commutative Property of Addition
description: Students explore the Commutative Property of Addition using dominoes and the addition table.

title: Fact Families and Unknown Numbers
description: Students build on their understanding of related addition equations to identify and write fact families and model problem situations.

title: Writing and Solving Problems Vertically
description: In this learning experience, students relate addition and subtraction on the soroban and place value charts to solve real-world word problems. They also record the numeric representations vertically.

title: Making a Difference Survey
description: Students reflect on what they’ve learned throughout the unit about environmentally sustainable practices by seeking out opinions and sharing their ideas by conducting a survey. They talk about how a single person can help the environment and how little things can be done to accomplish something big.

title: How We Will Make a Difference
description: Students display, interpret, and summarize their survey data and create a poster to communicate their results.

title: Foundational Skills Test
description: Students complete a diagnostic assessment to collect informative baseline data. They demonstrate their mastery of identifying place values, names, and expanded forms of numbers up to 1,000, identifying units of time and linear measurements, regrouping to add and subtract, and locating whole numbers and common fractions on a number line.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students continue to build on their knowledge and document it through drawings and writings in journals. They also contemplate and write reflections based on their observations and learning experiences.

title: Scaling Numbers
description: Students develop a quantitative understanding of large multidigit numbers through further exploration of place value and place value periods. They integrate their exploration of place value with their study of science and cultural history by writing about the numeric values associated with various geologic periods in numerals, words, and expanded form.

title: Comparing and Ordering Numbers
description: In this learning experience, students apply their understanding of place value to plot, compare, and order numbers. They also explain how to use place value to compare and order numbers.

title: Rounding Numbers to Estimate
description: Students work through this learning experience in conjunction with the integrated project “Calculating Elapsed Time—Timelines Throughout Our Evolving Planet.” They practice rounding large numbers, such as those on their timelines, to the nearest ten, hundred, thousand, and million, and reason about why numbers are sometimes rounded or estimated.

title: Backward and Forward Through Time
description: Students use the inverse operations of addition and subtraction to model and solve elapsed-time problems relating to Earth’s history on a number line.

title: Daily Schedules on a Number Line
description: Students create a timeline of their typical daily activity schedule or their ideal schedule and calculate elapsed time between activities.

title: Using Patterns and Properties
description: Students examine the relationship between addends and their sum using an addition table. They begin to explore addition properties and use what they know to solve equations involving tens, hundreds, and thousands.

title: Reading Scaled Graphs
description: In this learning experience, students continue to build on comparing and analyzing the timespans between prehistoric dates, measurements providing geological context for fossils, and so on. They read, interpret, and use scaled pictographs and bar graphs to solve problems.

title: My Personal Time Scale
description: To conclude the unit and build on their Cultural History studies, students demonstrate their understanding of relative and absolute dating, as well as elapsed time, by designing timelines of their own lives.

title: The Timespan of All Mammals
description: To collect informative baseline data, students complete a diagnostic assessment, demonstrating their understanding of multiplication. They use the previous unit’s timeline to identify the time intervals between the first pre-mammals, the first true mammals, the beginning of the Age of Mammals, and the present day.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit, students document in their Mathematics journals their understanding of multiplication, division, and mammalian evolution through writings, drawings, and reflections related to the concepts in this unit.

title: Factors in Multiplication
description: In this learning experience, students circulate through learning centers while using a variety of models and manipulatives to represent the meaning of factors and to solve for products.

title: Multiplication Properties and Patterns
description: Students work together to explore multiplication properties and use number lines, multiplication tables, and arrays to prove their mathematical reasoning. They also discuss strategies and develop a plan to memorize multiplication facts through 12.

title: Dividing to Solve Multiplication Problems
description: Students gain an understanding of the relationship between multiplication and division by solving multiplication problems that contain unknown factors. They rewrite those equations as division equations and solve for the unknown value.

title: Scaling Up and Down
description: Students explore scaling or resizing as another context for whole-number multiplication and division, in connection with their Mammal Morph Books learning experience in Cultural History.

title: Making Scale Drawings
description: As part of their Cultural History integrated project Mammals and Scale, students identify an appropriate ratio to create a scale drawing of a prehistoric mammal they have researched.

title: Analyzing a Set of Data
description: Students use data they have collected about mammals in their Cultural History studies to create line plots and then interpret the data by investigating the mean, median, mode, and range.

title: The Scale of Evolutionary Changes
description: Students consider the nature of the measurements they have encountered and used throughout the unit, in connection with their study of fossils in science. They discuss and reason about the need to measure multiple fossils in order to establish a typical measurement for a species, and the concept that evolution occurs as physical changes take root within a population, not just a single organism.

title: Measurements from Fossils
description: To conclude this unit, students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts developed in this unit by creating a model set of fossils to represent an established size measurement.

title: The Evolution of Human Mammals
description: Students map out and explore how the evidence of human evolution compares to evidence of evolution for other mammals, connecting learning from Cultural History and Science.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical concepts, mathematical practices, and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals.

title: Multiplication and Division Patterns with Place Values
description: In this learning experience, students identify patterns with zero and use place value and manipulatives, such as the soroban, to multiply and divide numbers by 10; 100; 1,000; and 10,000. They also relate to their Cultural History studies of measuring garbage as they measure items in kilograms and grams.

title: Decomposing to Multiply and Divide
description: Students explore the Distributive Property of Multiplication and apply the concept to division by decomposing a dividend into addends that are multiples of a divisor to find a quotient.

title: Division with Dental Evidence
description: Students continue their work with division by recognizing division situations in the context of human evolution. They practice recognizing division situations involving partitioning, or fair sharing, and separating in problem scenarios involving dental evidence.

title: “Miniature Me” Figure Drawings
description: Students visually compare and estimate length differences between corresponding body parts in the skeletons of humans, other primates, and early hominids; measure lengths of their own body parts; use fractions and mixed numbers to describe and compare lengths related to the evolution of bipedalism; and then divide these lengths to create a half-sized figure drawing of an early human.

title: Learning from the Laetoli Footprints
description: Students integrate the Laetoli Footprints learning experience in Cultural History, in which students make fossilized footprints and measure the length of the stride to determine the relative height of each walker.

title: How Important Are Size and Shape?
description: Students explore area, surface area, and volume by using cubes to build shapes with square or rectangular faces and then calculate the surface area and volume.

title: A Possible Addition to the Family
description: To conclude this unit, students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts developed in this unit by inventing an early human species. They also write a reflection about measurements of one aspect of the fictional species.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical concepts, mathematical practices, and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals.

title: Strength in Numbers
description: To begin this unit, students investigate human development during the Paleolithic period to explore the nature and level of number sense and mathematical reasoning skills in early humans.

title: One-to-One Correspondence
description: Students investigate the use of one-to-one correspondence to count and keep track of amounts with tally marks as they think critically about the process of counting and creating a number system.

title: Area and Perimeter at Archaeological Sites
description: As students investigate the archaeological sites at Terra Amata and Dolni Vestonice during their cultural history studies, they explore how archaeologists employ area and perimeter at dig sites while searching for and analyzing tools and other artifacts.

title: Equivalent Fractions and Equal Chances
description: This learning experience is the first in a series in which students develop their understanding of fractions through investigations of probability concepts.

title: Adding and Subtracting Fractions to Calculate Probabilities
description: Students explore adding and subtracting fractions with like denominators as they discuss the probabilities of events not occurring and single events that can have one or more acceptable outcomes.

title: Identifying Fractions of Numbers
description: Students investigate how to visually represent a fraction of a whole number and determine the product using multiplication.

title: Fractions and Decimal Money Amounts
description: In this learning experience, students use decimal equivalents of common fractions. They use manipulatives, including coin currency and the soroban, to explore equivalency.

title: Prehistoric Decision Making
description: In this summative assessment, students identify how basic probability concepts relate to factors in the survival and cultural development of early humans.

title: Unit 1 Foundational Skills Test
description: Students complete a diagnostic test to demonstrate their prior knowledge of concepts and skills essential to this unit, such as the word names and expanded forms of numbers, addition and subtraction with regrouping, multiplication and division facts through 100, and the use of area models to show those facts.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students continue to build on their knowledge and document it through drawings and writings in journals. They also contemplate and write reflections based on their observations and learning experiences.

title: Early Modern Human Evidence Timeline
description: Students broadly outline the 200,000-year history of Homo sapiens to contextualize the time period and review place values and addition and subtraction with multidigit numbers. Then students create a timeline showing the provided ages of fossils and important artifacts. Students use the data to write, compare, and order numbers, subtract to make comparisons, and use inverse operations to check their answers.

title: Adding and Subtracting Thousands
description: Students add and subtract numbers having four or more digits and use inverse operations to check their answers. They use the soroban and standard written algorithms as they explore computation strategies, expanded and written forms of numbers, and place value concepts.

title: Rounding and Comparing the Sizes of Communities
description: Students apply place value relationships to make multiplicative comparisons related to communities of varying sizes. They multiply and divide by ten, powers of ten, and multiples of those numbers. They explore patterns, order, and rounding of numbers as they compare populations

title: Types of Comparisons
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the difference between additive and multiplicative comparisons by using both to describe how the size of their clan of classmates in Cultural History compares to a typical upper-Paleolithic or Neolithic clan making up a village.

title: Clan Baby Statistics
description: Students apply their data analysis skills to their Clan Baby Project in Cultural History. Each clan collaboratively devises and follows a plan for sharing caretaking responsibilities fairly and for measuring the group’s overall success and the contributions of each member. As they analyze and summarize the collected data for their performance, students reflect on whether a historically larger clan might informally perform the same type of assessment and if they would view roles and responsibilities in a similar manner.

title: Whole-Number Units and Patterns
description: Students explore basic number theory concepts and factorization during this learning experience. They define and identify even and odd numbers, prime and composite numbers, and factors and multiples of whole numbers. Students explore how these classifications relate to patterns with operations and categorize numbers by their properties.

title: Multiplication and Division by Ones
description: Students build on understandings of number theory and factorization from the previous learning experience (MA_G4_U1_08_LE) to decompose multidigit numbers in order to multiply and divide multidigit numbers by a single-digit number. After some exploration, students learn the standard algorithm for multiplying and dividing multidigit numbers by a single-digit number. In addition, to prepare for the final learning experience and assessment in this unit (MA_G4_U1_10_LE; MA_G4_U1_11_AS), students reflect on reasons why a week has been defined as having seven days.

title: Cycles of Time
description: Within a two-week integrated project in Cultural History on cycles of time, students investigate whether larger units of time—such as days, weeks, and months—were selected for mathematical, scientific, cultural, or religious reasons. Students also investigate how time is measured and recorded by creating timekeeping tools. They have made tally-stick lunar calendars using one-to-one correspondence in Cultural History and now closely examine these primitive models and compare them to actual artifacts, including the Blanchard and Ishango bones. With a cooperative group, students design and create a current solar calendar that measures and represents all aspects of time.

title: Sun and Moon Calendar
description: Students conclude the unit by creating a calendar for the month, using an original unit of time that demonstrates their understanding of the natural elements. The calendar incorporates dates and solar and lunar cycles, as well as the human conception of time.

title: Fraction Skills Test
description: Students take a diagnostic test to demonstrate their prior knowledge of fraction concepts and skills essential to this unit and the next unit, to help tailor instruction and help students set personal learning goals.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students continue to use their Mathematics journals by applying their new knowledge and skills to their archaeological investigations. Also, they record daily practice using the four arithmetic operations to solve geometric measurement problems and word problems. Students will be assessed on accuracy and attention to details while drawing and labeling geometric figures.

title: Early Human Travel and Migration
description: Students investigate distances involved in early human migration across continents, using maps to estimate and measure distances. They collaboratively write multiplication and division equations that they can use to convert map measurements and create tables for map scales. They reason about distances represented by fractional map lengths, add and subtract distances, and gauge the total amount of time it might take to cover that much ground on foot.

title: Multiplying to Convert Measurements
description: As students measure and document artifacts from their simulated archaeological dig in Science, they discuss the equivalents for common measurement units in the customary and metric systems. They multiply to convert measurements from larger to smaller units in the same system. Then students are challenged to determine and model the number of square feet equal to one square yard, using arrays and strategies for multiplying two-digit factors.

title: Long Division with Single-Digit Divisors
description: Students begin an ongoing investigation of the long-division algorithm, continuing their work with units of measurement by dividing to convert measurements from smaller to larger units. They focus on units of capacity and other measurements that involve single-digit divisors. Then they work collaboratively to write fractions to express each larger unit in terms of the next smaller unit, such as understanding that one foot is the same as one third yard.

title: Prehistoric Geometry at Göbekli Tepe
description: Students begin to connect mathematics to their studies of Neolithic settlements in Cultural History and megalithic structures and archaeoastronomy in Science. They demonstrate their prior knowledge of geometric shapes and spatial relationships associated with the oldest known temple, the Göbekli Tepe temple in Turkey, which dates from 10,000–9,000 BCE. Students identify and sketch the geometric shapes that make up the individual structures and the general layout, and they describe the mathematical relationships between different parts of the structure, including proportionality and symmetry.

title: Angles, Degrees, and Directions at Cahokia
description: Students learn about the building blocks of geometry, namely points, line segments, lines, and rays, and use them as a basis for a deeper investigation into angles. Through a series of hands-on activities, they gain an understanding of the relative sizes of acute, right, obtuse, and straight angles and how they relate to a full circle. They make connections to fractions of a circle, hours on a clock, and the compass rose. Students learn to measure and draw angles using a protractor. They then apply those skills and relate to their studies of archaeoastronomy in Science with an analysis of a Mississippian woodhenge circular structure at the Cahokia site in Illinois.

title: Degrees of a Circle
description: Students take a quiz to demonstrate their understanding of the relationships among angles, degrees in a full circle, and the compass rose. They apply their knowledge by creating a technical drawing of one of the woodhenge circles at the Cahokia historical site.

title: Organizing Space with Perpendicular and Parallel Lines
description: Students investigate perpendicular and parallel lines and explore how those types of line segments relate to the other attributes of various quadrilaterals. Students connect this learning to their studies of Neolithic settlements by exploring how parallel and perpendicular lines may have applied to the organization of crop fields, animal enclosures, and architectural structures at Jericho, Göbekli Tepe, Catal Huyuk, and Cahokia.

title: Bountiful Harvests
description: Students connect to their study of staff-of-life crops in Cultural History with the classic exponential growth problem of one grain of rice that is doubled each day. They practice their multiplication skills and gain a rudimentary understanding of exponentiation by completing the pattern established in the story One Grain of Rice by Demi. As an extension, students express several ratios associated with different varieties of dry rice, water, and cooked rice from around the world.

title: Space for Settlement
description: This assessment integrates with the Human Settlement Project in Cultural History and requires students to combine what they have learned about spatial measurement and organization in this unit with their comparative study of population sizes in the previous unit. By integrating this knowledge with research about a particular Neolithic settlement, students prepare a fact sheet about the site layout and dimensions, which can then be used to help them fulfill their various project requirements, including a site blueprint.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: As students build their knowledge and understanding of concepts throughout this unit, they document those understandings, observations, and reflections through writing and drawing in their Mathematics journals.

title: Surveying Native American Tribes and Nations
description: Students conduct a survey on their knowledge of Native American tribes and nations. They then collect and compile data as a class for analysis. A map of Native American tribes and nations is studied and students discuss how many tribes and nations existed.

title: Building Iroquoian Longhouses with Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: In this learning experience, students study Iroquois longhouses in terms of dimensions, structural characteristics, and cultural significance. Students apply the concept of adding and subtracting fractions and mixed numbers with like denominators in considering how longhouses were constructed and then extended to accommodate growing families.

title: Renaming and Comparing Unlike Fractions
description: Students extend their fraction skills and conceptual understandings by exploring how to compare fractions with unlike denominators. They use models to learn how to find a common denominator in order to rename fractions and apply those concepts to their studies in Science on farming and domestication.

title: Culture and Coins
description: In this learning experience, students examine currency from around the world and discuss common and unique characteristics of denominations and coinage. Students then review understandings of decimal money amounts by playing a game.

title: Decimal Tenths and Hundredths
description: Students extend their understanding of decimal place value and money from the previous learning experience (MA_G4_U3_06_LE) to money amounts up to $100.00. Students connect understandings of equivalent fractions to explain decimal place values and to read and write decimal numbers. Then students refer back to the wampum they created (MA_G4_U3_05_IP) and describe wampum values in terms of decimals or fractions.

title: Surveys and Random Sampling
description: In this learning experience, students analyze survey questions and real-world survey results, reflecting on sample populations and how questions are written to determine opinions of those surveyed. Students then work collaboratively to create a survey to answer a question or to test a theory related to opinions on personal values or the value of resources. Students conduct the survey and display survey results using a table and a graph.

title: Multiplying Fractions and Making Predictions
description: In the previous learning experience, students wrote fractions to represent each group of participants that selected an answer option to a survey question (MA_G4_U3_08_LE). In this learning experience, students extrapolate their survey results for each possible answer by multiplying the fraction of their sample group by the number of people in the larger population group to predict the number of people who might report a certain opinion. Students then reflect on the accuracy of their survey results.

title: Marketplace Bartering
description: This learning experience integrates with the Mississippian Marketplace in Cultural History. Students discuss tactics for bartering and estimate the worth of available and sought-after resources in terms of the clay wampum they have created. Students record the details of trades during the simulated marketplace activity.

title: Taking Stock of Trades
description: Students wrap up the unit by creating a display showing trades made during the Mississippian Marketplace simulation (CH_G4_U3_12_LE), evaluating these trades, and assessing their success using wampum as currency. Students summarize their bartering experience in a written reflection.

title: Symmetry and Order in Olmec Cities
description: Through a study of Olmec archaeoastronomy and city designs, students learn how mathematics can be applied to mapping directions and spatial relationships. As part of their investigations, students learn several geometric constructions. The activities in this two-part learning experience facilitate the consideration of the codevelopment of mathematics, science, technology, and culture in Mesoamerica, which integrates with students’ concurrent studies of the Olmec in both Science and Cultural History.

title: Comparing, Rounding, and Estimating Whole Numbers
description: Students review the concept of place value and use it to practice rounding, ordering, and estimating with whole numbers. As part of this review, they discuss the historical origins of zero and its importance as a placeholder.

title: Exponents and Roots
description: Students explore exponents and roots with geometric models and determine how they relate to each other. For example, they use perfect-square area diagrams to investigate the relationship between perfect squares and square roots. In addition, students use number lines as a visual aid to estimate the square root of nonperfect squares.

title: Mental Mathematics and Properties of Operations
