description: Students learn how to simplify mathematical expressions mentally with the aid of the commutative, associative, and distributive properties.

title: Order of Operations
description: Students review the meaning of the acronym PEMDAS and apply it to simplifying numerical expressions. As part of this learning experience, they are challenged to write their own expressions involving order of operation rules.

title: Positive and Negative Numbers
description: Students investigate what it means for a number to be negative or positive and apply the concept to real-world scenarios. They also discuss the meaning of absolute value to understand that a number and its opposite are located the same distance from zero on a number line.

title: Understanding Decimals and Place Value
description: Students review decimal place values, and practice reading, writing, comparing, rounding, and ordering decimals. Place-value charts, grid models, and coins are used to reinforce concepts, including the role of zero as a critical placeholder.

title: Adding and Subtracting Decimals
description: Students investigate the importance of place-value alignment when adding and subtracting decimal numbers. They apply that understanding to a real-world budgeting and shopping scenario.

title: Multiplying Decimals
description: Students use area models to explore decimal multiplication. They compare the product of that operation to multiplying with fractions to reinforce equivalency relationships. Students apply decimal multiplication to the process of estimating the square roots of nonperfect squares, refining the method they learned earlier in the unit.

title: Dividing Decimals
description: Students investigate decimal division by building on their understanding of decimal multiplication and analyzing patterns with powers of ten. They learn how to divide decimals with the standard algorithm and use that knowledge to solve real-world problems. Students apply decimal division to an ancient Babylonian method for estimating the square roots of nonperfect squares, called divide-and-average.

title: Test: Rational Number Concepts
description: This test assesses students’ understanding of the rational number concepts studied thus far in the unit. Students solve contextual and noncontextual problems involving rounding, comparing, exponents, the order of operations, properties of operations (commutative, associative, and distributive), and decimal operations.

title: Estimating, Comparing, and Ordering Fractions
description: Students compare and order fractions with unlike denominators using a variety of methods—estimating, identifying relative positions on number lines, and writing equivalent fractions with a common denominator.

title: Converting Between Decimals and Fractions
description: Students learn various methods for converting between decimals and fractions and test their skills in a matching game.

title: Converting Between Decimals and Mixed Numbers
description: Students investigate how to convert between decimals and mixed numbers, especially in the context of monetary amounts, in both modern and ancient Greek coin denominations. Students also begin to compare various forms of rational numbers.

title: Equivalent Fractions, Ratios, and Proportions
description: Students further investigate equivalent fractions and ratios and use those concepts to find the missing number in a given proportion. They discover, through their explorations, that there are an infinite number of equivalent fractions for any one fraction.

title: Phoenician Travel and Trading Excursion
description: This learning experience is divided into two parts. Part I is carried out in close coordination with the Cultural History class and focuses on how ratios and proportions can be applied to scale maps and on a study of Phoenician sea travel. Part II builds both students’ map-reading skills and proportional thinking through a study of Carthaginian explorations and trade.

title: Test: Fractions, Decimals, and Proportions
description: This test assesses students’ understanding of the relationship between fractions and decimals, the relative sizes of fractions, equivalent fractions, and proportions.

title: Divisibility Rules and Factors
description: Students investigate how to identify factors and use this to simplify fractions with large numerators and denominators. One strategy that students investigate is to think of the factors of a number as the dimensions of a rectangle whose area is that number.

title: Factors and Prime Factorization
description: Students learn about prime factorization and practice expressing composite numbers greater than 1 as a product of prime factors. With the aid of factor trees, students learn to show the prime factorization of a number using exponential notation.

title: Greatest Common Factor
description: Students investigate a variety of ways to determine the greatest common factor of two or three numbers. Students explore the use of the following three methods: listing factors, using prime factorizations, and using a ladder diagram.

title: Least Common Multiple
description: Students learn a variety of ways to determine the least common multiple (LCM) of two or three numbers. Students explore the use of the following three methods: using a number line, listing multiples of both numbers, and using the prime factorizations of both numbers.

title: Fraction Concepts and Number Theory Test
description: Students demonstrate their ability to identify factors and the greatest common factor, multiples and the least common multiple, prime and composite numbers, and equivalent fractions, and they convert between an improper fraction and a mixed number.

title: Adding and Subtracting Fractions with Like and Unlike Denominators
description: Students apply what they have learned about fractions to the addition and subtraction of fractions with like and unlike denominators. Students explore those operations using number lines and fraction bars, and also use the concepts of least common multiple and least common denominator.

title: Adding and Subtracting Fractions with Regrouping
description: Students learn how to add and subtract fractions with regrouping and apply this to a set of practice problems. They model problems with manipulatives (such as fraction bars) and write out each step to help clarify the concept of regrouping for subtraction.

title: Multiplying Fractions and Whole Numbers
description: Students practice multiplying fractions and whole numbers through a series of problem sets. They then model a school fundraiser situation, in which they apply their fraction multiplication skills to a real-world, multistep problem.

title: Multiplying Fractions
description: Students use manipulatives and area models to practice multiplying fractions. Through those investigations, students discover that fully reducing fractions before multiplying makes calculations easier and often eliminates the need to simplify the product.

title: Multiplying Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students investigate and practice multiplying fractions and mixed numbers using a real-world scenario.

title: Dividing Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students explore the “Keep-Change-Change” and “Big C Over Little C” methods for dividing fractions, mixed numbers, and improper fractions, and then compare the two methods.

title: Student How-To Guide
description: Students make a “How-To Guide” that demonstrates their understanding of the major concepts studied in this first unit. Their guides demonstrate both conceptual development and problem-solving skills through the inclusion of examples, descriptions, and diagrams. At the conclusion of the unit, students also compose a “Dear Reader” letter as a means of passing on wisdom to next year’s incoming sixth graders.

title: Exponents, Powers of 10, and Scientific Notation
description: Students learn how to convert numbers written in scientific notation to very large standard-form numbers. As part of this study, they review the concept that positive exponents represent repeated multiplication. They investigate patterns to interpret the effect of powers of 10 on decimal numbers in the context of scientific notation.

title: Quiz: Concept Review
description: Students review concepts and skills that will be applied to topics in this unit. They revisit all operations with mixed numbers and decimals, some in the context of geometric figures. They set up and solve a proportion. They simplify expressions with exponents and square roots using the correct order of operations. They review degrees in a circle. Students also assess their conceptual understanding of percent in preparation for the next learning experience.

title: Percentages, Percent Discount, and Sale Price
description: Students explore the meaning of the word percent and express the relationships among equivalent percents, decimals, and fractions. Students investigate a real-world scenario to learn about percent discount and sale price and uncover a mistaken assumption about consecutive discounts.

title: Project: Surveys and Circle Graphs
description: Students design and conduct their own survey and display the results in a circle graph. They collect and analyze empirical data and apply their understanding of ratios and percents to construct their circle graphs. During the process, they learn about the concept of sampling and what it means to extrapolate conclusions from a sample. They create circle graphs both by hand and using technology.

title: Quiz: Factors, Multiples, and Fractions Review
description: Students revisit concepts such as multiples, factors, divisibility rules, and equivalent fractions. They also perform operations with fractions and mixed numbers.

title: Pythagoras and the Pythagorean Theorem
description: Students begin their investigation of Greek mathematics with Pythagoras of Samos. They learn about his followers, the Pythagoreans, and their belief in number symbolism. Students investigate the properties of figurative numbers (square, oblong, and triangular). Next, they learn the Pythagorean theorem. They review the parts of a right triangle and prove the theorem by creating squares from the sides of a right triangle. They then use the theorem to find the length of a triangle’s hypotenuse, given the lengths of its legs. In doing so, they launch into an introductory discussion of the nature of irrational numbers, with a focus on  [begin mathsize 10px style square root of 2 end style] . They will revisit irrational numbers in upcoming learning experiences.

title: Test: Pythagorean Theorem
description: Students demonstrate their ability to apply the Pythagorean theorem to find the missing hypotenuse of right triangles. Some of the problems are set in real-world contexts. Students also show and explain why the theorem holds for any right triangle.

title: The Fibonacci Sequence and the Golden Ratio
description: Students simulate the original rabbit question posed by Leonardo Fibonacci to generate the first several numbers in the Fibonacci sequence. They then identify and apply the pattern rule to generate the first 20 numbers in the sequence. After some other explorations with the famous sequence, students use their calculators or a spreadsheet program to derive the golden ratio by comparing successive terms in the sequence.

title: Natural Expressions of Phi
description: Students continue their explorations with the Fibonacci numbers by investigating their appearance in nature. In doing so, students begin to understand and appreciate the cultural significance of the golden ratio and its aesthetic appeal. They then relate the golden ratio to geometry through concepts of proportionality and similar figures. They use a compass and straightedge to construct golden rectangles and spirals of their own.

title: The Vesica Piscis and Venn Diagrams
description: Students discuss the historical background of the Vesica Piscis, the ancient figure the Pythagoreans used as a sacred symbol of the number two, and the elements of nature the dyad represents. Students review the parts of a circle and then use only a compass and straightedge to construct the Vesica Piscis. Students create a variety of inscribed figures in the Vesica Piscis. In doing so, they explore how the application of formal definitions and geometric relationships can lead to new understandings. Students also use Venn diagrams, a form of the Vesica Piscis, to sort and analyze sets of information. This learning experience concludes their focused study of Greek mathematics in the unit.

title: Quiz: Percent and Geometry
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of concepts associated with percent, the Pythagorean theorem, Fibonacci numbers, the golden ratio, and Euclidean constructions.

title: Pi and Circle Measurements
description: Students continue their explorations of ratio as they spend a full week discovering the meaning of pi (the ratio of the circumference to the diameter of any circle), historical methods for approximating pi (), and how to use pi to determine the circumference and area of circles.

title: Customary and Metric Units of Measurement
description: Students learn standard units of measure for length, mass, and liquid capacity and the relationships among them. They develop strategies for converting between different units within each system based on their understanding of ratios and proportions.

title: Test: Circles and Measurement
description: Students recall the meaning and value of pi. They determine the radius and diameter of various circles and use those measures to calculate the circumference and area. They apply their understanding of circle measures to real-world problems, including the representation of survey data in a circle graph. Students also demonstrate their understanding of the relative sizes of units of measure in the customary and metric systems and their ability to convert within a system.

title: Student How-to Guide
description: Students continue to make a How-to Guide that demonstrates their understanding of the major concepts studied in this unit. Their guides show both conceptual development and problem-solving skills through the inclusion of examples, descriptions, and diagrams. At the conclusion of the unit, students compose a “Dear Reader” letter as a means of passing on wisdom to next year’s incoming sixth graders.

title: Chinese Magic Squares
description: This learning experience integrates with students’ investigation of ancient Chinese culture in Cultural History and Science. Students determine how it is possible to arrange the digits 1–9 in a 3 × 3 square matrix formation to create a magic square, in which the sum of all rows, columns, and diagonals is the same. Students are introduced to the historical significance of these numbers and their arrangements in ancient China and other civilizations.

title: Angles, Triangles, and Angle Sums
description: Students review how to approximate and measure angles, classify triangles by their angles and their sides, and investigate the Triangle Sum Theorem. Students work in pairs to prove the Triangle Sum Theorem through a hands-on investigation, and they use the theorem to find missing angles measures.

title: Area and Perimeter of Polygons
description: Students previously explored the relationships between right triangles, squares, rectangles, and their areas to deduce rules and formulas. They now apply the same concepts to develop strategies for finding the perimeter and area of any polygon, including irregular and composite shapes.

title: Quiz: Polygons and Circles
description: Students’ ability to classify triangles and calculate area and perimeter of regular and irregular polygons is assessed through a series of short-answer questions. The quiz also includes review questions on circles and circle measures.

title: Three-Dimensional Figures: Platonic and Archimedean Solids
description: Students now investigate the nets and properties of solids, focusing on the two-dimensional shapes that make up their faces. Students then investigate the properties of Platonic and Archimedean solids. They identify how those solids are formed from the two-dimensional polygons with which they are already familiar. Students are also encouraged to reflect on the qualitative and symbolic characteristics of those solids, based both on their own personal response to each shape and their prior knowledge of ancient and classical Greek mathematics and science.

title: Bar Graph Project
description: Students began their investigation of statistics and data displays in the previous unit by focusing on survey methods and circle graphs. Now, students investigate other types of graphs—particularly bar graphs—and reinforce their knowledge of surveys and sampling methods by conducting a second survey. For this project, students draw upon their past survey experience and craft a hypothesis about their possible results before conducting the survey.

title: Using Proportions
description: Students use a variety of strategies to solve proportions with a variable for the missing value, including reasoning with equivalent fractions and the cross-multiplication method. Students then apply proportions in order to solve for missing side lengths in similar figures, and they convert units of measure.

title: Introduction to Probability
description: Students spend three weeks investigating theoretical and experimental probability. They will reinforce their prior knowledge of fractions, decimals, and percentages in order to write and calculate probabilities. Students then experiment with dice, cards, marbles, and coins to calculate experimental probability and compare their findings to the theoretical predictions.

title: Test: Geometry, Data Displays, and Probability
description: This test assesses student understanding of the following concepts: area, perimeter, nets of a cube, angle sum in triangles, triangle classification, conversions within customary and metric units of measure, proportions, probability, survey data, and line graphs. Several cumulative review questions are also included.

title: Cumulative Concept Review
description: Students review all course concepts in preparation for their cumulative final test. They begin by reviewing their How-to Guides for mathematics topics. Students then work in collaborative learning groups to review their quizzes, tests, and projects. Review problem sets and worksheets are provided for students to practice for the final test.

title: Test: Cumulative Final
description: Students are assessed on their understanding of all concepts studied throughout the year. The test includes short-answer, fill-in-the-blank, and extended-response questions. Students are required to show all work and justify responses where appropriate.

title: Place Values in Base 20
description: Students learn how to write numbers using bases other than 10, particularly base 5 and base 20, in preparation for writing numbers in the Maya base 20 system. Students use coins to convert numbers into base 5 from base 10, and are then challenged to apply the understanding gained to creating a base 20 conversion chart.

title: Maya Numbers 0–399
description: Students learn about the classical Maya number system, using symbols to represent numbers and base 5, 10, and 20. They learn symbols for 1 (dot), 5 (bar), and 0 (shell), and discuss the probable origins of these symbols. Students examine how amounts are represented using just these symbols, vertical place-value positions, base 5 (for amounts less than 20), and base 20.

title: Maya Numbers 400–8,000+ and the Dresden Codex
description: Students learn that the Maya used a modified base 20 system—with 360s instead of 400s for the third place value—to record dates. Students examine images of the Dresden Codex, which displays astronomy tables with predicted dates for events such as eclipses, as well as tables of multiples of numbers that are integral to the Maya calendar. This activity integrates with studies of the Venus cycle in Science.

title: Quiz: Maya Numbers
description: Students are assessed on their ability to read Maya numbers using the first three places of the base 20 place-value chart, and also on their ability to write Maya numerals.

title: Adding and Subtracting Maya Numbers
description: Students work independently to add and subtract Maya numbers less than 20 and build up to larger numbers with carrying and borrowing. With practice, they develop their own strategies for operations and share these through a group discussion comparing operations with Maya numerals to those with Hindu-Arabic numerals.

title: The Tzolkin and Haab Calendars
description: Students conduct a “web quest” on the purpose and characteristics of Maya sacred and civil calendars. They then investigate how the calendars were connected mathematically, while relating this study to their earlier investigation of the Dresden Codex. Students discuss their initial findings as a class, recalling the meaning of greatest common factors (GCF) and least common multiples (LCM) and applying this understanding to determine the role that factors/multiples play in connecting the two calendars.

title: Quiz: Greater Maya Numbers
description: This quiz assesses students’ ability to write Maya numbers greater than 1000 (using the third and fourth base 20 place values), add and subtract Maya numbers, and find the LCM and GCF of numbers.

title: The Venus Round and Long Count Calendar
description: Students discuss the Venus Round and the correlation between the Tzolkin, Haab, and Venus cycles. To reinforce the mathematical achievements of the classical Maya—as well as the necessity of a well-designed number system—students are introduced to another Maya calendar: the Long Count. Students discuss how the classical Maya calendars reflect their knowledge of mathematics and astronomy, as well as their cultural and religious beliefs. This learning experience integrates with their studies in Science.

title: Test: Maya Mathematics
description: The Maya Mathematics test assesses students’ ability to translate and write Maya numerals through the fourth place value, add and subtract Maya numbers, and find the LCM and GCF of numbers.

title: Operations with Rational Numbers
description: Students recall adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing fractions, mixed numbers, and decimals. As a class they discuss the historical context for rational numbers, in that during the time period of study, fractions were used but not decimals, and they are encouraged to draw on their prior knowledge of the development of number systems and mathematics, building on their investigations of Maya mathematics from the previous unit.

title: Exponents and Square Roots
description:
Students review terms such as base, raised to a power, squared, cubed, and perfect square as they discuss powers and roots. Students are guided to define a means of using decimals to obtain a more precise approximation of square roots, such as a decimal number to the tenths or hundredths place. 

As part of their studies, students review procedures to determine the prime factorization of a given number, and they are also challenged to write it in exponential form.

title: Laws of Exponents
description: Students investigate to understand each law by rewriting exponents as repeated multiplication sequences, applying the associative and commutative properties, identifying patterns, and relating the result back to the original expression.

title: Negative Exponents
description: Students learn the meaning of negative (integer) exponents by investigating decreasing powers of 10 and discussing the role of repeated multiplication and division.

title: Scientific Notation and Metric Conversions
description: Students learn how to convert large and small quantities into expressions using scientific notation. They apply their knowledge of positive and negative exponents to converting metric units of measure.

title: Quiz: Operations and Measurement
description: Students use the skills that they have acquired to solve a variety of problems involving decimals, fractions, square roots, exponents, prime factorization, scientific notation, and metric unit conversion.

title: Algebraic Expressions and Variables
description: Students learn that a variable is an unknown number and that expressions are made up of variables, numbers, and symbols. They discuss the difference between expressions and equations and evaluate expressions by substituting a given value for the variable.

title: Solving One-Step Equations
description: Students discover how to solve basic one-step equations using a flowchart and backtracking, and are required to check their solutions in the original equation.

title: Solving Two-Step Equations
description: Students determine the importance of adding or subtracting to combine like terms and then multiplying or dividing to isolate the variable to solve two-step equations.

title: Quiz: Introduction to Algebra
description: Students’ ability to evaluate algebraic expressions by substituting for the variables as well as solving simple one-and two-step equations is assessed through a series of short answer questions.

title: Real Numbers and Adding and Subtracting Integers
description: Students are formally introduced to the categories of real numbers: natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, and irrational numbers (nonterminating and nonrepeating decimals). They learn the rules for adding and subtracting integers.

title: Multiplying and Dividing Integers
description: Students learn rules for the sign of the product and quotient of integers based on whether the factors, dividend, and divisor are positive or negative.

title: Test: Integers
description: Students’ ability to solve word problems and real-world application problems with integers is assessed. Students demonstrate their knowledge of all operations with integers, as well as the order of operations, exponents, square roots, and scientific notation.

title: Solving Equations with Integers
description: Students solve one- and two-step equations containing positive and negative integers, with inverse operations. They practice using the sign rules with the backtracking method for isolating the variable in an equation.

title: Combining Like Terms and Solving Multistep Equations
description: Students begin by using algebra tiles to combine like terms and simplify variable expressions. As students work with the algebra tiles, they are challenged to make connections and comparisons to their studies of one-to-one correspondence systems, the use of tokens before writing, and the various forms of numbers used in ancient times. Students then learn how to solve equations with variables on both sides of the equal sign.

title: Solving Multistep Equations and Inequalities
description: Students graph simple and compound inequalities on number lines, translate verbal statements into inequalities, solve inequalities algebraically, and graph solution sets.

title: Ordered Pairs
description: Students learn about the x- and y-axes, and the x- and y-coordinates that make up an ordered pair. They locate the origin, plot points using their ordered pairs, and identify ordered pairs for plotted points. Students make connections between the geometric and algebraic representation of simple linear equations. They research and explain how the coordinate system was invented by René Descartes during the seventeenth century. A worksheet assesses students’ ability to evaluate expressions, solve equations and inequalities, and identify ordered pairs that satisfy a given equation.

title: Test: Solving and Graphing Equations
description: This test assesses students’ understanding of all concepts covered in this unit of study. Students solve an equation with variables on both sides and build algebraic expressions to find the perimeter of geometric shapes.

title: Surveys, Populations, and Sampling
description: Students examine a variety of survey scenarios and define and discuss the differences between populations, samples, and sampling methods (random, systematic, or stratified) for each. They are introduced to the concept of bias and challenged to identify possible bias in the given scenarios.

title: Survey Project: Designing and Conducting a Survey
description: Students are introduced to the parameters of the project, generate ideas for surveys, and set personal goals for the project. The Survey Project challenges students to design their own survey, survey 50 students, and then create the appropriate graph to display their results.

title: Organizing and Analyzing Data
description: Using sample data, students learn to use tables to organize information and are introduced to stem-and-leaf plots and back-to-back stem-and-leaf plots. Students then work individually or in small groups to practice creating and interpreting stem-and-leaf plots.

title: Quizzes: Data Representation
description: This series of 3 quizzes challenges students to construct stem-and-leaf plots; measure central tendency; and identify the population, sample, and bias for surveys.

title: Displaying Data
description: Students review bar graphs, histograms, and lines graphs, noting their effectiveness for displaying data. They then examine a third type of plot—the scatter plot.

title: Survey Project: Displaying Survey Data
description: Students draw on their prior knowledge of circles, measuring and drawing central angles of circles, and percent to create circle graphs by hand to represent their findings from their surveys of 50 students.

title: Test: Data Representations
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of comparing sampling methods; measuring central tendencies; constructing stem-and-leaf plots, box-and-whisker plots, and histograms; and constructing frequency tables. They also answer questions about bar and line graphs and create a circle graph to represent a given data set.

title: Number Patterns and Linear Relationships
description: Students practice identifying rules for geometric and numerical patterns and write the rules symbolically (algebraically) as equations. Students are then challenged to relate rules for patterns to linear equations and their graphs.

title: Slope and Graphs of Linear Equations
description: Students review the characteristics of the Cartesian coordinate system. They plot points and discuss the x- and y-axes and quadrants. They relate points on the plane to x- andy-coordinates as ordered pairs. Students are challenged to look for the connections between the algebraic and graphic representations of linear relationships.

title: Proportionality and Nonlinear Relationships
description: Students investigate direct variation and indirect (inverse) variation using the same online graphing utilities provided in the previous learning experience.

title: Angles and Angle Relationships
description: As a class, students discuss definitions of the following figures: lines, segments, rays, and angles; acute, right, obtuse, straight, and reflex angles; and angle bisectors and perpendicular lines. They use a ruler, protractor, and compass to construct angles and diagrams.

title: Quiz: Geometric Constructions
description: Students’ basic construction skills using a protractor, ruler, and compass are assessed. They draw circles, angles, bisections of line segments and angles given specific parameters and answer questions about geometric relationships.

title: Angle Relationships and Transversals
description: Students review angle relationships and are introduced to transversals. They identify the types of angles formed when a transversal crosses parallel lines and their inherent properties and relationships.

title: Quiz: Angle Relationships
description: Students are challenged to define geometric terms and relationships through written explanations and diagrams.

title: Triangles and the Pythagorean Theorem
description: Students investigate how properties of triangles, angle relationships, and side relationships can be used with the Triangle Sum Theorem and the Pythagorean Theorem to identify missing angle measures and missing leg or hypotenuse measures in triangles and other geometric diagrams.

title: Quiz: Geometric Constructions 2
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the properties of triangles and perform constructions based on previous learning experiences.

title: Quadrilaterals and Other Polygons
description: As a class, students discuss and review the basic types of quadrilaterals—squares, rectangles, rhombuses, parallelograms, and trapezoids—and compare the properties of their angles and sides.

title: Vesica Piscis and Geometric Proofs
description: Students investigate the Vesica Piscis, an ancient and symbolic fish-bladder figure formed by two circles that overlap and share the same radius such that the center of each circle lies on the circumference of the other circle. They use this figure as a basis for reviewing and constructing various geometric figures and their properties, and for writing geometric proofs.

title: Quiz: Advanced Geometric Constructions
description: Students demonstrate advanced construction skills to draw a rhombus and to show congruence, similarity, transversals, and angle relationships. This quiz serves as a final check for understanding before the summative assessment.

title: Test: Angle Relationships and Polygons
description: Students’ knowledge of key vocabulary words relating to angle relationships and polygons and their ability to identify figures using the correct naming conventions are assessed. Students also determine angle measures when two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, find missing interior and exterior angles in triangles, calculate the sum of the measures of the interior angles of polygons, and classify quadrilaterals by all the possible names that apply.

title: Area and Perimeter of Irregular Polygons
description: Students review methods for finding the perimeter and area of triangles and quadrilaterals as they apply this understanding to irregular polygons. In finding the perimeter and area of these composite figures, they also make use of the Pythagorean Theorem, methods for solving equations, and the double distributive property.

title: Surface Area and Volume of Solids
description: Students investigate how to find the surface area and volume of three-dimensional objects: polyhedra, cylinders, and cones. With the aid of nets, they connect to the previous learning experience by extending their understanding of area of two-dimensional figures to surface area and volume of three-dimensional figures.

title: Transformations
description: Students investigate symmetry, reflections, dilations, translations, and rotations of figures in the coordinate plane. They identify addition, subtraction, opposite signs, and scale factors as they relate to each transformation and learn how to use algebraic notation to represent the changes to the figures in the coordinate plane.

title: Test: Geometry
description: This assessment addresses topics from both this unit and the previous unit. Students demonstrate their understanding of angle sums, writing algebraic equations and solving for the indicated variable, calculating surface area and volume, and analyzing transformations of figures in the coordinate plane.

title: Ratios, Unit Rates, and Proportions
description: Students discuss ratios, rates, and proportions, and practice using cross multiplication and other proportional thinking strategies to solve for missing values in proportions. Students apply proportional reasoning to investigations with similar figures, scale drawings and models, and the relationships between the surface areas and volumes of scaled three-dimensional figures. Later in the unit, students extend this learning to scaled maps in the Rome Project, where they apply their knowledge of ratios and proportions and their study of Vitruvius and perspective to create an enlarged map of Rome as well as a scaled model of the Pantheon.

title: Quizzes: Ratios, Unit Rates, and Proportions
description: Students convert units of measure, find the missing side lengths in similar figures, and apply proportions to solve word problems. They also solve problems involving equivalent fractions, proportions, and unit rates.

title: Test: Ratios and Proportions
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of ratios and unit rates, proportions, units of measure, and scale factors. They apply these concepts to a variety of real-world problems, such as determining the height of a tree based on the length of its shadow and translating distances on a map to actual distances.

title: Roman Numerals
description: As part of an integrated study of Ancient Rome, students investigate Roman numerals. Expanding on their study of Roman numerals in Cultural History, students perform operations with Roman numerals and consider why the Hindu-Arabic number system is more prevalent in modern times.

title: Rome Project
description: Students apply their knowledge of ratios and proportions, three-dimensional figures, dilations, and scale drawings to this two-week project, which is integrated with the study of Vitruvius and perspective in Visual Arts and Cultural History. They draw an enlarged map of Rome, where they later place perspective drawings of key buildings from the Roman Empire. Students also research the dimensions and features of the Pantheon in Rome in order to build a scaled model.

title: Percent and Percent Applications
description: Students review equivalent decimals, fractions, and percent. They establish percent equations and percent proportions and use them to solve a variety of application problems, from simple to more complex. They discuss how estimation can help them make sense of percent problems.

title: Probability Review
description: Students review the use of fractions, decimals, and percent to describe probability. Students define an event, determine its theoretical probability, and then design and conduct a simulation to calculate experimental probability. Students investigate how theoretical and experimental probability compare for a given event, especially as the number of trials increases.

title: Final Course Review
description: In preparation for the cumulative final for this course, students work through a review of all concepts and skills taught in the course, including numeric, algebraic, geometric, and statistical topics.

title: Test: Course Final
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts and skills studied in this course. They perform operations with rational numbers and use proportional reasoning to solve application problems, including percent change, unit conversion, and scaled figures. They apply algebraic concepts to simplify expressions and solve equations. Students also apply geometric concepts and formulas to two- and three-dimensional figures, including area, volume, angle relationships, and transformations. They demonstrate understanding of how to calculate measures of center and create statistical displays.

title: Exploring Using the Five Senses
description: Throughout this unit, students practice walking meditation and exploring nature using all five senses. Their outdoor observations support all the learning experiences in this unit, as well as all the in-class activities.

title: Images from Light and Darkness
description: As students observe variations of light in nature, they explore light through activities, including making Sun prints, playing with shadows, and manipulating light with reflective surfaces and gels.

title: The Magic Forest
description: In the Magic Forest, students impersonate animals, plants, or rocks as they practice camouflage, mindful walking meditation, stillness, and stealth. They create dances and engage in activities that imitate the movements they observe in nature.

title: Symbols
description: Students study different symbols, from letters and numbers to pictographic symbols, movements, and gestures. By learning symbols, students enhance their early literacy skills and learn to find meaning in pictures as a form of text.

title: The Story Game
description: Together the class makes up Magic Forest stories and explores different communal approaches to writing stories.

title: What Is Media?
description: Students focus on representational practices and consider various forms of media in their lives in terms of technologies and human practice. Students master basic concepts and the vocabulary of media literacy.

title: Digital Footprint
description: Students consider how they represent themselves online. They are introduced to basic digital media literacy and online safety.

title: Introduction to the Moving Image
description: Students create short storyboards that tell a sequential story about themselves and their place in the world.

title: Video Production
description: Students learn basic video shooting and editing techniques and create videos based on their storyboards in the previous learning experience.

title: The Media Cave
description: Students create a video installation by constructing a large tunnel using recycled materials in their classroom and projecting their previously created videos onto the walls of the cave.

title: What Is Media?
description: To begin their investigation of media, students analyze and interpret moving images and develop the language to describe certain techniques used in moving image and cinematic storytelling.

title: Children’s Television Programming from Around the World
description: Students explore and study various popular television shows for children from different cultural contexts.

title: Creation Stories and Connections to Place
description: After studying several creation stories, students use drawing-based animation strategies to produce flipbooks that engage the creation stories and bring a portion of a story to life using visual storytelling techniques discussed in the first learning experience of this unit.

title: Storyboarding Goddesses
description: Based on female-centered scenes from creation stories and/or their Cultural History class, students develop scripts and storyboards that form the basis of short, live-action, dramatic videos.

title: Venus Videos
description: Students create short, live-action dramatic videos using their scripts and storyboards from the Storyboarding Goddesses learning experience.

title: What Is Media?
description: As an introduction to the media they will encounter in subsequent learning experiences, students play Telephone, examine a local map, and develop a code of laws governing classroom behavior.

title: Making Meaning
description: Students explore four levels of meaning and the interpretation of ordinary objects and stories.

title: Pictograms, Comics, and Animation
description: Based on research done in Cultural History class about pictograms and symbolic forms, students create comics and simple animation. They learn about two-dimensional representation and the pairing of image and text.

title: Architecture as Media
description: Students expand their concept of media to include spaces, focusing specifically on monumental architecture.

title: Tablet, Architecture, Interface
description: Students are prompted to look at contemporary interfaces and to draw parallels with early writing systems and architectural design, noticing how spaces are scripted to guide behavior. They are challenged to design a simple interface themselves.

title: Demonization of “the Other”
description: Students are introduced to concepts like “the other” and stereotypes and how they are depicted in media.

title: Creating Meaning
description: Students demonstrate their grasp of the different levels of meaning by producing an original narrative in their chosen medium and then write an interpretation of the fourth level of symptomatic meaning within their story.

title: What Is Media?
description: Students critically review the media in their lives and the period they are studying and consider the importance of circulation, audience and how changing media technologies influence how we learn about history and each other.

title: Rhetoric
description: Students learn the basic concepts of rhetoric as an essential language art by studying strategies of persuasion in a wide variety of texts, exploring bias and objectivity, and producing their own persuasive texts.

title: Universality and the Making of the Monomyth
description: Students examine Joseph Campbell’s theory of a universal structure of myth and identify this structure in myths from Cultural History class and today. They study counter theories and critiques of Campbell’s work and apply these to crafting alternative plot lines of the movie Avatar.

title: App Building Workshops
description: Students are introduced to the basics of HTML5 and JavaScript code and create their own apps.

title: Mobile Myths: The Hero Project
description: Students create an app based on their own mythological stories, demonstrating their critical awareness of biases found in “universal” myths.

title: Money as Media
description: Students research the imagery, texts, and iconography on the money of their home country, compare it with the money of ancient Rome, and design some money for their class.

title: The Silk Road: Travel and Trade as Media
description: After studying how the Silk Road fueled the mixing of cultures, students play a card-exchange game.

title: The Aeneid, Founding Epics, and the United States
description: Students explore the role of narrative in shaping national identities, study Virgil’s Aeneid and its role as Rome’s founding epic, and identify epic narratives that inform the identity of the United States, the Islamic State, and other nations or communities.

title: Website Design and Programming
description: Students learn how to design and construct interactive websites.

title: What Is Media? / Ancient Media
description: To begin the unit, students explore what media meant during the period 356 BCE–800 CE, a period that saw the rise of world empires and universal religions.

title: Imagined Communities
description: After exploring the concept of imagined communities and how media facilitates them, students consider the characteristics of different imagined communities.

title: National Identity Site
description: Students apply web-design and coding skills to the creation of a website dedicated to the Roman Empire.

title: What Is Media?
description: To begin the unit, students are introduced to the concept of abstraction.

title: Medieval Space
description: Students study the medieval representation of space in art and how it relates to the way medieval people saw the world.

title: Space and Cyberspace
description: In this learning experience, students study the development of cyberspace and its characteristics, comparing the idea of cyberspace with the medieval conception of space.

title: The Role of Media in Contemporary Conflicts
description: After analyzing the role of media in the Iranian Revolution, students bring their understanding to bear on contemporary social and religious conflicts in the Middle East and West Africa.

title: Wiki Project: Medieval Art on Its Own Terms
description: Students create a wiki website that presents what they’ve learned about medieval art and thought.

title: Self-portraits
description: Students create two self-portraits. The first is a simple observational sketch. The second is a mixed-media self-portrait that incorporates positive statements about themselves.

title: Egg Baby Nests
description: While studying clan dynamics in Cultural History, students create nests for raw eggs that represent the babies of their clans.

title: Blind Contour Line Drawing
description: In this learning experience, students arrange items they picked up in their Science studies of natural communities and draw the contour outline of that arrangement without looking at their drawings.

title: Continuous Line Contour Drawing
description: Students experience the challenge of drawing an object or an arrangement of objects in a single continuous line.

title: Contour Sculpture
description: After viewing several of Alexander Calder’s wire sculptures and discussing the relationship between these and continuous line contour drawings, students move into three-dimensional contour wire sculpting.

title: Watercolor Still Life
description: Students observe how light and shadow accentuate the dimensions of forms and then use tints and shades to represent those forms on a two-dimensional surface.

title: Goddesses for Archaeological Dig
description: Students create clay sculptures that emulate the size and style of the Venus of Willendorf. The sculptures will be buried to help simulate an archaeological dig in a Cultural History learning experience.

title: Pigment
description: Students learn how to access pigments from mineral and plant material to make paint. Then they create and compare two color wheels: a natural pigment color wheel and one made with modern colored pencils.

title: Cave Paintings
description: Students begin this learning experience by reading about early cave artists and viewing images of the Lascaux and Chauvet caves. Then they use contour drawing techniques learned earlier in this unit to emulate cave paintings on paper they have crumpled to simulate uneven cave walls. Finally, they fill in their drawings with natural pigment paints they have mixed themselves.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. They periodically review their sketchbooks with their teacher, discussing challenges, progress, likes, dislikes, and any other thoughts or observations students have had while sketching or otherwise recording what they have viewed and learned.

title: Portfolio Review
description: Students review the contents of their portfolios with their teachers to recognize what they have learned and enjoyed, how they might have improved what they created, and to set personal goals.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. They periodically review their sketchbooks with their teacher, discussing challenges, progress, likes, dislikes, and any other thoughts or observations students have had while sketching or otherwise recording what they have viewed and learned.

title: Three-Dimensional Rectangles
description: In this two-part learning experience, students explore three-dimensional shapes and design, learning relevant geometric terms. They learn how to draw three-dimensional rectangles in a multitude of sizes, first on graph paper by hand and then on a computer with the use of drawing software.

title: One-Point Perspective
description: Students examine instructional websites about how to draw one-point perspective. They research images that have one-point perspective and draw simple shapes that illustrate one-point perspective.

title: Early Architecture: Göbekli Tepe (10,000 BCE)
description: Students view images and a website about the Göbekli Tepe settlement. Using one-point perspective, they draw the Göbekli Tepe pillars in three dimensions. Students make monoprints and then create a collage using their drawn pillars and monoprints.

title: Early Architecture: Çatal Hüyük Settlement (7500 BCE)
description: Students research this Neolithic settlement, make three-dimensional and one-point perspective drawings of it, and then translate the drawings into a clay and natural material model.

title: Chi Wara Headdresses and Mud Cloth
description: Students research the headdresses and geometric mud cloth of the Chi Wara in preparation for the creation of costumes for “Beginnings,” an integrated project for Performing Arts and Cultural History.

title: Portfolio Review
description: Students’ progress is assessed by using a unit-specific rubric.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. They periodically review their sketchbooks with their teacher, discussing challenges, progress, likes, dislikes, and any other thoughts or observations students have had while sketching or otherwise recording what they have viewed and learned.

title: Exploring Clay
description: Students begin this multifaceted learning experience by exploring the properties of terracotta and earthernware clay. They write a short research paper about the history of clay and about a clay artist of his or her choosing. As they delve deeper into their research of clay artists and clay techniques, they amass a new vocabulary. Students produce four different clay artworks, displaying four clay techniques.

title: Mississippian Pottery and Clay Sculptures
description: Students focus on the stone statuary and pottery styles of the Mississippian culture. Their explorations include carving sandstone and researching museum websites for information and images of Mississippian pottery and sandstone sculptures.

title: Iroquois Pottery and Clay Sculptures
description: In this learning experience, students explore Iroquois pottery and clay pipe-making techniques, create a functional clay pipe in the Iroquois style, and compare and contrast Mississippian and Iroquois pottery.

title: Understanding Unit Goals
description: In this summative assessment, each student has a one-on-one meeting with the teacher to review the student’s portfolio, using a rubric to aid the two of them in their critique. Together they also review the student’s participation, reflections, and learning.

title: Summative Assessment Self Portrait
description: In this summative assessment, students create multi-media self-portraits using the Self-Portrait worksheet (VA_G4_U3_05_AS_A01_Worksheet).

title: Classroom Signals
description: Students become aware of the gymnasium as a learning space that is different from the playground. They review ground rules and important symbols and signals through games and movement experiences. Understanding these lessons helps students enjoy a successful and safe Wellness class.

title: Red Light, Green Light
description: In this classic children’s game, students respond to the colors red and green using different locomotor movement patterns. A discussion of color symbols in our everyday lives helps students recognize the importance of color in identifying symbolic meaning.

title: Signs of the Season
description: Just as people use signals and symbols to communicate, the natural world has signals and symbols that help us understand the outdoors. Students learn how to move safely through space using different locomotor patterns while being challenged to match flash card symbols with the appropriate seasons.

title: Seasonal Outdoor Activities
description: Students practice various locomotor and throwing skills while pairing the appropriate activity with each seasonal symbol.

title: Alphabet Pictures
description: Students use their bodies to create letter shapes to explore the alphabet as a written symbol for meaning. The teacher photographs the resulting formations to create a body posture alphabet poster.

title: How Many?
description: Students explore numbers as symbols of value by performing a specific number of exercises that correspond to a given number.

title: The Farmer and the Seed Game
description: Students practice locomotor skills while pretending to be seeds that are planted, grown, and taken to market. The teacher assesses them on their ability to demonstrate movement skills, follow directions, create signals, and cooperate with peers.

title: Songs That Move Us
description: As students explore songs and stories in the classroom, in Wellness they sing songs that help identify body parts and locomotor movements.

title: Movement Stories
description: Students use different movement patterns to create movement stories with a beginning, a middle, and an end.

title: Journey of Change: Monarch Butterfly
description: Students explore movement related to the stages of the monarch butterfly. From egg to caterpillar, to chrysalis, to adult butterfly, students change movement patterns related to each stage of development.

title: Water Ways
description: Students articulate the different ways that water exists in nature. From ocean waves to still ponds, they explore movement patterns that mimic various forms of water.

title: Exploring Change
description: Throughout the unit, students engage in learning experiences that explore the concept of change. In this learning experience, students discover the changes that take place between opposites.

title: Tai Chi
description: In this assessment, students enjoy the benefits of tai chi and explore the yin-yang symbol as it relates to changing tai chi postures. While students engage in classroom activities, the teacher observes each student and records evidence of student progress.

title: Exploring the Breath
description: Students engage in diagnostic inquiries, which informally assesses their current understanding of the properties of air and what it can do.

title: The Breath in Motion
description: After a review of respiration and finding the location of the lungs in the body, students practice a variety of yoga breathing exercises to discover the effects and benefits of learning to control their breathing. During a discussion following the activity, students share their feelings about the experience and identify applications of what they’ve discovered in real life.

title: Floating Through the Air
description: Students play with the movement of various objects such as bubbles, balloons, and kites as they run, hop, skip, and play games. They notice and describe how different materials move through the air.

title: Exploring Objects and Their Movement Through Air
description: Students play with balls of different sizes, shapes, and weights, and note how these factors affect their movement through the air.

title: Holding Air/Air Pressure/Buoyancy
description: Students discuss findings about air pressure and buoyancy after experimenting with different types of balls in a variety of inflated stages. Using a large parachute, they explore catching and moving air, and note the effects of air and movement on the buoyancy of various objects.

title: Scarf Juggling
description: After observing a professional juggler or watching a juggling video, students learn to use what they know about buoyancy, air resistance, and timing to master the skill of juggling by themselves.

title: Harnessing the Wind
description: Students demonstrate their learning from this unit of study by applying what they know about the power of air to fly paper airplanes, create and fly kites, and participate in relay races that require informed decision-making based on an understanding of air pressure, air resistance, buoyancy, and manipulation of objects while moving and while standing still.

title: Fitness Tools: Jumping
description: Students explore different fitness tools to practice and improve their jumping skills. They move through a circuit, record data from each station, and reflect on the effect of using the tools in a closing whole group discussion.

title: Fitness Tools: Poly Dots, Cones, Ladders, Hurdles, and Hoops
description: Students work in groups to create fitness circuits using various fitness tools. After moving through each of the circuits, they reflect on how the tools enhanced their experience.

title: Sport Tools: Striking with Paddles
description: Students explore and compare one-handed striking skills using paddles and their hands. As the skills become more complex, they investigate the advantages of using sport tools.

title: Sport Tools: Tee Ball
description: Students progress to two-handed striking skills and explore how using a different striking tool and a tee changes the skills needed for the experience.

title: Sport Tools: Playing with Scoops
description: Students wonder if all tools are helpful to all people as they explore using scoops to throw and catch.

title: Sorting It Out
description: Students explore a variety of ways to sort exercises and equipment and reflect on how sorting tools in Wellness class helps organize and enhance their experience.

title: Wellness Tools Circuit
description: Students perform a variety of activities using tools as extensions of themselves as the teacher uses a rubric to assess them based on their progress throughout the unit.

title: Explore Rhythm Through Movement
description: Students demonstrate their ability to respond to pattern-based music using locomotor and non-locomotor movements presented in various sequences.

title: GeoFitness
description: Students learn the rhythmic steps needed to form basic shape patterns when listening to music and using GeoFitness mats.

title: GeoFitness Advanced Mats
description: Students use movement patterns to explore GeoFitness GeoMats that teach them about clock patterns and nutrition while learning about rhythm.

title: Pattern Dancing History
description: After a fictional introduction to square dancing from a read-aloud of Barn Dance!, students review a brief history of folk dancing from around the world and then watch video demonstrations of several types of American pattern-based dancing in preparation for learning to dance on their own.

title: Square Dancing Basic Patterns
description: After learning six basic square dancing steps through cueing and demonstration, students combine, sequence, and add music to them to dance the Virginia Reel.

title: Square Dance Performance
description: Students perform patterned dances in small groups with only calls or verbal cues to direct them. They demonstrate their ability to perform the dances in time, in sequence, and in a pattern formation.

title: Reduce
description: Students explore ways they can reduce behaviors that hurt the environment and adopt new behaviors that benefit our world and then play a movement game that reinforces the ideas uncovered in the exploration.

title: Reuse
description: As students learn the value of reusing materials, they take a variety of recyclable materials and reuse them to create games and activities. They create a circuit training course that allows them to explore the various activities.

title: Recycle
description: Students learn about plastics and the steps taken to recycle them. They reinforce their learning of sorting recycled materials by participating in a fitness activity using an underhand throwing skill to aim at recyclable containers and sorting the containers into appropriate bins.

title: Water Cycle Game
description: While studying the water cycle in science, students participate in vigorous physical activities that reinforce the concepts of Sun, heat, evaporation, cloud formation, rain, and water collection. They continue to explore the concept of a cycle during this learning experience.

title: (ROSS) Responsible Nutrition
description: Students reflect on ways to eat that reduces their negative impact on the environment. Emphasis is on Regional, Organic, Sustainable, and Seasonal (ROSS), which is the Ross nutrition philosophy. Students also explore the different food groups and appropriate portions in their daily diet.

title: No More Resources!
description: Students play a game in which they use resources and then throw them away. There is no recycling or reusing. They consider, “What happens when our resources run out?”

title: Recycle Cardboard
description: Students learn about the steps taken to recycle cardboard and then develop three ideas for repurposing their cereal boxes. In groups, they decide on which idea is best for the environment and share the rationale for their decisions.

title: Pathways in Practice
description: Students access prior knowledge of Earth and other planets and then demonstrate their understanding of the orbit of a particular planet. They gain a basic understanding of manipulating a hockey ball with a hockey stick in a straight line.

title: Introduction to Wellness Solar System
description: Students play the game Planets Around the Sun, which they also play later with the addition of asteroids in the Functioning Within a System Learning Experience. They use balls of various sizes to represent the planets and model how each planet orbits around the Sun.

title: Sports Team as a System
description: Students build on the hockey skills they learned in grade 1 as they briefly explore the game of hockey and develop the concept of working as a team.

title: Functioning Within a System
description: During the first part of this learning experience, students play a game in which they explore what happens when asteroids or other objects travel into the pathway of a planet. They react to the obstacles and take note of their own communication styles and personal boundaries. In the second session, students play a competitive hockey game and compare the two activities.

title: Wellness Solar System Pathway Performance
description: In this assessment activity, students work in small groups to create patterns of movement that are different from a circular orbit. They map out their pathway and then designate the pathway on the floor surface with paper and tape.

title: Skeletal System
description: Students trace their bodies onto a large piece of paper and draw the basic bone structure onto the paper. They label the major bones and play games that help them learn the names of the bones.

title: Cardiovascular System
description: Students run an obstacle course that represents the cardiovascular system and discuss the important components and basic functions of the cardiovascular system.

title: Digestive System
description: Students help set up an obstacle course that represents the digestive system. They discuss the important components and basic functions of the digestive system. Afterward, they reflect on the similarities of body systems and Earth systems.

title: Basic Defensive Circuit
description: Students complete a defensive circuit that reinforces basic defensive concepts such as mirroring, blocking, and guarding. They explore how these components might relate to more complex games.

title: Basic Offensive Strategies
description: Students complete an offensive circuit that reinforces basic offensive concepts such as change of speed, change of direction, and good passing. They explore how these components might relate to more complex games.

title: Earth Tectonic Movement Challenge
description: Students reinforce their understanding of Earth tectonic plate movement that they learned in Science class through creative movement.

title: Systems Game
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of the different systems in a game through the application of defensive and offensive skills.

title: Nervous System
description: Students participate in physical challenges that simulate the stimulus and response patterns of the nervous system. They focus on the concepts of connections and cooperation within systems, where events that happen far away are connected to events that happen locally, and relate those concepts to sports systems and to the study of systems in other domains.

title: Muscular System
description: As with all systems, there must be connections and cooperation among elements of that system. In this lesson, students learn the names and related exercises of the large muscle groups. They also explore how muscles work in pairs in order to accomplish actions and tasks.

title: The Elements Race
description: Students form teams based on their element groups from Cultural History (Earth, air, water, fire) and create obstacle courses influenced by the study of these elements and their effects on our planet. After explaining the rationale for their designs, students challenge each other to race and complete each obstacle course.

title: Cooperative Newcomb Volleyball
description: Through the cooperative Newcomb game, students create systems and patterns of play for success. The game is a precursor to volleyball and emphasizes teamwork. Students serve, pass, throw, and catch a ball back and forth over a volleyball net.

title: Team Spirit: Competitive “Newcomb”
description: Students continue to develop Newcomb skills as the game progresses from a cooperative game to a competitive game that teaches students about team spirit, sportsmanship, cooperation, and competition. To display this team spirit, each team focuses on an elemental force (Earth, fire, water, or air), which guides them to create a team name, banner, and uniform. Students explain the rationale behind the team name, uniform, banner, and chosen colors.

title: Sport Statistics
description: Students collect statistics during competitive Newcomb games, graph the data, and then collaborate to decide how to improve the function of their team system.

title: Sport Data Displays
description: Students demonstrate an understanding of Newcomb terminology and skills by using data worksheets to track team serves, passes, and points during competitive games. They create graphs that represent the data and present an analysis of their team system function before and after improvement strategies are created and applied to team play.

title: Basic Fitness
description: Students perform activities that enhance and measure cardiovascular fitness, flexibility, strength, power, agility, speed, coordination, muscular endurance, and balance. They explore the basic fitness components used in different sports and how an athlete must adapt their training methods in order to succeed in specific sports.

title: Sports Nutrition
description: Students explore the nutritional building blocks for successful athletes and examine how athletes must adapt their diets to the demands of various sports and exercises. They learn about carbohydrates, proteins, fats, hydration requirements, and the timing of meals. They work in their workbooks to imagine a pre-game meal that prepares them for a sporting event.

title: Evolution of Kickball
description: In this unit, students study the evolution of the game of kickball, create a timeline about this evolution in the gym, and play three different versions of the game. They reflect on the evolutionary pressures to change the game over time and imagine the possible future of kickball.

title: Basic Compass Reading
description: Students learn the basic compass points and degrees that correspond to the four cardinal directions: north, south, east, and west. In addition, they explore natural phenomena such as wind, sun position, and storms in relation to compass points.

title: Moss and Lichen Hike
description: While walking and exploring moss and lichen, students map the walk and indicate the locations where they find moss and lichen.  They explore trends to see if this type of plant life grows in certain locations, facing specific cardinal directions.

title: Tumbling Basics
description: Students learn the basics of tumbling, including pyramids, forward rolls , jumps, turns, cartwheels, round-offs, and handstands. They combine these basic tumbling skills to create a more complex routine.

title: My Evolution as an Athlete Workbook and Timeline
description: Students demonstrate an understanding of the unit and of themselves as athletes by completing the My Evolution as an Athlete workbook and timeline.

title: Throwing
description: Students participate in a variety of activities during which they practice basic throwing skills, measure accuracy and distance, and connect their exploration to team sports and games.

title: Catching
description: Students participate in a variety of activities during which they practice basic catching skills, explore different catching techniques with and without implements, and connect their exploration to team sports and games.

title: Kicking
description: Students participate in a variety of activities during which they practice basic kicking skills and connect their exploration to team sports and games. They measure accuracy and analyze variations in kicking techniques by attempting to punt various types of balls toward a target.

title: Striking
description: Students examine the building blocks of sports that involve striking. They apply their skills when exploring striking activities that simulate the sports of field hockey, badminton, baseball, handball, and racquetball.

title: Volley
description: Students complete a series of volleying activities that lead up to a cooperative game of volleyball. Skills include a variety of passes and serves that students practice and apply during the concluding group game.

title: Jumping
description: Students continue their exploration of evolution by examining the building blocks of sports that involve jumping. During their exploration of the fundamental skills of jumping, students take a simple skill and adapt it to more complex tasks.

title: My Evolution as an Athlete Workbook (Part 2)
description: Students complete Part 2 of their My Evolution as an Athlete workbook as a continuation from Part 1, in the Unit 1 assessment, My Evolution as an Athlete Workbook and Timeline (WE_G3_U1_07_AS). Students reflect on their athletic growth and on all the building blocks required to evolve into a complete athlete.

title: Rocks, Rocks, Rocks
description: Students warm up with a game to reinforce the definitions of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks they learn in Science Learning Experience: Rocks and Fossils (SC_G3_U2_07_LE) and then play the Hunt and Hunted game, a simulation of an early type of hunting that uses rocks to stun prey.

title: Spear Throw
description: The spear was an important hunting tool for early humans, and in this learning experience, students explore throwing techniques using a modern day javelin. After practicing and being evaluated for accuracy and distance, students discuss their reflections on throwing the spear as a method of hunting and connect it to the modern day javelin track and field event.

title: Running Down Prey
description: One of the most successful hunting techniques for small human bands was running down prey, or persistence hunting, which required great personal fitness and group cooperation. Students examine this technique with an activity that teaches running skills and chasing strategies.

title: The Offensive Unit
description: Students work with a small offensive unit to practice and apply basic group offensive strategies, which include the concepts of penetration, support, width, mobility, and creativity.

title: The Defensive Unit
description: Students build on individual basic defense skills learned in earlier grades when they work with a small defensive unit using the basic group defensive strategy concepts of delay, depth, concentration, balance, and patience.

title: Hunter Fitness
description: Students create a fitness test that determines the best hunters in the class and includes other qualities that might also be needed for small human bands to successfully survive in nature.

title: Project Adventure
description: To start the unit, students tackle Project Adventure challenges to learn Ross School Core Values and consider which core values are most important for successful clans and teams.

title: Archery
description: Students explore archery safety, equipment, shooting form, rules, and etiquette.

title: Good Sportsmanship
description: In this learning experience, students explore sportsmanship and participate in small competitions to demonstrate good behavior in both winning and losing. They play charades using sports scenarios and decide whether the scenarios show good or bad sportsmanship.

title: Spirit Animals in Sports
description: Students compare animal characteristics to their own athletic strengths and to the playing abilities necessary for each position in soccer. They also choose their own spirit animal.

title: Forming Clan Teams
description: After students form clan teams, each team chooses a name, a team value, and a captain and creates a pregame warmup and cheer. Teams share their choices with the class as they prepare for the Inter-Clan Competition.

title: Clan Conflict
description: While competing in a variation on the game Capture the Flag, students pretend to be Neolithic clans raiding one another’s food supplies.

title: Clan Competition
description: In this final activity, student clans play several sports in an Inter-Clan Competition. They assess their teams’ successes and challenges and reflect on core values shared between sports teams and Neolithic communities.

title: Domestication Game
description: To begin the unit, students play a tag game in which they tame “wild animals” and domesticate as many of the “animals” as possible. Students reflect on the many ways animals might have been domesticated in the Neolithic Period.

title: Astragali Games and Divination
description: Students explore games of chance by rolling dice and performing fitness tasks and other challenges. They also imagine the world of Neolithic societies, where divination, rites, and rituals helped ancient peoples to explain the natural world.

title: Pathogens
description: While playing a physical game, students learn about pathogens. They also discuss how changes during the Neolithic period encouraged the spread of pathogens and the emergence of infectious diseases.

title: Immunology: Fighting Back
description: Students explore different ways to prevent disease and the many things that can help the immune system to fight disease. Then, they play a tag game with pathogens, white blood cells, and antibodies.

title: Angles in Sports
description: To understand the many ways in which angles, degrees, and directions are critical to success in sports, students participate in a variety of activities that explore the defensive triangle, biomechanics, cutting angles, and shooting angles.

title: Creating a Sport Ritual
description: After exploring a variety of pre-game rituals and sport rituals in modern-day sports, students create their own pre-game rituals and perform them before competing in basketball.

title: Ritual Dance
description: Students explore modern ritual dances and the role ritual dances played in Neolithic settlements.

title: Exploring Lacrosse Equipment
description: To begin their investigation of lacrosse, students handle lacrosse equipment and hypothesize about the nature and history of the game.

title: History of Lacrosse
description: Students learn about the Native American origins and development of lacrosse.

title: Evolution of Lacrosse
description: Students compare native lacrosse and modern lacrosse, identifying distinctions and similarities by answering questions on a worksheet.

title: Lacrosse Skill and Technique
description: In preparation for playing lacrosse in a team scenario, students learn and practice basic lacrosse skills.

title: Iroquois Food
description: Students explore the connections between lacrosse and Iroquois farming and diet.

title: Creating an Iroquois Lacrosse Stick
description: Students create models of traditional lacrosse sticks.

title: Iroquois Lacrosse Game Simulation
description: To conclude the unit, students simulate an Iroquois festival, including a welcoming ritual, a simulated lacrosse experience using homemade sticks, and a harvest feast.

title: What Does It Mean to Think Like a Scientist?
