description: To assess their ability to Flash Forward to studying inter-nationalisms characteristic of the Complex Dynamical Mentality, students read the Declaration on the Promotion of World Peace and Cooperation from the Asian-African Conference of Bandung (1955) to build an argument that answers the question “What’s Wrong with One World?”

title: The Emergence of Post-Colonial Nationalisms
description: Students explore one of three case studies: on India, Antigua, or the American West, in teams that they form around questions they believe worth investigating in the case study material in order to support their own research and share what they learn in frequent short discussions.

title: The Emergence of New Inter-Nationalisms
description: Students explore one of three case studies in teams around questions they believe are worth exploring in the case study material in order to support their own research: the nonaligned movement and the evolution of UN development programming; bottom-up struggles for civil rights as contrasted to the UN’s Universal Declaration of Human Rights; or the early grassroots struggles of the environmental movement.

title: Identifying Patterns in Nature
description: During this diagnostic assessment, students share with each other their prior knowledge of different patterns in nature. They also create tree illustrations that will be used again during the formative assessment.

title: The Outdoor and Indoor Classroom
description: In the classroom, students and teacher curate a collection of natural materials and images that will enhance the investigation of patterns in living things. The collection is built throughout the unit and has a sampling of a variety of patterns: from linear to tessellations to branching patterns.

title: Patterns and Cycles: Monarch Butterflies
description: Based on observations of classroom butterflies and research, students document the butterfly life cycle, the linear patterns in the caterpillar, and the symmetrical patterns in the butterfly. Together students create a class representation of the butterfly life cycle. They each create a fictional butterfly and document its life cycle and physical patterns.

title: Studying Patterns in Trees
description: Using tree-related natural materials, students learn the names of the six basic patterns in nature, and then identify them in trees. They record observations, compare patterns found in nature, and do bark or leaf rubbings and observational drawings.

title: Deciduous and Coniferous
description: Through a classifying and sorting experience, students distinguish between deciduous and coniferous trees. They express their understanding through comparative sculpture or drawings of deciduous and coniferous trees in the same season.

title: Patterns and Cycles: Honeybees
description: Students explore the lives of honeybees, from the role they play in the life cycles of many plants to the tessellating patterns of the honeycomb to the structure of their organized community. They participate in a read-aloud of The Honey Makers, by Gail Gibbons, and conduct their own research on honeybee life cycles and honeycomb patterns. To make their study hands on, students visit a beekeeper and taste honey.

title: Natural Cycles
description: Building upon their knowledge of patterns and cycles, students explore and observe the life cycle and decomposition cycle of a tree through a nature walk, class reading, and research, in which they compare live and fallen trees.

title: Nature Journals
description: During each of the previous learning experiences in this unit, students have made entries in their Nature journals. These entries and a new, more detailed drawing of a tree are graded using a rubric.

title: Seeds and Their Needs
description: Through a hands-on activity of germinating seeds, students connect their knowledge of trees to their kindergarten study of the four elemental forces.

title: Mentors: Rachel Carson
description: After reading about the life of Rachel Carson, students brainstorm ways in which one person can make a difference to sustain life on Earth, especially the lives of honeybees and monarch butterflies.

title: Bee, Tree, and Butterfly Collage
description: Students synthesize what they have learned about trees, butterflies, honeybees, patterns, the needs of living things, and environmental stewardship by creating collages.

title: Tools Word Web
description: Students work collaboratively to create webs that relate tools to tasks they help facilitate, therefore establishing the idea that tools are extensions of ourselves.

title: Cultural History Journal
description: Throughout the unit, students record information in their Cultural History Journals, which serve as a record of their understanding. Students and teachers also use their journals for conferencing and goal setting.

title: Classroom Tools
description: Students explore the classroom and identify a variety of tools that are used to assist with daily learning. They focus on the Japanese soroban, a tool used in mathematics, by learning its history and using it during mathematics learning experiences.

title: Antique Tools
description: Working with a local museum or historical society, students select a tool and conduct research to discover its purpose, time period in which it was used, and if it has evolved and is in use today.

title: Tool Collage
description: Students connect to the concept of tools as extensions of the self by creating a collage of tools. They glue pictures of tools cut from magazines onto outlines of their bodies drawn on butcher paper.

title: Tools Visitors Use
description: Community members, including parents, caregivers, faculty, and staff, are invited into the classroom to discuss tools they use in their jobs and hobbies and to share how those tools make their tasks and pastimes easier or more enjoyable. Students predict visitors' tool use and later document what they've learned in their Cultural History Journals.

title: Field Trip to See Tools in Action
description: The class travels into the community to build understanding of tools' value and function by observing people using tools at their jobs.

title: Simple Machines
description: Students identify and explore simple machines used in everyday life. In the classroom, a center is set up with materials that students use to experiment with simple machines.

title: Technology Programs as Tools
description: Students investigate electronic equipment and computer programs to understand how specific technologies and programs are tools. They make a web of technology-based tools.

title: Designing and Making Tools
description: Students design, build, and assess a tool of their own creation.

title: Cycles in Nature
description: Building on previous units of study, students identify various living and nonliving cycles in nature and create a working definition of the word cycle.

title: Cultural History Journal: Nonliving Cycles in Nature
description: Students create water and rock cycle journals which are used to check their understanding of the concepts and ideas presented over the course of the unit.

title: Evaporation
description: Students explore evaporation by observing the gradual disappearance of outdoor puddles and by watching a pot of hot water boil. They relate what they see to what they have learned about the water cycle and record observations in their Cultural History journals.

title: Field Experiences and Measuring Water
description: Students spend time outdoors observing, interacting with, and measuring water that they find in various phases of the water cycle.

title: All the Fresh Water in the World
description: Students create visual representations of the percentages of types of water available on Earth and after recognizing how little fresh water is available, brainstorm conservation ideas to protect freshwater lakes, streams, rivers, and groundwater.

title: Water Cycle Journal Entries
description: Students present their Cultural History journals to the teacher during individual conferences. They are assessed on their understandings of the water cycle and its significance, as demonstrated in their journal entries.

title: What Is the Rock Cycle?
description: After viewing a video that explains the rock cycle and describes the three major types of rocks, students go on field experiences to collect rock samples which they take back to the classroom to identify, analyze, and add to the rock center.

title: Creating a Rock Cycle
description: As students participate in a shared reading experience of The Rock Factory: The Story About the Rock Cycle, they create individual rock cycle diagrams and collaborate to create a three-dimensional diagram to be displayed in the classroom.

title: Three Types of Rocks
description: After exploring the three main types of rocks through independent reading and Internet research, students create a large Venn diagram comparing them. They use rocks from the rock center for specific examples of each type of rock and record sketches and descriptions of each in their Cultural History journals.

title: Rock Collecting
description: Students consider the importance of understanding rocks from a historical perspective as they participate in a shared-reading activity based on the book Let’s Go Rock Collecting.

title: Rock Cycle Journal Entries
description: Students present their Cultural History journals to the teacher during individual conferences and are assessed on their understandings of the rock cycle and its significance, as demonstrated by their rock cycle journal entries.

title: Identifying the Problem of Human Action
description: Students study and discuss images to develop an awareness of Earth’s garbage problem. They start a class T-chart and begin to add problems with garbage to one side and possible solutions to the other. Throughout the unit, students add further ideas to the T-chart.

title: Cultural History Journal
description: Throughout the unit, students record information in their Cultural History journals. The journals serve as a record of their understanding and are used for conferencing and setting goals for student performance.

title: Read-Alouds: The Lorax and A River Ran Wild
description: Students listen to and compare The Lorax by Dr. Seuss and A River Ran Wild by Lynn Cherry texts that feature the themes of human consumption and environmental conservation. They create a Venn diagram to compare and contrast the texts and use their Cultural History journals to draw conclusions.

title: Clean Up, Clean Up
description: In this active immersion experience, the class connects with a local environmental organization and participates in a clean-up project in a local park or on a beach or hiking trail. Students reflect on what they find and how the garbage ended up where it did.

title: Decomposition Garden
description: Students conduct a decomposition experiment either in a school garden or in the classroom. They “plant” materials and observe their decomposition, recording observations in their Cultural History journals.

title: Tracking Garbage
description: Students explore the guiding question, Where does garbage go once it leaves the classroom? They track a variety of garbage and recycling items from the classroom garbage receptacle to a compost pile to the local recycling center. As they revisit readings, students reflect on how the stories connect to their lives.

title: Finding a Solution
description: Students explore how one person can make a difference. They read the true story of Wangari Maathai, environmentalist and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, and reflect on how they can have a similar effect on the world through reducing, reusing, or recycling.

title: Read-Aloud: Jen Green’s Why Should I Recycle?
description: After listening to the story read-aloud, students connect it to their ideas from previous activities in the unit.

title: Read-Aloud: Time to Reduce
description: After reading two books that focus on reducing the use of natural resources, students list the things they can use less of, which leads into a public service campaign to reduce the use of water and electricity at school.

title: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle Field Trips
description: Students investigate the community and identify businesses and places that actively reduce, reuse, and/or recycle.

title: Reduce/Reuse/Recycle School-Wide Assembly
description: Students perform in an assembly and create posters to demonstrate their understanding of the unit.

title: Early Life on Earth: Recapitulation of Earth Systems
description: Through two readings and a creation of a class KWL chart, students revisit the last unit of second grade in order to lay the foundation for new understandings of the evolving planet, Earth.

title: Cultural History Journal Check-Ins
description: This formative assessment establishes a formal way of checking in with student understanding as expressed through their Cultural History journals. The journals are checked several times throughout the unit.

title: Reading: Bacteria
description: Students participate in a read-aloud of From Lava to Life by Jennifer Morgan. They discuss the importance of bacteria and reflect on that concept in their Cultural History journals.

title: Early Earth Timeline
description: After participating in a read-aloud of Michael Rubino’s book Bang! How We Came to Be, students work cooperatively to design a timeline documenting early life on Earth according to a determined scale, which they add to throughout the unit. Outdoors, they pace off time periods and create a physical timeline.

title: Fungus and Mold
description: Students participate in a read-aloud about the evolutionary journey from bacteria to cells. They grow fungus and mold in jars and record and share observations as they learn about the conditions necessary for life.

title: Moss and Lichen Hike and Garden
description: Students photograph, collect, and observe moss and lichen specimens. Back in the classroom, they set up a moss and lichen ecosystem in a terrarium that they then observe.

title: Reading: Focus on Algae and Ferns
description: Through reading and observations, students learn about the origins of algae and ferns.

title: Fossilized Earth
description: How do fossils and rocks help to determine Earth’s history? Students transition to the exploration of geological evidence to discover how scientists use fossils to interpret Earth’s past. They read Fossils Tell of Long Ago by Aliki and explore fossil specimens.

title: Miniature Grand Canyons
description: Using glass jars, natural materials, and interlocking toy bricks, students create models of geological strata. They learn about the concept of an index fossil and how geologists and paleontologists use index fossils to determine the age of other findings.

title: Making Fossils
description: Students review and research information about fossils and then simulate the creation of a trace, or imprint, fossil using shells, modeling dough, and plaster. They draw and write a step-by-step explanation of how an imprint fossil is formed.

title: Archaeological Dig
description: Students engage in and document an archaeological dig, further deepening their understanding of the role of archaeologists, geologists, and paleontologists in the study of early life. They answer the question, “Based on what you uncovered, what can you tell about life in the past at our archaeological dig site?” in their Cultural History journals.

title: The Age of Dinosaurs
description: After reading about dinosaur bones, students answer the question, “Do you think it is difficult for archaeologists, geologists, and paleontologists to know exactly what happened in the past?” in their Cultural History journals. They use examples from their reading and other resources to support their answers.

title: Evolving Planet Tour
description: Students use books and the website Evolving Planet to research different geological time periods. They then take their research to World Languages and Literature: English class and turn it into a three-paragraph essay that is graded as a part of their summative assessment.

title: Living Fossils
description: Students listen to a read-aloud that uses poetry and prose to tell the story of evolutionary survivors. They add to a class timeline to make connections between evolution and existing organisms on Earth.

title: Dinosaur Stop-Motion
description: As a part of the Dinosaur Study Integrated Project, students create stop-motion animation videos depicting a day in the life of their dinosaur species.

title: Evolving Planet Museum
description: Students demonstrate the understandings they have developed during the unit by presenting their process and final products in an Evolving Planet Museum.

title: Mammal Mind Maps
description: Students work cooperatively to create mind maps that list their prior knowledge about evolution, adaptation, mammals, and the Cenozoic Era. They discuss the answer to the guiding question, “What changes took place on Earth that established mammals as a dominant group?”

title: Cultural History Journal Check-Ins
description: This formative assessment establishes a formal way of checking in with student understanding as expressed through their Cultural History journals. The journals are checked several times throughout the unit.

title: From Dinosaurs to Mammals
description: Students listen to a read-aloud from Mammals Who Morph by Jennifer Morgan and from the website “How Did Mammals Evolve?” to find out about mammal evolution. They define synapsids and revisit the question, “What changes took place on Earth that established mammals as a dominant group?”

title: Mammal Morph Books
description: Students choose mammals to investigate, tracing its lineage from prehistoric ancestors to modern descendants. The information helps create an accordion book tracing the morphological changes in the animals; each page depicts an image of the animal, as well as the representative time period. Students represent both the initial and final size of their mammal while working outdoors.

title: Mammal Classification
description: Over the course of several days, students take notes on mammalian characteristics and conduct research on a specific mammal. Students form three groups and select one type of mammal (marsupial, monotreme, placental) and create a chart for that mammal.

title: Adaptations and Survival
description: Based on a read-aloud from Ubiquitous: Celebrating Nature’s Survivors by Joyce Sidman, students discuss squirrel adaptation. Students list and research the adaptations their prehistoric mammals exhibited in order to create hypotheses about how those adaptations might have led to the mammals’ survival.

title: Life on Earth: Evolve versus Adapt
description: To complete their study of mammalian evolution, students read Billions of Years, Amazing Changes: The Story of Evolution by Laurence Pringle, discussing connections between the external environment and adaptation. Then students apply all that they have learned to create mammals, detailing their attributes and adaptations in both the Tertiary Period and the modern day.

title: Human Evolution, What Do You Know?
description: Through reviewing timelines, viewing the online National Geographic Prehistoric Time Line, and creating illustrated timelines, students revisit Cultural History Unit 2 to lay the foundation for new understanding.

title: Cultural History Journal
description: This formative assessment establishes a formal way of checking in with student understanding as expressed through their Cultural History journals. The journals are checked several times throughout the unit.

title: Prehistory and Archaeologists
description: Students define new vocabulary and listen to a read-aloud about archaeology. For the second part of the learning experience, they act as classroom archaeologists by sorting a bag of garbage into two categories (biodegradable and nondegradable) and drawing conclusions about it.

title: Updating History
description: Students conduct Internet research on early human evolution. The articles they find lead to a discussion on how recent discoveries are always changing what scientists think they know about early humans.

title: Human Evolution Exploration
description: Students explore the Smithsonian website about human evolution. After their exploration, they answer questions related to the site in their Cultural History journals.

title: Hominids vs. Apes
description: After reading and taking notes on selected pages of Eyewitness Early Humans, students create a Venn diagram to show the similarities and differences between early humans and our genetic relatives, apes.

title: Bipedalism and Quadrupedalism
description: Students act out the differences between walking upright and walking on all fours. They use this experience to make inferences about why walking upright might have been beneficial to human evolution.

title: Laetoli Footprints
description: Students watch two short videos about the discovery of the Laetoli footprints from Tanzania. Then they work collaboratively to create their own model of the Laetoli footprints.

title: The Size of the Brain
description: Students use mathematics manipulatives to model the size of the brain of both modern humans and our hominid ancestors. This is integrated with a mathematics study of finding volume.

title: Walking Through Human Evolution
description: Students work in groups to create reports about five early human species: Ardipithecus ramidus, Australopithecus afarensis, Homo habilis, Homo erectus, and Neanderthal. Each group also creates a silhouette shape of their species. The silhouettes and reports are displayed in the classroom.

title: Natural History Field Trip
description: If possible, students travel to a natural history museum featuring an exhibit on human origins. Alternatively, they take a web field trip and record information about human origins.

title: From Bands to Clans
description: Students explore the evolution of human consciousness, from hunting bands to forming clans. They focus on the structure of clan life, spirituality, early crops, and housing structures.

title: Forming Clans
description: Students form clans with classmates. Using a set group of questions, each clan forms a story about their lifestyle, culture, and rituals.

title: Neolithic Spiritual Beliefs
description: Students imagine that they are living in Neolithic times, visiting a place of worship. They explore the understanding that Neolithic people had no scientific explanations for natural events; therefore, anything in nature may have been considered a spirit, or a god or goddess, or at least the result of magic.

title: Clan Baby Project
description: Each clan member demonstrates the ability to work together with the clan as a whole to delegate responsibilities, create shelter, provide food, and meet the wants and needs of their egg “baby.” Students also create a ritual for naming their baby, and a healing or death ritual if their baby should “get sick” or “die.”

title: Origin Stories
description: Students have been exploring the idea that having an imagination allowed Homo sapiensto evolve, and early humans used their observations from their environment along with imagery from their dreams to describe their natural world and beliefs. These beliefs led to cultures developing an oral storytelling tradition. In their clans, students brainstorm, write, and illustrate their own origin stories.

title: Feast of the Ancestors
description: The Feast of the Ancestors is a time to celebrate our ancestors and the circle of life, while sharing a meal and stories. Students learn about contemporary celebrations that honor ancestors and then research personal family recipes that have special significance, bringing one dish to share with peers at the class feast.

title: How Art Made the World—Cave Painting
description: Students look at cave paintings as a means of spiritual communication and ritual significance. They recall their knowledge about the shaman and learn that most shamans were also the cave artists of their clans

title: Göbekli Tepe: World’s First-Known Ceremonial Center
description: Students study the Göbekli Tepe ceremonial site. Through videos and discussion, students explore the role of Neolithic ceremonial sites and the job of archaeologists. They then create their own carved pillars inspired by the study of Göbekli Tepe.

title: Göbekli Tepe Quiz
description: Students take a quiz to assess what they have learned about Göbekli Tepe.

title: Artifacts of the Cosmos
description: This multisession learning experience explores astronomy—the observation of celestial objects and events—and identifies it as one of the oldest sciences.

title: Early Humans’ New Face
description: Students watch the video clip “Mankind: The Story of All of Us: The Earliest Humans” and then read and view the National Geographic website “The Human Journey: Migration Routes.” They use information from the website to complete a worksheet.

title: Out of Africa: Why Early Humans Settled Around the World
description: This learning experience is an ongoing investigation of the migration of early humans and their subsequent population of the globe. The learning experience is meant to occur over the course of several class sessions.

title: Out of Africa: Migration Map
description: This formative assessment occurs midway through the Out of Africa: Why Early Humans Settled Around the World learning experience. Students work with a copy of the Early Human Migratory Paths Map and complete 10 short-answer questions and tasks to demonstrate their understanding and map-reading skills.

title: What Does It Mean to “Settle”?
description: In this learning experience, students brainstorm and discuss ideas about what it means to “settle.” They recognize that when people settle, they take up residence or find a permanent place to live and that people usually settle in groups so they can work cooperatively to build shelters and find food.q

title: Human Settlement Scenario
description: This formative assessment takes place after the study of the human migratory experience is complete. Students address one of several scenarios: writing short-answer responses to questions about climate, natural resources, food, and shelter; drawing a picture of the settlement; and writing a paragraph explaining whether the new settlement location is good for the clan.

title: Investigating Staff-of-Life Crops
description: Students investigate the history and importance of staff-of-life crops. They then identify the different staff-of-life crops from cultures around the world.

title: The Domestication of Animals
description: Students investigate the history and importance of animal domestication. They learn about the important roles that animals, such as sheep, pigs, goats, and dogs, played in enabling early humans to thrive.

title: Investigating Çatal Hüyük
description: Students explore the early settlement of Çatal Hüyük. Through research, they investigate the archaeological artifacts, processes, and mysteries of one of the oldest and largest Neolithic settlements.

title: Bamana Rituals and Chi wara Headdresses
description: Students learn about the Bamana tribe of West Africa and their continued practice of the Chi wara agricultural ritual, which is steeped in ancient myth and history.

title: Field Trip to Museum
description: In this learning experience, students visit a museum that displays artifacts from early cultures to reinforce what they have been learning in the unit.

title: What Makes a Community Work?
description: Students participate in a class discussion about communities and how they work, using examples from their previous study of Paleolithic and Neolithic cultures. They create a Venn diagram comparing the different types of communities studied so far this year.

title: Social Systems
description: Students define the concept of a “system” using appropriate reference materials and then compare systems found within human communities.

title: The First North Americans
description: Students listen to readings, read about, and discuss early Native American cultures in North America.

title: Field Trip: Local Native American Historical Museum
description: Students conduct field research at a local Native American museum to learn about a Native American culture. They record their findings in their Native American journals.

title: The Iroquois: Stories as a Lens to Culture and Belief
description: Students read, illustrate, and present Iroquois myths depicting social, cultural, and spiritual beliefs and their connection to nature.

title: The Iroquois: Explorations
description: Students research and explore the Iroquois. Areas of research include festivals, government structure and rules, shelters, clans, written and oral language, community life, food, clothing, games and sports, spiritual beliefs, and trade. They then compare and contrast Iroquois culture with another Native American culture.

title: The Great Law of Peace
description: Students read and discuss sections of the Iroquois Constitution, the symbolism behind it, and how it relates to the laws of a community as well as Ross Core Values.

title: Council Meeting
description: Students participate in a simulated Iroquois council meeting to resolve a classroom issue.

title: Festivals and Rituals
description: Students research and design elements for the Iroquois Green Corn Festival.

title: Mississippian Culture – Social Systems
description: Students watch a short video documentary about the Mississippian mound builders and answer questions about their society.

title: Mississippian Pottery and Art
description: Students view and analyze the techniques and symbolism behind Mississippian pottery.

title: The Mississippian Marketplace
description: Students learn about Cahokia as a center for Native American trading and the role the Mississippi River played in their culture. They then participate in a simulated Mississippian marketplace

title: Comparing Early Cultures
description: As a final assessment, students complete a Venn diagram to compare the Iroquois, the Mississippians, and another early culture.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia
description: Students read and discuss Kingfisher History Encyclopedia and The City of Rainbows: A Tale from Ancient Sumer. They also study maps and view the video Time Life’s Lost Civilizations: Mesopotamia: Return to Eden. Students formulate answers to questions such as “Where are the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers? What is the Fertile Crescent? Why is the region known as a crossroads of cultures? Which of the world’s great religions were born in the region?”

title: Three Vocabulary Quizzes
description: Students take three vocabulary quizzes related to their study of ancient Mesopotamia.

title: Interpreting a Creation Myth
description: Students consider the myth Enuma Elish and how it is related to the shift from a matristic to a patriarchal civilization. They present their interpretations in discussion and in writing.

title: Gilgamesh
description: Students read the epic of Gilgamesh and discuss its universal themes of friendship and immortality.

title: Code of Hammurabi
description: Students analyze the significance of Hammurabi’s Code of Laws and the development of a legal system in the context of the birth of civilization. They write an argument for or against one of the laws in Hammurabi’s code.

title: Grains of Mesopotamia
description: Students see, touch, and taste a variety of grains—amaranth, quinoa, millet, barley, and wheat—that developed in the Fertile Crescent and consider how irrigation made their cultivation possible. They bake breads of Mesopotamia and then each researches a specific grain for a report. They exhibit what they learned in a display “Grains of the Fertile Crescent.”

title: Ancient Mesopotamia Test
description: Students take a summative assessment that consists of fill-in-the-blank questions (with vocabulary from a word bank about ancient Mesopotamia) and one short-answer question.

title: The Origins and Myths of Civilization: Egypt
description: Students explore the geography and mythology of Egypt, including the five themes of geography and five characteristics of civilization. They study maps to understand the significance of the Nile River in the rise of Egyptian civilization, focusing on the idea that Egypt is “the gift of the Nile.” Students also learn about Egypt’s creation myth and gods and goddesses.

title: Origins of Civilization Quiz
description: This assessment is used to check for student understanding about ancient Egypt. Students demonstrate their knowledge of the materials covered from the prior learning experience by answering several questions.

title: Origins of Writing: Egyptian Hieroglyphs
description: Students explore the origins of writing by examining pictograms, ideograms, and early alphabets. As they explore these ancient artifacts, they ponder how writing began. They study hieroglyphs and learn the importance of the Rosetta Stone.

title: The Rosetta Stone Quiz
description: In order to demonstrate an understanding of the material covered in the prior learning experience, students take a multiple choice and short-answer quiz on hieroglyphs and the Rosetta Stone.

title: Ancient Nubia
description: Using maps and other geographic resources, students explore the areas around the White and Blue Nile rivers in the Sudan. They use the information gleaned from multiple resources to understand the connection between the natural environment and Nubian civilization.

title: Ancient Nubia Quiz
description: This assessment is used to check for student understanding of the material covered in the prior learning experience; students take a multiple choice and short-answer quiz.

title: Comparing Egyptian and Nubian Societies
description: Students compare Egypt and Nubia, noting differences in housing, clothing, food, architecture, and other aspects. They use multiple resources, including the library and websites, to conduct research to facilitate their comparisons.

title: Ancient Egypt Quiz
description: This quiz assesses students progressing knowledge of ancient Egypt. The quiz has six questions, each requiring a written answer of between two and five sentences.

title: The Myth of Isis and Osiris
description: The myth of Isis and Osiris is a lens through which students explore the worldview of the ancient Egyptians. Students read, research, and discuss the iconic myth as it reveals the Egyptian concept of the afterlife and why Egyptians mummified their dead.

title: Geography and the Indus Valley Civilization
description: Students begin their study of the Indus Valley by reviewing maps that emphasize the strategic position of the region. Then, they read and discuss texts on the Indus Valley, learning about life in the planned cities of Harappa and Mohenjo-Daro with their gridded streets, indoor plumbing, and use of cylinder seals. Students also engage in study of Hindu temples and temple sculptures.

title: World Religions: Focus on Hinduism
description: Students discuss world religions, particularly Hinduism and the gods and goddesses in the Hindu pantheon. They read the Hindu creation myth Purusha Sukta and view sculptures and artifacts of Hindu deities, such as Ganesha and Siva. Students memorize two Rig Veda verses in Sanskrit, and also perform Bharata Natyam in Siva’s Dance of Creation, which they chant and dance in their presentation of the Hindu Deities Integrated Project later in the unit. Further enrichment, if possible, will include a visit to an Indian temple.

title: Meditation and Other Rituals
description: Students learn and practice Hindu meditation and mantras, building on their study of sacred spaces and megalithic structures of worship and ritual from grade 4.

title: Indus Valley Quiz
description: This sentence-completion, multiple-choice, and short-answer quiz assesses students’ knowledge of the Indus Valley civilization.

title: Shang Dynasty Quiz
description: This multiple-choice and short-answer quiz assesses students’ knowledge of China’s geography and the history of early ancient China.

title: Geography and the Caral-Supe Valley
description: Students research the Caral-Supe Valley in Peru and examine the complex society that developed there, with its urban planning, temple architecture and amphitheaters, varied crops, and fishing. Caral has been called the oldest city in the Americas.

title: Geography and Civilizations of the Aegean: Minoans and Mycenaeans
description: Students study maps of the Aegean and read about ancient Crete and the civilizations of the Aegean in The Kingfisher History Encyclopedia.

title: Artifacts and the Bronze Age
description: Students examine a reproduction of an ancient Cretan artifact, the Phaistos Disk, speculating on its use and understanding how one learns about a culture through its artifacts.

title: The Myth of the Minotaur
description: Students read, outline, and summarize a brief version of the myth of the Minotaur before reading aloud a longer version of the myth. They also create drawings and paintings of the Minotaur.

title: Twilight of the Goddess Writing Assignment and Vocabulary
description: Students write about how the Minoan civilization represented the twilight of the goddess and the matristic society. They imagine living in ancient Crete and ponder its demise. This formative assessment is given in World Languages and Literature: English as well as in Cultural History, requiring students to use vocabulary connected with the topic.

title: The Minotaur Puppet Project
description: Working in small groups, students make puppets, write scripts that re-create the myth of the Minotaur, and present puppet shows to the class.

title: Test: The Minoan Civilization
description: Students answer 15 short-response questions to demonstrate their knowledge of the Minoans.

title: Syrtos Dancing
description: Students learn about the traditional Greek folk dance called the Syrtos. This introduces students to one of the most ancient forms of pre-Classical Greek dance.

title: Quiz: Ancient Civilization Geography
description: This multiple-choice quiz is used as a simple review of what students have learned about important issues involving geography and ancient civilizations throughout the year.

title: Geography of the Americas and the Five Characteristics of Civilization
description: Students examine, analyze, and interpret a series of nine maps pertaining to global geography and the geography of the Americas. Students engage in discussion applying the five characteristics of civilization to the society of the Americas.

title: The Mayflower Compact: What Is Power and Who Has It?
description: Students discuss, analyze, and evaluate the Mayflower Compact of 1620 and the notion and value of self-governance. They compose and reflect upon a 5th Grade Classroom Compact, a set of classroom rules to which all students agree to follow and support. Students also discuss the questions: “What is governance?” and “How is governance established?” by examining the signers of the original Mayflower Compact.

title: Religion in the Americas
description: Students discuss the meaning of religion, regarding it as an institution, as part of the framework of society, and as a set of beliefs. Students research and examine the Church of England, the Puritans, and the Quakers, analyzing their role in the establishment of the colonies and founding of the United States. Students analyze the demonization of women in the Salem Witch Trials.

title: Economics in Colonial and Revolutionary America
description: Students examine how the early settlers in America supported themselves with farming (sometimes aided by enslaved labor), whaling, and various cottage industries. They study how women shaped the economy and analyze how British tax policies contributed to the beginning of the American Revolution.

title: Literature Circle: My Brother Sam Is Dead
description: Students read and discuss the novel My Brother Sam Is Dead by James Lincoln Collier and Christopher Collier, comparing its portrayal of life in the colonies with what they have learned about colonial America and sharing their opinions of the characters and the novel as a whole.

title: The Nation’s Founding Documents
description: Students examine and discuss the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights. They learn of the impact of the Iroquois Confederacy’s Hiawatha Wampum Belt and the Great Law of Peace in the creation of U.S. founding documents. In a homework assignment, students write about the meaning and impact of the U.S. Constitution for the United States and beyond.

title: Birth of the United States, 1763–1789
description: Students review the colonial history in the United States in preparation for a final unit quiz. The quiz addresses the causes for the War for Independence, the Declaration of Independence, and the Constitution.

title: Garbage Pail Archaeology
description: Students work in teams to analyze today’s garbage from the perspective of a 23rd-century archaeologist to determine what it reveals about 21st-century culture.

title: Quetzlcoatl
description: Students read, analyze, and discuss the poem “Quetzlcoatl” by Ross School mentor, Willliam Irwin Thompson.

title: Olmec Test
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the Olmecs by arranging the ancient Mesoamerican civilizations in chronological order, identifying countries that make up modern Central America, defining terms related to Olmec culture, and analyzing Quetlzcoatl as man and god.

title: Introduction to the Phoenicians
description: Students learn about the Phoenicians with a focus on their boats, trade routes, and the products traded in the ancient world.

title: Phoenician Test
description: With this test, students demonstrate their knowledge of important places and trade routes in the Mediterranean and define significant concepts related to the topic.

title: Phoenician Mariner’s Log
description: Students write an imaginary journal or log of a Phoenician mariner. They include at least six entries, a map of the journey, a drawing of their sailing ships, and a Phoenician bill of sale, using the Phoenician alphabet.

title: Introduction to the Ancient Hebrews
description: Students read, take notes on, and discuss Judaism, incorporating information gained in class and from reading a variety of sources.

title: The Story of the Hebrew Prophets
description: Students read, take notes on, and discuss passages from the Old Testament about the prophets Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses, and David.

title: Flood Stories From the Ancient World
description: Students use a Venn diagram to compare and contrast Biblical and Sumerian flood stories in preparation for writing an essay in World Languages and Literature: English.

title: Ancient Hebrew Test
description: In this assessment, students demonstrate their ability to define key terms, identify important figures, and write two brief paragraphs related to the ancient Hebrews.

title: Ancient Hebrews Group Project
description: Students collaborate to research and present an oral and visual report on the ancient Hebrews. They speak from an outline, cite sources, and create a visual, such as a poster or slideshow to support the ideas in their presentation.

title: Reflection on the Olmecs, Phoenicians, and Hebrews
description: Students reflect on similarities and differences among the three cultures studied—the Olmec, Phoenician, and Hebrew—and consider the different patterns of movement of the Phoenician traders and the Hebrew tribes.

title: The Greek Pantheon of Gods and Goddesses
description: Students research, discuss, and give short oral presentations on the major Greek gods and goddesses.

title: Ancient Greek Art and Architecture
description: Students examine, discuss, analyze, evaluate, and write about Greek art and architecture, viewed both on the Internet and on a field trip to a local museum or gallery.

title: Pre-Socratic Scholar
description: Students are introduced to scholars Thales, Anaximander, Anaximenes, Pythagoras, Heraclitus, and Democritus, whose activities in philosophy, natural history, science, and mathematics were key factors in the transition in ancient Greece between an epic/mythical dimension and a spirit of scientific inquiry.

title: Dialogue with Pythagoras
description: Students explore the ideas of Pythagoras through written dialogue.

title: Ancient Greece Oral Presentation
description: In pairs or groups of three, students research a topic relevant to ancient Greece. They prepare an oral presentation based on their findings, with supporting visuals.

title: Confucius, Lao-Tzu, and the Buddha
description: Students read and research texts on ancient China and India, particularly the writings of and about Confucius, Lao-Tzu, and the Buddha.

title: Chinese Culture Group Presentation
description: Working in groups of three, students select one topic related to ancient China, research it, and make a group oral presentation about their findings.

title: Confucius Meets Lao-Tzu
description: Working in pairs, students envision an encounter between Confucius and Lao-Tzu, creating an imaginary dialogue between them that reveals the students’ understanding of the views and character of each philosopher.

title: Making a Mandala
description: Students analyze mandalas and their connection to Buddhist practice, and then create their own.

title: Feng Shui Activity
description: Students analyze the 3,000-year-old system of feng shui and discuss its connection to the Taoist vision of nature. They then apply the tenets of feng shui to their own bedrooms.

title: Ancient China Test
description: The test assesses students' understanding of the origins of the three philosophical schools of thought—Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism—and their basic codes of belief.

title: Background to the U.S. Civil War
description: Students review the American Revolution and the United States’ founding documents, the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, analyzing and discussing how the institution of slavery conflicts with the ideals embedded in these documents.

title: Social and Economic Issues That Gave Rise to the U.S. Civil War
description: Students analyze the plantation economy that was based on the institution of slavery versus the subsistence farming and industrial economy prevalent in the north. Students examine the impact of the Louisiana Purchase on the United States as it provoked an important albeit divisive national debate on slavery.

title: Comparing Two Young Adult Novels of the U.S. Civil War
description: Students read and discuss two novels set in the Civil War era: one about an enslaved girl in the South and another about a factory worker in the North. They write an essay comparing the situations of these two young girls.

title: Visionaries and Prophets
description: Students examine the actions and legacies of William Lloyd Garrison, Harriett Tubman, Frederick Douglass, John Brown, and Abraham Lincoln.

title: Major People, Events, and Battles of the U.S. Civil War
description: Students focus on four battles: Antietam, Gettysburg, Vicksburg, and Sherman’s March to the Sea. They analyze how the Union victory at Antietam provided Lincoln with the political cover necessary to issue the Emancipation Proclamation. Students do further research on Lincoln, the impact of the Emancipation Proclamation, Jefferson Davis, Robert E. Lee, Ulysses S. Grant, and William Tecumseh Sherman.

title: U.S. Civil War Journal Project
description: Students research the Battle of Gettysburg, including historical documents and maps. They create a twelve-year-old witness to the events and write a journal of observations of the battle and of the dedication of the cemetery, when Lincoln made his Gettysburg Address.

title: Concepts of Beauty in Different Cultures: Greece and Japan
description: Students are introduced to the course and some basic principles of art criticism. They then read an excerpt from Stokstad’s and Cothren’s Art History and write an essay comparing and contrasting different concepts of beauty as seen in the Greek statue The Medici Venus and the Japanese artist Utamaro’s Ukiyo-e print Woman at the Height of Her Beauty.

title: Visual Analysis of Art Work
description: Students write a visual analysis of a single painting or sculpture, explaining how elements of art work together to create meaning.

title: Art and Connoisseurship: Goya’s Black Paintings
description: After viewing a presentation on Goya and the Black Paintings, students read an article that questions the paintings’ authenticity. Students then respond to the article by evaluating the author’s argument and asserting their own opinion in an essay.

title: Contemporary Chinese and Korean Art
description: Students explore styles and themes in contemporary Chinese and Korean art, comparing and contrasting the art of Cai Guo Qiang and Do Ho Suh using the art history vocabulary learned in class.

title: Paleolithic Art
description: Students view the presentation “Paleolithic Imagery” and learn terms associated with Ice Age art. They read and write a reflection on an excerpt from Clayton Eshleman’s book, Juniper Fuse, examining the shift of consciousness from animal to human.

title: Mesopotamia and Egypt
description: Students compare and contrast the art and architecture of Mesopotamia and Egypt, and discuss the cultural influence of the two on later civilizations.

title: The Parthenon
description: Students examine the architecture and art connected with the Acropolis, concentrating closely on the Parthenon, to gain an understanding of the terms and characteristics of classical Greek art.

title: Classicism and “the Greek Revolution”
description: Students examine the terms, artists, architecture, and works of art connected with classicism and Greece’s fifth-century “revolution,” further analyzing connotations of the term “classical” and its appropriation by the Nazis in the 20th century and its use in contemporary culture.

title: Rodin and Classical Greece
description: Students examine the influence of the classical, particularly the work of Polyclitus and Praxiteles, on the work of Auguste Rodin, concluding their study by writing a reflective analysis discussing how Rodin transformed classical elements into his own unique vision.

title: Ancient and Contemporary Chinese Art
description: Students examine the social and moral order in third-century China as reflected in the recently discovered tomb of China’s first emperor Qin Shi Huangdi, who died in 210 BCE. They also look at contemporary Chinese artist Ai Weiwei and the relationship of his work to China’s past traditions.

title: Heidegger’s Journey Essay
description: Students read Paul Duro’s essay “The Return to the Origin: Heidegger’s Journey to Greece” (2007) and write an essay about the encounter with the classical Greek art and architecture expressed in the writings of Freud, Stendhal, and Heidegger

title: Religious Structures of the Algebraic Medieval—The Cathedral and the Mosque
description: Students view a presentation introducing them to the art and architecture of medieval Europe and Islam. They specifically investigate the role of religion in medieval society and how it is manifested in the art and religious structures of the period.

title: Oral Presentation of the Algebraic Mentality
description: Working in teams of two, students plan and then give oral presentations in which they visually analyze works of art, discuss iconography in its historical context, and explain how the works of art represent aspects of the Algebraic Mentality.

title: Shirin Neshat: Body and Text
description: Students view a presentation on the work of contemporary Iranian artist Shirin Neshat, thereby prompting discussion of her use of the traditional Islamic art form of calligraphy for feminist, political, and artistic purposes.

title: The Proto- and Early Renaissance in Italy
description: Students examine, analyze, and discuss art from the Proto-Renaissance and early Renaissance time periods. They apply concepts from Wölfflin’s Principles of Art History to what they view.

title: Gericault and Romanticism
description: Students examine the work of Theodore Gericault and the “qualities” of Romanticism. They focus in particular on Gericault’s The Raft of the Medusa.

title: Art History Term Paper on the Dynamical Mentality
description: Selecting either a pair of paintings to compare or one painting to focus on in-depth, students compose a visual analysis of their chosen art in a five-page paper with a complete MLA bibliography.

title: Art History Exam
description: Students take an exam consisting of four essay questions. Each essay includes a comparison and contrast of two images. Students are expected to apply the art history terms they have learned throughout the unit.

title: The Modernist Avant-Garde: Dada and Surrealism
description: Students explore Dada and surrealism as precursors to and influences on art produced between 1948 and the present.

title: Concepts of Aura and Originality
description: Students respond to Walter Benjamin’s “The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction” in an essay addressing issues of originality and the “aura.”

title: The Influence of the Atomic Bomb
description: Students examine paintings, photographs, and sculptures influenced by the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. They also learn of the crowning of Miss Atomic Bomb and other United States publicity campaigns that contributed to Cold War ideology.

title: The Heroic and the Sublime: Abstract Expressionism
description: Students examine the paintings of Pollock, de Kooning, Dubuffet, and Rothko as they recognize post-war issues of alienation in consumer society.

title: Proto-Pop Art and the Role of the Spectator
description: Students examine the works of proto-pop artists Rauschenberg and Johns, recognizing the shift away from abstract expressionism. They also reflect on Leo Steinberg’s essay, “Contemporary Art and the Plight of Its Public.”

title: Joseph Cornell
description: Students explore this maker of enigmatic boxes and consider his connections to both surrealism and pop art.

title: Concepts of Realism in Robert Frank
description: Students consider and write about the works of Robert Frank and Diane Arbus, analyzing new techniques and functions of documentary photography in 1950s and 1960s America.

title: Minimalism and Earth Art
description: Students examine two important art movements of the 1960s and 1970s—minimalism and Earth art.

title: Oral Presentation and Research Paper
description: Two students collaborate to present a 10-minute comparison of works by two artists or multiple works by one artist. Then, working individually, each student develops his or her own four-page research paper based on the oral presentation.

title: Art History Exam
description: Students take an exam consisting of five essay questions. Each question asks students to compare and contrast two images. Students are expected to apply the art history terms they have learned throughout the unit.

title: Al-Khwarizmi: The Father of Algebra
description: Students discuss al-Khwarizmi’s general contributions to mathematics during the Golden Age of Islam. In the process, they model and solve a simple problem to consider the nature of algebraic thought and define “algebra.” Students compare their model equation to the six linear and quadratic equations that al-Khwarizmi described as fundamental to algebra. They then complete a creative research project to present details about al-Khwarizmi’s life and work in the form of election campaign material for a position at the House of Wisdom.

title: Start of the Year Review
description: Students review and assess their prior knowledge of algebraic expressions and operations with real numbers to gauge their preparedness for upcoming work. As an opening activity, students create a scenario to match a given numerical expression and discuss the significance of rearranging terms and replacing a known amount with a variable. Students then solve and discuss diagnostic review problems: they use the order of operations to combine like terms and simplify numerical and algebraic expressions, write algebraic and verbal expressions to model given situations, work with integers, exponents, and radicals, estimate square roots, and convert to and from scientific notation.

title: Equations in One Variable and Their Solutions
description: Students practice writing and solving one- and two-step equations with one variable, as they review the difference between an algebraic expression and an algebraic equation, the properties of equality, and inverse operations. They also translate example problems from al-Khwarizmi and discuss the influence of geometry on early algebra in regard to the historical representation of numbers as magnitudes, the related concepts of congruence and equality, and the general aversion to negative numbers outside of China and India.

title: Quiz: Solving Simple Equations
description: Students demonstrate their ability to solve simple equations in one variable. Both one- and two-step equations are included, and students work with positive and negative rational numbers. They also write and solve equations for two word problems involving real-world scenarios.

title: Simplifying Algebraic Expressions
description: Students develop their ability to simplify polynomials by identifying and then combining like terms using the distributive and other number properties. Students discuss a geometric representation of the distributive property from Euclid’s Elements and write an equation to represent the property algebraically. They then practice applying the property to algebraic expressions with negative numbers, distributing negative coefficients through parentheses, and keeping track of the sign of each term.

title: Solving Multi-Step Equations
description: Students now progress to solving equations in one variable with multiple operations, variables on both sides of the equation, and fractions. Through this investigation, students recognize that there are many ways to solve problems, but different approaches can make the process simpler. They solve an ancient Egyptian problem to compare an algebraic approach to equations with fractions to an arithmetic method of adjusting estimates. Students also reason about equations as true and false statements about the equivalence of expressions and discover that equations may have one solution, many solutions, or no solution.

title: Quiz: Multi-Step Equations
description: This short quiz assesses students’ ability to solve equations with variables on both sides of the equal sign, negative and decimal coefficients, and fractional terms. Students also write and solve a multi-step equation modeling a real-world problem scenario.

title: Literal Equations and Formulas
description: Students apply what they have learned to transform and solve literal equations for variables, and they use formulas to solve problems in the context of geometry, science, and other real-world situations. They also learn how to use a graphing calculator to evaluate formulas and literal equations. Students then revisit al-Khwarizmi’s six fundamental equations in order to preview their future investigations of quadratic equations and connect algorithmic methods for solving problems for the development of general mathematical equations and formulas.

title: Quiz: Solving Equations
description: Students demonstrate their ability to solve multi-step equations with parentheses and variables on both sides of the equation. They recognize when an equation has no solution and an infinite number of solutions, and they also write and solve equations representing a geometric figure and real-world situations.

title: Proportional Reasoning: Islamic Inheritance Ratios and Percent
description: Students develop their understanding of proportionality by reasoning about ratios used with Islamic inheritances and different applications of percent. They discuss the fact that proportional relationships involve relative, multiplicative comparisons, and they transform the percent proportion and equation as needed to solve percent problems. Students also recognize that the percent rate is a constant of proportionality relating the part and whole amounts.

title: Direct Variation Investigation
description: Students now connect the concepts of proportionality and linearity as they investigate the directly proportional relationship between an object and its shadow. They collect their own measurement data outdoors, make a scatter plot, and then use their graphing calculators to find the equation and graph a line of best fit. Students use these representations of their data to discuss the meaning of direct variation and begin to review their prior knowledge of linear equations, the graphs of lines, and slope.

title: Test: Solving Equations
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of all concepts reviewed and introduced thus far. They solve multi-step equations in one variable with positive and negative rational numbers and variables on both sides of the equation, and they solve literal equations for specific variables. Students also write and solve equations for two real-world scenarios and explain whether a table of values represents a direct variation relationship.

title: Coordinate Geometry: Applying Algebra to Geometry
description: To prepare for their study of linear equations and lines, students review the features and use of the Cartesian coordinate system to calculate the slope of lines and distances between points. They analyze the segments given by points and investigate how the slope, length, and midpoint formulas are derived from the characteristics of right triangles and the Pythagorean theorem. Students then classify polygons drawn on the coordinate plane using quantitative measures of side lengths, slopes of parallel and perpendicular sides, and their prior knowledge of geometric figures.

title: Quiz: Coordinate Geometry
description: For this quiz, students are given coordinates for the vertices of two quadrilaterals. They quantitatively prove that the figures are a rhombus and a rectangle, and they show their work and explain their reasoning in words.

title: Linear Functions
description: Students discuss the concept of functions and relate the general shape of various function graphs to the degree of their corresponding equation. They then draw on their understanding of lines on the coordinate plane to consider how both lines and linear equations represent a specific type of functional relationship. Students compare different representations of linear functions to discuss the relationships between solutions to linear equations, slope, and graphs of lines and review their prior knowledge of the slope-intercept form of linear equations.

title: Linear Equations, Slope, and Points on a Line
description: Students now investigate how they can manipulate and write linear equations to easily graph lines using the slope and a point on the line. They use given standard-form equations and coordinates of points to write and graph equations of lines in slope-intercept and point-slope form. Students then apply what they learned to write the equations of lines that are parallel or perpendicular to given lines and pass through a given point. Throughout this learning experience, students reflect on the following questions: Why are there multiple ways to write the equation for a line? Why is it possible to manipulate equations in this way? What information is needed to graph linear equations?

title: Quiz: Linear Equations and Lines
description: This quiz assesses students’ ability to use the slope-intercept and point-slope forms of equations to both graph lines and represent given graphs. Students also rewrite slope-intercept equations to change them into point-slope form, and they write equations for lines that are parallel and perpendicular to another line.

title: Investigating Intercepts of Lines
description: Students learn how to find the x- and y-intercepts of a line algebraically using any form of a linear equation. They also use their graphing calculators to observe how changing the value of b in a slope-intercept equation translates the graph of the original line. Throughout this learning experience, students consider the following questions: Does every line have both an x-intercept and y-intercept? Why is the y-intercept usually used to graph a line instead of the x-intercept?

title: Graphing Calculator Review: Linear Equations and Lines
description: Students work with a partner to solve problems using their graphing calculators and review the following concepts and skills: identifying and analyzing linear functions, constants of variation and slope, and the relationship between lines and solutions to linear equations, and writing and graphing linear equations for specified or given lines. Students then discuss how they used the calculator for specific tasks and collaboratively revise the class graphing calculator guide to address additional topics and calculator functions.

title: Quiz: Linear Equations with Calculator
description: Students are allowed to use their calculators for this quiz. They demonstrate their understanding of the same concepts addressed in the Linear Equations and Lines Quiz, in addition to identifying the x- and y-intercepts of a line from a given equation. Students also write equations to model a real-world situation and the linear relationship given in a table of values.

title: Systems of Linear Equations and Their Graphs
description: Students begin to explore the concept of systems of linear equations in two variables and learn how to solve them graphically. They graph systems by hand as well as with their graphing calculators. Students also consider the fact that Babylonian mathematicians solved this type of problem long before the Cartesian coordinate system was invented. They begin thinking about the limitations to solving by graphing and other possible solution methods.

title: Solving Systems of Equations Algebraically
description: Students learn how to solve systems of linear equations in two variables using the substitution and elimination methods. They focus on investigating one method at a time and then compare methods to consider how they can choose the best approach for solving a system. Throughout this learning experience, students revisit problems they previously solved by graphing and solving historical problems from Babylonian and Chinese sources. This approach reinforces their understanding that many ancient civilizations explored systems of equations. If time allows, students may also investigate the use of matrices to solve systems of equations, in the manner of ancient Chinese mathematicians.

title: Quiz: Systems of Equations
description: Students demonstrate their ability to solve systems by graphing and substituting for one variable and their ability to write and solve systems for situations given in word problems. They also determine whether a given ordered pair is a solution to a system of equations.

title: Modeling with Systems of Equations
description: Students review and apply what they have learned about systems of linear equations in two variables by writing and solving systems to model real-world and mathematical problem situations. They work collaboratively and independently in class to allow time for the instructor to review past assignments and quizzes from the entire unit with students individually.

title: Test: Linear Relationships
description: The second unit test assesses students’ understanding of linear relationships between two variables—their algebraic and graphical representations, systems of linear equations, and how linear equations may be used to model real-world situations. About half the questions allow students to choose what form of a linear equation or solution method they may use.

title: Islamic Art and Geometry
description: Students explore the mathematics underlying Islamic geometric designs and decorative patterns. They discuss how geometric figures, proportions, and spatial relationships were used to express abstract, spiritual concepts, and then create their own geometric design using Geometer’s Sketchpad®. This investigation connects to their previous studies in Visual Arts, and may be conducted at any point during the unit.

title: Rose Windows, Number Symbolism, and Geometry
description: Students investigate the geometry of European rose windows to learn about medieval number symbolism, and then apply these concepts to create a personal rose window design with Geometer’s Sketchpad®. This learning experience integrates with their studies of Gothic architecture in Cultural History and Visual Arts, and is recommended to follow the Islamic Art and Geometry exploration.

title: Linear Inequalities in One Variable
description: In this learning experience, students apply their understanding of simple linear equations in one variable to discuss the properties of inequality, represent inequalities verbally, algebraically, and graphically on number lines, and solve and verify the solutions to inequalities. They begin by writing and translating simple statements of inequality, and move to compound inequalities and solving multi-step inequalities involving negative numbers. Students also learn how to use their graphing calculator to solve inequalities.

title: Linear Inequalities in Two Variables
description: Students now transition from inequalities in one variable on a number line to inequalities in two variables and solution sets that include a half-plane. They apply their prior knowledge of linear equations to solving linear inequalities by graphing by hand and with their graphing calculators.

title: Quizzes: Concept Check
description: Throughout the unit, students take short quizzes to monitor their skill development and assess their understanding of each major concept before the summative test on that topic. The provided quizzes address linear inequalities in one variable, systems of linear inequalities in two variables, absolute value equations, probability of single and independent events, probability of dependent events and the concept of replacement, and operations with monomials

title: Systems of Linear Inequalities and Their Graphs
description: In this learning experience, students apply their knowledge of linear inequalities in two variables and systems of linear equations to solve systems of linear inequalities by graphing. They conduct a cooperative learning activity involving solution regions in the shapes of polygons, to develop the understanding that the solution of a system of linear inequalities is the intersection of the solutions for each inequality. Students then write and solve systems modeling real-world and mathematical problem situations.

title: Absolute Value Equations
description: Students learn how to solve absolute value equations in one variable algebraically, by reasoning about the meaning of absolute value and the necessity of solving for two cases (positive and negative values). They also consider the historical significance of this concept and notation. Throughout this learning experience students use number lines to reinforce their understanding of the solution process, and they check their answers using substitution.

title: Absolute Value Inequalities
description: Students apply their understanding of absolute values to reason about and solve absolute value inequalities in one variable. They discuss the nature of their solutions, investigate the solution process for each general case of less than and greater than inequalities, and work up to solving multi-step inequalities. As with absolute value equations, students sketch and label number lines by hand to represent solutions.

title: Absolute Value Functions
description: Students examine the features of absolute value functions represented with equations in two variables and coordinate graphs. They generate tables of values to sketch the graphs of absolute value equations, and they identify and interpret the main characteristics of the graphs. Students then explore the correlation between absolute value equations and graphs. They graph functions using the linear equations for positive and negative cases, as well as using transformations of the parent function.

title: Inequalities and Absolute Values Test
description: This test assesses students’ ability to solve and graph linear inequalities and absolute value equations in one and two variables. Students also write an absolute value inequality to represent a given real-world situation. They then write a system of linear inequalities for a real-world scenario, solve by graphing, and explain the meaning of one point from the solution region.

title: Probability and Odds Review
description: In grade 7, students explored the concepts of experimental and theoretical probability. They now review and build their understanding of these and other basic probability concepts, as they reason about and count possible outcomes to find the probabilities of simple and compound events. Students also discuss the relationship between the probabilities and odds of events and use their graphing calculators to simulate probability experiments and compare experimental and theoretical probabilities. Throughout this learning experience, students consider: How accurately can we quantitatively predict the occurrence of future events?

title: Probability of Independent and Dependent Events
description: Students reason about the probability of compound events and calculate the probability of independent and dependent events with and without replacement. Throughout this learning experience, a type of probability scenario is introduced and the reasoning process is modeled and discussed as a class; students then work in collaborative groups to solve a variety of problems based on the same principle and discuss the considerations for each situation. Special attention is given to using probability tree diagrams and Venn diagrams to represent sample spaces and analyze the relationships between sets of outcomes.

title: The Counting Principle and Pascal’s Triangle
description: In this learning experience, students apply their understanding of independent and dependent events to understand how the fundamental counting principle can help them solve probability problems with greater numbers of events and possible outcomes. They are also introduced the use of Pascal’s Triangle in probability and learn that these number patterns were studied by Islamic mathematicians during the time period under study.

title: Test: Probability
description: This test assesses students’ cumulative understanding of the main probability concepts investigated in this unit, focusing on the probability of compound events. Students find the probability of independent and dependent events, convert between given probabilities and odds, and apply the fundamental counting principle to find the total number of possible outcomes and combinations.

title: Quiz: Exponents and Order of Operations Review
description: Students take this quiz to demonstrate their prior knowledge of the notation for powers and basic understanding of operations with exponents. Students simplify powers, including a power of a negative number, and apply the order of operations to evaluate numerical and algebraic expressions including exponents.

title: Powers and Products of Monomials
description: Students review the laws of exponents and investigate how they translate to operations with monomial exponential expressions. For this learning experience, students focus on applying the meaning of exponents to raise monomials to a power and multiply monomials. They also discuss the significance of the algebraic conception of powers that was introduced about two hundred years after al-Khwarizmi by the mathematician Abu Bakr al-Karaji (ca. 953–1029).

title: Quotients of Monomials and Negative Exponents
description: In this learning experience, students apply the definition of powers to understand the division of monomial exponential expressions, interpret negative exponents that arise naturally from division, and simplify quotients involving negative exponents. They also relate this topic to the continuing development of algebra in history, as they learn that the mathematician Ibn Yahya al-Maghribi al-Samaw’al (ca. 1130–1180) incorporated negative numbers into operations with algebraic expressions.

title: Test: Exponents
description: Students are assessed on their understanding of the laws of exponents and ability to apply them to simplify powers, products, and quotients of monomial exponential expressions. Students simplify numerical and algebraic exponential expressions, including monomials with coefficients and negative exponents.

title: Scientific Notation
description: Students apply their knowledge of exponential expressions to write, translate, and operate with numbers in scientific notation. They also learn how to use the EE function of their graphing calculator.

title: Exponential Functions
description: Students explore the general characteristics of exponential functions and compare the graphs of exponential functions with different bases. They generate tables of values to sketch graphs and then learn how to use their graphing calculators to graph exponential functions and solve real-world application problems.

title: Test: Monomials and Exponential Functions
description: This final test for the unit provides a second assessment of students’ ability to perform different operations on monomials. Students demonstrate their understanding of scientific notation, exponential functions and graphs, and their real-world applications. Students also sketch the graphs of two exponential functions and explain why the different bases result in different graphs.

title: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
description: In Unit 1, students learned how to simplify polynomials in one variable by combining like terms. They now formally define polynomials, apply their prior knowledge to add and subtract polynomials, and discuss how those skills will help them to ultimately solve equations with polynomials. Students also consider their learning goals for this unit and briefly explore how polynomial functions compare to linear and exponential functions.

title: Multiplying Polynomials and Finding Special Products
description: Students learn how to multiply polynomials, working up from multiplying a monomial and polynomial, to two binomials, to two polynomials of any size. Major emphasis is placed on reasoning about the Distributive Property and the FOIL method for multiplying binomials, using area models or tables of partial products. Students also develop and use formulas for special products, such as perfect-square trinomials.

title: Binomial Expansions and Pascal’s Triangle
description: Students have explored how they can use Pascal’s triangle to count combinations of objects and determine the probabilities of binomial events. They now generate the triangle themselves and connect the number patterns to the coefficients of the expansion of (a + b)n, as an informal introduction to the binomial theorem.
