Students also consider the efficiency of that approach to writing expanded powers of binomials and discuss the historical development of the general rule for the binomial theorem.

title: Quiz: Binomials
description: This quiz assesses students’ ability to explain and use the FOIL method for multiplying binomials, to apply Pascal’s triangle to binomial expansions, and to find the area of quadrilaterals with dimensions given by binomials. Several problems involve special products—the square of a binomial and the difference of two squares—that students may find using any method.

title: Factoring Polynomials
description: Students apply their knowledge of polynomial multiplication and the Distributive Property to the reverse process of factoring, gradually focusing on factoring quadratic polynomials (trinomials). Students investigate different factoring methods in turn and develop a sense of which initial method appears most appropriate, based on the polynomial. They learn to factor by using the greatest common factor, grouping, special products, and trial and error. Throughout this extended learning experience, geometric representations are emphasized with the use of area models and algebra tiles.

title: Quiz: Factoring
description: Students demonstrate their ability to factor polynomials (mainly trinomials) using any method. The problems progress in difficulty, to include polynomials with leading coefficients greater than 1 and terms with two variables.

title: Test: Polynomials
description: Students are assessed on their ability to perform all polynomial operations introduced thus far: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and factoring. Students also expand a power of a binomial and solve two problems relating a product and factors to the area of a rectangle.

title: Solving Quadratic Equations by Extracting Roots and Factoring
description: Students now apply their understanding of manipulating equations and factoring to solve quadratic equations. They compare al-Khwarizmi’s fundamental forms of equations to the modern, standard form of a quadratic and discuss the relationship between the greatest exponent in a polynomial equation and the number of its solutions. Students then investigate how they may solve quadratic equations by extracting roots or factoring and applying the zero-product property.

title: Quizzes: Quadratics
description: Throughout their studies of quadratic equations and their graphs, students take several quizzes to help monitor their skill development and understanding of concepts as they are introduced. The quizzes assess students’ ability to solve quadratic equations using specified methods and the method of their own choice. Students also demonstrate their understanding of the relationship between quadratic equations and their graphs as well as their ability to solve application problems in which quadratic equations model real-world situations.

title: Al-Khwarizmi and Completing the Square
description: Students learn the classic method for solving quadratic equations, particularly those that cannot be factored: completing the square. They investigate that technique algebraically and with geometric models, use it to solve equations, and compare al-Khwarizmi’s algorithms with the modern approach that allows for negative roots. Students then complete the square in order to rewrite standard-form equations in vertex form, which they will connect to the graphs of quadratic equations in the next learning experience.

title: Graphing Quadratic Equations
description: With this learning experience, students switch from rectangular representations of quadratic equations to parabolas as they graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane. They identify and relate the main features of parabolas to quadratic equations in standard and vertex forms and learn how to graph from those equations. Students also use their graphing calculators and online graphing tools to investigate transformations of the parent quadratic function represented graphically and symbolically with equations in vertex form.

title: Using the Quadratic Formula
description: Students investigate how they can use the quadratic formula to identify whether an equation in standard form has any real-number solutions (using the discriminant) and is factorable and they calculate those solutions for equations that cannot be factored. They are then introduced to complex solutions and solve geometric and other word problems involving quadratic relationships. Students also discuss the use of quadratic equations as simplified models of physical situations, and they interpret coordinate graphs and solutions within those contexts.

title: Quadratic Inequalities
description: In this learning experience, students apply their understanding of linear inequalities and the general characteristics of parabolas to solve and graph quadratic inequalities. As with linear inequalities, students begin by reasoning about quadratic inequalities in one variable before addressing quadratic inequalities in two variables. Students also learn how they may use their graphing calculators to help with solving and sketching graphs by hand.

title: Test: Quadratic Equations
description: For this test, students demonstrate their ability to solve quadratic equations using both specified methods and those they judge to be most appropriate. They also write standard-form equations in vertex form, calculate and interpret the discriminant, and solve an application problem. Students then sketch the graphs of several quadratic equations and one quadratic inequality.

title: The Great Depression
description: Students apply their understanding of numerical patterns to their Cultural History studies of the Great Depression in American history. Students research and debate the economic causes and effects of the Great Depression, comparing economic statistics from that era to those for the Recession of 2008. They also investigate the concept of inflation, using anecdotal information and other research to track and analyze price changes in consumer products over time.

title: Rational Expressions and Functions
description: Students have previously explored the addition, subtraction, and multiplication of polynomials. They are now introduced to rational expressions and the concept that a polynomial can also be divided by another polynomial. They make comparisons to fractions as they identify values of the variable for which a rational expression is undefined, and they simplify and evaluate rational expressions. Students also graph rational functions and relate the restrictions on the domain to the vertical asymptotes shown on the graph.

title: Operations with Rational Expressions
description: Students apply their prior knowledge of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions. Throughout this learning experience, students write a general rule in symbolic notation for each operation to help them think conceptually about their work and reinforce the understanding that they are following the same rules as when operating with fractions. Students also consider how that practice relates to al-Khwarizmi’s work with quadratic equations and they reflect on his contributions to the development of algebra.

title: Quiz: Rational Expressions
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of all operations with rational expressions. They state the excluded values for rational expressions and simplify to write the expressions in simplest form. Students then multiply, divide, add, and subtract rational expressions and are required to find and use common denominators for the last two operations.

title: Solving and Graphing Rational Equations
description: Students learn how to solve rational equations by using the common denominator method or cross multiplication, relating those techniques to their previous work with fractions and proportions. Special attention is given to the concept of extraneous solutions and the importance of checking solutions to ensure they do not result in division by zero. Students also investigate how to identify solutions of rational equations by graphing.

title: Operations with Radicals
description: Students apply the multiplication and division properties of radicals and exponents to simplify and operate on radical expressions, working primarily with square roots. They evaluate and estimate square roots, write square roots in simplest radical form, and then learn how to perform all four operations with radicals.

title: Quiz: Radicals
description: Students demonstrate their conceptual understanding of square roots as well as their ability to simplify square roots of numbers and algebraic expressions. Given numbers and radicals with numerical radicands, students identify positive and negative square roots, principal roots, cube roots, and fourth roots, and they state whether a given square root is a rational or irrational number.

title: Solving Radical Equations
description: Students apply their understanding of the relationship between squares and square roots to solve radical equations containing square roots, continuing to develop their ability to solve quadratic equations in the process. They also revisit the Pythagorean Theorem as they solve mathematical and real-world problems involving triangle measures.

title: Test: Radicals
description: The test consists of two parts, based on the allowed use of calculators. Part I is similar to the previous quiz on radicals. For Part II, students mentally estimate the value of square roots, write irrational roots in simplest radical form, and then use their calculators to provide approximate values. They also create a table of values and a graph for , solve radical equations involving square roots, and apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find missing side lengths in right triangles.

title: Unit and Year-End Cumulative Review
description: Students cooperatively solve problems to review all concepts and skills learned throughout the course as they consolidate and contextualize their knowledge and look for connections between topics. During this time, students also address their past work and outstanding questions with the instructor individually.

title: Test: Cumulative Final
description: This test assesses students’ understanding of the main concepts and skills investigated throughout the year. Unlike previous quizzes and tests, the problems are not grouped by topic or presented in any particular order; students are thus expected to be able to identify the nature of each problem and solve it without those contextual clues. Students have the opportunity to receive partial credit for incorrect answers, based on the work shown.

title: One Hand or Two Hands?
description: Students approach the unit theme of symbols by showing the numbers one through ten using their fingers and discussing whether they can count different things on one hand or if they need two hands. Students explore and count things in the classroom and make a class display for each number.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout the year, students use their journal to document their numerical discoveries and observations and practice the skills they are learning. The teacher regularly assesses the journal to identify any difficulties and note progress throughout the unit.

title: Everyday Numbers
description: As students begin exploring signs and symbols in cultural history, they similarly look at pictures of numerals found in different real-world contexts and share their ideas about what they represent or how they are used. They begin thinking about the many numbers they encounter in daily life and sketch places on campus where they see numbers or people using numbers.

title: Our Number Books: Starting with Zero
description: This learning experience begins by reviewing the number names and meanings from zero through twelve and how to illustrate the meaning of these numbers with a simple picture book. Students then begin to use mathematical language such as more than andless than and consider different ways to represent the same number. They begin creating their number books.

title: Writing Numerals and Counting Up from Left to Right
description: Students distinguish left and right as they form digits correctly and read or write numbers with two or more digits. They discuss how the counting sequence of numbers increases to the right when looking at a horizontal ruler or playing games. To reinforce their understanding, students also dance a version of the Hokey Pokey, adding steps that incorporate numbers.

title: Counting One by One
description: Students now count collections of 12 or fewer items by touching or moving each, naming how many they have altogether, and recording this amount with the correct numeral.

title: The Teens to Twenty
description: After using songs and games to memorize the sequence of number names and numerals from 13 to 20, students represent the numbers using their fingers as well as double ten frames. Students learn to identify odd and even numbers visually from two-row arrays and begin to associate each type of number with alternating single-digit numbers.

title: Stones and Bowls, Tally Marks, and Units of Five
description: Students show numbers greater than 10 with their fingers, stones and ten stones, and tally marks.

title: Symbols with Geometric Shapes
description: To prepare for creating their treasure maps in Cultural History, students learn to identify and create common two-dimensional shapes using a variety of materials. In addition to describing their relative locations and sizes, students use the numbers and mathematical language they have learned to describe their shapes and then add shapes to relevant pages in their number books.

title: How Many Shapes?
description: Students count aloud to find the total number of geometric pattern blocks in a mixed row. They rearrange the same blocks and count them again in the correct sequence to end with the same number, rather than associating each shape with its previous ordinal number.

title: A Story about Numbers
description: Students write and present a story that features numbers. While telling the story to the class, they display a poster they made with these numbers written in numerals, modeled with a drawing, and illustrated to represent the significance of the numbers to the story.

title: Beginnings with Numbers
description: Students open the unit with a countdown to the official start and an introduction to a hundred chart. They share their observations, noting “beginnings,” visual patterns, and the number names corresponding to the numerals. There is a strong emphasis on counting by tens.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students continue to document their numerical discoveries, observations, and learning in their journals. The teacher regularly reviews the entries to assess each student’s thought processes, understanding of new concepts, and progress toward goals.

title: Conservation of Numbers and Change
description: Students use the seeds of the Coco-de-Mer (Lodoicea maldivica) palm tree to investigate a deceptively-simple property—the conservation of numbers—to address any misconceptions about what creates “more” or “less” of something. Pretending to be seeds, they plant themselves in different configurations and learn that the total number of seeds does not change. They model the same conclusion with connecting cubes.

title: Describing, Sorting, and Comparing
description: In this series of activities, students investigate how they can organize a set of objects and make them easier to find and count by making their own, smaller sets. Students collectively decide on an attribute and their rules for sorting then create a class list of comparative terms. During this learning experience, students work with rocks and bowls as a pre-soroban activity.

title: Repeating Patterns of Shapes
description: Students apply their new understanding of attributes to describe repeating patterns of geometric shapes and letters. To define a repeating pattern, students discuss rhythmic and rhyming patterns in music and poetry, as well as patterns of geometric shapes to help build their pattern recognition in different contexts. They find missing shapes, extend the pattern, and describe the rule for the pattern.

title: Growing Numbers
description: Students now compare consecutive whole numbers and identify the “plus one” pattern of counting numbers using examples drawn from their studies of seeds and plant growth and number lines. They describe and identify numbers based on clues involving “one more” or “one less.”

title: Numbers Inside Numbers
description: Students make connections to The Everything Seed creation myth from Cultural History as they explore the following essential question: How are numbers made up of other numbers? They extend their understanding of “one more” and “one less” to decompose numbers from 1 to 20 into pairs of addends.

title: Planning a Dream Garden
description: Imagining a garden with more than 4 types of plants and 20 plants altogether, students create posters of their dream gardens. They also explain how the combined numbers of each type of plant make up 20.

title: Comparing Lengths
description: Students now focus on change in measurable attributes, specifically length, as it relates to growth. They compare the length of objects in the room to a craft stick and collaboratively arrange these objects in order from shortest to longest. Students also use several other nonstandard units to measure the length of the same object, pondering how one object can have several different lengths. Finally, they measure the lengths of each dimension of a box using one of their units.

title: Comparing Mass
description: Students first compare the masses of objects by holding one in each hand and then move to balance scales and kitchen scales when presented with objects that are too close in weight to distinguish easily. They also make general comparisons and measure mass with nonstandard units to identify the heaviest and lightest objects. They pay special attention to the idea that “bigger” does not always signify “heavier.”

title: Baby Weight and Height Bar Graphs
description: Expanding on the Rice-and-Stocking Babies Integrated Project in Cultural History, students make baby dolls to match their own birth height and weight. They display the measures using bar graphs, which they use to compare the babies. After sorting the babies by various criteria, students create a collaborative timeline that shows important milestones in their lives.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Students continue to document their discoveries, observations, and learning in their mathematics journals. In this unit, students complement their daily weather observations in Cultural History by creating bar graphs and complete sentences to reinforce sequence and units of time. They also record journal entries related to their increased fluency with two-digit numbers.

title: Looking Forward to 100 Days
description: Students use manipulatives, such as base-ten blocks, hundred charts, and a Slavonic abacus to identify how many school days they have been in attendance thus far. Then they use a year-long school calendar to identify the date of the hundredth day of school. A celebration for the hundredth day of school is planned.

title: Hot, Cold, and In-Between Temperatures
description: Students develop their sense of temperature differences by relating them to everyday experiences and estimated heights of the bar on nondigital thermometers. Next, students discuss the use of thermometers to measure temperature and model temperatures using their bodies to show appropriate bar heights for different situations, seasons, and objects.

title: Ordinal Numbers and Positions in a Sequence
description: Students develop their understanding of the first ten ordinal numbers by learning their names, meanings (as distinct from cardinal numbers), and symbolic representations (1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and so on). Students investigate ordinal numbers as applied to physical positions and time.

title: Developing Fluency with Two-Digit Numbers
description: In this learning experience, students continue to develop their ability to identify, represent, and compare two-digit numbers up to 100. They use images, numerals, and manipulatives to model and represent numbers while solving riddles in the book Math for All Seasons.

title: Comparing and Ordering on Number Lines
description: Students create their own number lines from 0 to 20. They then play games to locate pairs of one- and two-digit numbers in this range and compare them using their relative distances from zero on the number line. As students continue to work towards fluently counting to 100, they also may extend their number lines by adding segments of tens. They use their number lines to demonstrate how their shadow lengths change over the course of a day, and they predict how it may change over the season.

title: Number Patterns and Sequences
description: With this learning experience, students demonstrate their recognition of numerals as they identify patterns, find missing numbers, and extend patterns. Students investigate repeating patterns as well as patterns of increasing and decreasing numbers and begin to discuss placevalue concepts such as why any two-digit whole number is greater than a one-digit whole number, and what each digit represents.

title: Winter by the Numbers
description: To conclude the unit, students use numbers to describe seasonal changes in winter, such as temperatures of true hibernating animals and migration destinations, as well as measuring current local temperatures. They also label winter months on a yearly calendar and incorporate collected data on the Cultural History mural.

title: Mathematics Journal
description: Throughout this unit and the year, students record their discoveries, drawings, observations, and reflections related to mathematical practices and individual learning experiences in their Mathematics journals. Entries in this unit include using and writing numbers from 0 to 20, fluently adding and subtracting amounts up to 5, using plus and minus signs to represent addition and subtraction, and explaining answers with illustrations and in their own words.

title: Signs of Spring Survey
description: Students take a nature walk to observe and take note of the seasonal changes taking place as spring approaches. Each student makes a chart with representative drawings that display signs of spring and conduct a survey among their classmates to find the favorite signs of spring of their peers. They use this collected data to create a living pictograph and then draw a pictograph and bar graph to represent the data.

title: Light: Adding and Subtracting with Earthworms
description: As students learn how worms are beneficial for soil and plants in Science and Cultural History, they also consider why earthworms live underground. In this learning experience, students observe how worms react to light, describe their movements in terms of addition and subtraction, and write and solve their own problems.

title: Water: Measuring Capacity
description: Students continue to learn about water by exploring capacity. They analyze containers and order them from least to greatest by capacity. Through hands-on investigations and demonstrations, they identify the capacities of each container using non-standard measuring tools.

title: Adding and Subtracting Volumes
description: Students fill two small rectangular boxes of different dimensions with cubes, which they use to investigate and then model how to find the total volume of the boxes as well as the difference in the volumes of the boxes.

title: Air: Two-Dimensional Shapes and Air Resistance
description: In this learning experience, students investigate and explore two-dimensional shapes and the relationship of these shapes to the force of air. They use their prior knowledge and new discoveries to create and explore a pinwheel and parachute.

title: Halves and Symmetry in Nature
description: This learning experience integrates with students’ nature studies in Science, particularly their observations of new leaves on trees and flowering plants. Students investigate the basic concept of unit fractions as equal parts of a whole and explore halves of shapes and lines of symmetry.

title: Shapes and Silhouettes
description: Students continue to develop the concept of two-dimensional shapes to create a silhouette image. Using tangrams, they then recreate a classmate’s silhouette image and discuss the process of recreating the silhouette images.

title: Names and Attributes of Three-Dimensional Shapes
description: In this learning experience, students learn to identify common three-dimensional shapes by their mathematical names as they describe, compare, and sort them by attributes.

title: Constructing Three-Dimensional Shapes
description: Students continue their study of three-dimensional shapes by creating them. They then use their created three-dimensional shapes to design and build a model of an animal. They present the animal creations and explain the reasons for choosing certain shapes for animal parts.

title: Numbers and Shapes
description: Students solve problems involving counting, addition, subtraction, sorting, and identifying shapes.

title: What Is Mass Media?
description: Students study the emergence of mass media and how media helps to facilitate large-scale democracies.

title: Media and Revolutions
description: Students study the role of media in revolutions from history and the world today.

title: Photography, Art, and the “Noble Savage”
description: Students consider how photography played an important role in underwriting slavery, colonialism, and the westward expansion of the United States into Native American territories through visual representations of the “noble savage.”

title: Photography and War
description: Students study the history of photojournalism in war and its impact today.

title: Photography
description: Students learn the technical and creative procedures of photography, darkroom processing, and Photoshop basics.

title: Visualizing Sapere Aude and the Rise of the Individual
description: Students produce a series of photographs and collages to visualize Kant’s motto, Sapere Aude, and the theme of “the rise of the individual.”

title: What is Media?
description: Students are introduced to media and concepts studied in grade 11, initially discuss how these media altered people’s conception of time and space, conveyed ideology, functioned as spectacle and commodity, and are introduced to some common terms.

title: Cognitive Bias and the Art of Persuasion
description: Students study the susceptibility of the mind to external influence and how advertising takes advantage of this fact. They examine different forms of cognitive and implicit bias and advertising techniques, laying the groundwork for the exploration of propaganda and ideology.

title: Ideology and Fascist Aesthetics
description: This learning experience introduces students to the concept of ideology, its development as a concept, and instances of the mobilization of ideology both extreme and subtle. The primary focus is on films with ideological messages, but special attention is paid to the various forms that fascist ideology took in the mid-20th century.

title: Origins of Film: Document and Spectacle
description: Students look at early innovations in moving images from Marey to Meliès, exploring how the new language of film was at first oriented toward a “cinema of attractions” and creating their own short videos.

title: They Live
description: The class explores what is known as “guerilla communication” or “culture jamming” and spectacles of dissent—work that alters or reveals something about a site through media intervention and produce their own works of détournement.

title: Global Media Issues
description: Students produce both a spoken rhetorical argument for their position on an issue of global significance and a media product that employs the persuasive techniques used in propaganda and advertising.

title: What Is Media?
description: Students recapitulate this essential question through interviews with K-11 students and begin setting up a blog for sharing their findings and experiences.

title: Post-War Media
description: Students study the evolution of media from 1948 to the present and get an overview of the field of media studies with a particular emphasis on the history and practice of radio.

title: Technological Determinism
description: Students are introduced to the concept of technological determinism and look back on the Spiral of Cultural History to see how media and technology have played important roles in major bifurcations. (Postman, Virilio)

title: Media Issues: Globalization
description: Students explore the work of Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky and Chinese filmmaker Jia Zhangke to look at some of the unintended consequences of globalization.

title: Noetic Polities
description: Students are introduced to the concept of “noetic polities” and explore how media technology might be driving the emergence of a global culture and how the “digital era” is not experienced the same everywhere. (Lanier)

title: Dystopias and Apocalypse: The Role of Technology at the End of the World
description: Students explore the role of technology in dystopic science fiction films and literature.

title: A Comparative Exploration of Communications Policy
description: Students study the history and current communications policy of nation-states such as the United States, China, Canada, a European nation and/or India, Mexico, or Nigeria (others can be substituted).

title: Media Debates—A Comparative Debate on Communications Policy
description: Students engage in formal debates about big-picture questions they have formulated about media and about communications policy from a comparative perspective.

title: Examining Science and the Role of Scientific Models
description: Students visit a science museum and analyze the exhibits and models to determine their effectiveness in communicating the concepts and scientific relationships being presented.

title: Habits of Mind Discussion
description: Students are challenged to answer the questions, What is science? and What do scientists do? Students summarize responses into categories that describe how science is empirical; science is open to revision; science is social; and science is explanatory and descriptive.

title: Silver and Shiny Laboratory Investigation
description: Students are challenged to collect empirical observations about the characteristic properties of a mystery substance.

title: Design a Research Strategy: Silver and Shiny
description: Students develop a research strategy to investigate the identity of the mystery material from the Silver and Shiny Laboratory Investigation based on the properties of the material.

title: Discussion: States of Matter
description: Students discuss states of matter and their relationship to molecular arrangements and energy, setting the stage for future discussions about phase changes and the kinetic molecular theory of matter.

title: Guided Investigation: What Is This Stuff?
description: Students work with a non-Newtonian fluid, which challenges the traditional model of states of matter, and analyze observed changes in this material as physical versus chemical.

title: Readings
description: Selected readings take the phenomenon the students observed in the previous laboratory investigations to a molecular level of understanding.

title: Guided Investigation: Red Sand vs. Beach Sand
description: Students observe and compare the properties of a treated hydrophobic sand to beach sand to help them conceptualize the terminology used to describe different types of mixtures and solutions.

title: Red Sand Investigation
description: Students conduct independent Internet searches to identify the hydrophobic sand based on its properties. They then design and conduct an independent inquiry into the “true” identity of the red, sand-like material. Students also share their results with the group through a focused discussion on the data that led to the “tipping point” in their research.

title: Demonstration: Water, Water, Everywhere
description: Students observe two similar-appearing liquids and document their observations when colored ice cubes are introduced into both liquids. They analyze the changes within the systems to determine the identity of the liquids.

title: Discussion: Patterns in the Data
description: Students’ discussions of laboratory investigation performed to date center on how each set of experiences demonstrated the importance of characteristic properties or behaviors in matter that acts as identifying features, and relate these topics to the grade 10 theme: The Rise of the Individual.

title: Guided Investigation: Polymers
description: Students examine two types of polymers, observe their behavior with water, and identify the changes they observe and classify and justify them as physical or chemical based on sound reasoning.

title: Guided Investigation: Wet Diaper
description: Students collect quantitative data describing the change in volume and mass of a diaper as water is added to it, until it reaches its saturation point. Students then construct a scatter plot to show the relationships among the data.

title: What Is Alchemy?
description: Students use the analytical skills developed in their Visual Arts studies to examine art that depicts alchemy through the ages, and they are challenged to appreciate the role that alchemy played in paving the way for modern-day science.

title: Alchemy and the Emergence of Modern Chemistry
description: Students research timelines and readings on the subject of alchemy and witness how societal and political pressures led alchemy to turn toward the occult in the 14th to 17th centuries.

title: Demonstration: Bobbers
description: Students observe how two cylindrical bobbers react to two water columns of different temperatures, and they then relate their observations to density changes as explained by the kinetic molecular theory of matter.

title: Guided Investigation: Crazy Mixtures
description: Students separate a mixture of colored beads by gradually changing the salinity of the salt solution the beads are mixed into and relate the buoyancy of the beads to the changing density of the salt solution.

title: Reading: Connecting Ideas
description: Students connect their laboratory experiences to the molecular theory while reading selections on bonding.

title: Group Discussion: Final Recapitulation
description: Through a group discussion, students respond to a series of guiding questions and scenarios that help them synthesize their learning in preparation for the final problem set.

title: Multiple Angles Analyses Problem Set
description: Students synthesize information from their investigations into a meaningful body of knowledge and place their own laboratory experiences into the historical framework, appreciating the power of empirical evidence as a means of shaping understanding.

title: Test: Multiple Angles Analyses Problem Set
description: Students demonstrate conceptual knowledge, and the application and synthesis of information, while completing an assessment on the topics covered in the Multiple Angles Analyses Problem Set.

title: Exploratory Lab: Introduction to Light and Optics
description: Students work in small groups to complete a series of hands-on investigations focused on building an understanding about the behavior of light (reflection, refraction, and diffraction) and its relationship to the field of optics.

title: Measuring Angles
description: Students review techniques for measuring angles in preparation for studying the law of reflection. They demonstrate the use of appropriate tools to measure angles and the use of proper terminology to discuss reflections.

title: Light Bounce
description: Students undertake a creative problem-solving experience requiring the application of the law of reflection. They first prove the law of reflection, and then they apply the law in an attempt to bounce a laser light around the room using mirrors.

title: Glossary: Light Concepts and Terms
description: Students explore the vocabulary and basic ideas in the field of optics. They learn about the wave-particle theory of light, the production of artificial light, and the formation of color. Students are introduced to scientists who studied the nature of light, including Newton, Young, Franklin, and Einstein.

title: Focusing the Light: Development of Optical Instruments
description: Students build image boxes, astronomical telescopes, and terrestrial telescopes, and they compare them in terms of image production through a series of field tests. This activity provides a historical bridge to the development of optical instruments during this time period.

title: Report: Focusing the Light: Development of Optical Instruments
description: Students write a short essay about their discoveries during the previous investigation. They answer questions on how types of lenses, concave and convex, affect image production.

title: Reading: Working with Waves
description: Students read “Working with Waves,” taken from Macaulay's The New Way Things Work, in order to visualize the behavior of light. They learn to describe light as an energy form, comparing it to sound waves and heat rays.

title: Exploratory Lab: Geometric Optics
description: Students explore light in a more quantitative manner, using an optics bench to explore how compound lens systems (convex) differ in image production. Through experimentation and discussion, the class discovers that geometric optics ignores the true electromagnetic wave nature of light and assumes instead that light travels in straight lines, called rays, that take paths through an optical instrument that can be calculated with simple rules to predict the location of an image.

title: Reading and Response Questions: Lenses
description: Students learn about virtual and real images through both a guided reading and examples given in the reading, as well as the conditions necessary for those images to form.

title: Film Presentation: Newton’s Dark Secrets
description: Students watch the film Newton’s Dark Secrets to foster an appreciation of Newton as a scientist, an alchemist, and an inventor. The film ties into this unit of study, as it describes his discovery of white light as being composed of all the colors in the visible spectrum, his exploration of the role of refraction and reflection in the development of telescopes, and his fascination with understanding how light moves through the eye.

title: Quiz: Light and Optics
description: Students complete a quiz that assesses understanding about the behavior of light and contributors to the advancement of our understanding of light through multiple-choice and short-answer problem-solving questions.

title: Exploratory Lab: Eyes on You
description: Students perform an investigation to understand the form and function of the eye. They begin the exploration with the external anatomy of their own eyes, by sketching their eye as viewed in a mirror or by closely examining a peer's eye.

title: A Bare Bodkin: Newton’s Studies of the Eye
description: Students read about Newton experimenting on his own eye with a needle. This reading links light studies to the anatomy of the eye and focuses on Newton's empirical work in this area. As a class, students read and discuss the article “Papers Reveal Newton's Religious Side,” which describes how Newton’s religious beliefs influenced his scientific journey.

title: Exploratory Lab: Comparative Eye Dissection
description: Students dissect pig, sheep, and cow eyes. Their dissections allow them to compare and contrast morphological differences and similarities among mammalian eyes, as well as begin to understand how the eye is designed to receive light.

title: Optics Lab: The Role Skulls Play in the Vision Process
description: Students perform a comparative investigation to consider the role that orbit position plays in the organism's perception of its world. They explore of a variety of skull specimens to identify orbit positions and determine whether the organisms see in stereovision or have greater peripheral vision.

title: Camera Dissection
description: Students dissect a single-use camera to compare the mechanics of the camera to the anatomy of the eye. These experiences further deepen their understanding of the mechanistic relationship that exists between organ systems and human-made tools and instruments, notably how form follows function.

title: Test: Optics
description: Students are tested on their understanding of the structure of the eye and the behavior of light through multiple-choice questions, short-response questions, and application questions.

title: Eye Model
description: Students build a three-dimensional model of the eye using representative materials that highlight the function of each eye structure. They also create a guide that accompanies the model to provide justification for the selected materials.

title: Light Receptors and Visual Perception
description: Students complete a series of activities that help develop an understanding of how the brain actively reconstructs information it receives from external stimuli. They discover that the brain connects incoming information to existing data based on prior experiences, and thus can lead to the development of altered realities in terms of visual perceptions.

title: Reading and Interpreting: Rods and Cones
description: Students learn about and discuss the importance of rods and cones in the ability to receive and perceive light. They also gain experience decoding scientific information from technical graphs and charts.

title: Reading: Seeing and Imagining
description: Students read “The Minds Eye” from The Mind’s Eye, where they explore the formation of mental imagery and through a written reflection relate the information to what they learned in their studies on visual perceptions.

title: Optics Research Project
description: Students perform research into any area of optics and present the information as a slide presentation, research essay, or digital movie.

title: Voltaire’s Letter on Newtonian Optics
description: Students read and discuss Letter XVI, Voltaire's views on Newton's work in the field of optics. As a class, they trace their knowledge pathway through the analysis of the reading and learn more about the historical figures of the scientific revolution.

title: Test: Optics Final
description: Students take a test to assess their understanding of the structures and function of the eye, the role of the brain in processing light images, and how these findings relate to the development of optical instruments. The test consists of multiple-choice questions, short-response questions, and application questions.

title: What Is Disease?
description: This initial learning experience is designed to allow students to first review the knowledge they have acquired from their studies of plagues in grades eight and nine. They then use reference sources to research definitions of the terms disease andpathogen. The same concepts are revisited at the end of the unit study.

title: Case Study: Hooke and van Leeuwenhoek: From Cells to Bacteria
description: Students examine the work of Robert Hooke and Antony van Leeuwenhoek, pioneers in the study of microbiology and histology. Students first brainstorm, and then research, how disease and the agents of disease may have been viewed prior to the development of microscopes. Through their research, students discover the role the Royal Society played in both men’s lives as a forum for sharing information, and the revolutionary nature of this field of inquiry during the late 17th and early 18th century.

title: What Are Germs?
description: Students first brainstorm responses to this question: “What are germs?” After discussing their ideas, students research germs from references provided by the teacher that give basic information and an all-encompassing definition for “things that make you sick.” The references also introduce bacteria, viruses, and fungi as agents of disease.

title: Discussion: What Characterizes a Living Organism?
description: Students brainstorm what it means to be a living organism. They then discuss the characteristics of living organisms and describe how their ideas are supported or challenged by the study of viruses and bacteria.

title: Reading: What Is Life?
description: This reading explores the theory of spontaneous generation as it relates to the field of microbiology. Students review the empirical evidence that Pasteur provided to challenge that paradigm of thought and develop the concept of biogenesis (i.e., that living things come from other living things).

title: Laboratory Investigation: Cells
description: This laboratory investigation provides students with an opportunity to view cells in both animals and plants for comparative purposes. Students learn to make slide cultures of cheek and onion cells to identify and view cell organelles under the microscope. As part of this exercise, students research the function of cell organelles and relate their findings back to how cells meet the requirements of life.

title: Reading: “Cells”
description: Students read the excerpt “Cells,” from Bill Bryson’s book A Short History of Nearly Everything. Bryson’s description of cells focuses on both the similarities and differences between cells, the simplicity and complexity of cells, and the functioning of life at a chemical and electrical level. This reading stresses the importance that DNA plays in defining life.

title: Laboratory Investigation: First Line of Defense
description: This exploratory study is aimed at helping students understand that germs (bacteria, in this case) are everywhere, and that proper hand washing can remove germs. A discussion after this activity also provides a historical perspective about the development of city or other public sanitation practices, and relates back to students’ studies of feudal Europe and the Islamic empire in grade 8.

title: Reading: “Small World”
description: Students read and respond to questions from “Small World” in Bill Bryson’s book A Short History of Nearly Everything. The reading presents the various roles of bacterial organisms in sustaining and eliminating life on Earth, the effects of antibiotics, and the classification systems for categorizing biodiversity. Students read this selection at the same time as they carry out the following laboratory exercise.

title: Microbe Culture Investigation
description: This series of investigations helps students to appreciate the world of microbes, particularly bacteria. The laboratory investigation is aimed at helping students to view the world of microbes in a more personal manner as they culture bacterial growth plates. The investigation stresses the importance of designing a fair-test study to determine which types of conditions favor microbial life. As part of these investigations, students learn both culturing and identification techniques.

title: Laboratory Report: Microbe Culture
description: Students write a formal report of their cultural investigations, documenting the results, observations, and significance of their findings. They also integrate the investigation with the Bryson readings to answer a summative question on microbial life.

title: Class Discussion: Pathogens and Disease
description: Students discuss the classification of pathogens in terms of their defining characteristics, response to the environment, reproductive strategies, evolution, and treatment protocols. Through those discussions, students discover that diseases play an important role in maintaining homeostasis in natural environments, as well as in understanding the effects that modern medicine has had on this process.

title: Investigation: Disease Detective
description: Students simulate disease transmission and its spread in a population. They then seek to identify the epidemic’s “patient zero.” The students consider what type of graphic model would best illustrate the movement of epidemics, allowing them to continue to build their graphing scientific literacy skill.

title: Viruses versus Bacteria
description: Students conduct reference research to compare the two pathogens viruses and bacteria, and learn how to battle their onslaughts. This exercise prepares students for the Jared Diamond reading “Lethal Gift of Livestock” from the book Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies.

title: Smallpox and Edward Jenner
description: Students examine the history of the smallpox disease through the reading by Heather Brannon entitled “The History of Smallpox: The Rise and Fall of a Disease.” The article outlines the recent threats this virus posed to human populations, as well as outlining its path through history.

title: Voltaire’s Letter XI: On Inoculation
description: Voltaire’s letter on smallpox is read aloud in class. Student discussion focuses on the connection to the laboratory mentioned in the letter, as well as the role of empirical evidence and a systems approach to the discovery of the cowpox connection. A portion of Edward Jenner’s original work “Introductory Note” is read as well.

title: Guns, Germs and Steel: Lethal Gift of Livestock
description: Students read “Lethal Gift of Livestock” from the book Guns, Germs and Steel. Throughout the course of the reading, students are given opportunities in class to ask questions or to embark on a discussion about the ideas presented as they relate to their previous studies.

title: Disease Research Project
description: Students select a disease to research in depth. In all cases, they describe the disease vector, how it is treated or controlled, and its historical significance. Students prepare a research paper, poster, slide presentation, comic, or other artifact based on their research. They then share their findings with the class through an oral presentation.

title: Discussion: What is Chemistry?
description: Students explore the question “What is chemistry?” by brainstorming ideas or definitions. They continue their exploration by consulting reference sources to find classic definitions that are shared and compared to form an operational definition. Students also begin to explore the concept of the kinetic theory of molecular motion.

title: Swirling Colors Investigation
description: This hands-on, highly visual laboratory experience solidifies, for students, the notion that molecules are in motion by examining the rates of diffusion of food coloring in water at different temperatures. Key concepts they are introduced to in in this learning experience include the kinetic molecular theory of matter; average temperature is a measure of kinetic energy; more energy results in a greater number of molecular collisions; and Brownian motion. Students also consider the following statement in light of their observations: “No two things can be in the same place at the same time.” For homework, students examine Daniel Bernoulli’s work and then trace the evolution of his ideas through the creation of a timeline.

title: Investigation: Dissolving Hard Candy
description: Students examine the factors that affect the rate at which a hard candy dissolves. Students work independently to address the research question about how to make hard candy dissolve faster, thus promoting creative problem solving in a laboratory context. The investigation challenges them to develop a working understanding of the types of interactions occurring at a molecular level in a system. Students summarize their results in a formal laboratory report.

title: Demonstration: Fog Chamber
description: This demonstration allows students to visualize the movement of molecules during phase changes and offers an explanation of thermal exchange necessary for those physical changes. Students are introduced to the concept of attractive forces (intermolecular forces, or Van der Waals forces) between molecules and the energy required in a system to overcome those forces.

title: Marshmallow Morph Investigation
description: Students perform a series of investigations that link the concept of molecules in motion to the gas laws, making the tenets of Boyle’s Law more visible to the students. In these investigations students use marshmallows that are exposed to increased and decreased pressure to demonstrate the relationship of pressure and volume. They answer questions about their findings from this laboratory investigation and create a graph to display the results.

title: Proving Charles’ Law Investigation
description: Students design their own protocols and perform a laboratory to prove Charles’s Law and write a formal laboratory report. Students are encouraged to creatively think about how to design a study to address the relationship between volume and temperature at a constant pressure. They present and discuss their results in a round-table format. Students follow up their investigations with a reading introducing the concepts of moles, Guy-Lussac’s Law, and the Ideal Gas Law, as well as providing historical background.

title: Application of Gas Laws: The Collapsing-Can Demonstration
description: Students witness the power of gas molecules during a demonstration in which an aluminum can is collapsed with air pressure. Students learn the importance of systems thinking and find that the gas laws often work together in the real world. After the demonstration, students design and perform a laboratory investigation by altering such variables as the sizes of can used, amount of water used in the system, and the temperature differential between the two systems.

title: Atomic Structure and Mendeleev’s Periodic Table
description: Students explore and discuss the historical significance of the table of elements as developed by Dmitri Mendeleev, focusing on the contributions of numerous scientists to the periodic table, as well as Mendeleev’s ability to see patterns and relationships among the elements. They revisit and describe the structure of the atom, noting that each element’s inherent atomic structure distinguishes it from other elements.

title: Problem Sets: The Periodic Table
description: Students complete two problem sets in order to explore the history and the organization of the periodic table. They learn about the contributions of key historical figures such as Robert Boyle, Mendeleev, and Moseley. Students practice navigating the periodic table as a reference table and learn how the periodic table enables one to find information about a given element’s atomic structure and its bonding behavior.

title: Introduction to Chemistry
description: Prior to taking the quiz, students refresh their understanding of atomic structure. Then they demonstrate their mastery of the periodic table, the contributions of Mendeleev to the periodic table, Boyle’s Law, kinetic molecular theory, atomic structure, and bonding behavior.

title: Science Biographies
description: Students collaborate as they collect data about scientists from a specific time period and form an opinion about whether those people are part of the paradigm shift from alchemy to empirical sciences. Students gain an appreciation of the length of time paradigm shifts take to occur in science.

title: Plop - Fizz Investigation
description: Students perform a laboratory investigation that introduces the idea of reading the landscape of a reaction for signs that a chemical change is taking place. They collect quantitative and qualitative data to bolster the concept of chemical changes. Students learn the terms reactants and products as they explore the concepts of endothermic vs. exothermic reactions, ratios or proportionality in chemistry, thresholds, rate of reaction, and energy shifts in reactions as they relate to investigation at hand.

title: Fizz II Investigation
description: Students extend their understanding of reactions by performing a follow-up investigation to the previous laboratory experiment. They investigate neutralization reactions with common household substances: baking soda, baking powder, vinegar, and lemon juice. Students are challenged to compare and contrast reaction types and to ask questions about the chemical nature of those everyday substances. Students assesses their understanding of physical and chemical changes, atomic structure, and bonding with a multiple-choice and short-answer quiz.

title: Energized Molecules Investigation
description: Students perform an investigation that highlights a phase shift in an aqueous solution. They discover that the reactant is calcium chloride, which releases energy when dissolved in water. Students compare the Plop - Fizz and Fizz II series of activities, and this activity, to recognize calcium chloride dissolving as an exothermic reaction. They gain knowledge in this activity that prepares them for studying chemical bonding.

title: Volumes of Fun Investigation
description: Students explore a reaction between baking soda, calcium chloride, and water that enables them to trace how reactants disassociate and recombine into new products. They work collaboratively to trace the pathway of the reaction and represent it in symbolic form.

title: Sweet and Salty Investigations
description: Students examine covalent and ionic bonds. They explore salt (ionic bonds) and sugar (covalent bonds) both macroscopically and microscopically. Students witness the effects of heat and compare the conductivity of salt and sugar solutions using simple circuitry. They complete two readings to reinforce the ideas presented in the discussions and investigations of salt and sugar.

title: Quiz: Periodic Table
description: Students complete an assessment that evaluates their familiarity with the periodic table as well as their ability to use it as a reference tool through a series of multiple-choice and short-answer questions. Students demonstrate their knowledge of protons, electrons, neutrons, orbitals, cations, and anions, and how the periodic table provides information about a given element’s atomic structure and bonding behavior.

title: From Magnets to Molecules
description: Students perform a simulation that illustrates the idea that energy exists within atomic bonds as well as between the molecules themselves, while also reinforcing the idea that energy can be released during a chemical reaction. Students complete a reading and a problem set on bonding that reinforces use of the periodic table for pertinent data.

title: Bonds in Household Substances
description: Students brainstorm ways to determine the classification of common household substances as either ionic or molecular. They design experimental protocols to identify whether selected household substances are ionic or molecular.

title: Replacement Reactions
description: Students investigate a replacement reaction between two ionic compounds, ferric chloride and sodium hydroxide, and model the reaction. Students perform a laboratory investigation in which they observe and model a single replacement reaction. Students are challenged to think about how and why cations exchange places.

title: Investigation: Determination of Chemical Formulas
description: Students explore the connection between a chemical formula and the formation of ionic compounds through a double replacement reaction. They perform two laboratory investigations to determine the chemical formula of a precipitate. As a class, students discuss possible sources of experimental error.

title: Combustion and Organic Chemistry
description: Students perform and analyze a combustion reaction as an introduction to organic chemistry. They explore the law of conservation of matter and the differences between ionic and covalently bonded substances through a laboratory investigation. Students determine the properly balanced chemical equation with which to represent the reaction.

title: Chemistry Final
description: Students complete a take-home assessment that revisits several of the learning experiences and essential questions studied in this unit. They demonstrate their knowledge of kinetic molecular theory, Boyle’s and Charles’s Laws, the periodic table, endothermic and exothermic reactions, and atomic bonding.

title: Local Actions with Global Consequences
description: Students participate in an initial discussion to contextualize the waves of Industrial Revolution(s) through time, tracing the growth of the first Industrial Revolution through Great Britain, then to Belgium, and France. They study subsequent industrial waves, first traveling through Germany, the United States, and Japan and then culminating with the rapid Industrialization of China, India, and Brazil. Throughout the discussion, students come to appreciate and understand the current state of Earth’s ecosystems and natural resources.

title: Industrial Waves Readings
description: As a reinforcing activity and exercise in scientific literary skills, students research current articles that help further illuminate how Industrialization moves around the globe. Students explore the difference between open and closed systems and how these ideas relate to the study of Industrialization and environmental changes.

title: Why Do We Care?
description: Students read Wallace Stegner’s Wilderness Letter to create an emotional attachment to nature and demonstrate that human actions have consequences in the natural world. They then research, explore, and share how other cultures, both current and historical, view nature and human consequences in the natural world.

title: Geochemistry Link
description: Students link their understanding of the Industrial Revolution to concepts of chemistry with emphasis on conservation of matter, conservation of energy, and synthesis and decomposition reactions as they relate to the idea of the harvesting of fossil fuels. Students search the Internet for information about how carbon credits are used to offset carbon release from fossil fuels and discuss the carbon cycle and climate change through this lens.

title: Introduction to Malthus
description: Students are introduced to the work of Thomas Robert Malthus, specifically his ideas on population growth and resource management. Students review Malthus’ positive and negative checks and re-examine their understanding of disease in this context. Students also read selections of biographical material on Malthus to further explain his hypotheses.

title: The Fish Game of Resource Management
description: Students perform a simulated resource-management exercise in which they are tasked with managing a swordfish company under changing environmental and political conditions. Through the activity, they are introduced to the ideas of carrying capacity, renewable and nonrenewable resources, and sustainable yield, as well as exploring environmentally ethical and sustainable fishing practices. To further the idea of a global society, students research the fishing attitudes of other countries.

title: Debriefing Analysis: The Fish Game of Resource Management
description: Through discussion and reflective writing, students gain an understanding of the concepts of sustainability and resource management—both with respect to the Fish Game and on local and global scales. As they analyze their data from the game, they explore what it means to share a common pool of resources, differentiate between finite and infinite resources, and consider the effect of natural resource depletion on other organisms and the psychology and group dynamics of natural-resource extraction.

title: Graphs Tell a Story
description: Students explore the use of graphs to tell stories about scientific data through a presentation of data and graphs on population growth and determine what type of regression analysis to run on the given set of data. They then analyze graphs of current world data to learn about the power of quantitative data, including how it is gathered, analyzed, and communicated and how interpretations can lead to the formation of misconceptions. This activity sets the stage for the upcoming analysis of data related to the work of Malthus.

title: Particulate Matter Survey
description: Students perform a particulate matter survey to explore firsthand the air quality on the school grounds. By constructing particulate matter traps, students gather both qualitative and quantitative data about air quality variations among trap locations and correlate the data to potential sources of air pollution.

title: Particulate Matter Survey Analysis
description: Students analyze the data collected from the particulate matter survey on both micro and macro scales, in terms of the size of the study itself. They are challenged to determine a method for quantifying their data sets using creative problem solving and to connect their findings to the idea of the ripple effect and the significance of the Clean Air Act.

title: Determining an Ecological Footprint
description: Students quantify their individual impact on the environment by determining the amount of productive land and water area necessary to provide the resources consumed in support of their lifestyle. They search the Internet for sites that determine ecological footprints, in order to assess the types of data that are collected during this procedure and examine their own lifestyles. Exploring the relative sizes of ecological footprints as organized by country, students discuss global responsibilities and ecological inequity.

title: Service Learning Experience: Invasive Plant Removal
description: Students participate in an invasive plant removal project in order to appreciate both the beauty and diversity in the local landscape, while also considering that not all species of flora or fauna are indigenous. An example of an ongoing project is the removal of invasive knapweed and later restoration with native grasses in a bay beach area. Students weave together the concepts of globalization, local action, the “Romantic Reaction” to the environment, and the need to restore and preserve natural beauty.

title: Prelude to the Baroque
description: Students study compositional techniques from the medieval and Renaissance periods to better understand the transition to harmony in the Baroque period.

title: Musical Structure Presentation
description: Students select a familiar musical piece familiar and explain its structure in a brief presentation to the class.

title: Birth of the Baroque
description: Students place the Baroque period within the context of the Dynamical Mentality, connecting its music with other significant changes occurring in the world at that time. They then look at how composers in the early stages of the Baroque period adopted harmony and meter as organizing principles and invented opera.

title: Practice Listening Quiz
description: Students aurally identify a musical piece from the previous lesson by title and composer, as well as recall any notable features.

title: Climax of the Baroque
description: Students examine techniques and musical forms invented during the late Baroque period.

title: Baroque Period Music Test
description: Students demonstrate knowledge of Baroque composers, pieces, and techniques, contrasting key differences with the prior Renaissance style.

title: Shift from Baroque to Classical
description: Students examine the elegance, restraint, and carefully balanced form that mark the Classical style. Works by Haydn and Mozart provide examples of typical forms, including the string quartet, symphony, opera, and mass.

title: Climax of the Classical
description: Students watch a video that provides a broad overview of the Enlightenment period in Europe. They also read about John Locke and Thomas Hobbes.

title: Composition Project
description: Students create an original melody or sound cluster in an established musical form using music composition software.

title: Classical Period Music Test
description: Students create an original melody or sound cluster in an established musical form using music composition software.

title: Rise of the Romantic Period
description: Students examine the new techniques and approaches of the Romantic period through works of Shubert, Chopin, and Robert and Clara Schumann. Students also investigate how the cultural context in which these musicians worked influenced their compositions.

title: Composition Workshop
description: Students work in class on their composition projects, obtaining assistance and feedback from the instructor and their peers.

title: French Romanticism, Thematic Transformation, and the Climax of Opera
description: Students examine how the French Opera tradition reached its height through the Romantic operas of Bizet and Berlioz. Then they explore thematic transformation by studying Robert le diable and Symphonie fantastique. After this, students look at the climax of Italian and German opera with Verdi and Wagner.

title: Presentation of Final Composition Project
description: Students present their composition project and speak briefly about the process of creating it.

title: Climax of the Romantic Period
description: Students delve into the innovations and novelties found in works by Liszt, Brahms, and Bruckner, reinforcing the unique aspects of music from the Romantic period.

title: Romantic Period Music Test
description: Students demonstrate knowledge of Romantic composers, pieces, and techniques, contrasting key differences with the prior Classical style.

title: The Nature of Science
description: Students engage in a brief inquiry investigation into scientific methodology, recording their observations and questions in a Science journal. They compare the methods they used during the investigation with their classmates’ approach to illustrate that there is no single scientific method.

title: Introduction to Evolution
description: Students express their prior knowledge about evolution, review what a scientific theory is, how it relates to a scientific law, and the role of experimentation in the advancement of knowledge and the understanding of the natural world.

title: Film—Evolution: Darwin’s Dangerous Idea
description: Students watch the two-hour PBS film about Darwin and evolution, discuss its main points, and answer questions designed to focus their thinking on the major concepts presented.

title: Darwin and Lamarck and the Development of the Theory of Evolution
description: Students learn about the development and implications of the theory of evolution by natural selection. Students will examine theories proposing that selection operates at the species level instead of the individual, directly influenced by the environment.

title: Inclusive Fitness and Group Selection
description: Students examine under what conditions natural selection may act beyond the level of the individual, while considering that the potential importance of the number of genes individuals share with other individuals depends upon the degree of relatedness and the possibility that selection can act on a group of individuals.

title: Sexual Selection
description: Students learn about how choices regarding mates confer direct fitness on the opposite sex and, as such, acts as a selective force.

title: Phylogenies
description: Students examine the anatomical relationships between living organisms and how early relationships are identified in the fossil record through the use of phylogenies and the construction of cladograms.

title: Macroevolution: The Process of Speciation
description: Students learn about the direction and actions of selection in the evolution of species and the concept of species. Students compare the two major accepted modes of speciation, gradualism, and punctuated equilibrium that demonstrate how speciation involves many pathways.

title: Mechanisms of Speciation
description: Students learn about events that lead to the evolution of new species and distinguish these events as gradualism or punctuated equilibrium and explain these designations. Through this study, they identify the importance of reproductive isolation in speciation.

title: Other Considerations
description: Students discuss current topics and issues associated with the theory of evolution, intelligent design, and common arguments countering evolution and speculate on the future of human evolution.

title: Evidence for Evolution—Reading and Teaching
description: Students break into small groups to complete the Why Evolution Is True teaching project. As part of this project, each group of students is assigned a chapter in What Evolution Isto read and then teach to their peers.

title: Reviewing Evolution
description: Students listen to a lecture given by leading evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins, which challenges them to compare his views about evolution with their own.

title: Evolution Research Project
description: Students choose an evolutionary topic generated from their own interest or from material in the course and produce a three-page paper and presentation, a poster and presentation, or a 12-minute multimedia presentation.

title: Test: Evolution
description: Students take a unit test that assesses their knowledge of evolution through short-answer, essay, and multiple-choice questions.

title: Getting to Know Drosophila melanogaster
description: In this learning experience, students learn important skills for upcoming laboratory experiments, such as how to cultivate and observe fruit flies, determine their sex, and identify physical characteristics. They also learn to anesthetize, sort, count, and return fruit flies to their vials.

title: Drosophila Inquiry Laboratory
description: Students cultivate the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster during a long-term project. Students cross a wild type fly (homogeneous) with a fly exhibiting a recessive trait, and they then take newly emergent adults of an F1 generation and cross a heterogeneous (dominant) wild population with an apterous population (recessive). Students are unaware of the dominant and recessive nature of the traits. During several weeks of fruit fly cultivation, observation, and data collection, students compare results and consider similar outcomes of Mendel’s work in the next learning experience, Historical Perspectives on Genetics.

title: Historical Perspective on Genetics
description: This introductory learning experience allows students to contextualize the unit historically. It is suggested to begin the learning experience with a review of the tenets of Darwin’s Theory of Evolution and a discussion of “what is missing from the equation” to help students recognize the necessity of understanding how traits evolve and are passed on to the next generation. Next, students research Lamarck’s views on inheriting acquired traits, Darwin’s pangenesis theory (a revision of Lamarck’s ideas), and the blending theory. After reviewing their research as a class, students create a profile of Gregor Mendel, including his work and the forces that motivated his inquiry.

title: Introduction to Mendelian Genetics
description: Students research Gregor Mendel’s work, crossbreeding, and Mendel’s laws of inheritance. Students then discuss those concepts as a class.

title: Punnett Squares
description: Students are introduced to the history of the Punnett square through a presentation. Then, in pairs or small groups, students work on problems that begin with simple Punnett square analyses of monohybrid crosses and progress to increasingly complex Punnett squares for dihybrid crosses, codominance, incomplete dominance, and multiple alleles. Students then check their understanding by completing the Punnett Square Worksheet (SC_G11_U2_05_LE_A01_Worksheet).

title: Mendel Meets Darwin
description: Although Darwin and Mendel were contemporaries, neither was aware of the other’s work. Students imagine a conversation between the two scientists had they happened to meet. Students work in small groups to brainstorm, write a draft of a one-act play, rehearse the play, and perform it during class.

title: Real-World Connection: Determining Blood Types: Expression of a Single Trait
description: Students read background information on blood types and discuss the concept of multiple alleles. Students then complete a problem set on blood types. Students consider the ABO system as an example of a multiple-allele system, and they make a personal connection to that system by researching their own blood types and genetic roots through discussions with their families.

title: Population Genetics and the Hardy-Weinberg Principle
description: Students speculate on gene pools and the types of environmental pressures that influence natural selection and lead to strong populations. Students read about and discuss population genetics and the Hardy-Weinberg principle. Then students use their newly acquired knowledge to complete two worksheets in which they solve related problems.

title: Compilation of Data from Drosophila Investigation
description: Students write a laboratory report to describe their Drosophila Inquiry Laboratory. In their reports, they use the data compiled from the class and perform chi-square statistical testing. Their reports also summarize their methods and their findings, including an analysis of the data.

title: Genetic Drift
description: Students explore the concept of genetic drift by studying appropriate visual aids and written passages. Through their explorations, students come to appreciate the power of genetic drift as an agent for evolutionary change, and they discuss its effect in large versus small populations. To conclude the discussion, they consider the concepts of coalescence, probability of fixation, and the loss of heterozygosity due to drift and inbreeding.

title: The Discovery of DNA Structure
description: Students read about the discovery of DNA and examine a model of the DNA molecule. After completing the reading, students discuss the Human Genome Project and the genesis and inheritance of mutations and disease.

title: DNA Replication and Transcription
description: Students learn about the mechanisms for DNA replication and translation and transcription of its code to messenger RNA (mRNA) for making proteins.

title: The Cell Cycle
description: Students view prepared slides of onion root mitosis and sketch their observations. Students read about and explore cell division by first analyzing the relationships among DNA, genes, chromosomes, and cells. Students examine mitosis and meiosis, with particular attention paid to the end result of each (for example, haploid versus diploid cells).

title: Review of Genetics and DNA
description: Students review the concepts of this unit concerning genetics and DNA. Students may revisit topics of their choosing or they may be assigned topics by the teacher. Students conduct research to reinforce or extend their knowledge of particular topics.

title: Advances in Molecular Genetics
description: Students learn about processes of modern genetic engineering using a variety of resources. They research a technique of interest and design and present the information in a poster session. Students include in their presentations descriptions of how the technique has changed society and the issues involved in genetic engineering of food plants and other organisms.

title: Review of Newtonian Physics
