They distinguish astronomy and astrology as they investigate the scientific concepts underlying one pseudo scientific prediction for this date.

title: Quiz: Archaeoastronomy
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the nature and characteristics of Classical Maya astronomy, the relationship between astronomy and timekeeping, and the topic of retrograde motion.

title: Classical Maya Codex Project
description: Students create a codex pamphlet commemorating at least two astronomical achievements of the Classical Maya astronomer-priests with written explanations and supporting diagrams or images. They also describe one of the celestial events that the Classical Maya tracked and research and provide modern dates for this event.

title: Test: Maya Astronomy
description: Students demonstrate understanding of all main topics and concepts investigated in this unit as well as their ability to recall basic facts and definitions for key terms. The test consists of matching, fill-in-the-blank, multiple choice, and open-response questions that include explaining or drawing diagrams to represent the causes of celestial phenomena.

title: Earth’s Biomes
description: Students examine Earth’s major biomes and the characteristics of ecosystems, focusing on the basic components and cycles essential to ecosystems, such as the roles of producers, consumers, and decomposers; the nonliving environment; and the material cycles within ecosystems. After discussing the relationship between ecosystems and biomes, each student researches a major biome.

title: Biomes Project
description: In small groups, students plan and deliver a five-minute presentation identifying all locations around the world where the biome they studied can be found, the biome’s major features, and at least six examples of native flora and fauna.

title: Classical Maya Ecosystems and Agriculture
description: Students compare the main ecosystems located within the Classical Maya region, the specific agricultural challenges of each region, and solutions devised by the Classical Maya to overcome these challenges. Students also consider the Classical Mayas’ spiritual connection to nature and the land, discussing their cultural, religious, and political practices tied to agriculture and the growing season.

title: Corn Growth and Reproduction
description: Focusing on corn, students investigate plant reproduction, growth, and the process and consequences of plant domestication. They read about modern-day uses of corn, genetically engineered corn, and the effects of modern slash-and-burn farming practices. Students integrate their knowledge of Maya ecosystems and corn growth and reproduction to describe an imaginary, realistic corn variety native to a particular Classical Maya region.

title: Decline of the Classical Maya Civilization
description: Students investigate whether agricultural practices contributed to the decline of the Classical Maya civilization around 900 CE by evaluating evidence for three theories—climate change and drought, poor agricultural techniques, or warfare. As a class, students develop an understanding of how these factors are related, and they compare the sustainability of Classical Maya and ancient Mesopotamian agricultural practices.

title: Quiz: Decline of the Classical Maya Civilization
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of the ecosystems found in the Classical Maya heartland, and summarize the main theories about the decline of this civilization.

title: Sustainability and Industrialized Agriculture
description: Students apply what they learned about Classical Maya agriculture to consider how modern agriculture and their own lifestyle choices influence the stability of the environment and society. They also compare organic and factory farming and evaluate the environmental impact and sustainability of factory farming and industrial agriculture. Students examine three environmental problems that develop in the atmosphere—global warming, the depletion of ozone in the stratosphere, and the buildup of ozone in the troposphere—and learn how human activities contribute to these problems.

title: Sustainability Performances Project
description: Students work collaboratively to communicate their understanding of global warming, ozone depletion, ozone buildup, or factory farming, and share their research about actions they can take to help counteract these problems. Each group prepares a five-minute performance to educate the class on the topic and answers questions from classmates.

title: Test: Maya Agriculture
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the fundamental concepts investigated throughout the unit, as well as their retention of key information about Classical Maya agriculture. They identify the characteristics of ecosystems located in the Classical Maya region, explain the agricultural challenges and solutions related to each, and describe the sustainability of different agricultural practices.

title: Scientific Collections Project
description: Students discuss the state of the natural sciences during the Hellenistic period and the library of Alexandria, as well as the purpose of natural collections. They then collect, research, and develop a plan for specimen preservation as part of starting their own collection of natural specimens.

title: Introduction to Classification
description: Students investigate the general nature, purpose, and workings of classification systems. They first explore various ways in which they could group their natural specimens or assorted classroom objects, then conduct a Fingerprint Classification lab to begin to identify the characteristics that make a classification system effective.

title: History of Classification: Aristotle
description: Students discuss the significance of Aristotle’s belief in the value of empirical knowledge and examine the hierarchy and groupings he used to describe the order of living things. Students then discover the strengths and weaknesses of Aristotle’s classification system by comparing it to modern dichotomous keys and using it to classify plants and animals.

title: Modern Taxonomy
description: Considering scientific adaptation to new knowledge and technology, students discuss Carl Linnaeus’ contributions to modern taxonomy and explore the six-kingdom classification system. Students then research the six kingdoms of organisms to develop an understanding of their distinctions and similarities at the cellular level.

title: Phylum Research Project
description: Students address the diversity within the animal kingdom by individually researching one of the nine major animal phyla and presenting their findings to the class in a three to five minute multimedia presentation.

title: Scientific Collections Project Continuation
description: Students apply what they have learned about biological classification and nomenclature to their collections of natural specimens. Working in collaborative groups, students combine their individual collections to make a museum department collection and classify and name their specimens according to a system of their own making.

title: Scientific Collection Display and Presentation
description: Working in their museum department groups, students display and present their collection exhibits to the class. To complete their specimen labels, students also research and include the accepted scientific names for their specimens. Each group explains their rationales for their classification and naming systems, both in their presentations and in writing.

title: Tyto alba (Barn Owl) Pellet Dissection Laboratory
description: Students study Tyto alba, the common barn owl, to investigate and discuss the relationship between physiological form and function in a specific species. Working with a partner, students extract and identify skeletal remains of prey from owl pellets, reconstruct and label skeletons, identify the species represented, and then interpret the significance of this evidence.

title: Test: Classification
description: Students take a test to demonstrate their understanding and recall of key information about Aristotle’s beliefs and classification system, the history of taxonomy, modern hierarchal taxa, and the six-kingdom classification system. Students are also expected to know the basic characteristics of organisms in each kingdom and the nine major phyla of the animal kingdom.

title: Aristotle and the Vegetal Soul
description: Students revisit the topic of Aristotle’s hierarchal organization of nature (the Great Chain of Being), as they explore their own ideas about the differences and similarities between plants and animals, referring to fungi as a point of comparison. They discuss and write reflection essays about the distinctions and relationship between plants and humans.

title: Introduction to Plant Evolution
description: Students learn about the main stages in the beginning evolution of plants: the development from aquatic plants to bryophytes, the simplest land plants, to the vascular plants and trees that are most commonly associated with the plant kingdom. Through discussions, readings, and video clips, students explore the physical adaptations in plants that allowed them to transition from aquatic to terrestrial environments.

title: Vascular Plants
description: Students take a closer look at evolution of different types of vascular plants (ferns and seed plants) and conduct a xylem lab to investigate the mechanisms of the vascular system. They also make connections back to their study of the Silk Road, as they consider the variety of products obtained from seed plants.

title: Quiz: Plant Evolution
description: Students compare the physical characteristics performing basic life functions in aquatic and land plants. They also distinguish between the xylem and phloem tissues of vascular plants and analyze a diagram of tree rings to evaluate the environmental conditions that correspond to different sections of growth.

title: Roots
description: Students begin an in-depth study of plant structures, following the life cycle of a vascular seed plant. They examine the primary functions and types of roots, launching an ongoing discussion of how biome variations favor different adaptations among plants. Students then conduct a germination lab to observe the development of roots and investigate the response of roots to different environmental stimuli.

title: Quiz: Roots
description: Students demonstrate knowledge of the primary root functions and the purpose of different types of root modifications or adaptations.

title: Stems
description: Students follow their investigation of roots with a study of stems, the part of a plant that develops once it has germinated and stabilized itself with roots. They learn about the functions, composition, and different types of stems, creating their own diagrams and sketches to record and analyze this information. Students then conduct laboratory investigations to observe plant tropisms in stems as compared to roots.

title: Quiz: Stems
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of stem functions and parts, as well as their understanding of how various types of adaptations reflect the environmental conditions in the plant’s habitat.

title: Leaves
description: Students discuss the function of plant leaves, and further develop their knowledge of the variation among leaves of plants, particularly trees. Students learn about the specific leaf adaptations of deciduous and evergreen trees and plants and relate the behaviors of dropping or retaining leaves to surviving seasonal climate changes.

title: Photosynthesis
description: Students learn the chemistry of photosynthesis. They first consider a quote from Aristotle to revisit their own notions about how plants gain nutrition and dispose of waste, then they learn how stomata regulate the distribution of reactants and products of photosynthesis. Students then conduct a laboratory demonstration to detect Elodea consumption of carbon dioxide when exposed to light.

title: Quiz: Photosynthesis
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the chemical equation for photosynthesis, and the ways in which plants obtain carbon dioxide and solar energy.

title: Plants with Seeds and Flowers
description: Students investigate the evolution and characteristics of the two main divisions of plants with seeds—gymnosperms (nonflowering) and angiosperms (flowering)—and consider the roles of flowers and seeds in plant reproduction. Students conduct independent research on the differences among gymnosperms and angiosperms, seed adaptations, flower anatomy, and angiosperm reproduction. Students then dissect a flower to examine and identify its parts, and they connect their discoveries to the work of Aristotle and Theophrastus.

title: Quiz: Gymnosperms and Angiosperms
description: Students demonstrate knowledge of the differences between gymnosperms and angiosperms, as well as of the major reproductive parts of angiosperms.

title: Pollination
description: Students take a closer look at pollination as the first step in examining plant reproduction. They learn about the structure and composition of pollen grains, how pollen varies among plants, the processes of pollination and fertilization, and the formation of seeds. Students also discuss the relationships between flower structure and self-pollination or cross-pollination, before they pollinate a flower and observe the growth of pollen tubes under microscopes.

title: Germination
description: Students bring their study of plant life cycles full circle as they examine what happens after pollination has occurred, focusing on the process of germination and the relationship between seeds and seedlings. Throughout this learning experience, students recall their prior knowledge and documentation of germination from their grade-5 studies of Plant Growth in the Classroom: Seed Germination (SC_G5_U2_06_LE), to further contextualize and discuss the changes they have witnessed. Students also connect to their Cultural History studies as they discuss Chinese white mulberry trees, Morus alba.

title: Carnivorous Plants
description: Students explore the distinctions between carnivorous and noncarnivorous plants, and the different adaptations of carnivorous plants that facilitate survival in nutrient-poor environments. They then design their own human-eating carnivorous plant, describe and visually represent its characteristics, and present their plant design to the class.

title: Quiz: Pollination and Carnivorous Plants
description: Students answer multiple-choice questions to demonstrate their knowledge of specific details in the process of pollination, as well as their understanding of carnivorous plants.

title: Design a Flower Project
description: Students design a flower using materials that best represent the function of each part of a flower and create a collage to represent the flower. They present their flower collages to the class and are assessed on both their flower design and ability to verbally explain how their collage represents the relationship between form and function.

title: Introduction to Earth Science
description: Students consider the nature of the field of Earth Science through an introductory discussion of Mount Vesuvius’s 79 eruption and the destruction of the cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum. They also consider the inherent difficulties of observing Earth’s internal structure and processes and discuss the importance of evidence to the formation of scientific theories.

title: The Origin and Composition of Earth
description: Students are introduced to the current understanding of, and evidence for, the origin, structure, and composition of Earth. Students also compare hypotheses and theories and describe how modern technology has enabled us to understand meteorites in a way not possible for the ancient Romans.

title: Continental Drift and Plate Tectonics
description: Students examine the current models explaining geologic processes and land formation on Earth: the continental drift theory, plate tectonic theory, and convection currents. They also reinforce their understanding of the process of convection with a laboratory investigation and use an interactive website to explore the relationship between specific tectonic plate movements and boundaries and the location of earthquakes and volcanoes.

title: Quiz: Plate Tectonics
description: Student demonstrate their knowledge of how the theory of plate tectonics was developed over recent centuries, the principles of the theory, and the major types of tectonic plate boundaries.

title: Volcanism: Mt. Vesuvius and Pompeii
description: Students apply their understanding of Earth’s composition and plate tectonics to a study of different types of volcanoes, conduct a laboratory investigation on viscosity, and relate this property to magma. Students then identify and explain the processes that led to each stage of the 79 eruption of Mount Vesuvius, as documented by Pliny and the archaeological record.

title: Quiz: Volcanoes
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of the different types of magma, lava, and volcanoes, as well as their understanding of the relationships between the viscosity and composition of magma, the volcanoes formed by different magmas, and the nature of eruptions caused by different magmas.

title: Earthquakes
description: Students investigate earthquakes as integral components of the geological processes they have been studying thus far. They examine seismic wave characteristics and behavior within Earth and determine the location of an earthquake epicenter using seismogram readouts and S-P wave charts.

title: Quiz: Earthquakes
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of the general characteristics of earthquakes, the main types of faults, and the properties of seismic waves. Students also compare two seismograms to identify what they reveal about the epicenter of an earthquake.

title: Earth as a System
description: Students apply their combined understanding of plate tectonics, volcanism, and earthquakes to a review of the seismic activity that occurred before the 79 eruption of Mount Vesuvius. They read articles connecting the eruption with an earthquake about 16 or 17 years earlier and consider the relationship between these events as they develop a public service announcement warning the citizens of Pompeii and Herculaneum of the impending eruption.

title: Geological Guide to Mount Vesuvius
description: Students synthesize and demonstrate their understanding of the natural history of Mount Vesuvius, creating a tourist brochure featuring essential information about Mount Vesuvius’ formation, eruptions, and topography. Students identify the plate boundary and source and type of magma that created Mount Vesuvius, noting other key details specified on their assignment handout and incorporating meaningful images.

title: The Concept of Technology
description: Students engage in an introductory discussion on the concept of technology. Guiding questions help students to independently define technology, collectively identify the forces driving its development and continuous improvement, and discuss various ways in which technology can be both beneficial and harmful.

title: Technology and Society
description: Students examine the dynamic relationship between culture and technology and the ways in which they have coevolved, by discussing the developmental milestones of Paleolithic technology, the Neolithic Revolution, and the Bronze Age. This discussion serves to contextualize the Greek and Roman technologies that students investigate in the remainder of the unit.

title: Technology and Engineering in Ancient Greece
description: Students investigate the ancient Greek technological innovations from the time period under study, focusing on those developed by Archimedes of Syracuse. Through research, readings, and discussion, students learn about his mechanical inventions, the principle of buoyancy, and the use of his engines during the Roman siege of Syracuse. Students also develop their understanding of how science and mathematics are applied to technology and engineering and discuss the sharing of technologies and scientific knowledge in antiquity.

title: Technology and the Rise of Rome
description: Students explore how the needs of the Roman Empire drove the direction of technological development. They discuss Roman innovations in warfare, public works and infrastructure, and architecture and recognize that Roman technologies were primarily focused on engineering structures to support the wealth and prestige of the empire and its elite. Students then connect technology with the physical concepts of work and machines, as they contrast the Romans’ sophisticated construction machines with the lack of domestic labor-saving devices.

title: Roman Machines Project
description: In this extended project, students design, build, and test a model of a Roman-era machine, applying the principles of simple mechanics and problem-solving skills. Students are also expected to quantify the performance of their model and analyze this data to help them make and assess the effectiveness of design changes. In the process, students develop a practical understanding of how technologies are developed and improved through testing.

title: Mechanics and Engineering
description: Students switch from a historical and philosophical approach to technology to a scientific study of the principles governing physical forces, machines, and work. Students develop their prior knowledge of simple machines through a series of laboratory investigations. They identify how each machine changes the size or direction of the force applied, measure the work done, and calculate the mechanical advantage and efficiency of machines. Students are then encouraged to consider how they can apply these principles to improve their Roman Machines Project models.

title: Technological Solutions to Local Environmental Challenges
description: Students connect their current studies of technology to their earlier explorations of environmental issues. They invite a guest speaker to visit the class and discuss the environmental problems currently facing their community, as well as the various technologies being developed and proposed to address them.

title: Test: Ancient Technology and Simple Machines
description: This short test assesses students’ understanding of Archimedes’s technological notoriety, prehistoric milestones in the development of technology, and the purpose and principles of machines. Students also use given information to calculate the work output, mechanical advantage, and efficiency of machines.

title: Roman Machines Project Reports and Presentations
description: To complete the Roman Machines Project and bring the unit to a close, students demonstrate what they learned by writing a report describing the features, functionality, historical context, and development of their machine. They also describe their problem-solving process throughout the project, formally present their model to the class, and answer questions about their project and process.

title: Exploring Symbols
description: The knowledge of the alphabetic principle is explored as students begin to understand that the letters in written words represent the phonemes in spoken words.

title: Let’s Identify Symbols
description: During alphabet book read-alouds, students follow the teacher’s directions to trace letters in the air while naming the letters. They identify letter symbols and make connections based on their prior knowledge.

title: Wonders of Symbols (Read-Aloud)
description: Students recognize that symbols mean something. They relate symbols to words they can read by sight.

title: Wonder of Symbols with Word Study
description: As students identify symbols, they use letter symbols and shapes to build high-frequency words and learn consonant and vowel sounds, as well as the beginning, middle, and ending sounds/symbol relationship.

title: Interactive Games Using Symbols
description: Working in small groups, students use symbols and sounds to play games, sort objects, demonstrate letter/sound relationships, and build words.

title: Use of Vocabulary Related to Symbols in the Classroom
description: In this learning experience, students relate to picture symbols and gestures associated with classroom objects and activities.

title: Wonders of Symbols Writing Workshop
description: During this writing workshop, students apply the letter/sound symbol relationship to writing the alphabet and creating stories.

title: Native American Symbols
description: Students explore symbols, pictograms, and petroglyphs that various Native American tribes used to communicate and document cultural history. They compare and contrast symbols used historically to symbols used today.

title: Reading Maps
description: In Cultural History, students learn how to read maps and map legends, and plan a treasure hunt. In this learning experience, they use knowledge gleaned from prior learning experiences to create symbols for the Cultural History map.

title: Mapping: Make It Clear
description: Using prior learning about signs and symbols, students create individual maps of familiar areas around the school. A rubric aids evaluation of student understanding of symbols, mapping, and the learning presented in the unit.

title: Sharing Knowledge About Beginnings
description: Students continue to share their understanding of the concept of beginnings, explored in a related Cultural History learning experience. Through listing, discussing, modeling, and drawing a variety of things that have beginnings, they develop a definition of what a beginning is.

title: The Everything Seed: Modeling Note Taking
description: During a whole group shared reading of the book The Everything Seed by Carole Martignacco, students use guiding questions to interact with and discuss the story. While investigating beginnings, they learn note taking.

title: Shared Writing with Illustrations
description: Students are introduced to poetry and review what they know about beginnings to generate topic ideas for a classroom poem. As they brainstorm descriptive language and poetry topics, they also explore turning ideas into phrases and sentences. Their compiled ideas will be incorporated in the group poem in a corresponding Cultural History learning experience.

title: Reflections for the Journey of a Monarch Butterfly
description: Students observe and document stages of the monarch butterfly’s metamorphosis. They track daily changes in the classroom habitat, drawing the caterpillars’ progress, using high-frequency words and standard writing conventions to record the insects’ development.

title: Creation Myths: Writing Workshop
description: Expanding their understanding of beginnings, students use their exploration of multicultural creation stories to write, edit, and illustrate their own original creation myths.

title: Read, Research, and Write for Rice-and-Stocking Babies Project
description: Coordinated with the Cultural History Integrated Project: Rice-and-Stocking Babies Project, students create a personal timeline, using high-frequency words and sentence-building games to record personal growth developments, such as beginning to walk or to speak.

title: Weather Vocabulary
description: Students explore the essential question, “What is seasonal change?” through read-alouds and discussion of nonfiction books. Key weather terms are reinforced through the sharing of experiential weather scenarios.

title: Understanding Migration
description: After listening to nonfiction texts followed by whole-group discussions about seasonal change and migration, students consider the question: “What do animals and plants do in the winter months?” They demonstrate their understanding of the answer through drawings and verbal explanations that are assessed during teacher conferences.

title: Winter Journal and Observation
description: Students return to findings on winter behaviors of animals, plants, and humans recorded in their Cultural History journals during the previous Cultural History learning experiences and add words and drawings to create interactive textbooks that reflect their explorations and investigations.

title: Questioning Winter Migration
description: Students ask and answer questions about migration during group discussions using information obtained through read-alouds and personal observations and by making connections between animal movement and seasonal change.

title: Migration Mapping
description: Students map the migrating flight patterns of the monarch butterfly, Canada goose, and American robin after using flyway route maps and read-alouds to explore mapping as a form of communication. Students create symbols and a map key to indicate each animal’s flyway route.

title: Hibernation Research
description: Students work together to conduct research on hibernating animals, such as bears, turtles, and skunks, using books from the classroom library and read-alouds. Each student chooses an animal to focus on, and creates a book explaining how that animal copes with seasonal change.

title: Exploring Winter Mural Project
description: Students brainstorm ideas about what to include in a classroom mural that reflects the impact of winter weather on animals and humans. Additionally, students create cutouts of themselves dressed in clothing appropriate for an outdoor winter activity.

title: Exploring Earth/Soil and Sand
description: After listening to nonfiction read-alouds about soil and sand, students create a Venn diagram to chart similarities and differences in these two Earth substances.

title: Earth and the Elemental Forces
description: While students actively problem solve during the unit’s learning experiences and assessments, the teacher circulates the room to record evidence of student progress on the “Performances of Understanding” note-taking sheet.

title: Connecting the Four Elemental Forces
description: Students participate in shared readings about how the elemental forces affect their lives. They examine how each author represents a particular force and connects it to daily life. A list of the various representations and authors’ connections is assembled, and students illustrate the textual connections and their personal experiences.

title: Words to Know About Earth, Air, Fire, and Water
description: Students are introduced to elemental forces vocabulary, discover how to use text features to identify terms, chart the vocabulary words, and infer meanings.

title: Researching the Elemental Forces
description: Students research the four elemental forces, including how each force affects the living things on Earth. Using various media sources, students compile their research and, after discussion, enter their findings on the class Elemental Forces charts.

title: Elemental Forces Writing Workshop
description: Students are introduced to writing journals that are used to collect information for the Elemental Forces Informational Book.

title: Elemental Forces Informational Book
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the concepts studied throughout this elemental forces unit by reflecting on their writings, drawings, journals, and illustrations and creating an Elemental Forces Informational Book that documents the importance of the four elemental forces in sustaining life on Earth.

title: The Golden Bull: Guided Reading
description: As a guided reading experience, students read The Golden Bull by Marjorie Cowley, a fictional story about a brother and sister living in ancient Mesopotamia. Students learn that Marjorie Cowley, an author of many prehistoric time period books, carefully researches the time periods in which the stories are set, thus giving the reader a realistic window into the time period and culture of the characters.

title: Inanna Stories and Hymns
description: In grade 5 students explore myths as tools to understand the history and culture of ancient civilizations. They begin by exploring the mythological Sumerian goddess of love, fertility, and warfare, Inanna. Students use the learning experience to begin identifying the characteristics of myths and of mythological characters.

title: Enheduanna: World’s First Named Author
description: Students conduct an author study of the Akkadian/Sumerian high priestess, poet, and author, Enheduanna. Students research and write a biography about the life and literary works of this ancient author.

title: Lugalbanda
description: Students participate in a shared reading of a book about Lugalbanda, the father of Gilgamesh and a main character found in Sumerian mythology. Students begin an in depth study of mythological characters. They compare and contrast characters such as Inanna and Lugalbanda and develop a formula for creating a mythological main character.

title: Gilgamesh
description: The class reads three myths from the Epic of Gilgamesh and creates a formula for writing an engaging myth. Students compare these myths to the previous myths they have read about Inanna and Lugalbanda.

title: Writing a Myth
description: Students have explored a many myths from ancient Mesopotamia. As a final assessment, students write their own myths using style similar to those of the myths they have been exploring in this unit. Their myths must convey a historical event, an ancient belief, or a cultural understanding of the time period.

title: Tuck Everlasting: Reading, Writing, and Discussing
description: In conjunction with their reading of the Epic of Gilgamesh in Cultural History, students read, write about, and discuss the contemporary young adult novel Tuck Everlasting by Natalie Babbitt.

title: Tuck Everlasting Writing Assignment
description: Students write a persuasive argument supporting an opinion about a topic related to the novel Tuck Everlasting. Students’ work is evaluated for comprehension and writing skills, as well as for their ability to engage intellectually with the topics of the unit.

title: Tuck Everlasting: Comparing Media
description: Students view the Disney movie version of the novel Tuck Everlasting, comparing and contrasting the two versions critically through class discussion and in writing.

title: Storytelling and the Mythopoetic Worldview
description: Students read and discuss Why the Sun and Moon Live in the Sky and The Star-Bearer: A Creation Myth from Ancient Egypt, which introduces them to a mythopoetic worldview. Students discuss how a mythopoetic worldview differs from a scientific worldview.

title: Night Sky Poem
description: Students imagine what ancient people might have seen as they observed the heavens. They write and illustrate poems based on their own observations of the night sky.

title: Ancient Egypt Vocabulary Quiz
description: Students take a 10-word vocabulary quiz to test their knowledge of definitions and parts of speech.

title: Tales of Ancient Egypt: Reading, Discussing, and Visual Language
description: Students meet in literature circles to discuss the short story “Isis and Osiris” from Tales of Ancient Egypt. They also read other retellings of the story and then explore Plutarch’s translation of the myth. Students have the opportunity to read The Egypt Game by Zilpha Keatley Snyder or The Golden Goblet by Eloise Jarvis McGraw as part of their independent reading.

title: The Origins of Writing: Cuneiform from Mesopotamia and Egyptian Hieroglyphs
description: Students complete a series of activities to learn about pictograms and how they were created and about the rebus principle and its connection to phonetic signs. They study examples of cuneiform from Mesopotamia and Egyptian hieroglyphs and, finally, use a chart of hieroglyphs to write their names.

title: The Shipwrecked Sailor: An Egyptian Tale with Hieroglyphs
description: Students read aloud an ancient Egyptian folktale, which was inscribed on a papyrus scroll. They use a glossary to decode the hieroglyphs in the final sentence.

title: The Egyptian Scribe
description: Students write a biography or autobiography of an Egyptian scribe, noting the scribe’s prominence in and contribution to Egyptian society.

title: The Big Wave
description: Students read The Big Wave by Pearl S. Buck. Sitting in a literature circle, they analyze the novel in terms of narrative elements such as setting, characters, plot, sequence, conflict resolution, and theme. They also analyze the text for figures of speech such as metaphor, simile, and personification.

title: Vocabulary Assignment, Quiz 1, and Monthly Reading Log
description: The Vocabulary Assignment and Quiz 1 align with and support the readings about the Indus Valley in Cultural History. Students track their independent reading progress using their Monthly Reading Log.

title: Catastrophe Short Story and Grammar Review
description: In this creative writing assignment, students imagine that they have survived the forces of a natural catastrophe and write an original short story about their experience. Students evaluate and revise the first drafts of their story using the Revision Checklist to create a final draft. Their work is assessed using the Catastrophe Short Story Rubric.

title: Vocabulary Assignment, Quiz 2, and Monthly Reading Log
description: The Vocabulary Assignment and Quiz 2 align with and support the readings about Hinduism in Cultural History. Students continue to track their independent reading progress using their Monthly Reading Log.

title: Shiva’s Fire
description: Students read Shiva’s Fire by Suzanne Staples Fisher. Sitting in a literature circle, they discuss the novel, focusing on the main character, Parvati, and her struggles to achieve her destiny.

title: Vocabulary Assignment, Quiz 3, and Monthly Reading Log
description: The Vocabulary Assignment and Quiz 3 align with and support the reading of Shiva’s Fire. Students continue to track their independent reading progress using their Monthly Reading Log.

title: Hindu Creation Myths: The Purusha Sukta
description: The Purusha Sukta is the “Hymn to the Cosmic Man,” the all-knowing source of all creation. Since the story is part of the Rig Veda and often chanted, it is a good introduction to the Vedas and to the Rig Veda in particular.

title: Vocabulary Assignment, Quiz 4, and Monthly Reading Log
description: The Vocabulary Assignment and Quiz 4 align with and support readings about the Hindu deities. Students continue to track their independent reading progress using their Monthly Reading Log.

title: Vocabulary Assignment, Quiz 5, and Monthly Reading Log
description: The Vocabulary Assignment and Quiz 5 align with and support readings on Ancient China. Students continue to track their independent reading progress using their Monthly Reading Log.

title: Chinese Creation Myths
description: Students read the Chinese creation myth and compare it with the creation myths of Sumer, Egypt, and the Indus Valley.

title: The Chinese Book of Odes
description: Students read excerpts from the Chinese Book of Odes. The Chinese Book of Odes, sometimes called the Book of Songs, is the oldest recorded collection of Chinese poems, dating from as early as 1000 BCE in the early Zhou Dynasty. Students read and discuss these poems.

title: Vocabulary Assignment, Quiz 6, and Monthly Reading Log
description: The Vocabulary Assignment and Quiz 6 align with and support readings on Peru’s Caral-Supe Valley. Students continue to track their independent reading progress using their Monthly Reading Log.

title: William Pène du Bois’s The Twenty-One Balloons
description: Students read The Twenty-One Balloons independently or in groups and respond to guided questions to discuss the novel. They write about the novel in their journals, adding new vocabulary they have learned and information about the island of Krakatoa. They also may draw a map of the island in their journals.

title: The Myth of the Minotaur
description: In collaboration with Cultural History class, students research, read, and discuss the myth of the Minotaur.

title: Vocabulary Assignments
description: Students learn vocabulary associated with the myth of the Minotaur and ancient Crete.

title: Essay Writing on the Myth of the Minotaur
description: Students write an essay using the revision process on a theme from the myth of the Minotaur.

title: Twilight of the Goddess Writing Assignment and Vocabulary
description: Students write about how the Minoan civilization represented the twilight of the goddess. They imagine living in ancient Crete and ponder its demise. This formative assessment is given in Cultural History as well as World Languages and Literature: English. Students also study vocabulary connected with the topic.

title: Letter Writing
description: Students write letters to incoming fifth graders describing the year's highlights.

title: Field Trip
description: Students draft a proposal for a field trip and implement it. After the trip is finished, students write reflections on the trip.

title: Ongoing Reading Assignment
description: Students read fiction and non-fiction of their own choosing independently throughout the year and keep an annotated bibliography of books they have read.

title: Olmec Were-Creature Narration
description: Students create were-creatures and write essays that serve as voiceovers to narrate their visual creations.

title: Writing a Phoenician Mariner’s Log
description: Students write imaginary journals or logs of Phoenician mariners. The logs include maps, drawings, and receipts or bills of sale written in the Phoenician alphabet.

title: Research and Presentation for Ancient Hebrews Group Project
description: Students work collaboratively to research and present oral and visual reports on topics related to the ancient Hebrews. They speak from outlines, cite sources, and create either posters or digital presentations to support ideas in their presentations.

title: Writing News for The Biblical Times Project
description: Students use their research from the Ancient Hebrews Group Project to create The Biblical Times, a print or virtual newspaper based on events in the ancient Hebrew culture.

title: Flood Story Essay
description: Students write a four-paragraph essay comparing biblical and Sumerian flood stories, based on Venn diagrams they completed in Cultural History class.

title: The Story of The Iliad
description: In connection with their study of Greek gods and goddesses in Cultural History, students read Rosemary Sutcliff’s book, Black Ships Before Troy, which tells the story of the Iliad. Then they construct a timeline of events in the epic and discuss the concept of the Greek hero as embodied by Achilles, Agamemnon, and Odysseus. Finally, students complete four worksheets to review the plot and themes and to prepare for a quiz on the text.

title: Black Ships Before Troy Quiz
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the main ideas, themes, and characters in Black Ships Before Troy by completing a short-answer quiz. They answer 10 questions, plus one challenge question, based on the first three reading assignments of the text.

title: The Story of The Odyssey
description: Students explore ancient Greek epics by reading The Adventures of Ulysses by Bernard Evslin. They get more exposure to Greek mythology and culture and use the reading to take notes, make a timeline, and review events and themes from the story. They discuss what a Greek hero is and use Ulysses (Odysseus) as their model.

title: The Adventures of Ulysses Quiz
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of plot and characters in The Adventures of Ulysses by completing a short-answer quiz. They identify five characters from the text and then answer five questions about events in the story.

title: Odyssey Board Game
description: Students show their understanding of the story of The Odyssey by creating a board game about the story. Working in three teams to create the game, students divide the work into the location of the adventure, questions about Ulysses travels, and bonus questions. All students contribute to the game by suggesting specific rules, scoring systems, and objectives in a class discussion. When the game is complete, students play in teams. The first team to reach Ithaca successfully is the winner.

title: Lost Atlantis Essay
description: After researching the lost city of Atlantis, students write an essay that proposes three different hypotheses as to where it was located, what it was like, and why it disappeared. They support their claims with evidence from mythology and current Science. They respond to one of these questions: “Which story—or hypothesis—do you find most believable, and why?” “Why you think these stories about the unexplained spring up so frequently?”

title: Ancient Greece Unit Final
description: Students take a final test about ancient Greek myths and the classic tragedies they have read. They answer short-response, identification, and fill-in-the-blank questions, and an extended-response essay.

title: Confucius, Lao-Tzu, and the Buddha
description: Students read and research texts on ancient China and India, particularly writings of and about Confucius, Lao-Tzu, and the Buddha.

title: Chinese Culture Group Presentation
description: Working in groups of three, students select one topic related to ancient China, research it, and make a group oral presentation about their findings.

title: Confucius Meets Lao-Tzu
description: Working in pairs, students envision an encounter between Confucius and Lao-Tzu and create an imaginary dialogue between them that reveals the students’ understanding of the views and character of each philosopher.

title: Feng Shui Activity
description: Students learn the principles of feng shui and analyze their own bedrooms to find the best arrangement of furniture and objects.

title: Chinese Poetry Portfolio
description: Students read, discuss, and write about the context and characteristics of Chinese literature and poetry and then create their own Chinese poetry portfolios, writing and illustrating original poems.

title: Ancient China Test
description: This assessment, given in Cultural History class, tests students’ understanding of the origins and tenets of three philosophical schools of thought—Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism.

title: Introduction to the Short Story
description: Students learn about the elements of the short story and how to map these elements.

title: The Short Story Persuasive Essay
description: Students practice analyzing short stories and then write a persuasive essay based on one short story, answering the question, “Is love selfish or selfless?

title: Introduction to the Qur’an
description: Students learn about the significance of the Qur’an and read the opening sura.

title: The Qur’an as Literature: Examining the Suras
description: Students read, respond to, and share a collection of suras from the Qur’an with a focus on the themes and images included in the works.

title: The Emergence of Islamic Literature
description: Students explore how Islamic writers used figurative language to convey sometimes subversive ideas in their works. They learn how this use of language is an example of the emergence of the Algebraic Mentality.

title: The Arabian Nights
description: Students read a play version of Scheherazade’s nightly telling of tales to save her from her violent, ruling husband.

title: The Arabian Nights In-Class Short Answer Assessment
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of several of Scheherazade’s tales by answering analytical questions about The Arabian Nights.

title: The Arabian Nights Play Production Essay
description: Students write an essay explaining creative choices a member of a production crew would make in staging a performance of The Arabian Nights play.

title: The Poetry of Rumi
description: Students view a film about Rumi’s life and influence and read and discuss a selection of his poems.

title: Salman Rushdie’s Haroun and the Sea of Stories
description: Students read and react to this text. They also research and discuss Rushdie’s experiences following publication of The Satanic Verses.

title: Persian Poetry Test
description: After working on the various translations of The Rubáiyát and examining poetry by Rumi, students demonstrate their learning through short-answer responses to the Persian Poetry Test.

title: Beowulf Versions Analysis
description: Students examine and analyze various versions of Beowulf and complete character studies of Beowulf and Grendel.

title: Snorri Sturluson’s Prose Edda: The Prologue and Gylfaginning
description: Students explore the first two parts of Snorri Sturluson’s Prose Edda, a renowned work of Scandinavian literature and the most extensive source for Norse mythology. They explore the Norse creation myth and the final battle of Ragnarok to gain a foundational understanding of the culture and belief system of the Vikings.

title: Gylfaginning Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students take short reading comprehension quizzes on the second part of Snorri Sturluson’s Prose Edda.

title: The Illustrated Skaldskaparmal
description: The Skaldskaparmal is another section of Snorri Sturluson’s Prose Edda in which many of the important stories of the Norse mythology are told. Students read and illustrate the 10 stories as a graphic novel.

title: Eaters of the Dead
description: Students read Michael Crichton’s novel Eaters of the Dead, which is based on the travels of Ibn Fadlan and on Beowulf, to extend their understanding of the Vikings.

title: Eaters of the Dead Final Project
description: Students choose from a variety of optional projects to demonstrate what they have learned about Eaters of the Dead.

title: Satire in The Canterbury Tales
description: Students explore the literary technique of satire and examine stereotyping as these two elements apply to their reading of the General Prologue and select tales from Chaucer’s work.

title: The Canterbury Tales Best-Told Tale Short Essay
description: Students decide which character in The Canterbury Tales tells the best tale and then write a persuasive essay to explain and justify their choice.

title: The Canterbury Tales Final Test
description: Students take a final test to demonstrate their knowledge of the themes and characters in Chaucer’s The Canterbury Tales.

title: Japanese Poetry: Haiku and Waka
description: Students learn the structure and meaning behind haiku and waka forms of feudal Japanese poetry.

title: Writing Waka Poetry
description: Students work in groups to create a waka, after which they individually complete a collection of waka, based on the ephemeral quality of nature and of filial devotion.

title: Murasaki Shikibu’s The Tale of Genji
description: Students read excerpts from this romantic novel about cultural life in feudal Japan.

title: The Tale of Genji Essay
description: Students write a short essay to address aspects of the novel.

title: Historical Novel: Of Nightingales That Weep
description: Students read and respond to this historical novel set in feudal Japan.

title: Of Nightingales That Weep Quiz
description: This short-answer quiz addresses the political and cultural aspects of feudal Japan as well as characters in the novel.

title: Of Nightingales That Weep Essay
description: Students write an essay about either the rites of passage that the protagonist undergoes throughout the novel or the role that cultural expectations play in the protagonist’s life.

title: Historical Novel: The Samurai’s Tale
description: Students read and respond to The Samurai’s Tale, a historical novel by Erik Haugaard that depicts the world of the samurai and the honor code of the Bushid.

title: The Samurai’s Tale Test
description: This extended- and short-response test addresses quotation analysis, the qualities of Japanese writing, and the qualities of a samurai in comparison with the qualities of a European knight.

title: West African Storytelling
description: Students learn about griots and the role of oral storytelling in West African cultures.

title: Griot Praise Songs
description: Students learn about griots and the music they perform. They then create and perform original, griot-style praise songs.

title: In-Class Essay on the Role of the Griot
description: In class, students write an essay that explains and analyzes the role griots play in preserving and establishing cultural tenets.

title: Traditional African Poetry
description: Students explore traditional African poetry, analyze one assigned poem, and present their findings to the class.

title: Critical Reviews
description: Students examine the critical review genre and act as critics, writing reviews for classmates’ Cultural History presentations.

title: What Is Media?
description: Students explore television as a technology in relation to its history, the history of screens, and the emergence of today’s “screen culture.”

title: Screen Culture
description: Students analyze how screen media affects them and explore patterns of events, symbols, and behavior in nature and in classic film clips.

title: Working with Screens and Light
description: Students experiment with light and how light and screens interact by studying the work of artists Georges Seurat, Paul Signac, Nam June Paik, and Gunther Uecker.

title: Storytelling without Words
description: Students explore the concept of storytelling without words by examining techniques used in films that depend on non-verbal communication.

title: Film Project(ion)
description: After experimenting with zoetropes, flip books, and a 16-mm film projector, students plan and participate in a live projection event.

title: Fitness Testing
description: To determine their fitness starting point, students complete a baseline test. They perform various activities to gauge their levels of strength, balance, agility, speed, endurance, and flexibility.

title: Basic Nutrition, Portions and Guidelines
description: Students review basic nutrition information to help them keep food logs. They discuss always, sometimes, and rarely foods; basic nutrition guidelines; portion sizes; and food groups.

title: Developing Wellness Logs and Determining Needs
description: Students identify types of fitness and how to develop them. They learn fitness measurement skills, identify lifetime wellness activities and how to perform them safely, and create fitness and nutrition goals. They also state their wellness philosophies and set up wellness logs.

title: Strength and Conditioning Skills
description: To help develop a wide range of fitness skills, students explore a variety of fitness activities.

title: The Ancient Hebrews-Wellness Philosophies
description: Along with their wellness practices, students explore ancient Hebrew texts on health and wellness. They learn a dance and discuss other ancient Hebrew leisure practices.

title: Diet of the Ancient Hebrews
description: Students analyze the ancient Hebrew diet, which is still followed by some modern Jews. They will learn about foods available to ancient Hebrews and how they were obtained, and complete a worksheet on the ancient Hebrew diet.

title: Fitness Testing
description: Students submit wellness logs for feedback on progress and record keeping, retake fitness tests to check progress, and complete a quiz on fitness components.

title: Wellness Logs
description: To complete the unit, students hand in their wellness logs, including a Lifetime Wellness Plan, which will synthesize everything they have learned in this unit.

title: My Olympics
description: Students begin this unit by writing a short essay in class on the role of sports and competition in their lives.

title: History of Greek Olympics and Sport in Everyday Life
description: In this learning experience, students explore the myths and evidence of the early Olympics and other early athletic competitions and examine art, artifacts, and writings to investigate the evolution of the Olympic Games. Students then learn about the events in the Sixth Grade Greek Olympics, which occurs during the Integrated Project: Greek Week and forms part of their Summative Assessment for Unit 2.

title: Running: The Olympic Mini-Marathon (Dolichos 5K)
description: In this learning experience, students learn about the history of the marathon and about a footrace called the dolichos, which first took place in the 15th Olympiad in 720 BCE and was about the length of a modern 5K. Using the “Couch-to-5K” program, they begin preparing for their own 5K race in the Sixth Grade Greek Olympics, where the 5K serves as a mini-marathon.

title: Olympic Diet: Then and Now
description: Students analyze the ancient Greek diet and compare it to a modern Greek diet and a typical American diet. They also explore what we know about the diet of ancient versus modern Olympians. In this way, students better their understanding of how food choices can affect not only a person’s health and well-being, but also his or her physical performance levels in athletic pursuits. Students also explore the concept of eating locally.

title: Pentathlon
description: After learning about the sports involved in the pentathlon, students practice a modified version of these sports in preparation for the Sixth Grade Greek Olympics.

title: Pankration
description: Students explore skills derived from the ancient Greek Olympic event of pankration, which combines boxing and wrestling. They learn how to play the memory game  “Boxing,” which represents pankration in the Sixth Grade Greek Olympics.

title: 2.5K Race
description: Students participate in a 2.5K race to assess their progress in the “Couch-to-5K” program and submit their training logs for graded feedback on their progress and on their ability to keep careful records.

title: Olympic Report
description: For this summative assessment, students develop a presentation that reflects their study of the Olympics through modern history.

title: Sixth Grade Greek Olympics
description: As the culminating activity of the unit and as part of the Integrated Project: Greek Week, students participate in a Greek Olympics. The events are as authentic to the original Greek Olympic Games as possible and consist of the following modified activities: discus throwing, javelin throwing, a 5K run, boxing (using a memory-recall game), chariot races (with students serving as horses), long jump, and short-distance races.

title: Philosophies of Confucius and Lao-Tzu and How They Relate to Wellness and Health
description: To begin their study of ancient Chinese wellness practices, students explore the philosophies of Confucius and Lao-Tzu and how they relate to health and wellness. They compare the premises behind Confucianism and Taoism and explore the concepts of wholeness, energy flow, and balance in their own experience of the world. Finally, they apply the two philosophies to some hypothetical modern, preadolescent health situations.

title: Yin and Yang and How It Reflects in Our Lives
description: Students participate in a balancing breathing exercise of “Dao (Tao) yin” to begin this assessment. They write a reflection on their understanding of the concept of yin and yang and relate it to their experience of the health and wellness of the human body and the natural world and its cycles, such as night and day and winter and summer.

title: Qi and Its Role in the Human Meridian Energy System
description: Students explore images and classical Taoist teachings in order to better understand the patterns of the flow of life force, or Qi, through nature and how it reflects in our human body, mind, and spirit according to ancient traditional Chinese philosophy.

title: Wushu: Chinese Martial Arts Program
description: In this learning experience, students learn the fundamental skills necessary to perform and create basic Wushu sequences.

title: Wushu Performance
description: Working in small groups, students choreograph and perform original Wushu movement sequences, based on their understanding of the principles of Wushu and traditional Chinese philosophy they have learned over the course of several classes.

title: Traditional Chinese Medicine—The Five Elements
description: Students explore the classical concept of the five elements in relation to the understanding of traditional Chinese medicine, based on a review of the underlying principles of energy flow and the balancing of the five elements.

title: Chinese Medicine Guides
description: To show their understanding of the basic principles of traditional Chinese medicine, students create their own charts of the meridian flow wheel, the five elements, or the yin-and-yang symbol or in a chart form.

title: Yin and Yang Nutrition
description: In the final learning experience of this unit, students analyze the ancient Chinese diet as it relates to health and well-being. They learn which foods have yin qualities and which have yang qualities and how to create meals to develop balance and support health. They also discuss ancient food procurement methods and Chinese food today as a cross-cultural phenomenon.

title: Ancient Chinese Festival
description: As the culmination of Wellness Unit 3, students participate in an Ancient Chinese Festival. Classes throughout the school, families, and guests are invited to participate in the festival and observe the performances. They come dressed in the costumes they created for their original Wushu sequence, perform their original Wushu sequence as well as the group performance of the 16-hands boxing form, and prepare a yin and yang feast to highlight their understanding of Chinese cuisine in relation to its health benefits. In addition, the Chinese Medicine Guides are presented for friends and family to observe.

title: Debunking Stereotypes
description: Students complete a diagnostic assessment to help them understand terms used in discussing tolerance, while also helping them examine their own tendencies toward stereotyping. The assessment will serve as the basis for discussion.

title: Continuum of Hate
description: By creating a continuum that tracks the roots of hate, students recognize the dangers of small acts, such as jokes and stereotyping, and their role in generating hate that can lead to the worst kinds of social injustice.

title: Beyond Tolerance: Modern Understanding of Islam and Arab Nations
description: In this learning experience, students explore the treatment of Muslims in the United States, including the origin of the Patriot Act as it relates to civil freedoms, while discussing if this act has the potential to act on sterotypes and prejudices possibly interfering with civil liberties as a result. In addition, they learn about modern Islam, and contemporary practices that reflect Islamic influence in order to dispel misunderstandings about Islam and to appreciate the richness and significance of Islam and Islamic culture.

title: Islamic Teachings: Health, Wellness and Medical Advances
description: Students learn how Islam, and the Quran in particular, created a foundation of health and wellness among early Muslims. They discover how the Muslim civilization helped preserve Greek medical theory and achieved major advances in medical knowledge.

title: Medieval Islamic Medical Guide
description: Students create a Medieval Islamic Herbal and Nutritional Medicine Guide that will be displayed during Banquet Day and compared to their Medieval European Herbal Medicine Guides in grade 8, Unit 2.

title: Halal, Food Procurement, and Etiquette
description: Students learn about halal, the Islamic dietary laws, and explore common foods and food procurements in the region during the medieval period. In addition, they review the teachings of the Hadith, which relate to food, dining, and social etiquette. As part of this learning experience, students complete a recipe development worksheet as a step in planning for the summative assessment that concludes the unit.

title: Islamic Sport and Leisure
description: Students explore the sport and leisure activities of Muslims during the Golden Age of Islam. They examine the spiritual Sufi dance performed by the Whirling Dervish; study competitions and contests, such as equestrian events; and learn about the strategy games of backgammon and chess.

title: Field Hockey Skills and Drills
description: In this learning experience, students learn about the game of field hockey. They learn about the equipment used, the rules, and the techniques required to play the game.

title: Field Hockey
description: In this assessment, students participate in a game of field hockey and are assessed on their skill development.

title: Banquet of the Alhambra: Preparing an Islamic Meal
description: For this summative assessment, students participate in an Islamic Banquet, which integrates with their Cultural History class. Students dress as medieval Islamic figures, play backgammon and chess, perform the Whirling Dervish Sufi dance and the call to prayer, and prepare an Islamic meal from the recipes they chose in an earlier learning experience. They display their Medieval Islam Herbal and Nutritional Medicine Guides.

title: Knight Fitness Pretest and Core Values
description: The unit begins with students participating in a diagnostic physical exam to assess their current level of “knight” fitness. They complete a basic fitness test to assess general fitness and a strategy game to assess their abilities in logic and planning. Students’ chivalry skills are also assessed, as they complete the fitness and strategy tests.

title: Medieval Diet of the Peasants and Nobility
description: Students compare the diet of the nobility in medieval Europe to the diet of the peasants, discover how unhealthy eating habits developed in medieval Europe, and compare the medieval diet with eating habits in today’s world.

title: Medieval Food Guides
description: Students apply their knowledge of the diets of the nobility and peasants by creating Medieval Food Guides. Students compare the diets of the nobility and peasants and create sample menus for both. Then they relate these diets to modern diets of excess and healthy eating. Students discuss food choices and food preparation as a sign of status in medieval times and in today’s world.

title: Knighthood in Medieval Europe
description: Students explore the function and rise of knights in medieval Europe and the significance of the castle. They also review the steps for becoming a knight. They learn about armor and crests, weapons, levels of fitness, fighting, hunting, strategic thinking, and chivalry. In addition, they study coats of arms and think about appropriate heraldry for their own family histories.

title: Page
description: Students begin the first training phase of knighthood at the page level. They participate in basic fitness activities, which involve fighting, hunting, and strategy skills.

title: Squire
description: By synthesizing skills as fitness and strategic activities become more complicated, students raise their level of knight training. To showcase their skills, students conduct chess and backgammon tournaments, create “knight routines,” and participate in an obstacle course.

title: Medieval Medicine and Herbal Cures
description: Students explore medieval European medical practices and medical theory. They look at the lack of hygiene in medieval Europe, especially in England, and the effect of city living on health. Students examine medieval European herbal medicine in great detail to help them understand the role of nature and folklore in healing and the rise of the medieval garden.

title: Medieval Gardens and Herbal Guide
description: In this assessment, students research and create medieval European herbal guides and also create personal maps of a medieval garden. The students then use their medieval garden maps to plant a medieval herb garden.

title: The Black Death and HIV
description: In this learning experience, students compare elements of the bubonic plague (Black Death) to HIV as it relates to a genetic protective factor. Through this comparison, students learn about genetic mutation and the Delta-32 sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Tournament: The Knight’s Test
description: Students participate in an obstacle course to test their progress and development throughout the unit and to determine if they are physically, socially, and mentally prepared for knighthood.

title: Knight Dubbing Ceremony
description: Students create and reenact a knight dubbing ceremony. In addition, both medieval Islamic herbal and nutrition guides and medieval European food guides and herbals are displayed. Students write an essay about the role of knighthood in their lives and another essay that compares the guides.

title: Wellness of the 1920s
description: Students answer several questions about topics relating to the 1920s to assess their current knowledge of the era prior to beginning the unit.

title: The “Golden Age of Sports”
description: While learning about sports in the 1920s, students discuss professional sport culture and the emergence of both male and female sports heroes. They also focus on the popularity of tennis and its relation to socioeconomic class as they prepare to play tennis.

title: Tennis Skills
description: Through drills and playtime, students learn the basic skills required to play the game of tennis and develop those skills in order to progress toward game play.

title: Prohibition Studies
description: In this assessment, students research and prepare a brief presentation in order to inform their class about a specific element pertaining to the Eighteenth Amendment and the emergence of new elements of culture based on Prohibition.

title: Leisure in the 1920s
description: Students examine leisure in the 1920s as it relates to youth culture, music, race, and economics, and especially women and the new liberated values regarding dress, attitudes, alcohol, and substances. As students discuss F. Scott Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby in other domains, they develop a context to better understand leisure in the 1920s as it is discussed in this wellness unit. Students learn the history of dance, such as the Charleston, as well as learning the basic steps of the Charleston. In addition, they conceptualize the raciness of the liberal dance moves of the Charleston as it relates to risqué dance moves popular with some of today’s youth.

title: Drug Culture of the 1920s and Today
description: Students explore drugs other than alcohol of the 1920s as they relate them to modern substance use and abuse. They investigate questions such as the rationale for drug use in the 1920s and in contemporary American culture and touch on the causes and cycle of addiction.

title: Legalization vs. Criminalization (Prohibition) Debate
description: Based on leading questions and defined subject areas, students research and debate assigned topics about the legalization of alcohol vs. Prohibition in the 1920s and the legalization of marijuana vs. criminalization today.

title: Pandemics Throughout History
description: In this learning experience, students compare the 1918 flu outbreak with other pandemics, past and present. They also investigate the role of modern medicine in controlling pandemics and other communicable diseases.

title: Tennis Match
description: In this summative assessment, students play in a doubles tournament and are graded on their tennis skill development and their performance in the game.

title: News Writing Workshop
description: Students explore the structure and style of news and feature articles. They write news and feature stories based on real or imagined events during the Classical Maya period.

title: Latin American Myths and Maya Origin Myth (Popol Vuh)
description: Students read two versions of a Maya nature myth and read aloud Popol Vuh, a Maya origin and creation myth. They study vocabulary words to support their understanding ofPopul Vuh.

title: Popol Vuh Vocabulary Quiz
description: Students take a quiz on the vocabulary words they have studied to support their understanding of Popol Vuh.

title: Creative Nature Myths
description: Students write original nature myths based on their reading of a Maya nature myth.

title: The Well of Sacrifice
description: Students read The Well of Sacrifice by Chris Eboch, a historical novel that takes place during the Maya empire. They discuss the novel in groups and take notes as they read.

title: The Well of Sacrifice Essay
description: Students use their notes to choose a topic related to The Well of Sacrifice and write a full-length essay on the novel.

title: Maya Research Paper, Creative Project, and Oral Presentation
description: In conjunction with their Cultural History class, students write a full-length research paper about an aspect of the Maya that has not been specifically covered in class. They create independent projects based on their research and present their projects orally.

title: Greek Derivatives: Vocabulary from Classical Roots
description: Students complete and discuss activities in Vocabulary from Classical Roots.

title: Biography
description: Students examine the genre of biography and independently read biographies of their choice.

title: Hellenistic Greece Readings and Class Discussions
description: In conjunction with Cultural History studies of Alexander the Great and Hellenism, students continue to read and take notes on a biography of Alexander the Great, Alexander the Great and Ancient Greece by Miriam Greenblatt.

title: Autobiographical Essay Planning
description: In connection with their studies of biography, students read and write autobiographical incident essays.

title: Autobiographical Essay
description: Students demonstrate the writing process by writing autobiographicalincident essays for evaluation.

title: Monologue Project
description: In conjunction with their studies of Alexander the Great in Cultural History, students complete research and write monologues from the point of view of individuals, real or fictional, in Alexander’s life.

title: Interview Project
description: To practice using interview as a method of prewriting, students complete an interview project.

title: Silk Road: Readings
description: In conjunction with their Cultural History classes, students read historical fiction about travel along the Silk Road. Each student keeps a reading journal and participates in discussions about cultural fusion along the Silk Road.

title: Silk Road: Fables
description: Students read and retell fables and folktales from countries along the Silk Road. They analyze the stories for information about the cultures.

title: Silk Road: Essay Writing Project
description: Students write three one-paragraph expository essays on topics inspired by their historical fiction reading about the Silk Road.

title: Silk Road: Independent Writing Project (IWP)
description: Each student writes one composition per week, each in a different genre, all related to a theme. Students learn from the evaluations of their previous compositions as they work on each new composition.

title: The Origins of Rome: Virgil’s Aeneid and Other Stories
description: Students read and discuss the Aeneid as retold in Emily Frenkel’s Aeneas: Virgil’s Epic Retold for Younger Readers and stories about Romulus and Remus. They also view a slide presentation of artistic renderings of the story The Rape of the Sabine Women.

title: Historical Fiction: Augustus and the Rise of Empire
description: Students read a novel about a young, enslaved person in imperial Rome. Through the novel, they encounter historical figures, such as Augustus, and important landmarks, such as Roman baths.

title: Imperial Rome in Fiction Quiz
description: Students complete a quiz that assesses their understanding of life in imperial Rome as depicted in a historical fiction novel.

title: Readings and Performance: Julius Caesar
description: In conjunction with Performing Arts classes, students read, rehearse, and perform an abridged and adapted version of Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar.

title: Historical Fiction: Cleopatra and Roman Egypt
description: In conjunction with their Cultural History classes, students read and annotate a novel about Cleopatra.

title: Cleopatra Writing Assignments
description: In Cultural History and World Languages and Literature: English classes, students write essays based on their annotations in their Cleopatra novels.

title: Romans in Judea: The Bronze Bow
description: In World Languages and Literature: English and Cultural History classes, students read and analyze the novel The Bronze Bow, a work of historical fiction about Roman occupation in Israel by Elizabeth George Speare.

title: The Bronze Bow Journal and Essay
description: After reading The Bronze Bow, each student writes a reflective essay developing an original thesis statement about or inspired by the novel. The essay, completed in Cultural History and World Langauges and Literature: English classes, assesses students’ grasp of the content and historical time presented in the novel.

title: The Parables of Jesus
description: Students read and discuss a selection of parables from The New Testament, examining literal and figurative language, including metaphors, and the morals of the parables.

title: Parable Writing Activity
description: Students plan, draft, revise, and edit their own parables to share with the class.

title: Buddhist Koans and “The Buddha Bowl”
description: Students learn about Ashoka and the spread of Buddhism. They read and discuss Buddhist koans, comparing them to parables. They then read and act out the script of “The Buddha Bowl” parable.

title: The New Imperialism: 19th-Century European Perspectives
description: Students read Rudyard Kipling’s “The White Man’s Burden,” excerpts from John Hanning Speke’s The Discovery of the Source of the Nile, and excerpts from David Livingstone’s Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa in order to access European thought concerning expansion and imperialism.

title: Native Perspectives: Chinua Achebe’s Things Fall Apart
description: Students read Achebe’s classic novel to understand how traditional Ibo culture in Nigeria is threatened by outside forces.

title: Chinua Achebe’s Things Fall Apart Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students complete short-answer quizzes to assess their understanding of Things Fall Apart.

title: Things Fall Apart In-Class Essay
description: Students write an in-class essay on one of the following topics: the nature of Okonkwo’s character in the face of changing circumstances, or the Ibo’s loss of culture and values.

title: Evolving European Perspectives: The Essays of George Orwell
description: Students read “Shooting an Elephant” and “A Hanging” to further their insight into the psyche of the people forced to carry out and enforce their culture’s often-brutal hegemony.

title: Literary Movements of the Modern Period: Short Stories
description: Students examine elements of Romanticism, Realism, Naturalism, and Psychological Realism in four representative short stories of the modern period.

title: Literary Expressionism in Franz Kafka’s The Metamorphosis
description: Students read The Metamorphosis and place Kafka within the artistic context of expressionism. They also compare Kafka’s work to Max Beckmann’s painting Family Picture and other expressionist paintings.

title: The Metamorphosis and Sigmund Freud’s Theories of the Mind
