description: Students are introduced to Sigmund Freud’s tripartite theory of the mind and his Oedipus complex. They then write a critical essay in which they apply Freudian principles to Kafka’s The Metamorphosis.

title: Dream Log and Narrative: Expressing the Unconscious Mind
description: In this assessment, students record a series of their dreams; then choose one to expand into an extended narrative.

title: Modern Poetry: Charles Baudelaire, Langston Hughes, and Others
description: Students discuss the poems of modern poets, including Charles Baudelaire and Langston Hughes. They note the relationship between the modernist innovations of free verse, symbolism, jazz elements, and African-American language and culture.

title: World War I Poetry
description: Students analyze seminal World War I poems that address the realities of warfare. They also learn about technological innovations in weaponry and the challenges of trench warfare.

title: Erich Maria Remarque’s All Quiet on the Western Front
description: Students read Erich Maria Remarque’s All Quiet on the Western Front, the prototype of the modern war novel. They examine characterization and recurring themes, such as desensitization to death and loss of youth, as well as broader connections to absurdism and existentialism.

title: All Quiet on the Western Front Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students take short quizzes to assess reading comprehension and essential understanding of All Quiet on the Western Front.

title: All Quiet on the Western Front Final Essay
description: Students write an in-class essay on one of several themes in All Quiet on the Western Front.

title: Introduction to Early Feminism and Virginia Woolf’s A Room of One’s Own
description: Students learn about the contributions that early feminists, such as Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Victoria Woodhull, made to the women’s rights movement. They also read a chapter from Virginia Woolf’s classic essay A Room of One's Own to explore women as writers and portrayals of women in literature.

title: Alice Walker’s “In Search of Our Mothers’ Gardens”
description: Students read Alice Walker’s essay “In Search of Our Mothers’ Gardens,” which extends Virginia Woolf’s claims of the inequity of women in fiction to the hardships of African American women who are writers and artists.

title: Zora Neale Hurston’s Their Eyes Were Watching God
description: Students read Zora Neale Hurston's novel Their Eyes Were Watching God. They discuss the portrayal of the protagonist, Janie, as well as the use of African-American dialect and the power of language to undermine dominant cultural values.

title: Their Eyes Were Watching God Final Essay
description: Students write an essay on one of two topics about the novel Their Eyes Were Watching God.

title: The Holocaust: Background and Scale
description: Using print and digital resources, students learn of the political, economic, and cultural conditions that gave rise to the Holocaust. They are also introduced to three major works of Holocaust literature: Primo Levi’s Survival in Auschwitz, Elie Wiesel’s Night, and Viktor Frankl’s Man’s Search for Meaning.

title: Art Spiegelman’s Maus
description: Students read and respond to Art Spiegelman’s Pulitzer Prize-winning graphic novel Maus. Specifically, they explore characterization, the split-narrative technique, and the effect of metafiction in post-modern literature.

title: Art Spiegelman’s Maus Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Students take short quizzes to assess their understanding of Maus.

title: Maus Group Presentations
description: In groups, students fully examine a topic they explored during their reading and discussion of Maus, sharing that information with the class in a formal presentation.

title: Totalitarianism and the Dystopian Novel: George Orwell’s 1984
description: Students learn about the dangers of totalitarian governments and track elements of dystopian literature through their reading of Orwell’s classic novel 1984.

title: George Orwell’s 1984 Reading Comprehension Quizzes
description: Student takes short quizzes to assess their reading comprehension of Orwell’s 1984.

title: Dystopian Narrative Writing
description: Students draw on the themes of 1984 and the elements of dystopian fiction to construct their own dystopian narrative.

title: The Vietnam War and The Things They Carried
description: Students read Tim O’Brien’s The Things They Carried and explore the geopolitical context of the Vietnam War. Particular focus is given to the vulnerability of all political systems to corruption.

title: “The Things We Carried” Short Story Writing
description: Students craft their own short story modeled on Tim O’Brien’s title story “The Things They Carried.” They reflect on what teenagers carry in their backpacks, focusing on how the objects symbolize aspects of individual identity and experience.

title: Post-Colonial Literature: Short Stories (Alexie, Lahiri, Kincaid, and Mukherjee)
description: Students discuss the elements of post-colonial literature and examine a representative collection of short stories in which these elements appear.

title: Post-Colonial Literature Presentations
description: In groups, students present a close reading of a post-colonial short story.

title: Connecting to Post-Colonial Definitions of Self: Essays (Baldwin, Murakami, and Asayesh)
description: Students read a collection of personal essays emphasizing post-colonial elements.

title: The Art of the Personal Essay
description: Students draw on post-colonial themes to write an informal personal essay about an aspect of their identity.

title: The Importance of Clans
description: Students explore clans and their importance during the Neolithic era. They form their own classroom “clans” and write stories about their clan’s lifestyle, spiritual beliefs, and rituals.

title: Writer’s Workshop—Origin Stories
description: Students learn about the oral storytelling tradition and develop a working definition of the term origin story. They read origin stories from Africa and Australia, create and illustrate origin stories for their classroom clan, and perform the stories in class.

title: Reading Workshop
description: Students read and discuss historical fiction set in the Neolithic Era and determine which portions of these books are fact and which are fiction.

title: Researching Neolithic Spiritual Beliefs
description: Students research and write reflections on aspects of Neolithic spiritual beliefs, then compare Neolithic beliefs with those of today.

title: Quiz: Neolithic Rituals and Practices
description: Students create quizzes that reflect what they have learned about people of the Neolithic period. They also write answer keys and take the quizzes as a formative assessment.

title: Lunar Stories
description: Students use their knowledge of Neolithic peoples and their cultural practices to write historical fiction about ways early humans may have used the phases of the Moon for timekeeping.

title: Early Humans and Their Environment
description: Based on information students learn in Cultural History class, they write an essay on how humans used their environment to survive and thrive.

title: Bridging Connections out of Africa
description: After exploring the migration routes of early humans, students create a migration journal for a fictional early human character traveling with a clan.

title: The Meaning of Human Settlement
description: “What does it mean to settle?” Students consider this question and create charts to display their conclusions.

title: Documenting Staff-of-Life Vocabulary
description: Students explore vocabulary words from Cultural History class by adding them to their World Languages and Literature: English class documentation board.

title: Researching Çatal Hüyük
description: Afer exploring the Mysteries of Çatal Hüyük website, students choose an artifact from the site and write a short fiction piece about a ritual that involved it.

title: Support for Cultural History Integrated Project: Human Settlement Project
description: To support the Cultural History Integrated Project: Human Settlement, students participate in writing workshops on planning, drafting, editing, revising, and publishing their research, proposal, and script.

title: Writing About a Trip to a Museum
description: After visiting a museum to view artifacts from early human settlements, students write a paper comparing what they learned during their visit with knowledge gained from this unit.

title: What Makes a Community Work?
description: Students discuss communities they have learned about or experienced, from pre-Neolithic to their classroom communities. They create Venn diagrams for comparison, develop a thesis statement, and write a short essay on communities, including a prediction about how Native American communities may be similar to or different than those previously studied.

title: Research and Write: The First North Americans
description: Students read about, research, and discuss Native American cultures. They visit a local museum with Native American exhibits, and write about their findings in their journals, distinguishing between main ideas and details.

title: Illustrating Iroquois Myths
description: Students read and illustrate Iroquois myths. They then write and illustrate original myths based on similar themes. Students act as storytellers to present their myths to the class.

title: Researching the Iroquois
description: Students develop their research skills by investigating aspects of Iroquois life. They use their research to write a report that they present as part of a class symposium.

title: The Great Law of Peace
description: Students apply their study of communities to the Iroquois Great Law of Peace and the formation of the Iroquois Confederacy. They discuss the role of governing documents, not only among the Iroquois but also among government today. Then, in collaboration with Cultural History, the class simulates an Iroquois-style council meeting.

title: Mississippian vs. Iroquois
description: Students research Mississippian culture and compare it with the Iroquois. They develop theories about why the Mississippian culture did not survive and write persuasive essays supporting their positions.

title: Creating a Mississippian Marketplace
description: In conjunction with Cultural History, students study Cahokia as a center for Native American trading and the role the Mississippi River played in Mississippian culture. They then participate in a simulated Mississippian marketplace.

title: Feudal Japan: Geography and Key Terms
description: Students are introduced to Japanese geography and its role in shaping Japanese society and culture, as well as key vocabulary for the unit.

title: Shintoism and Zen Buddhism
description: Students research Shintoism and Zen Buddhism, contributing the main ideas about these two important Japanese traditions to a class discussion.

title: The Heian and Kamakura Periods
description: Students read about and compare and contrast two different periods of feudal Japan.

title: Feudal Japan Quiz
description: Students answer questions about Japanese geography and the Ring of Fire, as well as the historical impact of the two clans, the Fujiwara and the Minamoto.

title: Japan in Film: Kurosawa’s Seven Samurai and Others
description: Students view and respond to films that illuminate feudal Japan’s society and culture.

title: Gagaku Music, Brush Painting, and the Tea Ceremony
description: Students choose one aspect of feudal Japan to explore and present to the class. Potential topics include Gagaku music, the tea ceremony, Japanese brushwork, Japanese feudal castles, Japanese armor and weapons, Shinto shrines, and Zen temples and gardens.

title: Feudal Japan and Medieval Europe Essay
description: Students connect their learning from this unit with that of Unit 2: Medieval Europe: The Vikings, Franks, and English by writing an essay comparing the life of a Japanese samurai warrior with that of a medieval European knight.

title: West African Geography, Caravans, and Trade Routes
description: Using online maps and photos, students create their own maps to understand the physical and cultural geography of West Africa, as well as the purpose and significance of caravans and caravanserai.

title: Key Terms for the Study of West African Empires
description: Students learn key vocabulary and terms related to their study of West African empires.

title: Salt and Gold Trade
description: Students examine West African economic systems in this time period, focusing on the importance of salt and gold as well as of bartering and taxation.

title: Sundiata and the Griot
description: Students read aloud and act out the story of Sundiata, the Lion King of Mali, focusing on the role of the griot and oral tradition in African society.

title: Mansa Musa: The Legend and the Man
description: Students research Mansa Kankan Musa, the Kingdom of Mali ruler, whose lavish pilgrimage to Mecca was well documented and revealed the wealth of his West African kingdom. They imagine themselves traveling on the pilgrimage and write about it in a first-person account.

title: West Africa Guidebook Project
description: To reinforce and extend their knowledge of the medieval West African kingdoms of Ghana and Mali, students create a West Africa guidebook. This assessment can take the form of an actual book with illustrations and maps, a website, or a series of classroom presentations.

title: West African Empires Test
description: Students respond to recall and extended-response questions on a final unit test.

title: The United States and World War I: Isolationism or “Make the World Safe for Democracy”
description: Students focus on when and why the United States entered World War I and the war’s effect on the nation. The United States emerged from the war a global player. Woodrow Wilson, calling the Great War the war “to end all wars,” proposed the League of Nations as a means to keep world peace. After the war, however, the United States retreated back into its prewar mood of isolationism and rejected Wilson’s plans. Students discuss and evaluate Wilson and the League of Nations in terms of their idealism.

title: The Roaring Twenties
description: Students explore the dichotomies of the 1920s. On the one hand, there were positive social and cultural changes, such as the 19th Amendment, which gave women the right to vote; the Harlem Renaissance, which popularized African American music and literature; and jazz, flappers, Charlie Chaplin, and the advent of the Model T. On the other hand, there were negative social, cultural, and economic changes, such as the 18th Amendment (Prohibition), speakeasies, gangsters, immigration quotas, and the rise of the Klu Klux Klan. The party of the Roaring 20s ended with the stock market crash of 1929.

title: The 1930s and the Great Depression
description: The 1930s provide a stark contrast to the free-wheeling 1920s. The party came to an end with the Stock Market Crash of 1929. The Dust Bowl worsened the nation’s dire economic situation. Students compare President Hoover’s inaction in the crisis with Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal, an aggressive plan to heal the nation.

title: 1920s/1930s Comparison Essay
description: Students write a creative essay comparing life in the 1920s to the 1930s from the point of view of a family member whose family has live in both decades. Students use a Venn diagram to set up the essay.

title: Unit Final Exam
description: Students prepare for and take the Unit Final Exam in which they are assessed on their understanding and comprehension of World War I, the 1920s, and the 1930s. The exam has multiple-choice questions, fill-in-the-blank questions, and short-essay answer questions.

title: One-to-One Correspondence “Counting”
description: Students learn how one-to-one correspondence systems were used before the development of number systems, and they begin to see the benefits of symbolic representation for the abstract concept of numbers.

title: Tribal Warfare Counting Project
description: Students are challenged to develop a one-to-one correspondence method for communicating how many cows a losing tribe must pay to a victor, without the use of a number system.

title: Counting Herds Project
description: Students work in groups to develop a system that can keep track of herds, and they present their projects to the class. As part of this project, students are required to use materials that would have been present during the time period they are studying. At the completion of the project, students write summaries and reflections. They note how this experience relates to the systems used to develop lunar calendars, which are studied in their Cultural History and Science courses.

title: Egyptian Hieroglyphs: Pictorial Numbers
description: Students explore and create Egyptian hieroglyphs, comparing them to Hindu-Arabic numerals. The class carefully analyzes visual representations to determine what they symbolize, in preparation for interpreting the hieroglyphs from King Narmer’s war club. As part of this exercise, students identify the advantages and disadvantages of the Egyptian hieroglyphic number system as compared to previous one-to-one correspondence systems and our modern place value system.

title: King Narmer’s Mace: Hieroglyphs
description: Students interpret hieroglyphs from King Narmer’s war club, or mace, translating the symbols to our current number system to identify the specifics of the king’s booty.

title: Ancient Egyptian Multiplication by Doubling
description: Students learn about the Rhind Papyrus and how to use the ancient African-Egyptian method of multiplication by doubling. They apply the method to solve a multistep historically based problem. They then compare the ancient doubling method to multiplication methods in our current decimal place value system.

title: Quiz: Multiply Like an Egyptian Scribe
description: Students complete the quiz to assess their understanding of this ancient Egyptian method of calculation.

title: Measurement Using a Personal Cubit
description: Students learn about the cubit as a historical measurement of length, and they participate in a simulated Egyptian market to gain an appreciation for the development of uniform units of measurement.

title: Using an Abacus to Explore Place Value Number Systems
description: Students use an abacus to explore how positional (place value) number systems work. This experience helps prepare them to learn the Sumerian base-60 number system, the focus of this unit’s integrated project.

title: Quiz: Mathematics Vocabulary
description: Students begin their study of whole numbers and number concepts by reviewing key terms. They make study cards to review previously learned mathematics vocabulary before completing a quiz that acts as a diagnostic assessment of preparedness for this unit. Students modify and add to the study cards throughout the unit as they continue to refine their understanding of the terms. Students then use their study cards to help them review for the summative assessment.

title: Place Value Review
description: Students identify whole-number place values to the billions, building on their prior knowledge and investigations of number systems from Unit 1. They play a place value game aimed at helping them appreciate the significance of place value in the functioning of our number system.

title: Comparing and Rounding Numbers
description: Students compare and round whole numbers to given place values. They are challenged to contextualize the use of number comparison and rounding in real-world settings.

title: Quiz: Place Value and Rounding Numbers
description: Students respond to a series of short-answer questions that test their knowledge of whole-number operations, place value, and rounding.

title: Estimation
description: Students round numbers in order to estimate sums, differences, products, and quotients, and they then discuss real-world applications of estimation. They work in collaborative groups to create and record written rules for rounding, which they can refer to while solving problems.

title: Quiz: Whole Numbers and Operations
description: Students respond to a series of short-answer questions that assess their knowledge of whole-number operations. They use those operations to solve word problems.

title: Adding and Subtracting Review
description: Students add and subtract numbers to the hundred-millions place and create their own problems to solve and exchange with a partner. As part of the process, they are reminded to use inverse operations to check the integrity of their solutions.

title: Multiplying
description: Students learn how to multiply multidigit numbers using the standard algorithm, including how to rearrange problems into a vertical format, if necessary. They then create their own problems to solve and exchange with a partner.

title: Dividing
description: Students learn how to divide multidigit numbers using manipulatives to model the process in the context of Riverine marketplace scenarios. They also review how multiplication can help them check for accuracy. Students are further challenged to create and share their own problems to solve with their peers.

title: Quizzes: Operations with Multidigit Numbers
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of division of two-, three-, and four-digit numbers by one- and two-digit divisors and other topics studied so far in this unit.

title: Problem-Solving Strategies
description: Students are challenged to identify and use various strategies to solve real-world application problems. They complete a series of problem sets to demonstrate their ability to appropriately apply a range of problem-solving strategies.

title: Perfect Square Numbers
description: Using objects and visuals, students learn how to square a number and how to identify perfect square numbers.

title: Order of Operations
description: Students utilize standard guidelines in the order of operations to create and evaluate multi step expressions. A worksheet helps to develop students’ ability to apply their understanding of order of operations to a variety of expressions.

title: Contest: Order of Operations
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the order of operations by working collaboratively to express a given number in multiple ways. Groups use a rubric to evaluate their work and then compare solutions with other groups to find out which group identified the greatest number of viable solutions.

title: Ancient Egyptian Multiplication by Doubling and Powers of Two
description: Students expand on the Ancient Egyptian Multiplication by Doubling learning experience from Unit 1, focusing on powers of two and the concept of exponents. Students make connections to other number concepts and compare the Egyptian methods to the common multiplication algorithm used today.

title: Quiz: Multiplication by Powers of Two
description: Students complete the quiz to assess their ability to rewrite expressions using powers of two as they calculate solutions.

title: Primes and the Sieve of Eratosthenes
description: Students apply their knowledge of multiples as they simulate the ancient method to identify and define prime numbers and composite numbers described by Eratosthenes.

title: Test: Whole Numbers and Number Concepts
description: This test assesses student understanding and application of all concepts and skills studied in this unit, with the exception of ancient Egyptian multiplication by doubling.

title: Building up to Base Ten
description: Students review previous learning experiences and discuss the meaning and advantages of using place, or positioning, to show different values. They explore how a given value is expressed through tally marks, hieroglyphics, cuneiform, and Hindu-Arabic numerals to trace the evolution of symbolic number systems to the present.

title: Decimal Place Value
description: Physical and visual models are used to explore the basic concepts of one whole, tenths, hundredths, thousandths, and ten-thousandths.

title: Reading and Writing Decimals
description: Students continue to develop their understanding of lesser decimal places as they read and write decimals to the ten-thousandths place using words, numbers, and equivalent fractional representations.

title: Comparing and Rounding Decimals
description: The class begins with a warm-up activity that reinforces previous lessons on place value. Then students learn how to compare and round decimals through individual and group games that involve the use of their calculators. They also create and write rules, in their own words, for rounding decimal values.

title: Quiz: Decimals and Review
description: The quiz assesses the following skills: decimal place value, rounding decimals to a given place, and ordering decimal numbers. Students are challenged to recall their knowledge of whole-number division and multiplication and the use of inverse operations to check the integrity of their work.

title: Adding and Subtracting Decimals
description: Once students have learned about decimal place value, they participate in class discussions, group activities, and individual assignments to add and subtract decimals.

title: Multiplying Decimals
description: Students learn to multiply a decimal and a whole number using repeated addition, manipulatives, and area grids. Then they relate multiplying by 0.5 to halving a whole number, then halving a decimal, and then using manipulatives/area models to work up to finding the product of any two decimal factors using place-value concepts.

title: Quiz: Decimal Operations
description: This quiz assesses students on the decimal operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication. Students also use their decimal-rounding skills.

title: Dividing Decimals
description: Students learn how to divide decimals by whole numbers using area models and are challenged to describe their understanding through diagrams. A worksheet supports students’ understanding of decimal division.

title: Converting Metric Units of Length
description: Students learn to recognize and convert metric units of length, applying their knowledge to estimate relative distances with which they are familiar. As part of this experience, they are encouraged to use an online map service to obtain a real-world value for a known, traveled distance.

title: Babylonian Measurement Project
description: Students draw diagrams of objects related to their studies of ancient Mesopotamia, including possible dimensions in both metric and Babylonian units. They then convert between these two units of measurement.

title: Decimal Measurements and Geometry
description: Students use decimal operations to solve real-life measurement problems involving geometric figures, including the area and perimeter of rectangles, squares, triangles, and other plane figures.

title: Decimals
description: This test assesses students’ understanding of all topics in this unit through a series of short-answer questions that require students to show all work and check the integrity of their solutions.

title: Percentages, Decimals, and Fractions
description: Students read If the World Were a Village, which focuses on world population statistics. They use those statistics as a basis for developing their prior understanding of the concept of percentages and representing percents as equivalent fractions and decimals in preparation for their application to related topics throughout this unit. The primary focus is a mathematical analysis of world food issues, including sustainability.

title: Percentages and Circle Graphs
description: Students learn how to read circle graphs and connect percentages to proportional degrees of a circle. They use graphic displays to help them determine part-to-whole ratios and to aid in the conversion between fractions and percentages, and they use technology to create circle graphs.

title: Reading Data Tables and Graphs
description: Students explore the uses of tables and graphs that they collected during the previous assessment. They learn how to read tables and graphs and how to identify which type of graphic representation is best for certain types of data.

title: Using Measures of Center to Summarize Data
description: Students learn how to find the measures of center, range, and outliers for data presented in tables and graphs. They begin to explore spreadsheet programs to help them better visualize those data descriptors.

title: Probability and Equivalent Fractions
description: During this learning experience, students explore the meaning of probability and the difference between theoretical and experimental probability. They incorporate those concepts into further study of ratios and equivalent and simplified fractions.

title: Statistics and Probability Quizzes
description: Students display their knowledge of the investigated concepts through two quizzes that feature short response questions on equivalent percentages, fractions, and decimals; statistical analysis; and probability. In addition, both quizzes include challenge questions that review concepts studied in previous units.

title: African Elephant Population Trends
description: In this study, students use population statistics of African elephants to predict future population trends. They display their findings graphically, characterize them using measures of center, and describe the natural history of the African elephant in terms of numbers.

title: Statistics and Probability Test
description: This final test of the unit assesses students’ ability to relate equivalent percentages, fractions, and decimals; read graphs and analyze the data shown; and identify the probability of given events occurring.

title: World Hunger Fact Sheets
description: During this assessment, students complete their visual data displays and country fact sheets. They present their findings to their classmates and engage in discussions concerning the analysis of the collected data.

title: World Hunger
description: Students research statistics and facts associated with world hunger, which they will use in later learning experiences to analyze and apply their understanding of percentages, fractions, and decimals to create fact sheets about food security and undernourishment in different countries.

title: Finding Multiples and the Lowest Common Multiples
description: Students review the concepts of multiples, identify lowest common multiples, and apply these concepts to authentic problems. Students revisit the Sieve of Eratosthenes to investigate common multiples and identify least common multiples. Students also demonstrate their understanding of polygon concepts through a review worksheet.

title: Writing Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students use pattern blocks and fraction bars to identify traditional fractions and mixed numbers in addition to fractional relationships. Students are challenged to identify how fractions are used in everyday life.

title: Finding Equivalent Fractions
description: Students use pattern blocks and fraction bars to explore, identify, and write equivalent fractions. They look for patterns in their data to determine a rule for creating equivalent fractions.

title: Simplifying Fractions and the Greatest Common Factor
description: Students investigate how to simplify fractions and mixed numbers. They also discover the role the greatest common factor plays in this process As part of this learning experience, students also review divisibility rules.

title: Converting Improper Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students use pattern blocks and fraction bars to investigate the relationship between improper fractions and mixed numbers and convert between equivalent forms.

title: Test: Equivalent Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students apply what they have learned about equivalent fractions and mixed numbers. The test requires students to find equivalent fractions using a given denominator and convert between improper fractions and mixed numbers. Students also convert between seconds and minutes and between inches and feet.

title: Comparing and Ordering Fractions
description: Students learn how to apply the concepts of equivalent fractions and common multiples to compare and order fractions and mixed numbers. Students are encouraged to model and check their ordering through the use of manipulatives, diagrams, and estimation skills.

title: Adding and Subtracting Fractions
description: Students add and subtract fractions with like and unlike denominators. In collaborative work groups, they determine how to apply their knowledge of common multiples and equivalencies to finding like denominators.

title: Test: Fraction Addition and Subtraction
description: Students apply what they have learned about comparing, adding, and subtracting fractions and mixed numbers. They are required to fully outline their problem-solving process.

title: Egyptian Fractions
description: Students learn how to convert to and use Egyptian fractions, which are sums of unit fractions. They examine how the Egyptians used this concept to write any fraction as a sum of unit fractions, a practice that was useful for trade purposes.

title: Multiplying Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students learn how to multiply fractions and mixed numbers with like and unlike denominators. They work in collaborative learning groups to determine rules for multiplying fractions.

title: Dividing Fractions and Mixed Numbers
description: Students learn how to divide fractions and mixed numbers with like and unlike denominators. Students also learn how to multiply and apply reciprocals. They work in collaborative learning groups to determine rules for dividing fractions.

title: Test: Fraction Multiplication and Division
description: Students apply what they have learned about multiplying and dividing fractions and mixed numbers. They are required to fully outline their problem-solving process.

title: Circle Designs Utilizing Compasses
description: Students create circles of designated diameters using a compass and straightedge. The goal of this lesson is to give students practice developing technical skills in the appropriate use of a compass.

title: Classifying, Measuring, and Constructing Angles
description: Students learn to use protractors to measure, classify, and draw given angles. They also construct common angles using a compass and straightedge. To reinforce the relationship between circles and angle measures, students fold paper circles in half to create straight angles, in half again to create four right angles, and a third time to create eight acute angles.

title: Classifying and Constructing Triangles
description: Students explore how to classify triangles by both their angles and sides and learn how to draw or construct given triangles. Through a series of investigations that make use of AngLegs manipulatives, students determine the relationships that exist between a triangle’s angles and sides.

title: Calculating Perimeter of Triangles
description: Applying their understanding of the characteristics of different classes of triangles, students measure and calculate the perimeters of triangles.

title: Classifying and Measuring Quadrilaterals
description: Through a series of investigations using AngLegs manipulatives, students classify, measure, and create quadrilaterals. A key understanding that students discover is that they may classify quadrilaterals into multiple subcategories, which may provide additional information about a quadrilateral’s properties.

title: Pyramid Project: Constructing a Pyramid
description: As part of the integrated Pyramid Project, students apply their understanding of the characteristics of triangles and quadrilaterals to construct a square pyramid. They also build scaled replicas of the pyramids at Giza.

title: Finding Areas of Rectangles
description: Using square tiles, students learn how to find the area of a rectangle. They investigate the concept of area geometrically, numerically, and algebraically and connect their findings to real-world applications.

title: Finding Areas of Triangles and Composite Figures
description: Students build on the previous learning experience to estimate and calculate the area of triangles. They also investigate the relationship between the area of rectangles, parallelograms, and triangles with the same base length and altitude, or height. Through the comparative area investigations they conduct, students deduce the formula for finding the area of a triangle.

title: Identifying Right Angles and 3-4-5 Right Triangles
description: Students use manipulative materials to investigate triangles with right angles and discover that triangles with side measures of 3 units, 4 units, and 5 units are always right triangles.

title: Pyramid Project: Egyptian Rope Stretchers
description: Students learn how the ancient Egyptian rope stretchers (land surveyors) laid out the square bases of pyramids, demarcated rectangular plots of land, and calculated the area of fields using 3-4-5 right triangles and knotted ropes. Students recreate this process through a hands-on investigation that integrates with their studies of the flooding of the Nile in Science.

title: Triangle Inequality Theorem
description: Students use AngLegs or similar manipulatives to discover the triangle inequality theorem. By constructing or failing to construct triangles with varying side lengths, students demonstrate that the sum of the lengths of the two shorter sides of any triangle must be greater than the third side length.

title: Creating a Labyrinth
description: In this assessment, students practice using rulers and protractors to construct mazes. Students create a maze that mimics that of the Minotaur myth that they learn about in Cultural History.

title: Circles
description: Students learn definitions, descriptions, and illustrations of a circle, center of a circle, radius, chord, and diameter. Students use compasses and rulers to construct circles of given radii and diameters.

title: Pyramid Project: Star Clock Project
description: Students review the relationship between the number of degrees in a circle; our division of time into hours, minutes, and seconds; the sexagesimal number system of ancient Sumer; and the angular rotation of stars around Polaris. They provide a written and illustrative explanation to demonstrate their understanding of these relationships.

title: Test: Geometry and Cumulative Topics
description: Students apply concepts that they have learned in this unit and throughout the year to respond to a series of short-answer, multiple-choice, and fill-in-the-blank problems. Students are required to show all work on short-answer questions. Review sessions are held in class prior to this final test.

title: Geometry in Nature
description: Students identify examples of geometry in nature by viewing physical objects, photographs, or videos. They study relationships between mathematics and nature.

title: Euclid’s Elements
description: Students are introduced to the work of Euclid and the manner in which his work transformed mathematical thinking. They learn about the concept of geometric algebra and learn how Euclid’s work relates to the field of logic. Through their introduction to Euclid’s Elements, students also learn about points, lines, and planes.

title: What Makes a Good Definition
description: Students discuss the characteristics of a good definition as it relates to the study of geometry. They apply their understanding of what makes a good definition to the study of geometric terms from Euclid’s Elements. As they consider those terms, they use the Ruler Postulate, the Segment Addition Postulate, and the Distance Formula.

title: Angles and their Measure
description: Students learn how to define an angle and how to measure an angle. They compare Euclid’s treatment of angles as magnitudes to the modern definition of angle measures. In this study, they use the Protractor Postulate and the Angle Addition Postulate.

title: Quiz: Basic Geometry Terms
description: Students are given a short-answer and multiple-choice assessment to demonstrate their understanding of points, lines and planes, segments, and angles and their measures.

title: Segment and Angle Bisectors
description: Students analyze and define the term bisect to aid in their understanding of a segment bisector and an angle bisector. They use a compass and straightedge to construct segment and angle bisectors, and they make connections to Euclid’s first three postulates. They examine and apply the Midpoint Formula.

title: Angle Pair Relationships
description: Students use digital software such as Geometer’s Sketchpad to construct vertical angles and linear pairs and to explore the relationships between the measures of the angles. They discover (but do not yet prove) the Vertical Angles Theorem, and they analyze and apply the Linear Pair Property. They compare those to the propositions in Euclid’s Elements relating to linear pairs and vertical angles.

title: Perimeter, Circumference, and Area
description: Students review the concepts and formulas for area, perimeter, and circumference of basic shapes and then develop methods to determine area, perimeter, and circumference of composite figures and solve related real-world problems. Students also apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find missing side lengths in order to calculate area and perimeter.

title: Review for Summative Assessment
description: Students work in pairs or individually to review key vocabulary, formulas, and postulates from previous learning experiences in preparation for a summative assessment.

title: Test: Introduction to Geometric Terms, Postulates, Theorems
description: Students apply their knowledge of basic geometry and geometric algebra from the first part of this unit to answer open-ended and multiple-choice items and to construct figures.

title: Introductions to Conditional Statements
description: Students begin the study of logic. They revisit postulates about points, lines, and planes and write them as conditional statements. Through discussion and analysis of logical statements, students learn about the converse, inverse, and contrapositive of a conditional statement. Students discuss Euclid’s contributions to the field of logic.

title: Biconditional Statements
description: Students are introduced to the definition of a biconditional statement. They learn about the relationship between a conditional statement, its converse, and the related biconditional statement, and they practice writing biconditional statements by using Euclid’s definitions. Students determine the truth values of biconditional statements.

title: Deductive Reasoning: Law of Detachment
description: Students use the laws of logic to discuss and evaluate the Mad Tea-Party from Lewis Carroll's Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland. They are introduced to the Law of Detachment as one of the laws of logic.

title: Quiz: Logic
description: Students work individually on a series of questions assessing their understanding of the principles and laws of logic.

title: Reasoning with Properties of Algebra
description: Students examine and apply the algebraic properties of equality. They complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Proving Statements About Segments
description: In this learning experience, students learn definitions for proof and theorem. They learn conventions for writing proofs and use the reflexive, symmetric, and transitive properties of segment congruence to prove statements about segments. Students also complete a compass and straightedge activity in which they construct segments.

title: Proving Statements About Angles
description: Students analyze the tenets of theorems concerning angle congruence, right angle congruence, congruent supplements, and vertical angles. They then prove the theorems.

title: Classroom Work Session
description: Students work in pairs or individually to review concepts of logic and proof in preparation for a summative assessment.

title: Test: Principles of Logic and Proof
description: Students apply their knowledge of the principles of logic and proof to answer open-ended questions and to write proofs.

title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
description: Students examine relationships inherent in parallel and perpendicular lines (and their postulates). They discover the role of transversals in the formation of alternate interior and exterior angles, consecutive angles, and corresponding angles. They complete compass and straightedge construction to form a perpendicular to a line. Students relate the information back to the study of Euclid’s elements. Students complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Proof of Perpendicular Lines
description: Students review and then and prove theorems about perpendicular lines. They complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Parallel Lines and Transversals
description: Students use software such as Geometer’s Sketchpad to construct parallel lines cut by a transversal. They examine the measures of the angles formed and discuss the Corresponding Angles Postulate, Alternate Interior Angles Theorem, Alternate Exterior Angles Theorem, and Consecutive Interior Angles Theorem, and they compare those theorems with corresponding propositions in Euclid’s Elements. Students prove the Perpendicular Transversal Theorem.

title: Using Properties of Parallel Lines
description: Students review and analyze theorems about parallel and perpendicular lines. Using a compass and straightedge, they are challenged to copy an angle and construct parallel lines, and they use their constructions to investigate converses of postulates and previously proven theorems. Students complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines in the Coordinate Plane
description: Students investigate the role of slope in proving parallel and perpendicular lines in the coordinate plane using Geometer’s Sketchpad. Students also recognize the contributions of Descartes, construct parallel and perpendicular lines, determine the slopes of the lines, examine the relationships of the slopes, and then analyze the Slope of Parallel Lines Postulate and the Slope of Perpendicular Lines Postulate.

title: Quiz: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of parallel and perpendicular lines by answering open-ended questions and writing proofs.

title: Unit Test
description: Students solve problems about points, lines, rays, and angles.

title: What Is a Triangle?
description: This initial learning experience introduces students to the formal definition of triangles and classifications by sides and angles. They use previously learned vocabulary terms relating to angles (acute, obtuse, right, vertex, adjacent) as they apply to triangles. The language of base and legs for isosceles triangles and legs and hypotenuse for right triangles is also introduced.

title: Angles in a Triangle
description: Students use diagrams to explore the interior and exterior angle measures of a triangle and discover properties relating to the sums of angle measures.

title: Congruence in Triangles
description: Students explore congruence and corresponding parts in triangles and other polygons. Given congruent triangles, students use equations to find unknown sides and angles. They prove the third angles theorem and examine congruent triangles in architecture.

title: Proving Triangles Congruent
description: Students investigate side-side-side (SSS) and side-angle-side (SAS) congruence of triangles by completing constructions guided by the handout. They relate their findings to those of Euclid’s Elements and use algebra to model and solve equations involving congruent triangles.

title: Construct Congruent Triangles
description: Students explore the angle-side-angle (ASA) postulate and the angle-angle-side (AAS) theorem, including their history. They learn that both Euclid and Thales made important contributions to the development of these two results. Then students use ASA and AAS to construct a triangle congruent to a given triangle, and they apply this knowledge by taking measurements on a map.

title: Formal Proof of Congruence
description: Students write formal proofs of constructions.

title: Exploring Congruent Triangles with Technology
description: Using Geometer’s Sketchpad, students explore the relationships that exist in congruent triangles. They compare measures of sides and angles in triangles that are congruent by SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, and HL and write algebraic statements to represent the relationships.

title: Coordinate Proof
description: Students graph triangles in the coordinate plane and learn to write coordinate proofs involving these triangles. This work includes the use of Geometer’s Sketchpad. They also research the contributions of Descartes and Fermat to the development of analytic geometry.

title: Pair and Share Work Session
description: Students participate in a problem-solving work session, applying the material from the prior learning experiences in this unit. Using their Mathematics notebooks, homework, and prior assessments, they revisit vocabulary, definitions, postulates, theorems, and proofs as they prepare for the summative assessment.

title: Test: Properties and Proving Congruence in Triangles
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of triangles and triangle congruence by responding to short-response questions, writing formal proofs, and completing constructions.

title: Perpendicular Bisectors
description: Students use paper-folding activities or Geometer’s Sketchpad to construct a perpendicular bisector and an angle bisector. They discuss the perpendicular bisector and angle bisector theorems and their converses, and they conjecture about the validity of these theorems for segments on a sphere. They use algebra to find unknown segment lengths and angle measures.

title: Finding Circumcenter and Incenter
description: Students use paper folding, compass and straightedge, or Geometer’s Sketchpad to construct the perpendicular and angle bisectors of a triangle. Through these constructions, they discover the circumcenter and incenter and explore the properties of these points. They develop formal proofs of the properties and solve related problems involving unknown measures as well as problems in the coordinate plane.

title: Centroid and Orthocenter
description: Students construct medians and altitudes of a triangle to discover the centroid and the orthocenter. They use paper folding and Geometer’s Sketchpad to explore properties of these points and to investigate related theorems.

title: Mobile Project
description: Students use triangles to make a mobile by finding the balancing point at the centroid of each triangle.

title: Midsegment Theorem
description: Students use constructions to explore the midsegment theorem. They investigate properties of midsegments of triangles by paper folding, and they use Geometer’s Sketchpad to investigate fractals created with midsegments. They construct a Sierpinski triangle and discuss the contributions of Sierpinski, Mandelbrot, and other mathematicians to the development of fractals. Finally, students write a coordinate proof of the midsegment theorem and apply it to find missing side lengths in triangles.

title: Inequalities in One Triangle
description: Students investigate and apply the Triangle Inequality Theorem. They begin by using triangle measurements to decide which side is longest or which angle is smallest. Students learn the notation to describe the sides or angles of a triangle from least measure to greatest measure. They determine whether three given side lengths will form a triangle, and they solve inequalities to find possible side lengths in a triangle.

title: Classroom Work Session
description: Students work with partners or independently to review congruence and properties of triangles learned in prior learning experiences in this unit. They focus specifically on properties and theorems related to congruence, points of concurrency, midsegments, and inequalities in a triangle.

title: TEST: Triangle Theorems
description: Students complete a 16-problem test on triangle congruence theorems, definitions of concurrence, midpoints, midsegments, and construction of perpendicular bisectors, angle bisectors, and medians.

title: Polygon Identification
description: Students explore shapes and identify which ones are polygons based on the definition of a polygon. Students then identify, name, and describe polygons by their number of sides and whether they are convex or concave. Students learn that polygons were used by ancient Greeks to approximate circles.

title: Parallelogram Theorems
description: Students learn that Propositions 33 and 34 in Euclid’s Elements Book I detail the properties of parallelograms. They use Geometer’s Sketchpad to construct quadrilaterals and then parallelograms specifically, and they make conjectures about the properties of these figures. Students then write formal proofs of four parallelogram theorems and compare their proofs to Euclid’s statements about parallelograms. They apply these theorems to solve algebraically for missing measures in parallelograms.

title: Properties of Parallelograms
description: Students discuss Descartes’s invention of the coordinate system in the context of its integration of Euclidean geometry and algebra. They explore properties of parallelograms and prove that a given quadrilateral is a parallelogram by constructing formal coordinate proofs.

title: Squares, Rhombuses, and Rectangles
description: Students build on prior study of the Pythagorean Theorem as they learn that the distance formula is an adaptation of the Pythagorean Theorem in the Cartesian coordinate system. They apply properties and theorems related to the diagonals of parallelograms to construct squares, rhombuses, and rectangles. Students use coordinate geometry and the distance formula to prove that a given quadrilateral is a square, rhombus, or rectangle.

title: Quiz: Properties of Quadrilaterals
description: Students solve problems about polygons, focusing mainly on quadrilaterals.

title: Properties of Kites and Trapezoids
description: Students begin by reading Euclid’s definition of trapezoid from the Elements and comparing it to the modern definition. Then they use Geometer’s Sketchpad to explore the properties of trapezoids and kites. They use these properties to prove related theorems and solve for missing measurements.

title: Special Quadrilaterals
description: Students learn how to identify special quadrilaterals and prove a given figure’s identity as a square, rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or rhombus, including proofs using coordinate geometry where needed. They also study applications of special quadrilaterals in art, architecture, and design.

title: Areas of Quadrilaterals and Triangles
description: Students learn the area addition postulate and the area congruence postulate and examine Euclid’s use of these concepts in the Elements. Then students complete a hands-on activity to explore the areas of parallelograms, trapezoids, and triangles, and they apply what they have learned to solve real-world and mathematical problems relating to areas of regions. Students conclude the learning experience by working with a partner to prepare for the upcoming assessment.

title: Test: Congruence and Properties of Triangles and Quadrilaterals
description: Students’ understanding of properties related to congruence, triangles, and quadrilaterals is assessed through short-answer and multiple-choice questions, compass-and-straightedge constructions, and coordinate and two-column proofs.

title: Geometry in Art
description: In this learning experience, students examine the presence of geometry in art, culture, and religion. Students study many examples of how geometry appears in art across time and culture, including Renaissance art, ancient Greek and Egyptian art, Islamic art, and Buddhist and Hindu art, as well as modern art. Students also investigate individual artists who are known for using geometry in their art.

title: Line Designs
description: Students examine geometric drawings that contain only straight lines and analyze the ways in which the artists nevertheless create curves and depth. Then they apply symmetry and proportion to create their own geometric line drawings.

title: Daisy Designs
description: Students learn about the Flower of Life, an example of sacred geometry found in early Assyrian and Egyptian art and architecture. As part of their study, they use a compass to construct daisy designs and other symmetrical geometric patterns. They also examine shapes and symmetry in images from stained glass art.

title: Optical Art
description: Students examine the geometry in the Optical Art of Victor Vasarely, analyzing the illusory effects Vasarely achieved through the use of shape, line, and color. They analyze a Penrose triangle and determine why it is an impossible figure to form in three dimensions. Students then use those mathematical techniques to create their own Optical Art.

title: The Geometry of Mandalas
description: Students explore mandalas and the cultures that create them, including the Aztecs and Hindus. They identify the shapes and symmetries found in mandalas, research their meanings, and then construct original simple mandalas.

title: Islamic Art
description: Students learn about the importance of geometry in Islamic art and culture. They analyze and describe geometric elements, including the Islamic star pattern, found in specific examples of Islamic art.

title: Renaissance Art
description: Students revisit the art of the Renaissance period and examine the shapes, symmetry, and proportions in various works. They investigate the use of the Golden Ratio in Renaissance art and create an approximation of the Golden Spiral.

title: Geometry in Art Project
description: Students choose one type of art studied during this unit as inspiration for a piece of original geometric art. Students present their original art to the class, describing its geometric characteristics and historical connections.

title: Scale
description: Students learn about scale and how it applies to the creation of blueprints, art, and models. They also review proportions and learn the cross products property, applying algebra to solve problems involving scale and proportions.

title: Similar Polygons
description: Students use dilations in a plane to learn about similar polygons. They discover that corresponding angles in similar figures are always congruent and that corresponding sides are proportional with the same scale factor. After writing proportions involving ratios of side lengths, they use algebraic properties, such as the cross products property, to solve for missing side measurements.

title: Angle-Angle Similarity Postulate
description: Students learn the Angle-Angle (AA) Similarity Postulate and how it may be applied to determine whether two triangles are similar. They use Geometer's Sketchpad to construct pairs of triangles with two congruent angles to further explore AA similarity in triangles.

title: SAS and SSS Similarity Theorems
description: Students discuss how Propositions 5 and 6 from Book VI in Euclid’s Elements and the AA similarity postulate can be used to prove the side-angle-side (SAS) and side-side-side (SSS) similarity theorems. They prove and apply the theorems to find missing measurements in triangles.

title: Similarity in the Coordinate Plane
description: Students use scale factors to understand dilations of figures about the origin of a coordinate plane. They practice dilating figures and discover that the resulting figures are similar, though not congruent, and that dilation is a similarity transformation. They also explore properties of dilated figures. Students research how dilation is used in optics and how the work of Abu Ali al-Hasan ibn al-Haytham contributed to the field of optics.

title: Quiz: Similarity
description: Students complete a quiz based on the first five learning experiences. They answer a number of short-answer questions related to scale, similar polygons, and triangle similarity.

title: Thales and the Great Pyramid of Giza
description: Students study how Thales of Miletus (c. 624–546 BCE), the father of geometry, measured the height of the Great Pyramid of Giza by using shadows to create similar triangles. They simulate Thales’s work by measuring objects in their environment.

title: Triangle Proportionality Activity
description: Students use Geometer’s Sketchpad and its measuring tools to explore Proposition 2 in Book VI of Euclid’s Elements, which states the Triangle Proportionality Theorem and its converse. Students then work through a guided proof of the theorems.

title: Triangle Proportionality Construction
description: Students apply their knowledge of the triangle proportionality theorem to develop a method using a compass for dividing a segment into three equal parts. This method is largely based on the construction using similar triangles to divide segments into congruent parts, as described in Proposition 9 in Book VI of Euclid’s Elements.

title: Proportionality and Similar Figures
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of all topics related to the study of proportionality and similar figures. Topics include similar polygons, AA similarity, and the triangle proportionality theorem and its converse.

title: Geometric Mean
description: Students learn about the geometric mean of two numbers and consider how it compares to the arithmetic mean of two numbers. This learning experience serves as a springboard for some of the later learning experiences in this unit, which relate geometric mean to right triangles. Students also apply algebra to solve problems.

title: Golden Ratio and Phi
description: Students make connections between phi, which represents the golden ratio, and architectural design. After using algebra and the golden ratio to construct a golden spiral, they consider the history of finding and using the ratio.

title: Investigation into the Properties of Similar Right Triangles
description: Students complete an activity using an index card cut into three right triangles. They measure the sides and angles of the triangles and discuss whether the triangles are proportional to each other.

title: Right Triangle Theorem
description: This learning experience is a continuation of the previous learning experience. Students now investigate the result of drawing an altitude from the hypotenuse of a right triangle. They use Geometer’s Sketchpad to explore and prove the resulting theorem.

title: Geometric Mean and Right Triangles
description: Students learn and prove two new theorems. The first theorem relates the geometric mean to the altitude and hypotenuse of a right triangle. The second theorem relates the hypotenuse, an adjacent leg of the triangle, and the altitude. Students apply algebra and the theorems to find measurements of real-world objects, such as heights in architectural drawings and images.

title: Use Technology to Prove Theorems
description: Students use Geometer’s Sketchpad to determine why the geometric mean theorems only apply to right triangles.

title: Proving the Pythagorean Theorem
description: Students study some of the many different proofs of the Pythagorean theorem. They see that several involve rotating a square and right triangles into an arrangement that they can represent algebraically to prove the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Finding the Area of a Triangle with Missing Dimensions
description: Students complete a quiz in which they apply the Pythagorean theorem and use algebra to calculate the area of right triangles. They also complete an assignment that guides them to reconstruct a proof of the Pythagorean theorem created by James Garfield, the 20th president of the United States.

title: Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem
description: Students learn the converse of the Pythagorean theorem, which states that if the square of the length of the longest side is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the remaining two sides, then the triangle is a right triangle. They also explore two Pythagorean inequalities, which determine whether a triangle is acute or obtuse.

title: Babylonian Tablet
description: Students investigate a Babylonian tablet, Plimpton 322, that contains several sets of triangle lengths. They explore the significance of what is recorded on this tablet and discuss how it suggests that Babylonians may have been aware of side-length relationships of special right triangles.

title: Constructing Special Right Triangles
description: Students construct special right triangles using a compass and straightedge. They examine ratios of the hypotenuse to the legs of the triangles and make conjectures about the relationship between the hypotenuse and legs.

title: Trigonometric Ratios
description: Students learn the first three trigonometric ratios found in right triangles: sine, cosine, and tangent. They also are introduced to the Greek letter theta, which is frequently used in trigonometry.

title: Applying Right Triangle Concepts
description: Students use trigonometric ratios and algebra to solve right triangles. They examine applications of trigonometry, such as the angle of elevation or depression, and how trigonometry may be used to calculate heights and distances, given one side length and angle measure.

title: Right Triangles
description: Students complete a test on right triangles, including theorems relating the altitude drawn to the hypotenuse, proofs of the Pythagorean theorem, the converse of the Pythagorean theorem, Pythagorean triples, special right triangles, trigonometric ratios, and applications of right-triangle trigonometry.

title: Circle Terms
description: Students are introduced to specific terminology associated with circles, such as chord,secant, and tangent. They learn that early mathematicians used chord measurements in circles to perform trigonometric calculations, and they study examples of circles in visual arts and music.

title: Properties of Circles
description: Using algebra and Geometer’s Sketchpad, students learn, prove, and apply theorems related to tangents and circles. First, students prove and then combine two theorems into a biconditional statement: A line is tangent to a circle if and only if it is perpendicular to the radius or diameter at the point of tangency. They also read and analyze related theorems from the Elements. Students then discover a condition under which two tangent segments are congruent.

title: Arcs and Chords
description: Students use algebra and constructions to explore, prove, and apply theorems related to arcs and chords in circles. They investigate chords that are equidistant from a circle’s center and diameters that are perpendicular to chords. They also discover congruence relationships between corresponding chords and arcs.

title: Compass and Straightedge Construction
description: Students use a compass and straightedge to explore the relationships between inscribed angles and their intercepted arcs. They start by reading Euclid’s definition of angle in a segment from Book 3 of the Elements. They then examine cases in which the center of the circle lies on, outside, or inside the inscribed angle. Students use algebra to determine missing measurements.

title: Inscribed Triangles with Geometer’s Sketchpad
description: Students examine inscribed triangles in a circle using Geometer’s Sketchpad. They use their knowledge of inscribed angles to explore results, including Thales’s theorem, about necessary and sufficient conditions for certain types of inscribed triangles (acute, right, or obtuse).

title: Quiz: Properties of Circles
description: Students complete a quiz based on the first five learning experiences, demonstrating their understanding by responding to a series of short-answer questions. Students’ understanding of the following topics is assessed: central angles, arcs and chords, tangent lines and segments, and inscribed angles and triangles.

title: Arcs and Angles
description: Students examine angles formed by intersecting chords, secants, and tangents. They learn, prove, and apply theorems using algebra that relate the angle measures to their intercepted arcs.

title: Segment Relationships With Geometer’s Sketchpad
description: Students use Geometer’s Sketchpad to explore segment relationships within intersecting chords, intersecting secants, and an intersecting secant and tangent. They use auxiliary segments and similarity to establish related theorems, and they use algebra in combination with the theorems to find missing measurements.

title: Deriving the Equation of a Circle
description: Students begin by revisiting Euclid’s definitions of a circle and its center from Book 1 of the Elements. They then use Geometer’s Sketchpad to derive the equation of a circle in the coordinate plane. They also determine equations of circles from their graphs or from given characteristics, and they graph circles when given their equations or characteristics.

title: Locus Exploration with Geometer’s Sketchpad
description: Students use Geometer’s Sketchpad to explore circles of Apollonius as an example of a locus. They also make a conjecture about a different type of locus, which they discover through construction is a parabola, a figure they have previously encountered in algebra. Students apply their knowledge of loci to determine the epicenter of an earthquake.

title: Circle Theorems Research Paper
description: Students complete a paper that states and explains the theorems related to circles. The paper also contains supporting diagrams, key equations, and examples that show how the theorems are applied.

title: Polygon Investigation
description: Students begin with an investigation of polygons in which they use constructions and measurements to analyze the relationships between the number of sides and the measures of the interior and exterior angles. They learn and apply the Polygon Interior Angles Theorem and the Exterior Angles Theorem. Students also examine Euclid’s Propositions 16 and 32 and their application to the measures of angles of polygons. They investigate the use of polygons and tessellations in architecture, paying particular attention to Renaissance and Islamic applications.

title: Regular Polygon Construction and Study
description: Students use a protractor and ruler to draw a regular hexagon and they investigate relationships contained within it. They explore constructions described in Book IV of Euclid’s Elements and use a straightedge and compass to construct a regular hexagon, an equilateral triangle, and a pentagon. As an extension, students may research Renaissance artist Albrecht Dürer and his constructions of a regular pentagon and other polygons.

title: Area of an Equilateral Triangle
description: Students begin their investigation of polygon areas by examining the area of an equilateral triangle using the Pythagorean Theorem. They explore the history of the development of the theorem and discuss the debate over whether the Chinese were the first to use it. Students also learn and apply the Area of a Regular Polygon Theorem.

title: Similar Polygons
description: Students develop formulas for perimeters and areas of similar triangles. Then, using the notion that similar polygons can be divided into similar triangles, students reason that the perimeter and area formulas for similar triangles can be extended to similar polygons. Students find ratios related to similar polygons in graphic design.

title: Quiz: Polygons
description: Students complete a nine-question quiz based on the first four learning experiences in this unit. They apply the Polygon Interior Angles Theorem and the Exterior Angles Theorem, demonstrating their understanding in words and by solving for variables using algebraic methods. They construct regular polygons using a compass and straightedge, find areas of regular polygons, and apply relationships in similar polygons to solve for unknown quantities.

title: Finding Circumference and Arc Length
description: Students revisit their prior studies of circles, recalling early estimates of  and Archimedes’s estimation method based on Euclid’s propositions.They perform a hands-on investigation of . Then they apply their knowledge to develop formulas for circumference and arc length. Students connect the ideas to methods used by Renaissance architect Sebastiano Serlio to construct approximate ellipses using arcs of circles.

title: Areas of Sectors and Circles
description: Students explore a method for finding the area of a circle using inscribed polygons. They then determine the areas of circles and sectors using formulas and theorems. They apply those concepts to solve related problems, including problems from ancient texts.

title: Test: Area of Polygons
description: Students complete a 12-question test on the areas of polygons and circles. They demonstrate their understanding through a series of short-answer questions on interior angle measures of polygons, areas of polygons, inscribed polygons, areas and arc lengths of sectors, and areas of segments of circles. Students must show all of their work on the test.

title: Geometry of a Sphere
description: Students are introduced to triangles on a sphere and they investigate the angle measures of those triangles using a Lénárt sphere and a spherical protractor. The topic connects to their study of non-Euclidean geometry and the “great circle.”

title: Platonic Solids
description: Students study the five regular polyhedra, including associated vocabulary and properties, and they learn the history of Platonic solids. Students then research the contributions of Leonhard Euler and apply his polyhedron formula. Students also explore the geodesic dome.

title: Using Nets to Calculate Surface Area
description: Students explore surface area by creating nets. They learn to find surface areas of prisms and solve related problems, such as finding unknown dimensions of a prism with a given surface area. Students are challenged to deconstruct a cylinder and form its net in order to determine the formula for its surface area. They also research Dürer’s 1525 work The Painter’s Manual.

title: Partnered Work Session
description: Students spend a period reviewing with a partner the vocabulary, formulas, theorems, and problems related to three-dimensional figures in preparation for the upcoming quiz.

title: Quiz: Properties of Solids
description: Students complete a quiz assessing their knowledge of the properties of three-dimensional figures.

title: Surface Area of Pyramids and Cones
description: Students find the surface areas of pyramids and cones, and they learn the theorems that support the related formulas. They are then challenged to find the surface areas of the Pyramids of Giza.

title: Volume of Prisms and Cylinders
description: Students discuss the volume of a cube and the true meaning of a cubic measurement. They learn the Volume Congruence Postulate, the Volume Addition Postulate, and the volume theorems. They then apply their understanding of those concepts to find the volumes of classroom objects by determining their shapes, measurements, and characteristics. Students explore Liu Hui’s slicing and dissection methods to derive volume formulas for prisms and cylinders. Finally, they research and apply Cavalieri’s principle to determine volumes of oblique cylinders and prisms.

title: Volume of Pyramids and Cones
description: Students begin with a hands-on investigation in which they construct a pyramid and a prism and are challenged to find the volume of each. They are then given the volume formulas, which they use to calculate the volumes of various cones and pyramids. Students explore the development of volumes of pyramids and cones in Euclid’sElements. As an optional extension, they may compare the related propositions presented by Campanus of Novara in his annotated version of the Elements.

title: Spheres
description: Students explore Archimedes’s discoveries related to a sphere inscribed in a cylinder, and they derive and apply his formulas for calculating surface area and volume of a sphere. They are then challenged to estimate the volumes and surface areas of various real-world spheres including baseballs, soccer balls, and Spaceship Earth at Epcot Center. Finally, students define a great circle of a sphere and derive a formula for the surface area of a closed hemisphere.

title: Test: Three-Dimensional Solids
description: Students complete a test on three-dimensional figures in which they are required to show their work for all problems and to justify their reasoning through the use of postulates and theorems.

title: Introduction to Functions
description: Students examine Euler’s definition of function and then discuss and compare with the modern definition in terms of ordered pairs. They examine graphs of functions, and they develop and apply the vertical-line test. They graph the common parent functions using tables of values and discuss the shape and other key characteristics of each graph.

title: Scatter Plots
description: Students construct scatter plots for data sets to determine whether a linear correlation exists. If a linear relationship is present, students estimate the correlation coefficient and equation for the best-fit line before using a graphing calculator to determine the least-squares regression line. They also discuss the feud between Legendre and Gauss over who first developed the least-squares regression technique.

title: Functions and Scatter Plots
description: Students are assessed on their understanding of functions and scatter plots using multiple-choice and short-answer questions about parent function graphs, scatter plots, and least-squares regression lines.

title: Graphing Linear Equations
description: Students calculate slope and graph linear equations from slope-intercept and point-slope form. They study Descartes' contributions to the development of the concept of slope. They determine the equation of a line through two given points and write the equation of a line from its graph.

title: Parallel and Perpendicular Lines
description: Students learn Euclid’s definitions of parallel and perpendicular lines, and then they discover the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines in the coordinate plane. They explore horizontal and vertical lines and write equations for lines that are parallel or perpendicular to a given line and that pass through a given point.

title: Graphing Lines, Parallel and Perpendicular Relationships
description: Students answer multiple-choice and short-answer assessment items related to linear equations and their graphs, including parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Systems of Equations
description: Students learn the history of solving systems of linear equations, from ancient China through René Descartes. They solve systems of linear equations in two variables by graphing and using two algebraic methods, the substitution method and the linear combination, or elimination method. Students learn the relationship of the number of solutions of a system and whether it is consistent and independent.

title: Applications of Linear Systems
