description: Students examine real-world applications of linear systems in two variables. They connect to their studies of motion in grade 9 by studying systems that are based on distance or the equation d = rt.

title: Quiz: Linear Systems
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of linear systems by using algebraic and graphical methods to solve related problems, including real-world applications. Students respond to a series of multiple-choice and short-answer questions on linear systems.

title: Lines with Three Variables
description: Students study the contributions of Greek mathematicians Apollonius of Perga and Archimedes and of 17th century mathematicians René Descartes and Pierre Fermat in defining the coordinate system and solving systems of linear equations. They plot points in three dimensions, given coordinates (x, y, z) and graph planes given equations in the form ax + by + cz = d.

title: Systems in Three Variables
description: Students begin studying linear systems of three equations in three variables by solving Problem 1 in Chapter 8 of The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art, which relates to the weights of three different types of grain. They consider a graphical method and then use an algebraic method to find an exact solution. Students use graphs and algebraic methods to analyze consistent, inconsistent, dependent, and independent systems.

title: Quiz: Linear Equations and Systems in Three Variables
description: Students demonstrate their ability to graph linear equations in three variables and to solve linear systems in three variables using algebraic methods by responding to a series of short-answer and graphing questions.

title: Matrices
description: Students learn matrix addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication in a historical context, with emphasis on The Nine Chapters of the Mathematical Art and Arthur Cayley’s A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices. They explore properties of matrix operations such as commutativity and associativity.

title: Multiplying Matrices
description: Students multiply matrices, understand the conditions for the product of two matrices to exist, and determine the dimensions of the product. They calculate determinants of  square matrices and  square matrices using Sarrus’s rule, and apply Cramer’s Rule to solve systems of linear equations. Students explore the history of determinants, including Chinese methods for solving systems, Cardano’s contributions in 1545, and Seki Kowa’s work in the 17th century.

title: Matrix Inverses
description: Students learn to solve systems of linear equations by using matrix multiplication and inverses of matrices. They represent systems in the form , where A is the matrix of coefficients, X is the matrix of unknowns, and B is the matrix of constants, and they show that the solution is . Students learn the formula for the inverse of a

title: Quiz: Matrix Operations
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of matrices, operations with matrices, and solving systems using matrices, including real-world applications. Students are not able to use calculators.

title: Augmented Matrices
description: Students use augmented matrices to solve systems of linear equations using a method found in The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art. In this method, equivalent to Gaussian elimination, students write a matrix in row echelon form. They also learn a variation in which a matrix is written in reduced row echelon form.

title: Test: Functions, Systems of Linear Equations, and Matrices
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of functions, systems of linear equations, matrices, operations with matrices, solving systems using matrices, and solving real-world application problems through a series of multiple-choice, short-answer, and graphing questions.

title: Graphical Analysis
description: Students analyze graphical representations that relate to real-world scenarios. They describe real-world situations that match given graphs, and vice versa. They explore parabolas that represent real-world situations and use a table of values to graph a quadratic function.

title: Transformations of the Quadratic Function
description: Students are given the quadratic parent function  and its graph as the next parent function in the toolkit of functions that will be explored throughout the course. They explore and discuss effects on the graph as the function is modified by substituting values for a, h, and k in the vertex form

title: Deriving the Standard Form of the Quadratic Equation
description: Students manipulate the vertex form of a quadratic function to write it in standard form. They learn of the contributions of Arabic scholar al-Khwarizmi and Renaissance mathematician Cardano to the process of solving quadratic equations. They discuss properties of parabolas and learn to find the axis of symmetry, vertex, and y-intercept in terms of a, b, and c. Students then graph quadratic functions by plotting the vertex and two other points. Students also learn to find the minimum or maximum value for a given function, and solve related application problems.

title: Solving Quadratics through Roots
description: Students learn and discuss the similarities and differences between zeros of a function and the solutions of the related equation. Students graph functions on a graphing calculator and find the zeros. They review the use of the Zero Product Property and factoring to solve quadratic equations, and they complete practice problems with that method. Students find zeros of quadratic functions as they apply their understanding to word problems. Students also explore al-Khwarizmi’s formulas for finding solutions.

title: Quadratics and the Square Root Property
description: Students solve quadratic equations using the square root property, and they compare this technique to al-Khwarizmi’s method of calculating roots by “completion” and “balancing.” This is followed by review of the previous four learning experiences in which students solve practice problems, including real-world applications involving projectile motion, as preparation for the upcoming formative assessment.

title: Quiz: Quadratics
description: Students complete a 6-question quiz on the concepts investigated during learning experiences in the first part of this unit. Students describe a real-world situation that matches a given graph, graph quadratic functions, and write functions that describe given graphs in both vertex and standard forms. They also find the zeros of quadratic functions.

title: Al-Khwarizmi and Completing the Square
description: Students examine how to complete the square visually, using a square broken into parts and revisiting al-Khwarizmi’s work on completing the square. Students then learn how to manipulate a quadratic equation in standard form to complete the square and find the solutions.

title: Areas of Composite Figures
description: In the tradition of Euclid, al-Khwarizmi, and Babylonian mathematicians, students solve problems related to both algebra and geometry by applying quadratic equations to the areas of composite figures. Their work includes real-world applications to fields such as architecture and physics.

title: Complex Numbers and Roots
description: Students explore and discuss that the graph of this function indicates there are no real zeros. They then attempt to solve for the zeros algebraically, arriving at , which they understand is not a real number. Students learn that this value, denoted i, is referred to as the imaginary unit, and they work in pairs to study its history and development. Students then use numeric and algebraic methods to solve

title: The Quadratic Formula
description: Students derive the quadratic formula from the standard form of a quadratic equation, and they use the formula to solve quadratic equations. They then explore the discriminant, b2 – 4ac, and its relation to the number and type of solutions. They learn the contributions of Babylonian mathematicians, al-Khwarizmi, Euler, and others to the development of the quadratic formula.

title: Quiz: Quadratics and Complex Roots
description: Students complete a 14-question quiz on the concepts investigated during the previous learning experiences. They supply short answers to demonstrate their understanding of the uses of quadratic functions and equations and the meaning of i. Students compute and interpret the value of the discriminant, find solutions using the quadratic formula, and solve application problems pertaining to projectiles, trajectories, and area.

title: Solving Quadratic Inequalities
description: Students solve quadratic inequalities in two variables both graphically and analytically using the table tool of a graphing calculator. They work with partners to apply quadratic inequalities to real-world problems involving projectile motion.

title: Quadratic Curve Fitting
description: Students learn how to find the best-fit quadratic model for a real-world data set using the regression feature of a graphing calculator. After identifying the model, they use it to describe the relationship between the variables and to make predictions. They also learn that the least-squares method for fitting nonlinear models to bivariate data has its origins in the work of Adrien Legendre, Pierre-Simon Laplace, and Johann Carl Friedrich Gauss.

title: Operations with Complex Numbers
description: Students graph complex numbers and find their absolute values. Students then add, subtract, multiply, and divide complex numbers. They revisit Cardano's contributions to the study of complex numbers, studied in an earlier learning experience in this unit, and learn that Gauss further developed the concept of complex numbers, leading to the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra.

title: Test: Quadratic Functions
description: To demonstrate mastery of the concepts investigated in this unit, students complete a cumulative test containing short-answer, graphing, and multiple-choice questions. They solve mathematical and real-world problems in which they make and analyze quadratic graphs, solve quadratic equations and inequalities, and fit a quadratic model to data.

title: Introduction to Polynomials
description: Students identify, evaluate, add, subtract, and classify polynomials. Students also use technology to examine the graphs of polynomial functions. They learn the vocabulary related to the study of polynomials so that they are able to be conversant with the behavior of polynomials.

title: Pascal’s Triangle
description: Students are introduced to the contributions of Blaise Pascal in the development of thearithmetical triangle, as well his contributions in conics, probability, game theory, and counting theory. They construct Pascal’s Triangle and use it to expand binomials.

title: Multiplying Polynomials
description: Working in small groups, students apply their knowledge of the Distributive Property to design and explore different methods for multiplying combinations of monomials, binomials, and trinomials. They use Pascal’s Triangle to expand binomials raised to powers greater than 3. Students apply their techniques to solve real-world problems involving area and volume.

title: Division of Polynomials
description: Students perform polynomial long division and a synthetic division procedure called Ruffini’s rule, after the Italian mathematician Paolo Ruffini. Students use those methods and the Remainder Theorem to divide and evaluate polynomials.

title: Factors of Cubes
description: Students use geometric diagrams, Pascal’s triangle, and algebraic methods to factor sums and differences of cubes.

title: Polynomial Expressions
description: Students complete a quiz that assesses topics from the first five learning experiences. They solve short-answer problems to demonstrate their understanding of operations with polynomials, binomial expansion, factoring polynomials, and characteristics of the graphs of polynomial functions.

title: Factors of Polynomials
description: Students factor polynomials by applying the factor theorem, by grouping, and by factoring sums and differences of cubes. They also analyze graphs of polynomial functions to solve real-world problems related to volume. They research the 18th-century French mathematician Étienne Bézout, who proved the remainder theorem, which is also known as little Bézout’s theorem.

title: Roots of Polynomial Functions
description: Students use graphs and equations to identify roots of polynomials, including their multiplicities. They are challenged to create a polynomial that models the volume of a box constructed from a given piece of paper and to maximize that volume. Students then apply the concept to applications in manufacturing and construction

title: Integration of Fundamental Theorem of Algebra
description: Students research the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, including its history and development. Then they use the fundamental theorem, in conjunction with Descartes’s rule of signs and other theorems and techniques, to find all roots of a given polynomial and to find a polynomial when given its roots.

title: Power Functions
description: Students explore power functions and their graphs, including power functions with negative and fractional exponents. They identify even and odd power functions and apply power functions to specific topics in geometry, biology, and physics.

title: Graphs of Polynomial Functions
description: Students analyze, describe, and graph polynomial functions by identifying and describing end behavior, real zeros, the y-intercept, and maximum and minimum values, which they use to solve real-world problems related to volume and surface area. Students connect their use of technology in this learning experience to the history of mathematics by researching various advances in technology, including the work of Charles Babbage, and their mathematical applications.

title: Quiz: Properties and Graphs of Polynomial Functions
description: Students complete a quiz assessing the polynomial concepts from the previous five learning experiences: factors and roots of polynomials, the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, and polynomial and power functions.

title: Transformations to Polynomial Functions
description: Students use transformation rules to predict how changes to the equation of a polynomial function will affect its graph, and they use technology to test their predictions. Students then write the equation of a polynomial function when given its graph.

title: Curve Fitting
description: Students explore finite differences of polynomial functions. They analyze scatter plots for bivariate data sets along with finite differences to determine appropriate types of polynomial models. They then use technology to generate the equations of best-fit polynomial functions for the data. Students discuss the principle of Occam’s razor in assessing the fit of the models and use the models to make predictions and solve problems.

title: Test: Polynomial Functions
description: Students complete a unit test that assesses their understanding of polynomials. In short-answer and graphing questions, students perform polynomial operations and factor polynomials. They find zeros, intercepts, maxima, and minima of polynomial functions. They also graph polynomial functions and describe key features of polynomial graphs.

title: Laws of Exponents
description: Students derive the laws of exponents by expanding several specific examples for each law. They discover that Archimedes proved the first law of exponents, and they explore his use of exponents in The Sand Reckoner to demonstrate the upper limit to the number of grains of sand in the Universe. Students also learn that Descartes developed modern exponent notation. They complete problem sets in which they apply the laws to mathematical and real-world contexts, such as astronomy and biology.

title: Introduction to Exponential Functions
description: Students review the concept of multiplication as repeated addition of the same number. They then consider what it means to multiply by the same number repeatedly. After creating a table of values for the function y = 2x, students plot ordered pairs and sketch and analyze the function’s graph. Students next consider exponential functions of the form f(x) = a(bx) and explore graphically the effects of changes in a and b. They are introduced to the idea of an asymptote. Lastly, they investigate transformations of exponential functions and describe characteristics of the functions’ graphs, including they-intercept and end behavior.

title: Determining Equations of Exponential Growth
description: Students learn to write equations of exponential growth curves when given their graphs by using the coordinates of two points to determine a and b, and they summarize the method using an example. They sketch the graph of an exponential growth curve for a given function, demonstrating an understanding of the asymptotic behavior on one extreme and the increasing behavior on the other. Students research the use of exponential functions and their graphs to predict and model population growth.

title: Exploring Annual and Compound Interest
description: Students learn that the Babylonians recorded compound interest problems on a clay tablet beginning around 1700 BCE and that, according to Bhaskara II’s treatise on mathematics written in 1150, Hindu mathematicians solved simple and compound interest problems using arithmetic and geometric progressions. Next, students consider a scenario in which a sum of money is invested in an account that earns annual interest. They identify future values of the sum over five years and derive an equation that gives the value in t years. Students learn the general function y = a(1 + r)t, where t is time, and investigate 1 + r = b for growth and 1 – r = b for decline. They solve for y, a, and t using the intersection function on a graphing calculator. Students discuss and investigate compound interest and solve related application problems.

title: Exponential Decay
description: Students begin their investigation of exponential growth and decay with a hands-on paper-folding activity. They create scatter plots based on data collected in the activity and determine the equations of functions that model the data. Students then analyze exponential functions and their graphs in more detail by working with a partner on a set of exercises involving transformations of exponential functions. Students also explore real-world applications of exponential decay, such as depreciation, radioactive decomposition, and metabolism of medications.

title: Quiz: Exponential Functions
description: Students complete a quiz containing multiple-choice, short-answer, and graphing questions that assess their understanding of the laws of exponents, writing and graphing exponential functions, transformations of exponential graphs, and real-world applications involving compound interest and depreciation.

title: Interest and e
description: Students investigate the effects of compounding interest on an initial one-year investment of $1 at 100% interest by increasing the frequency of compounding, discovering that as the frequency approaches infinity, the value of the investment approaches e. They also examine the characteristics of the graph of f(x) = ex and investigate the relationships between e and continuous growth and decline. They learn about the effect of increased trade in the 17th century on the development of mathematics related to finance, and they study the contributions of Bernoulli, Newton, and Euler to our understanding of the number e.

title: Thomas Robert Malthus
description: As a connection to Cultural History and Science, students study the theories of Malthus regarding the effects of economic issues on human population. They examine his work An Essay on the Principle of Population, in which he argues that the approximately exponential growth of population eventually exceeds the approximately linear growth of food production. To test Malthus’s hypothesis, students use given data to make scatter plots and predict the types of functions that will best model the data. Next, using actual population and wheat production data from the United Kingdom, students perform a similar analysis using the regression features on a graphing calculator. They then compare the functions that model the actual results with the functions that model Malthus’s hypothesis, and they follow up with a discussion and evaluation of his theories.

title: Introduction to Logarithms
description: Students are introduced to John Napier, who invented logarithms as a way to simplify astronomical calculations. They rewrite exponential equations as logarithmic equations and learn that the logarithm with base 10 is called a common logarithm. Students learn the natural logarithmic form and exponential form involving e. They find the inverses of exponential functions and discuss the characteristics of both exponential and logarithmic functions, including their asymptotes, intercepts, domains, and ranges. They also graph transformations of logarithmic functions.

title: Properties of Logarithms
description: Students use a table of values to investigate and derive properties of logarithms. They then use those properties to expand and simplify logarithmic expressions and to solve logarithmic equations. They learn and apply the change of base formula and solve application problems related to decibel readings, earthquakes, hurricanes, and the pH scale.

title: Exit Questions on Logarithms
description: Students complete a five-question quiz to assess their understanding of logarithms as well as the product, quotient, and power properties. They also solve a logarithmic equation and discuss the domains of logarithmic functions.

title: History of Logarithms
description: Students discuss the difficulties posed by complex calculations for scientists throughout history, and they investigate advances during the Scientific Revolution that simplified calculation methods. Students learn that one such advance is logarithms, which Napier invented to aid astronomers in the multiplication and division of very large and very small numbers. They extend their knowledge of logarithms to understand Oughtred’s invention of the slide rule as an application of logarithms. They also discuss calculators as a replacement for slide rules. Finally, students practice graphing logarithmic functions and their transformations, including vertical asymptotes.

title: Applications of Exponents and Logarithms
description: Students solve exponential and logarithmic equations. They engage in various methods of problem-solving, including the use of graphs, scatter plots, and analysis. Students also solve application problems related to topics such as compound interest, population growth, and carbon dating.

title: Regression Modeling
description: Students use the regression feature of a graphing calculator to determine exponential models for data, starting with tables of data values and then transitioning to real-world data from statistics, economics, and science. They discuss how models usually do not fit data perfectly. They also make predictions based on models and evaluate the reliability of extrapolation and interpolation. Students study the least-squares regression method and its origins with Legendre and Gauss. They discover that new methods are still being researched to find the best models for increasingly complex data sets.

title: Logistic Growth Functions
description: Students explore the logistic growth function, its graph, and its applications. They also learn about the function’s development by Pierre Verhulst during the 19th century as well as its connections to Malthus and industrialization.

title: Test: Exponents and Logarithms
description: After working with partners to review exponents, logarithms, exponential and logarithmic functions and equations, and logistic growth functions, students complete a test on those concepts. The test contains multiple-choice, short-answer, and graphing problems, including real-world applications about population growth, compound interest, depreciation, sound intensity, and radiocarbon dating.

title: Investigation with Variation
description: Students explore inverse variation by conducting an experiment in which they collect data on distance and apparent height. Using those data and concepts from geometry, students describe the relationship between distance and apparent height with an equation in the form . They then connect inverse variation and apparent height to their previous studies of perspective in Renaissance art.

title: Introduction to Joint and Inverse Variation
description: Students compare the standard forms for inverse variation and joint variation. Using points in a table that represent an inverse variation, they identify the value for k, write an equation representing the inverse variation, and find points not listed in the table. They examine real-world examples of inverse variation modeling speed and of joint variation modeling torque. As an extension, students research Isaac Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation.

title: Introduction to Rational Functions
description: Students define a rational function and use a table of values to graph a simple rational function. They also use a rational function's graph to identify domain and range. They are introduced to the hyperbola and investigate its characteristics, including asymptotes, and they learn that the hyperbola is an example of a conic section. They study Pythagoras's development of conic sections, in which he examined various intersections of a plane and a cone. Students also learn how to write a rational model for given data.

title: Graphing Rational Functions with Technology
description: In this learning experience, students use a graphing calculator to graph rational functions. They explore viewing windows, tables, and the limitations of the technology when showing the asymptotes. They look for and describe relationships between the location of a graph's branches and the power in the denominator of the function.

title: Quiz: Variation and Rational Functions
description: Students complete a quiz in which they solve mathematical and real-world problems involving joint and inverse variation and the graphs of rational functions.

title: General Rational Functions
description: Students learn how to graph general rational functions. Through discussion and evaluation, they identify the characteristics of those functions and their graphs, with a focus on vertical and horizontal asymptotes. Students then use graphs to solve real-life problems pertaining to electricity and optics

title: Rational Expressions in Simplified Form
description: Students learn how to write a rational expression in simplified form. They are introduced to Al-Samaw’al and his examples for simplifying rational expressions. They multiply and divide rational expressions and use a graphing calculator to verify the results of operations with rational expressions. Students then use rational expressions to model real-life ratios, areas, volumes, mixtures, and work problems.

title: Solving Rational Equations
description: Students learn to solve rational equations algebraically, and they use rational equations to solve real-world science problems involving weighted averages, mixtures, current, and work. Students explore equations with extraneous solutions, and they solve rational equations by finding the intersection of the graphs of two rational functions.

title: Test: Rational Equations and Functions
description: Students work with a partner on a review sheet that covers all concepts studied within the unit. Then each student individually completes a cumulative unit test that features short-answer and graphing problems.

title: Distance and Midpoint Formulas
description: Students revisit the derivation of the distance formula by applying the Pythagorean theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate plane. They recall that René Descartes developed the Cartesian coordinate system and the distance formula. They use the distance formula to classify triangles by side lengths, and then they revisit the midpoint formula. Students apply both formulas to real-world problems, such as using a map to find distances.

title: Parabolas
description: Students explore two different ways of generating a conic surface, one method described by Euclid and the other by Apollonius. They learn that conic sections result from the intersection of a cone and a plane, and they explore the different types of conic sections: circle, ellipse, parabola, and hyperbola. Students then focus on the parabola, defining a parabola as the set of all points in a plane that are equidistant from a line and a point. They graph parabolas, learn the standard form of the equation for a parabola, and explore key features of parabolas. Students solve problems involving real-world parabolas, such as satellite dishes, mirrors in car headlights, parabolic heaters, and parabolas formed by cables in the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: Circles
description: Students derive the standard form of the equation of a circle based on the Pythagorean theorem. They graph and write equations of circles, beginning with circles centered at the origin, followed by circles centered at other locations in the coordinate plane. Students write the equation of a line tangent to a circle using slope and a point on the circle. They use inequalities to solve real-life problems involving the lighted area from a beam of a lighthouse, air traffic controller screens, and the size of a ring. Students graph circles by solving the standard equation for y and writing the resulting equation as two separate functions.

title: Ellipses
description: Students recall prior experience with ellipses from their studies of Kepler’s laws of planetary motion. They complete a hands-on investigation in which they construct an ellipse using string and pushpins, and they learn that the sum of the distances from the foci to any point on the ellipse is always the same. They are introduced to the major and minor axes, center, vertices, and covertices. Students learn to sketch the graph of an ellipse using information derived from the equation and to write the equation of an ellipse based on the graph. Finally, they explore real-world applications to astronomy, physics, architecture, and design.

title: Quiz: Parabolas, Circles, and Ellipses
description: Students complete a quiz containing multiple-choice, open-response, and graphing questions about the midpoint and distance formulas and equations and graphs of parabolas, circles, and ellipses. Students combine their understanding of all of those topics to solve mathematical and real-world problems, including a problem about a parabolic reflector in a flashlight.

title: Whispering Gallery
description: Through lecture and class discussion, students learn about famous whispering galleries, and they examine circular and elliptical whispering galleries. They understand how properties of each shape reflect and collect sound waves so that a listener can hear even a whisper from across the room.

title: Hyperbolas
description: Students first explore hyperbolas in the context of shadows and sundials. They then learn the mathematical definition of hyperbola, compare the characteristics of hyperbolas to those of ellipses, and discover and describe relationships between graphs of hyperbolas and their equations. They connect to their studies of optics in grade 10 Science by investigating the properties of hyperbolic mirrors, and they solve real-world problems involving hyperbolas in fields such as navigation, astronomy, physics, and architecture.

title: Ellipses and Circles
description: Working in pairs, students complete an activity in which they shine a flashlight on graph paper attached to a wall. They hold the flashlight so the light forms a circle centered at the origin and they write the equation of the circle. Then, they hold the flashlight so the light forms an ellipse and they write the equation of the ellipse. Students discuss their results and make conjectures.

title: Transformations of Conics
description: Students graph transformations of all four conic sections using ideas developed by René Descartes. They also review Apollonius’s work in Conics. They use characteristics of conic sections to determine their graphs and equations. Students learn the general form of a second-degree equation in two variables, and they apply algebraic techniques to convert to the general form of the equation for a conic section. They learn that Fermat developed techniques for transforming the general quadratic equation into the general conic equation. They learn how to find and apply the discriminant to determine the type of conic section described by a given equation in general form.

title: Test: Conics
description: Students review the topics studied throughout this unit, including vocabulary related to conic sections; key characteristics of parabolas, hyperbolas, ellipses, and circles; and the relationships between conic sections and their equations. Then students demonstrate their understanding of conic sections by completing an assessment containing multiple-choice, short-answer, graphing, and real-world questions.

title: Right Triangles
description: Students review the right-triangle definitions of sine, cosine, and tangent, learning that right-triangle trigonometry emerged from the work of Copernicus, Regiomantus, and Rheticus. They examine examples of right triangles and discuss which trigonometric values can be determined from the information given. They apply that information to solve right triangles. As a real-world application, students study the medieval navigational technique known as the rule of marteloio, used by sailors to plan sailing routes and to change or correct course. They learn that those calculations were summarized in a table first found in Ramon Llull’s Arbre de la Ciencia. Students complete application problems similar to the navigation problems once solved by using the rule of marteloio. They discuss strategies for solving problems involving triangle trigonometry.

title: Unit Circle
description: Students review the contributions of the Egyptians, Babylonians and Greeks to the study of trigonometry for surveying and astronomy. By studying the gnomon and the shadow of reckoning, students learn that the Arabs introduced the tangent and cotangent ratios, and Habash al-Hasib constructed the first table of those ratios in about 870. They also learn that the name tangent first appeared in Thomas Finke’s Geometria Rotundi in 1583. Students interpret trigonometric functions on the unit circle and use the unit circle to find angle measures based on the circumference. They also convert degrees to radians and radians to degrees.

title: Arcs and Sectors
description: Students review the formulas for arc length and area of a sector using degree measures. Using the meaning of radian measure, they derive the formulas in radians and compare the two versions. They discuss the advantages of radian measure and research the historical development of radian measure by Roger Cotes and James Thomson. Students calculate arc lengths and areas of sectors in mathematical and real-world contexts, including distances on Earth and the area of a slice of pizza.

title: Trigonometric Values on the Unit Circle
description: Using a right triangle imbedded in the first quadrant of the unit circle, students learn to evaluate trigonometric functions. They learn the trigonometric values of the special angles and the quadrantal angles. Students also evaluate the six trigonometric values of an angle given a point on the circle. Students find reference angles and the sign of each trigonometric function within each quadrant on a graph. They explore the contributions of al-Khwarizmi and other early Islamic mathematicians, in determining trigonometric function values.

title: Quiz: Angles and Trigonometry
description: Students complete a quiz with open-response questions about radians and degrees, coterminal and reference angles, and arc length and area of sectors of circles. They also solve right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems.

title: Inverse Functions
description: Students investigate inverse trigonometric functions by using a table of values. They hypothesize about how to restrict the domain to ensure that the inverse is a function. Using their knowledge of trigonometric values and also a graphing calculator, students evaluate inverse trigonometric functions and solve inverse trigonometric equations and real-world problems related to calculating angles of repose, elevation, and depression, and they discuss possible answers that are not found using a calculator. In discussing the multiple answers, students explore Roger Cotes’s observations of the periodicity of trigonometric functions in Harmonia Mensurarum, published in 1722.

title: Graphing Trigonometric Functions
description: Students plot the sine value of the special angles of the unit circle on coordinate axes from  to create a graph of the function f(x) = sin x. They investigate and identify the characteristics of the graph. They do the same for the cosine and tangent graphs and learn the important terminology related to those graphs: period, amplitude,and maximum and minimum values. Students then sketch the transformations of those functions and identify the domain, range, period, midline, and maximums and minimums for each. They find that y = tan x is undefined when x = 0 and that the graph has an asymptote at that value.

title: Graphs to Equations
description: Using an interactive whiteboard and graphing calculator software, students explore the graphs of the basic trigonometric functions and write the equations of those functions from the graphs. They discuss how transformations affect the graphs of trigonometric functions, identify the graphs of transformed functions, and sketch graphs of functions.

title: Real-World Applications
description: Students solve application problems involving trigonometric functions, including modeling the hours of daylight, the height off the ground at a given time on a Ferris wheel, and the time of high and low tides. Students extend their models to predict values of each function and check their answers by graphing.

title: What Does Sound Look Like?
description: Students study Benjamin Franklin’s contributions to society, including the glass harmonica. In conjunction with looking at the harmonics of sound, students learn about the sine wave as a way of illustrating sound graphically and as a sine function. They also look at examples of Fourier series to approximate equations to illustrate the harmonics of sound.

title: Test: Trigonometric Functions
description: Students complete a test containing open-response and graphing questions, including writing rules for trigonometric functions, solving trigonometric equations, measuring angles in radians, calculating arc length and sector area, and graphing trigonometric functions and their transformations. They solve application problems that include modeling the number of hours of daylight.

title: The Counting Principle, Factorials, Permutations, and Combinations
description: Students begin by using tree diagrams to explore the number of different dinners they can order from a menu with several choices for appetizers, main dishes, side dishes, and desserts. Examining the diagrams leads them to derive the Fundamental Counting Principle as a more efficient way of making the calculations. Students also learn about factorials, including the use of the symbol “!”. They write permutations and combinations to describe situations by determining whether order matters. After calculating several examples of permutations and combinations by hand, students learn how to find  and

title: Permutations with Repetition
description: Using a real-world situation about the number of possible walking routes, students explore variations on permutations. They discover that, unlike the permutations previously encountered, this one contains items that are not distinct. Students reconceptualize the situation as a combination and apply the formula. They extend the concept by finding the number of permutations of the letters in MISSISSIPPI, and they explore circular permutations. Students review the construction of Pascal’s triangle and the contributions of Pascal, and they then use Pascal’s triangle to discover properties of combinations.

title: Quiz: Counting Principle, Permutations, and Combinations
description: Students review the Fundamental Counting Principle, permutations, and combinations and then complete an assessment with short-answer questions, including calculator-based questions. They perform calculations with factorials, and apply the Fundamental Counting Principle, permutations, and combinations to solve problems, including seating arrangements and the number of words that can be formed from a set of letters.

title: Pascal’s Triangle and Binomial Theorem
description: Students extend their learning about Pascal’s triangle, including its use in early Chinese and Arabic mathematics. They discuss properties of the triangle discovered by Pascal. They learn how the coefficients relate to the expansion of binomials, prove the Binomial Theorem, and apply it to expand binomials and identify coefficients for particular terms in a binomial expansion.

title: Theoretical and Experimental Probability
description: Students discuss the theoretical probability of an event as the ratio of the number of ways the event can occur to the number of equally likely outcomes. They use tables, organized lists, tree diagrams, counting methods, permutations, and combinations to find the size of a sample space. Students review key ideas about probability and practice calculating theoretical probabilities in contexts involving coins, dice, playing cards, and spinners. They examine problems from De Moivre’s text The Doctrine of Chances, and they discuss his work. Next, students compare and contrast theoretical probability with experimental probability, conduct experiments, and compare the experimental results to the corresponding theoretical probabilities, as discussed in Bernoulli’s Ars Conjectandi.

title: Compound Events
description: Students write statements using and, or, and not, act out compound probability situations, use lists and tree diagrams to determine the number of outcomes for a compound event, and calculate probabilities of compound events. They also find the probability of a compound event by subtracting the probability of its complement from 1. Students solve a set of practice problems that contains both theoretical and real-world applications, including problems related to games.

title: Probability with Independent and Dependent Events
description: Students review independent and dependent events and find related probabilities, both by counting outcomes in sample spaces and by using the multiplication rule. They learn that the rule is described in Cardano’s text Liber de Ludo Aleae. Students discuss common misconceptions related to independent events and correct the erroneous reasoning. They modify the multiplication rule for dependent events by using conditional probability to produce a version of the multiplication rule that holds for all events. Students complete practice problems and research the development of probability theory, including classic historical probability problems from Cardano, Pascal, and Fermat.

title: Binomial Distribution and Probability
description: Students use Galton boards to model binomial distributions, comparing their observations to Pascal's triangle. They also conduct probability experiments with simple manipulatives and analyze the results.

title: The French Salon
description: Students learn about French roulette and its connections to the French salon. They discuss the history of the game, beginning with its invention by Pascal, and then work in pairs to study the various bets and payouts associated with roulette and to calculate probabilities of given outcomes.

title: Test: Probability
description: Students participate in a review and practice session to prepare for the unit assessment. Then they complete a test of open-response problems that assess understanding of counting techniques; theoretical and experimental probability; independent, dependent, and compound events; the binomial distribution; and the binomial theorem.

title: Displaying Data
description: Each student is given a bag of M&Ms and creates a data display. Students discuss randomness and combine their data to one histogram. Lastly, students explore “the mean of the means” as part of their homework.

title: Frequency Histogram and Data Displays
description: Students discuss what type of display is correct for each data set. Then they define what the variables in data are and how to explore them. Next, students create a frequency histogram and discuss how to describe data displays.

title: Stem Plot and Trend Line
description: Students learn to create stem plots and split stem plots. Then students learn how to describe a trend line and create a time plot.

title: Five Number Summary
description: Students explore finding measures of center given histograms and stem plots. As a class, they discuss measures of spread and the five-number summary. Students compare two data sets, one of which has a possible outlier. They research and create boxplots, first by hand and later on a graphing calculator.

title: Quiz: Measures of Center
description: Students complete a short answer assessment to demonstrate their understanding of mean, median, mode, outliers, spread, and categorical and quantitative variables.

title: Outlier Testing
description: Students explore a specific way for testing for outliers. They create modified boxplots by hand and with the TI-84 calculator.

title: Standard Deviation
description: Students investigate the measure of spread for the mean (standard deviation). They follow a specific set of instructions to find the standard deviation. After they have analyzed two sets of data by hand, they check their work with the output tool of their graphing calculators.

title: Linear Transformations of Data Sets
description: Students review measures of center and spread with respect to resistant statistics. They find the five number summary, mean, and standard deviation of a given data set. They form hypotheses and test them for linear transformations.

title: Density Plots and Skewedness
description: The activity begins with a review of histograms and how the shape of a distribution affects the measures of center. Students explore the conversion of histograms to density plots and uniform density plots.

title: Measures of Spread and Resistant Statistics Quiz
description: Short answer, creation of boxplots, and finding the standard deviation by hand for a small data set. It also covers the concept of resistant statistics.

title: Introductions to Normal Curve
description: Students begin with a discussion of the difference between a parameter and a statistic. Students then create a normal curve and use the empirical rule. Students solve a series of real-world problems estimating with the normal curve.

title: Normal Curves and Z-scores
description: Students begin by finding the probability of a value between two given numbers. Then they are guided to assess whether a given data set is approximately normal via frequency histograms and standard deviation.

title: Back Solving with Z-score
description: Students study multiple problems and discover which technique is most appropriate. Then students use the proper technique to solve multiple authentic problems.

title: Empirical vs. Z-score
description: Students explore the relationship between the empirical rule and Z-scores, determine when to use each to efficiently solve problems, and apply both techniques to solve a variety of practice problems involving real-world population data.

title: Measure of Center and Normal Distribution Test
description: Students respond to short answer questions in order to demonstrate their understanding of mean, standard deviation, median, mode, outliers, spread, Z-scores, percentiles, and the normal distribution.

title: Scatter Plots and Overall Pattern
description: Students create and then define the properties of a scatter plot. They learn how to describe a scatter plot and do so for several unique scatter plots. Students complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Finding a Best-fit Equation
description: Students create a scatter plot and then draw their own best-fit equation. In doing so, they realize that each student’s interpretation is different. Next, they discuss the difference between interpolation and extrapolation. Students learn how to estimate strength of linear relationships with the correlation coefficient.

title: Least Squares Linear Regression
description: Students create a universal perfect best-fit line on their calculator called the Least Squares Linear Regression equation. Likewise, they find the value of the correlation coefficient. Lastly, students use the proper technique to solve a multi-step authentic problem. Emphasis is placed on explaining the slope of the LSLR in real-world terms.

title: Outliers versus Influential Points
description: Students examine relationships of outliers in the x- and y-directions. They discover thaty-outliers weaken the strength but not the LSLR, while x-outliers (influentials) affect the strength but also greatly affect the equation of the LSLR itself. Students create residual plots and use them to assess the quality of several LSLRs.

title: Classroom Work Session
description: Students work with partners to create scatterplots that identify categorical variables. They also review the principles of linear regression in preparation for the formative assessment on the topic.

title: Quiz: Scatter Plot
description: Short answer and creation of a scatter plot.  Students may define several vocabulary words and explain the real world meaning of their findings.

title: Causation
description: Students begin by reviewing extrapolated data and discussing its value. To explore causation, they are given a bivariate data set with a moderate correlation and are asked to study the possible cause of the relationship between the two variables. Students complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Two-way Tables
description: Students examine and discuss the how data from categorical data sets can be combined using two-way tables.  Then they create marginal distributions and conditional distributions. Using the distributions they find probabilities.  Lastly, students use the proper technique to solve multiple authentic problems.

title: Simpson’s Paradox
description: The activity begins with a review of two-way tables and condition probabilities. Next, students are given two two-way tables that have a specific association. The students then discover that when data sets are combined the association can switch.

title: Least-Squares Regression Line Quiz
description: Short answer, creation of scatter plot, finding a residual, and the assessing of a LSLR through a residual plot.

title: Test: Bivariate Data
description: Students complete short answer and multiple-choice questions as well as create data displays to demonstrate their understanding of the analysis of bivariate data.

title: Sample Design and Randomization
description: Sampling procedures, including probability and non-probability sampling, are explored in this learning experience. Students compare good, biased, and poor sampling techniques and learn to determine whether accurate inferences can be made based on the type of sample used.

title: Experimental Design
description: Students explore the history of experimental design and develop an understanding of aspects of experimental design in this learning experience. Experimental design topics that students consider include randomization, control groups, treatment, experimental groups, responses, and effectiveness.

title: Classroom Work Session
description: In this learning experience, students work with a partner to review the concepts of experimental design and observational studies,  and related vocabulary from the unit.

title: Sampling and Experimental Design Quiz
description: Students are assessed on their understanding of vocabulary related to sampling and experimental design by matching definitions to terms and by providing examples for some of the terms.

title: Probability
description: Students review probability concepts and vocabulary including theoretical probability, experimental probability, event, complement, outcome, sample space, and experiment. Students also discover the fundamental concepts of probability and discuss the origins of probability theory.

title: Independent and Disjoint
description: Students use real life events to define independent and dependent events.  Using the intersection rule for independence we find solutions to problems associated with “at least one”. Next they assess real life probability models for correctness. Students then use two-way table to assess for disjoint sets.

title: Venn Diagrams
description: Students review the intersection rule for independence and we find solutions to problems associated with “at least one." Students then visualize probability with intersections and union using Venn Diagrams. Then students learn how to create and utilize three sets of Venn Diagrams. Students complete problem sets and homework related to their discussions.

title: Test: Probability and Sampling
description: Students are given problems to demonstrate their understanding of sample design, experimental design, independence, disjoint, union, intersection, complements.

title: Introduction to Angles and Trigonometry
description: As a class, students discuss the relationship between radians and degrees and discover a conversion method. Students then use the basic relationships of trigonometry to find the six trigonometric relationships at a point, with no unit circle. Lastly, students study the trigonometric values of quadrantal angles on the unit circle.

title: Angles and Trigonometry Relationships
description: Students use the unit circle to investigate the relationship between special angles and their trigonometric function values.

title: Reference Angles
description: Students explore angles with the same reference angle and discover their properties. They practice using the properties and learn the acronym ASTC as it relates to the coordinate plane. Next, students are given descriptions of trigonometric values for an angle and deduce the quadrant in which the angle is located. That skill is then used to find the values of the six trigonometric functions of an angle with little information and without the use of a calculator.

title: Quiz: Trigonometry Basics
description: Students are given a short-answer assessment to demonstrate their understanding of angle conversion, trigonometric values at a point, trigonometric values of special angles in the first quadrant, and quadrantal angles. Calculators are not permitted.

title: Exploration of Transformations
description: Students explore transformations of trigonometric functions using graphing calculators or software.

title: Transformations: Graphing from Equations
description: Students review the effects of each parameter on the graph of a trigonometric function in general form, discussing amplitude, period, horizontal shift, and vertical shift. Students then complete a review sheet on graphing transformations of trigonometric functions given their equations.

title: Transformations: Phase Shifts
description: The learning experience begins with a simple review of factoring methods. Students are challenged to make hypotheses about given transformations of trigonometric functions to discover phase shifting. Then students practice identifying phase shifts and using them to graph trigonometric functions.

title: Graphs to Equations
description: Students review transformations of trigonometric functions. They graph transformations when given function rules and determine function rules from given graphs, beginning with simple graphs and functions and progressing to more complicated examples.

title: Quiz: Graphing Trigonometric Functions
description: Students complete a short-answer, non-calculator assessment to demonstrate their understanding of trigonometric values for special angles and graphs of trigonometric functions.

title: Graphing Tangent and the Reciprocals
description: Students begin with a discussion of the relationship between sine and cosecant and use a graphing calculator to explore their graphs. Then they review the basic properties of the tangent and cotangent functions. Students also investigate transformations of tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant functions and solve and graph solutions to real-world problems.

title: Test: Trigonometric Functions and the Unit Circle
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of trigonometric functions and the unit circle. Students are allowed to use a graphing calculator to complete a portion of the assessment. Topics on the test include converting angle measures between radians and degrees, finding reference angles, calculating trigonometric values, graphing transformations of trigonometric functions, and identifying key characteristics of trigonometric graphs.

title: Introduction to Identities
description: Students first review the definitions of each of the trigonometric relationships. They discover the first Pythagorean identity through a series of examples, and then they examine the remainder of the Pythagorean identities. Students also review even and odd functions and use those concepts to derive the negative-angle identities. Students then solve problems using simple identities.

title: Identities with Rational Fractions
description: Students begin with a review of the methods used for adding and subtraction fractions and rational expressions. They then discuss basic strategies and rules for identities, followed by an examination of a series of identities with rational fractions.

title: Proving Trigonometric Identities
description: Students discuss the homework from the previous learning experiences and share strategies they used to prove trigonometric identities. They organize the strategies into a presentation, such as a table or flowchart, that includes the identities covered so far. Then, students work in groups to solve problems that require them to combine multiple strategies.

title: Identities
description: Students work in pairs to demonstrate their understanding of identities.

title: Inverses
description: Students use a graph of the sine function to graph its inverse. They identify restrictions on the domain of the sine function that result in its inverse also being a function. In that way, they develop a definition for the inverse sine function, . Students use a similar procedure to explore the inverse cosine and inverse tangent functions. They then apply all six inverse trigonometric functions to solve mathematical and application problems.

title: Composition with Inverses
description: Students begin by reviewing compositions of two functions, including the composition of a function and its inverse. Then they explore compositions involving trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions and determine the domains of those functions for which  and

title: Inverses Versus Solving Trigonometric Equations
description: Students begin by determining whether given angle measures represent solutions to simple trigonometric equations. They then work in small groups to solve first-degree trigonometric equations and to represent the infinite solution sets algebraically. Next, they solve equations involving phase shifts or period changes by first substituting a variable for the argument of the trigonometric function.

title: Quiz: Trigonometry Basics
description: Students complete a quiz designed to formatively assess their understanding of inverse trigonometric functions and first-degree trigonometric equations (learning experiences 5–7).

title: Solving Quadratic Trigonometric Equations
description: Students begin by reviewing factoring of binomials and trinomials. They then apply those skills to factor trigonometric expressions. Next, students participate in a gallery walk activity that involves solving several trigonometric equations of the quadratic type. Following the activity, students discuss the strategies and methods they used to solve the equations and verify their answers. Throughout this learning experience, students will explore the differences in outcomes when finding the inverse versus solving a trigonometric equation, highlighting the change in the restriction in the outcome.

title: Inverses and Solving Equations
description: Students work in pairs to complete a set of practice problems that demonstrate their understanding of inverse trigonometric functions and their ability to solve trigonometric equations.

title: Test: Inverses and Solving Equations
description: Students complete a summative assessment designed to test their understanding of inverse trigonometric functions and first- and second-degree trigonometric equations.

title: Cofunctions and Pythagorean Theorem Applications
description: Students begin by reviewing the Pythagorean theorem and the six trigonometric functions. They then solve a set of practical application problems involving right triangles. Next, students complete an activity in which they discover the cofunction identities. Finally, they apply thee identities to solve problems.

title: Law of Sines
description: Students work as a class to derive the Law of Sines, and they discuss how the Law of Sines forms part of an axiomatic system. Next, they work in small groups to solve oblique triangles for the ASA and AAS cases, and they investigate the ambiguous case of SSA. Students also complete a homework assignment in which they solve additional problems with the Law of Sines, including application problems.

title: Quiz: Pythagorean Theorem and Cofunctions
description: Students complete a quiz designed to formatively assess their understanding of cofunction identities and applications of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Law of Cosines
description: Students work as a class to investigate and derive the law of cosines. They first examine oblique triangles that can and cannot be solved with the law of sines, and they explore how to use the law of cosines to find unknown sides or angles. Students complete practice problems that include real-world applications of the law of cosines.

title: Quiz: Law of Sines
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of the law of sines by answering short-answer questions. They may use a calculator during the assessment.

title: Areas of Non-Right Triangles
description: Students work as a class to derive the formula  for the area of an oblique triangle. Next, they complete an activity in which they research and discuss the mathematician Heron and his city of Alexandria. They then learn how to apply Heron’s formula to find the area of an oblique triangle when given its side lengths. Students practice what they have learned by working with a partner to solve problems involving the areas of nonright triangles.

title: Inverses and Solving Equations
description: Students work in groups of two to complete a set of practice problems and demonstrate their understanding of the Pythagorean theorem, the laws of sines and cosines, and area of oblique triangles.

title: Test: Right and Non-Right Triangles
description: Students complete a summative assessment designed to test their understanding of right and non-right triangles.

title: Introduction to the Polar Plane
description: Students discuss the contributions of Nicole Oresme, who used a rectangular plane to represent linear functions, and René Descartes, who developed Cartesian products. They learn about polar coordinates and the polar plane, and Newton’s equations for transforming rectangular to polar coordinates. Students learn about the lemniscate of Bernoulli and the logarithmic spiral. They learn about Bernoulli’s development of the modern-day version of polar coordinates. Students connect to the geocentric model they studied in grade 9 Science. Students learn to plot points in the polar plane and find polar and Cartesian coordinates of a point.

title: Polar Functions
description: Students describe the position of a point using the measure of rotation θ from the polar axis, at a distance r from the origin. They study Bernoulli’s observations about the logarithmic spiral, Archimedes’s calculations of the area within the Archimedean spiral, and Newton’s technique for locating a point as (r, θ). Students convert equations of lines and circles to polar form, plot the points of a polar function and connect them with a smooth curve, and plot points with negative radii.

title: Lines and Spirals in the Polar Plane
description: Students translate equations from Cartesian to polar form. They review polar equations for lines and circles, and they derive the polar equations for vertical and horizontal lines. Students construct a table of values, plot points, and connect them with a smooth curve to form an Archimedean spiral.

title: Polar Coordinates
description: Students complete a quiz with graphing and open-response questions in which they plot points in polar coordinates and translate points from polar to rectangular coordinates.

title: Polar Models
description: Students study the limaçon of Pascal, named after Blaise Pascal’s father, Etienne Pascal, by Gilles Personne de Roberval. They learn that Albrecht Dürer showed a method for drawing the limaçon, and the cardioid is a special case of the limaçon. Students study the contributions of several mathematicians in understanding the cardioid. They study the rose curve, named by Guido Grandi. Using graphing calculators and examples, students explore graphs in polar form, including the limaçon, cardioid, and rose curves. They apply those curves to solve problems related to directional microphones.

title: Work Session: Polar Models
description: Students complete practice problems working in pairs to demonstrate their understanding of polar functions and converting between polar and rectangular forms.

title: Test: Polar Plane
description: Students complete a two-part test on polar graphs and polar coordinates. In the first part, students graph polar coordinates, translate coordinates and equations from polar to Cartesian coordinates, label the graphs, and write equations in the first quadrant. Students are not allowed to used calculators. In the second part, with the help of a graphing calculator, students describe the graphs of polar equations, identify lines and circles, give key characteristics of graphs, and graph a lemniscate.

title: Introduction to Sequences
description: Students discuss pattern recognition in the development of mathematics by various cultures. They learn that the ancient Greeks wrote sequences, and that Archimedes used sequences of polygon areas to approximate π. Students define sequences and related vocabulary, and they try to recognize patterns within the sequences. They learn the notation for sequences in formula notation, in both recursive and closed forms, and calculate terms in sequences. With their graphing calculators, students model the iterations in a recursive formula by using a table in Seq mode.

title: Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences
description: Students discuss the origins of arithmetic sequences as a form of counting, beginning with the natural numbers. They learn the recursive and closed formulas that describe arithmetic and geometric sequences, and they apply the formulas to find specified terms. Using the table feature of their graphing calculators in SEQ mode, students model the iterations of a recursive formula.

title: Introduction to Series
description: Students learn that fourth-century Hindus summed sequences to solve interest and discount problems. They use numerical examples to derive formulas for the sum of an arithmetic or geometric sequence, also known as a series, by the method that Gauss discovered as a schoolboy. They learn the method that Aryabhata published inAryabhatiya. Students learn to write series in sigma notation.

title: Applications of Series
description: Students review and practice using the sequence and series formulas and writing series in sigma notation. They apply those formulas to solve a multifaceted, real-world problem about a beaded necklace.

title: Quiz: Sequences
description: Students complete an open-response assessment that includes closed and recursive equations based on arithmetic and geometric sequences. They find the nth term of a sequence and identify the number of a term, given its value. Students solve real-world problems about a bouncing ball and about the value of a house.

title: Finding the Sums of Finite Series
description: Students review the method that Gauss used to find the sum of the first 100 positive integers when he was only nine years old. They apply the pattern they discovered to write a general formula for the sum of the first n terms of any arithmetic sequence, and they then check the validity of their formula. Next, students develop a formula for the sum of the first n terms of any geometric sequence, and they verify their formula. They solve problems with real-world applications of finite series, such as finding the total amount of interest paid over the term of a loan or the total amount in an interest-bearing account that receives regular deposits.

title: Infinite Geometric Series
description: Students explore an infinite geometric series that diverges by analyzing a legend involving grains of rice in which the number of grains doubles each day. They then investigate Zeno’s paradox of Achilles and the tortoise by analyzing an infinite geometric series that converges. Students discover when an infinite geometric series converges, and they find the sum of the series.

title: Quiz: Series
description: Students demonstrate their understanding of series by completing a quiz with short-answer questions. They expand and evaluate series written in summation notation, write the summation notation to represent a given series, and find partial sums of arithmetic and geometric series. They identify infinite geometric series as convergent or divergent, and calculate the sum of convergent series. Students write a repeating decimal as a fraction in simplest form, and they solve application problems involving arithmetic and geometric series relating to a tennis tournament and to the distribution of grain.

title: Work Session: Sequences and Series
description: Students work in pairs to complete a set of practice problems and demonstrate their understanding of sequences and series.

title: Test: Sequences and Series
description: Students complete a summative assessment containing multiple-choice and open-response questions. They write recursive and closed formulas to represent sequences, compare recursive and closed formulas, and convert between recursive and closed formulas. Students find terms of arithmetic and geometric sequences, and they compare geometric sequences with exponential functions. They convert between expanded form and summation notation, evaluate finite series, classify infinite geometric series, find the sum of convergent series, and solve application problems that model real-world situations, such as the spread of an infectious disease.

title: Induction
description: Students verify the sum of the first n positive even integers for values of n up to 5. They consider whether that is sufficient to prove it for all positive integers, which leads them into an exploration of proof by mathematical induction. Students learn the structure of that type of proof, and apply it to complete a proof about the sum of the first n even numbers. They discuss other forms of proof and relate those forms to proof by mathematical induction. Students learn about the contributions of Francesco Maurolico, and they prove Maurolico’s proposition about the sum of the first n odd numbers. They prove formulas by using mathematical induction and verify or correct the proofs of others.

title: Work Session: Induction
description: Students work in pairs to complete a set of practice problems and demonstrate their understanding of proof by mathematical induction.

title: Introduction to Limits
description: Students explore the limit of a function. They examine the behavior of a graph as x approaches zero and verify their observations using a graphing calculator. Students use tables to find limits of rational functions for values of x for which the denominator is equal to zero. They review graphing piecewise functions, and they explore limits where the function rule changes.

title: Finding Limits
description: Students learn the substitution technique for finding the limit of a continuous function at a point. Students apply the technique to linear, quadratic, polynomial, and other functions. They examine limits of rational functions at zeros of the denominators. They factor the numerator and denominator, remove common factors, and apply the substitution rule to find the limits. Students explore the graphs of piecewise defined functions, find one-sided limits, and discover that the limit exists if and only if the left and right limits exist and are equal.

title: Limits and Continuity
description: Students observe piecewise functions in which the left and right limits are not equal. From the graphs, they see jumps between different pieces of the graph. Students also revisit limits of rational functions and learn about removable discontinuities. They discover the criteria for a function to be continuous and apply them to write a definition and determine whether functions are continuous.

title: Vertical and Horizontal Asymptotes
description: In reviewing vertical and horizontal asymptotes of rational functions, students recall that vertical asymptotes occur when the denominator is zero and the numerator is nonzero, and they discover that an infinite discontinuity always occurs at a vertical asymptote. They also review horizontal asymptotes, which represent the limit of the function as x approaches positive or negative infinity. They determine the end behavior of the graph, including horizontal asymptotes, based on the degrees of the numerator and denominator.

title: Quiz: Limits
description: Students complete a short-answer quiz to assess their understanding of limits. They use tables and algebraic techniques, and they sketch and analyze graphs to find limits. Students apply limits to determine the continuity of the graph of a piecewise function.

title: Limits
description: To prepare for the summative assessment on limits, students work in pairs to complete a set of practice problems. They use tabular, graphical, and algebraic methods to determine limits of different types of functions, and they apply their understanding of limits to determine continuity of functions. Students make conjectures about properties of limits and explore the epsilon-delta definition of a limit.

title: Test: Limits
description: Students complete a short-answer test to assess their understanding of limits. They solve calculator and noncalculator problems that require using tables and algebraic techniques, as well as sketching and analyzing graphs, to determine limits and to analyze continuity of rational and piecewise functions.

title: Fractals in Nature
description: Students are introduced to the concept of fractals. They begin by viewing images of fractals in nature and identifying defining characteristics of fractals base on those images. Students then investigate the Sierpiski triangle.

title: Fractals and the Sierpinski Carpet
description: Students begin with a review of the Sierpiski triangle and what they believe a fractal to be. Next, they construct a fourth-stage square Sierpiski carpet. Using their understanding of sequences and series and the concept of limits, students discover the unusual properties of the Sierpiski carpet. Next, they examine zero-, one-, and two-stage Sierpiski tetrahedrons that can be made with a three-dimensional printer. To conclude their investigation, students explore three-dimensional fractals by creating a third-stage Sierpiski tetrahedron and hypothesizing what a second-stage Sierpiski cube might look like.

title: Fractal Trees
description: Students begin by viewing photographs of trees in nature and discussing the properties they have discovered about fractals thus far. They are then introduced to the fractal tree, exploring its unique properties and formalizing the definition of a fractal. Students do that by writing both explicit and recursive code to create fractal trees. Finally, they learn to distinguish self-similar and strictly self-similar fractals by investigating several examples of each.

title: Fractal Curves
description: Students are introduced to one- to two-dimensional fractal curves. They begin by constructing the Koch snowflake and discover that it has an infinite perimeter yet contains only a finite area. Students compare the snowflake to other fractals they have studied and use their understanding of limits to explore limit curves.

title: Quiz: Fractals
description: Students complete a quiz in which they create third-stage fractals and respond to short-answer questions based on the figures they have drawn.

title: Fractal Dimension of a Square and a Cube
description: To investigate fractal dimension, students discuss the dimensionality of a line, a square, and a cube. By using a ratio related to the scale factor, students develop a formula for determining the dimensionality of each figure. As an extension of their investigation of fractal dimension, they are challenged to determine the dimensionality of the Sierpiski triangle.

title: Fractal Dimension of Artificial Fractals
description: Students learn that the dimension of a fractal is the exponent that must be applied to a linear measure to determine the corresponding length of a fractal, and that the exponent is usually not a whole number. They determine the fractal dimension of the Koch curve and analyze what the dimension indicates about the complexity of the fractal. Students learn a technique they can use to estimate a fractal dimension, which is often used when the construction method is not known, or for natural fractals such as coastlines. They apply the method to the Koch curve and compare with their earlier results.

title: Quiz: Fractal Curves
description: Students complete a quiz in which they analyze the first stage of a fractal curve, apply a given pattern to sketch the second and third stages of the fractal, and apply a method of their choice to determine the fractal dimension.

title: Fractal Dimension Project
description: This project begins with a class discussion on the definition of a fractal, followed by a group research activity on the history of fractals. Next, the class works together to manually find the dimension of a natural fractal. Then students work in pairs to find the fractal dimensions of a river and two coastlines, using maps of those geological features.
