They complete a formal report that presents their data and explains the process used. Lastly, they compare the fractal dimensions and interpret the results in the context.

title: The Tangent and Velocity Problems
description: Students define a line that intersects two points on a graph as a secant line, and they use the slope of the secant line to approximate the slope of a tangent line by considering the limit as the points move closer together. They investigate the experiments of Galileo with timed motion of balls, which led to the development of equations for falling objects. Through studying examples of simple functions and graphs, students note that velocity is a rate that shows the change in position over the change in time. They work in small groups to find average velocity, and they discuss as a class how the average velocity changes as the elapsed time approaches 0.

title: The Limit of a Function
description: Students learn that a function f(x) has a limit L at x = a if, as x gets closer and closer to a,f(x) gets closer and closer to L. They also explore one-sided limits and learn that the left-hand and the right-hand limits must be equal for the limit of f(x) to exist. Students use the table and graphing features of a graphing calculator to find limits for different functions, including piecewise functions. Students may explore the formal definition of limit, which was developed by the mathematician Bernard Bolzano; as an extension, students may also use that definition to prove limits.

title: Calculating Limits Using Limit Laws
description: Students explore limits of the functions f(x) = x and the constant function f(x) = k. Next, they examine specific examples of limit laws for sums, differences, products, multiples, quotients, powers, and roots of functions. They understand that those laws provide a method for calculating limits that does not require graphs or tables. Students learn that in cases where the laws cannot be directly applied, they may be able to use algebraic techniques for simplification, such as factoring or rationalizing, to rewrite functions in forms that allow them to find the limits. Students also apply the same techniques to one-sided limits.

title: Limits
description: Students complete a quiz to assess their understanding thus far. Topics covered include instantaneous velocity using a table of values, methods for calculating limits of functions, including indeterminate forms, evaluating limits from graphs of functions, and proving theorems about limits.

title: Tangents and Velocities at One Point
description: Students review how to approximate the slope of the tangent to a curve by finding the slope of a secant line. They learn to find the slope of the curve  by finding

title: The Derivative Function
description: Students compare the process of using the limit definition to find the slope of a curve at a given point to the process of using the limit definition to determine a function called the derivative. They  calculate derivatives using  or

title: History of the Derivative
description: Students research and analyze the work of 17th-century mathematicians and create a timeline. They learn that the derivative was the breakthrough that enabled scientists and mathematicians to understand relationships such as planetary motion and gravitational attraction. They research the dispute between Newton and Leibniz over who first calculated the derivative of a function, and they explore in depth each of their contributions to calculus.

title: Continuity
description: Students learn that a function f is continuous at a number a if and only if the following three conditions are satisfied:  is defined,  exists, and

title: Vertical and Horizontal Asymptotes
description: Students explore the historical understanding of the infinite, beginning with the ancient Greeks. They learn that John Wallis developed infinite expansions in the 17th century and introduced the symbol  [begin mathsize 9px style infinity end style] , and that Newton, Leibniz, the Bernoullis, Euler, and others often worked without rigorous treatment of infinity. They study the contributions of Jean Le Rond d’Alembert, Augustin-Louis Cauchy, and Karl Theodor Wilhelm Weierstrass to the theory of limits. Students use limits to determine whether a function has vertical or horizontal asymptotes, and they practice finding asymptotes and limits that involve infinity.

title: Test: Limits and Continuity
description:
Students solve both calculator and noncalculator problems related to the concepts studied.

They solve multiple-choice, short-answer, and open-response problems about tangents, instantaneous rates of change, and limits. They use a graphing calculator’s table function to find instantaneous rates of change and limits, connect graphs to the ideas of limits and continuity, and determine whether functions are continuous over the set of real numbers.

title: The Derivative as a Function
description: Students understand that the slope of the tangent line is the slope of the curve at the point of tangency and that the value of slope is a real number. They study early attempts by Gilles Personne de Roberval and Pierre de Fermat to construct tangent lines to curves, as well as the differential methods of Leibniz and Newton that are used today. Students sketch tangent lines and estimate the graph of the derivative given a graph of a function. They learn properties of the derivative at points where the graph is increasing, decreasing, or at an extreme value. They learn that a differentiable function is continuous, and a continuous function is differentiable, except at sharp corners or points of inflection where the tangent line is vertical. Students are introduced to the concept that the derivative represents an instantaneous rate of change of the function at a point.

title: Rules for Differentiation
description: Students learn simple derivative rules of functions, including the power rule, the constant rule, the sum and difference rule, and the derivative of the exponential function. They use those rules to find the slope at a given point and write the equation of the tangent line. Students also learn the many different notations for the derivative, especially the notation used by Leibniz.

title: More Rules for Differentiation
description: Students learn how to find the derivative of functions formed by functions that are multiplied or divided. The product and quotient rules are more complicated and require much practice, so students complete several problem sets, both individually and in small learning groups.

title: Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions
description: Students use the graphs of the sine and cosine functions to determine their derivatives. Students then develop the derivatives for the other four trigonometric functions using the definitions of the trigonometric functions and the quotient rule.

title: The Chain Rule
description: Students learn how to find the derivatives of functions that involve a composition of functions. That enables them to find derivatives of complicated functions with ease. The rule requires much practice, so students complete several problem sets, both individually and in small learning groups.

title: Velocity and Other Rates of Change
description: Students use their knowledge of derivatives to practice solving application problems. They are taught the definitions of displacement, average velocity, instantaneous velocity, speed, and acceleration, all using derivatives. They draw on their knowledge of kinematics from grade 9 Science, and their studies of energy in grade 11 Science. They use both sets of knowledge to solve real-world application problems involving velocity and distance traveled.

title: Quiz
description: Students work in small groups to practice all that they have learned so far. They then take a quiz covering the concepts studied.

title: Derivatives of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
description: Students learn to differentiate more complicated exponential functions, such as functions whose rule is given by a number raised to a function, using the chain rule. They also learn how to calculate the derivative of logarithmic functions with any base, but they focus primarily on the natural logarithm.

title: Quiz on the Derivative Rules
description: Students review differentiation rules with an emphasis on the chain rule, and they solve practice problems involving derivatives and velocity. After the review session, students take a noncalculator quiz on which they find the derivatives of different types of functions, including polynomial, trigonometric, logarithmic, and exponential functions, with an emphasis on the chain rule. Students also solve problems in which they are given a position function and asked to find the velocity, acceleration, and total distance traveled.

title: Implicit Differentiation
description: Students learn how to find the derivatives of nonfunctions—relations that cannot be solved explicitly for y—by using the chain rule. Because such derivatives may be complicated, students are given ample practice time.

title: Implicit Differentiation Again
description: Students are given additional practice with implicit differentiation, and they use the technique with the chain rule to find second derivatives. Students also practice writing equations of tangent lines, and they find horizontal and vertical tangent lines. They discover that horizontal and vertical tangents correspond to key points on the graph of a relation.

title: Derivatives of Inverse Trigonometric Functions
description: Students derive the differentiation formulas for the arc sine, arc cosine, and arc tangent functions. They learn that their cofunctions, arc secant, arc cosecant, and arc cotangent, have the same derivatives but with opposite signs.

title: Logarithmic Differentiation
description: Students discover how logarithmic differentiation is used to find the derivative of a function raised to another function. They also investigate how logarithmic differentiation is used to simplify the differentiation process for complicated functions.

title: Review
description: Students practice all that they have learned to prepare for the unit assessment. This practice is also good preparation for the next unit, Applications of the Derivative. Students solve problems that emphasize how to answer complicated questions using the calculator.

title: Test: Noncalculator Portion
description: Students complete the first part of the unit assessment. No calculators are allowed during this part of the exam. Students respond to a series of multiple-choice and free-response questions. They are given 15 minutes to complete each free-response question and about two minutes for each multiple-choice question.

title: Test: Calculator Portion
description: Students demonstrate their knowledge of the concepts studied through a series of both multiple-choice and free response questions. Students are given 15 minutes to complete each free-response question and about three minutes for each multiple-choice question.

title: Extreme Values of Functions
description: Students define absolute or global maximum and minimum values of a function. They explore the Extreme Value Theorem, which states that any continuous function on a closed interval must have at least one minimum and one maximum value. They learn that this theorem was proved independently by Bernard Bolzano and Karl Weierstrass in the 19th century. Students define local maximum and minimum values. They practice finding critical points of functions by determining when the derivative is zero or undefined for values in the domain of each function.

title: Extreme Values and the Mean Value Theorem
description: Students learn Fermat’s Theorem, which states that local extreme values that are not endpoints occur at the critical points of the function. They apply Fermat’s Theorem to find the extreme values of a function. Students also learn the Mean Value Theorem, which states that there exists at least one point between the two endpoints of a continuous interval of a function where the derivative is equal to the slope of the line connecting the endpoints. They explore how to find those point(s) and apply the Mean Value Theorem to real-world situations such as velocity and temperature.

title: What does f' say about f ?
description: Students learn how to calculate when a function is increasing or decreasing by finding where the derivative is positive or negative. Students also learn the first derivative test for functions to find local extreme values. Students must be given noncalculator problems to practice.

title: What does f" say about f?
description: Students analyze graphs of functions to determine concavity and inflection points. They learn that a graph is concave up where the first derivative is increasing, and it is concave down where the first derivative is decreasing. Students apply the second derivative test to find local extreme values of functions, and they determine when the test fails and the first derivative test must be used.

title: Optimization Problems
description: Students apply the derivative tests to find extreme values of functions in real-world situations, such as finding maximum volume or minimum surface area.

title: Using Derivatives to Graph the Function
description: Students use the first and second derivatives to sketch graphs of functions without the use of a graphing calculator. They locate extremes and inflection points, determine where functions are increasing, decreasing, concave up and concave down, and locate horizontal and vertical asymptotes. They incorporate that information into the sketch of each graph

title: Review
description: Students practice all types of problems from the first part of the unit, with an emphasis on noncalculator problems.

title: Quiz: Derivatives and Critical Values
description: Students take a noncalculator assessment that contains multiple-choice and free-response questions in the style of standardized exams. Questions include finding critical points from a graph, finding extreme values of a function, and sketching a graph using derivatives.

title: Related Rates
description: In situations involving two variables, students calculate the rate of change of one variable given a known rate and the relationship between the variables. They read a problem carefully, draw a diagram, and then assign symbols to all quantities that are functions of time. They express the relationship as an equation in terms of derivatives, differentiate both sides of the equation with respect to t, and solve for the unknown rate.

title: Practice with Related Rates
description: Students practice setting up and solving additional related-rates problems.

title: Linearization or Tangent Line Approximation
description: Students use the tangent line to approximate values of complicated functions by substituting the value into the tangent line. They use the concavity of the graph to determine when the approximation is greater or less than the actual value.

title: Applications of the Derivative on the Calculator
description: Students use graphing calculators to find critical points and extremes of complicated functions. They are given the first or second derivative, and they use the graph to find extreme values or determine concavity. Students use data to estimate derivatives and approximate the concavity of functions.

title: Review
description: Students practice solving Advanced Calculus-style problems on related rates and applications of the derivative, including calculator and noncalculator problems.

title: L’Hôpital’s Rule
description: Students apply L’Hôpital's rule to evaluate limits that produce indeterminate forms, such as  and  by differentiating the numerator and denominator separately. They then use substitution to find the limit. If another indeterminate form occurs, then they apply L’Hôpital's rule again, continuing until direct substitution produces an answer.

title: Test: Noncalculator Portion
description: In preparation for the unit assessment, students spend one class period working in pairs to review the topics from this unit and to ask clarifying questions. Then they complete the noncalculator portion of the test, which includes multiple-choice and free-response questions. Students are given 15 minutes to complete each free-response question and about two minutes for each multiple-choice question.

title: Test: Calculator Portion
description: This test includes both multiple-choice and free-response questions. Students are given 15 minutes for each free-response question and about three minutes for each multiple-choice question.

title: Rectangular Approximation Method (RAM)
description: Students estimate the area under a the graph of a function by drawing rectangles using the left-hand, right-hand, and midpoint rectangular approximation methods (LRAM, RRAM, and MRAM). Students discover which method is an over-approximation or under-approximation, and that the more rectangles used, the better the approximation. At this point, students are allowed to use the calculator and only use a small number of rectangles.

title: RAM on the Graphing Calculator
description: Students perform left-hand, right-hand, and midpoint rectangular approximations on a graphing calculator using the sum and sequence functions. By using technology, students are able to calculate the area of many rectangles in order to improve the estimation of the area under a curve.

title: The Definite Integral
description: Students are introduced to the definite integral as a limit of a rectangular approximation as the number of rectangles approaches infinity. They learn that if the curve is above thex-axis, the definite integral represents the exact area under the curve. If it is below the x-axis, then the definite integral is negative. If the curve falls above and below the x-axis, the definite integral is the net area. Students are challenged to evaluate definite integrals by graphing functions and then using geometric formulas to find the corresponding areas, including functions with areas above and below the x-axis.

title: Finding Area Using Definite Integral
description: Students evaluate definite integrals on a calculator. They explore the definite integral of the sine function. Then, using properties of the graphs, they determine the values of related definite integrals and investigate their relationships.

title: Properties of Definite Integrals and the Mean Value Theorem
description: Students learn rules for definite integrals, including the order of integration, zero, constant multiple, sum and difference, additivity, max-min inequality, and domination. These properties are examined and explained using graphs of functions and the idea that the definite integral is the net area between the function and the x-axis. Students are given multiple problems with graphs of functions and known area or calculable area, to evaluate the definite integral. Also, students learn the Mean Value Theorem for Integrals.

title: Average Value of a Function and Review
description: Students find the average value of a function over an interval by using a graphing calculator to evaluate a definite integral. When given the average value of a function, they find the value of the definite integral. For homework, students review all of the topics studied previously in this unit.

title: Summative Assessment - Definite Integrals and Their Properties
description: For the non-calculator portion of the test, students find areas using RAM with a small number of rectangles from a graph or table of values, determine whether their estimate is an overestimate or an underestimate, and use geometry and symmetry to evaluate integrals. For the calculator-driven portion of the test, students evaluate more complex integrals, find average values of functions, use the RAM methods with large numbers of rectangles, and evaluate integrals using properties of integrals.

title: Exploration of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part I
description: Students analyze graphs for the integrals in which one limit is a variable. They determine a function that represents the area for given integrals, using geometric formulas to find areas. Students examine the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1 and use their functions to verify the theorem. As an extension, students investigate mathematicians whose work helped develop this theorem.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 1
description: Students apply part 1 of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to find the derivative of an integral function. They practice finding the derivative of an integral function when the variable is in the upper or lower limit, and when the variable is a function, requiring the chain rule. Students also find local maxima and minima and concavity of accumulation functions.

title: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2
description: Students learn part 2 of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, and they compare it to part 1 of the theorem. They discuss strategies for using the second part of the FTC to determine the antiderivative for a function. Students discuss whether all functions are integrable, and what kinds of functions, if any, are non-integrable.

title: Practice of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus
description: To practice working with the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, students write a function F(x) and determine its derivative F'(x). Then, they write a definite integral which uses the function F'(x) and use the antiderivative F(x) to evaluate the integral. Students complete practice problems that apply both the first and second parts of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, and share their strategies for solving problems involving definite integrals.

title: The Trapezoidal Rule
description: Students learn how to approximate the area under the graph of a function by using trapezoids. They learn that the Trapezoidal Rule gives a close approximation even with a small number of trapezoids. They also discover that the approximation is the average of the LRAM and RRAM learned in the beginning of this unit. They apply the Trapezoidal Rule to solve real-world problems and estimate area when a function is not known but a list of data values is given.

title: Review of the Definite Integral
description: Students work in small groups to solve problems that parallel those on college placement exams, including problems that require graphing calculators as well as problems for which graphing calculators are not permitted. Students use rectangle and trapezoidal approximation methods to estimate areas, evaluate definite integrals, find average values of functions, use properties of integrals, and find antiderivatives.

title: Integral as a Net Change
description: Students interpret a velocity function and find position from displacement. They find the total distance traveled by evaluating the definite integral. They solve application problems involving net change over time in other real-world contexts, including population, money, and volume.

title: Test: Non-Calculator Portion
description: Students answer both multiple-choice and free-response questions about the rectangle and trapezoid methods of approximating area. They evaluate definite integrals to find the area under a curve, find average values, and solve problems using the Mean Value Theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

title: Test: Calculator Portion
description: Students answer both multiple-choice and free-response calculator-driven questions about rectangle and trapezoid methods of approximating area. They evaluate definite integrals to find the area under a curve, find average values, calculate position functions given the velocity, and solve problems using the Mean Value Theorem and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

title: The Indefinite Integral and Slope Fields
description: Students reverse the derivative rules to find an anti-derivative in one step, and they add constants to the function to generate additional anti-derivatives. They learn that Euler developed slope fields to represent slopes graphically, and they draw slope fields for differential equations, complete tables to calculate the slope of differential equations, and explore patterns in the slope field that represent possible anti-derivatives of the function. Students solve mathematical and real-world problems, including rates of change in velocity, population growth, and chemical reactions.

title: Initial Value Problems
description: Students solve initial value problems for functions with one-step anti-derivatives using an approximation of the graph of the anti-derivative on a slope field through the initial value. They use the notation of indefinite integrals to denote anti-derivatives and then use initial values to calculate the constant for the anti-derivative. They solve mathematical and real-world problems including velocity, population growth, and chemical reaction rates.

title: Introduction to Integration by Substitution
description: Students learn how to find the anti-derivative of functions containing a composition of functions, which means using the reverse of the chain rule. They choose a function that is a part of the integral and call it u, substitute u and du in the integral, and evaluate, if possible. They then replace u with the function in the anti-derivative. They discuss how to choose u, and they verify their results by differentiating.

title: Practice Problems with Integration by Substitution
description: Students practice integration by substitution, selecting their own u for substitution. Students also explore what happens when they choose an incorrect expression for substitution.

title: Integration by Substitution with Limit Changes
description: Students explore how the steps for solving an indefinite integral by u-substitution can be used to solve definite integrals. They review part 2 of the fundamental theorem of calculus and note that the upper and lower limits of integration are values for x. They share ideas with the class for rewriting the upper and lower limits of integration in terms of u, and they rewrite the interval [a, b] in terms of u. Students solve problems that include both definite and indefinite integrals to be solved by u-substitution and share strategies for determining when to change the limits on the integral while using u-substitution.

title: Quiz: Indefinite Integrals
description: After a review session, students complete a noncalculator quiz including short-answer and multiple-choice items in which they find anti-derivatives of different types of functions, analyze slope fields, solve simple differential equations with given initial conditions, and integrate using u-substitution.

title: Differential Equations and Initial Value Problems
description: Students solve differential equations and match them to slope fields. When given one point that the solution must pass through, they are able to find the exact solution of a differential equation. Students solve separable differential equations and understand that there are some differential equations that are not separable. They check their solutions using slope fields and graph the particular solutions on those slope fields. Students solve mathematical and real-world problems about differential equations, including problems about electrical circuits, and research the contributions of Leibniz in developing the technique of separating variables in 1691.

title: Final Review
description: Students work with partners to practice solving mathematical and real-world problems involving slope fields, differential equations, and indefinite and definite integrals. They solve those problems without the use of a graphing calculator.

title: Test: The Indefinite Integral
description: Students complete a noncalculator assessment covering all the topics in this unit, including slope fields, differential equations, indefinite and definite integrals, and integrals with u-substitution. The test consists of multiple-choice problems and a free-response question.

title: Area Between Two Curves
description: Students revisit the contributions of Bernhard Riemann to methods for approximating the area under a curve, which is found by using a definite integral. Using two functions displayed on the same coordinate grid, students explore how to find the points of intersection to determine the interval, and they then subtract the definite integral of the lower curve from that of the upper curve over the interval. They discuss how to find the area between two curves when one function is the upper curve for only part of the interval. Students solve both calculator and noncalculator problems and then share strategies for determining points of intersection and compare the methods used to find solutions.

title: Area Between Two Curves Continued
description: Students examine a new way to find the area between two curves: by finding a Riemann sum of horizontal rectangles. They analyze the area between two functions using vertical rectangles that requires dividing the area into two separate intervals, which can be found using horizontal rectangles over a single interval. Students discuss how to adjust the formula for finding the area between two curves so that it represents the area with respect to y. They discover the general form for the area between two curves as a function of y, and they discuss when to find the area with respect to either x or y.

title: Introduction to Finding Volume by Disc and Washer Methods
description: Students apply Riemann sums to find a volume when given a function, an axis, and an interval. They consider the solid figure formed by rotating a region around the x-axis. First they discover that the solid formed by rotating a single vertical rectangle in the region is a disc, and then they recognize that the volume of the solid figure can be approximated by adding the volumes of discs. Students then develop the formula for the volume as a definite integral, and they use it to calculate the volume. Students also develop a formula for the volume of a solid generated by rotating a region bounded by two graphs around an axis.

title: Using the Disc and Washer Methods When Rotating Around Lines
description: Students examine a graph and compare the solid formed when the axis of revolution is the x-axis to the solid formed when the axis of revolution is another line. They discuss possible methods to determine the radius of each disc when rotating around the line, and they adapt the integral formula to find the volume. Students apply the same concepts to additional volume problems, share their answers, methods, and strategies with the class, and then discuss and compare different solutions.

title: Quiz: Area and Volume
description: Students participate in a review session, practicing area and volume problems, and asking clarifying questions. Students then complete a quiz containing multiple-choice and short-response questions in which they calculate areas between curves and find volumes of solids of revolution. The quiz includes calculator and noncalculator sections.

title: Volumes of Solids Not Formed by Rotations
description: Students apply ideas developed by Cavalieri to find the volume of a solid that is not formed by rotating a region around a line. The cross sections of such solids may be squares, rectangles, triangles, trapezoids, or semicircles. Students create a volume formula by using the definite integral of the area of a cross section. Students use diagrams to find volumes of solids with different cross sections, including numerical examples and more general examples using variables.

title: Review of Area and Volume Problems
description: Students work in small groups to complete multiple-choice and free-response problems as a review of the previous learning experiences. They review area under the curve, area between two curves, volumes of solids of revolution using the disc and washer method (solids of revolution), and volumes of solids using cross sections. The problems are both noncalculator and calculator based.

title: Test: Noncalculator Problems on Area and Volume
description: Students complete a noncalculator assessment contains multiple-choice and free-response questions covering all topics in this unit, including areas between curves, volumes of solids of revolution, and volumes of other solids.

title: Calculator-Driven Analysis of Area and Volume
description: Students complete a calculator assessment with multiple-choice and free response questions on all the topics covered in this unit, including areas between curves, volumes of solids of revolution, and volumes of other solids.

title: What Makes a Name?
description: Students discuss what elements make up names, examine written format of names, and discover patterns to use in sorting and classifying names.

title: Letters in Our Names
description: Students demonstrate letter recognition and identification abilities by identifying the letters that make up their names.

title: Names in Our Classroom
description: Students work independently to write their names using natural materials to construct the letters. They then spell and read their names aloud.

title: Chanting and Singing Name Songs
description: Students move and vocalize to the tune of name-based songs and incorporate letter/sound associations and repetition to read and spell names.

title: Names Have Meaning
description: Students participate in read-alouds from My Name Is Maria Isabel by Alma Ada and discover names have particular meanings and often have family history associated with them.

title: What If . . . ?
description: During this formative assessment, students demonstrate their understanding of how we use names to identify people, places, and things; how naming gives objects life and animation; and the power of names.

title: The Name Game
description: Working in pairs, students use visual aids and their knowledge of letter names and sounds to spell each other’s names.

title: Identifying and Sorting Letters by Name
description: Using letters of various fonts and sizes, students work in small groups to identify each letter by name and practice voicing the sound associated with each letter.

title: Reading the Names
description: Working from trays of letters and cards containing the names of two classmates, students use hand signals to express their level of understanding of the task. Once the task is understood, students read the names aloud, identify the two classmates, and use the tray of letters to spell out the names.

title: Writing and Family History
description: Students question parents (or caregivers) about the origins of their personal names. They participate in a group discussion about their own names and the reason for their individual names.

title: Names Through Culture
description: Students develop further respect for the power of names by exploring versions of their names, along with common names from other cultures.

title: Naming our Surroundings
description: After learning about how names help people organize and make sense of their surroundings, students synthesize their knowledge of systems and naming by assigning names to various indoor and outdoor areas in an elementary school.

title: Reading for Information
description: Students engage in a read-aloud from Tell Me, Tree: All About Trees for Kids by Gail Gibbons. In pairs, they share two facts they already know about trees, and then work independently to illustrate three new facts or details they learn after listening to the book.

title: Vocabulary for Patterns and Cycles
description: Students investigate and collect vocabulary associated with the unit from texts, websites, and magazines, and then apply pattern words in discussions, writing, and pictures.

title: Nature Journals
description: Students are exposed to the nature journals of Charles Darwin and John Muir and examine different ways to document their own observations and revise and edit their journal entries.

title: Comparing and Contrasting Trees
description: Students learn about various biomes and the trees that are common to them—for example, the two main types of trees found in northeastern North America: deciduous and coniferous and offer suggestions to complete a large classroom Venn diagram that compares the similarities and differences between the deciduous and coniferous trees.

title: Writer’s Workshop Pattern of Living Things
description: Students choose an organism such as a monarch butterfly, honeybee, or a particular tree and create an informational book that uses text and visuals to describe the cycles and patterns of that organism.

title: Read-Aloud Mentors: Rachel Carson
description: After participating in a read-aloud of Rachel Carson and Her Book That Changed the World by Laurie Lawlor, students participate in a shared writing experience to chart their ideas about ways to help the planet. The ideas are assembled into a class book about how individuals can contribute to saving Earth’s natural habitats.

title: Collage Project
description: In the Cultural History Summative Assessment: Trees, Butterflies, and Bees Collage (CH_G1_U1_11_AS), students create a collage that reflects what they have learned. In this assessment, students use the unit’s teachings to create a narrative script that they record as an audio track to accompany the collage.

title: Tools Word Web
description: To initiate this unit, students work collaboratively to create word webs relating tools to the jobs they help facilitate, thereby establishing the idea that tools are extensions of the body.

title: Writing Tools: Cultural History Journals
description: Students access prior knowledge to answer guiding questions about tools and document their answers in their Cultural History journals, where they record information throughout the unit to serve as a record of their understanding. Their answers are revisited at the end of the unit in the summative assessment project.

title: History of Writing Implements
description: This learning experience begins an investigation of the history of writing tools and implements. Students create a timeline of writing tools and written text and investigate their own progression from crayons to pencils to keyboard.

title: History of Text and Reading Materials
description: Students explore the history of books and other reading materials to see how they have changed over time and add the information to the timeline they created in the previous learning experience.

title: Researching Tools
description: Students collect research information in preparation for writing a research paper about a specific historical tool.

title: Writing About the Tool
description: Using research notes collected from the previous learning experience, students write paragraphs about their individually selected historical tools.

title: Designing and Creating Tools
description: Students complete their unit of study about tools by designing, building, and assessing a tool of their own creation.

title: Read-Aloud and Journaling
description: Students listen to books about the water and rock cycles. In their journals, they independently write and illustrate information gleaned from the books and discussion.

title: Comparing Water Cycle and Rock Cycle
description: In Cultural History, students observe a boiling pot of water and compare the stages of this constructed cycle to that of the natural water cycle. In this learning experience, students work in small groups to complete a Venn diagram comparing the water cycle and the rock cycle.

title: Concept Map
description: In this learning experience, students create concepts maps in their journals for the water cycle and rock cycle. The concept maps provide a record of students’ understanding and indicate which students would benefit from further clarification on the subject.

title: Vocabulary and Water Cycle/Rock Cycle
description: In this learning experience, students are introduced to vocabulary words that relate to the unit. They write the vocabulary words in their journals, including an illustration and written definition.

title: Compare and Contrast
description: After listening to read-alouds of If You Find a Rock and Everybody Needs a Rock,students compare and contrast the information found in each book. Students each select a rock and describe it in an original poem.

title: Transforming Words to Movement
description: Students interpret the poems from Water Dance by Thomas Locker through an interpretive dance performance, using original artworks as a backdrop.

title: Cycle Review
description: Students use information gained throughout the unit to create an informational book about either the rock cycle or the water cycle.

title: Brainstorm and Identify Recycling
description: After students generate ideas on why they should be Earth’s caretakers, they design an informational presentation about the importance of recycling.

title: Journaling
description: Students record information in their journals as a record of their understanding of their reading and writing activities and set goals for their performance.

title: Read-Aloud Comparison: The Lorax and A River Ran Wild
description: Using two environmental read-alouds as mentor texts, each student writes a short story with a human consumption or environmental conservation dilemma that the main character solves.

title: Questioning Garbage
description: After listening to the book, Where Does the Garbage Go?, students track garbage items through a cycle of use, disposal, and recycling. They share their findings by making a poster of the cycle of one piece of recycled garbage.

title: Read-Aloud and Recycle: Jen Green’s Why Should I Recycle?
description: Students participate in a read-aloud of Jen Green’s, Why Should I Recycle?, and then take home a recyclable item to discuss with their families. An ongoing discussion of recycling generates new entries for the documentation board.

title: Recycling Paper Project
description: Students create a book about the importance of recycling and conservation using paper they have made by recycling used scrap paper.

title: Public Service Ad
description: Students create and film a public service ad about why it is best to take steps now to conserve the environment for future generations.

title: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle Performance
description: As a culminating event, students perform in an assembly in which they explain the process of reduce, reuse, and recycle.

title: Self-Portrait
description: At the beginning of Unit 1 in Visual Arts, each student draws a self-portrait that is revisited at the end of Unit 3 as a part of the year’s summative assessment. The class listens to a read-aloud and then compares and contrasts facial characteristics, using mirrors to study their faces. Using their observations, students make outlines of their self-portraits.

title: What Is a Collage?
description: Students learn about collage by viewing the work of two master collage artists. After comparing the work of the collage artists, students create collections of collage materials by sorting a variety of papers. They will use their collections to create their own self-portrait collages.

title: Collage Self-Portrait
description: Students prepare a variety of colored papers of all shapes and sizes for their own self-portrait collages. They assemble textured and colored paper shapes to highlight their own unique characteristics.

title: Spore Printing
description: In conjunction with their Science studies of spores and fungi, students make mushroom spore prints, fern ink prints, and impressions of ferns in clay slabs. Students use the clay slabs to mimic fossils in their archaeological dig later in the unit.

title: Bacteria Collages
description: Students observe bacteria under a microscope and make observational drawings. They use their drawings to create a collage. The collages are incorporated into the geological timeline later in the unit.

title: Artifacts for an Archaeological Dig
description: In conjunction with Science class, students make beads, pinch pots, trilobites, nautilus shells, and fern-print fossils from the earlier learning experience for an archaeological dig.

title: Collage Illustrations for a Geological Timeline
description: Students establish a timeline of the Cambrian, Jurassic, and Triassic periods that includes the time periods’ flora and fauna. They create their artwork in the style of Henri Matisse’s paper cutout collages. The resulting timeline collage is a classroom learning tool that can be used during this final unit.

title: Clay Dinosaurs
description: In conjunction with Cultural History, students create clay dinosaur sculptures. Students then build a natural habitat for their dinosaurs and display their work in the Cultural History classroom.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: Students and the teacher review sketchbooks and assignments for the unit, assessing students on their understanding of unit skills and concepts.

title: Sketchbook
description: Students reflect on and discuss their sketchbook work in a conference with the teacher. Students are guided in their review, and they evaluate their progress, challenges, and goals as artists.

title: Sketchbook
description: Students review their sketchbooks and discuss their progress and challenges in one-on-one teacher conferences during the unit.

title: Observational Drawing: Charles Darwin and Maria Sibylla Merian
description: Students explore the work of Charles Darwin and Maria Sibylla Merian, naturalists who were also skilled artists. They learn how the detailed observation in these naturalists’ artwork advanced scientific knowledge. From their explorations, students learn to create their own detailed observational drawings.

title: Naturalist Artists: Realism to Abstraction in Print
description: Students explore the life and artwork of John James Audubon and use hand lenses to draw their own detailed illustrations of plant and animal specimens. They use their drawings as references to produce collagraph prints, and they learn about printmaking and limited editions.

title: Imaginary Animals: Realism to Abstraction in Clay
description: Students apply their knowledge of animals and adaptation to create their own imaginary animals. They sketch them, model them in clay, and describe them in an essay.

title: Understanding the Unit Goals
description: Students meet with the teacher to review their work in the unit. Their work is assessed using a rubric.

title: Early Human Art
description: Students explore resources that describe the Chauvet cave paintings. They observe the early human art in the Chauvet cave and learn why these paintings are significant in both artistic style and content. Students observe and take notes, and then discuss the imagery, drawing techniques, and colors used to create the paintings in the cave.

title: Gesture Drawings
description: Students compare detailed observational drawing and gesture drawing techniques, and then continue by observing and practicing the gesture drawing technique. They take turns posing for the art class while the remainder of students create a gesture drawing of the posing figure.

title: Cave Paintings
description: Students create large drawings of wild animals on paper attached to the undersides of tables to experience the artistic challenges similar to those of the early Lascaux and Chauvet cave artists. They use various charcoals and natural color pastels to create their drawings in emulation of these cave paintings.

title: Sgraffito Cave Paintings
description: Students explore the engravings in the Chauvet and Lascaux caves. They learn that the technique of engraving into rock is similar to the art technique sgraffito. After making sketches of cave engravings and their own sgraffito designs, students use their designs in making terra cotta slab art with the sgraffito technique.

title: Cro-Magnon Jewelry
description: In this three-part learning experience, students begin by listening and viewing the story One Small Blue Bead by Byrd Baylor. They learn about ancient artifacts that are evidence of early human art by exploring the resources on the Smithsonian’s webpages. After taking inspiration from the story and their exploration of artifacts, students create their own bead necklaces and write a fictional story about who might have worn it.

title: Sketchbooks
description: Students reflect and discuss their sketchbook work in a conference with the teacher. Students are guided in their review, and they evaluate their progress, challenges, and goals as an artist.

title: Early Humans
description: In a conference with the teacher, students review their works of art, participation, written reflections, and their challenges and accomplishments during the unit. Then as an end-of-the-year self-assessment, each student creates a new self-portrait to compare to the self-portrait they created in Unit 1. In their comparison, students note their artistic achievements and the concepts they learned in grade 3 Visual Arts.

title: Riverine Art and Artifacts Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. Students use a sketchbook rubric at the end of each learning experience to monitor their own progress, challenges, and accomplishments.

title: Self-Portrait, Cuneiform Tablets, and Cylinder Seals
description: Students draw self-portraits and list their artistic goals for the coming school year. The self-portraits and goals are placed in students’ portfolios for review in Unit 3 at the end of the school year. Students share their current understanding of beginning writing forms, drawing from their learning about cuneiform tablets and cylinder seals.

title: Understanding Cuneiform Tablets
description: Students examine the origins of writing and symbolism and learn about cuneiform symbols and number symbols.

title: Creating Cuneiform Tablets
description: Students act the roles of ancient Sumerians. They partner with other students to create a cuneiform tablet in clay documenting sales, barters, and exchanges.

title: Peace Symbols
description: In response to the poem “Lament to the Spirit of War" by the Sumerian poet/priestess Enheduanna, students investigate universal and world peace symbols and then create their own peace symbol rubber stamps.

title: Mesopotamian Lion Hunt Panels
description: Students view artifacts and a video from the British Museum about the famous bas-relief Assyrian Lion Hunt panels.

title: Lion Hunt Panels
description: After studying the Assyrian Lion Hunt panels from the British Museum, students create drawings and a clay bas-relief of a lion hunt.

title: Mesopotamian Cylinder Seals
description: After learning about the first printing press—the ancient Mesopotamian cylinder seals—students research images and sketch their designs in their notebooks.

title: Personal Cylinder Seals
description: In this unit-culminating project, students use their unit learning and their personal knowledge to create their own personal cylinder seals in clay. They present their seals and explain their symbols to the class.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: At the end of the unit, students’ progress, challenges, and achievement during all of the learning experiences and projects in the unit is evaluated with a unit-specific rubric.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. Their progress, challenges, and accomplishments in the unit are assessed through the sketchbook and its accompanying rubric.

title: Egyptian Afterlife Paintings
description: In their study of Egypt, students look at the content, symbolism, and style of Egyptian painting as well as the Egyptian idea of the afterlife. They then create their own compositions on papyrus that they make in class, depicting themselves as Egyptians and including imagery and hieroglyphic symbols of the things they choose to carry with them to the afterlife.

title: Egyptian Profile Paintings
description: Studying the stylistic conventions in use in Egyptian portraiture, students create profiles on papyrus that feature one frontal eye along with a variety of costuming and personal decoration. They translate their names into hieroglyphics and enclose them in cartouches.

title: Canopic Jars
description: Students study the content, symbolism, and style of Egyptian art, learning about burial practices and ancient Egyptian examples of canopic jars. They then hand-build, fire, and paint their own clay canopic jars. They also write a reflection on the experience and are assessed with the Canopic Jars rubric.

title: Sketchbooks
description: In one-on-one sessions with their teacher, students look over their sketchbooks to review what they have learned so far and to determine whether there are any gaps or errors in their understanding of the material. Students also use these sketchbook review sessions to evaluate their progress as visual artists, discuss their artistic strengths and challenges, and set personal goals.

title: Indus Valley and Chinese Tomb Art
description: Students view art and artifacts of the Indus Valley and ancient Chinese Tomb art in books, on websites, and via other resources to gain an understanding of the types of jewelry and other objects that were buried with people from different levels of these societies. As they take notes and sketch images and designs of these artifacts in their sketchbooks, they are encouraged to speculate about how these burial sites reflect the societal organization of these cultures.

title: Indus Valley Jewelry
description: After viewing and learning about jewelry and other artifacts found in Indus Valley burial sites, students create funereal bracelets and necklaces made of paper-clay beads and also use the paper-clay to produce other fabricated artifacts.

title: Harappan Seals
description: Students view the clay seals of the ancient Harappan culture of the Indus Valley and discuss their possible uses. Then they make their own seals by carving designs of their own creation into soft rubber blocks, pressing those designs into clay and then firing the clay seals.

title: Chinese Tomb Sculpture
description: In this learning experience, students discover how people in ancient China viewed life after death and what they buried with their dead based on these beliefs. Next they consider what they might want to be buried with were they to share these views of an afterlife. They sketch images in preparation for modeling a sculpture of this object, person, or animal. Then, modeling clay, they turn their two-dimensional drawings into a three-dimensional form.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: In this summative assessment, students and teacher meet in one-on-one sessions to review the student’s unit work. They also discuss the student’s participation and learning throughout the unit.

title: Calligraphic Design
description: Students study, analyze, and practice Arabic calligraphy by examining images of calligraphic design in Islamic art and applying their skill to forming Arabic letters in their sketchbooks.

title: Geometric Design
description: Students study, analyze, and practice Islamic geometric design with the understanding that human and divine forms cannot be depicted realistically through art. Students use paper, a compass, and other tools to create unique patterns found in Islamic art.

title: Floral Patterning and Identity Poster Project
description: Students study, analyze, and practice Islamic floral patterning, or arabesque, and apply what they have learned in Islamic calligraphic design, geometric design, and floral patterning to the creation of an identity poster.

title: Cindy Sherman Portraits
description: Students analyze and reflect upon portraits made by Cindy Sherman and study her use of cinematic narrative in self-portrait photography.

title: Illuminated Letters
description: After viewing and analyzing examples of medieval illuminated manuscripts, students practice calligraphy and use gold leaf to create their own illuminated manuscript pages in conjunction with a Performing Arts integrated project.

title: Guild Project
description: Students review the media used to decorate medieval cathedrals, including tapestries, stained glass, sculptures, mosaics, and stone carvings. They then choose a medium to learn from a master craftsperson and, with that individual’s guidance, create a work of art that is typical of the medieval time period. Finally, they share their work in a group critique.

title: Medieval Africa Map
description: To familiarize themselves with the topography, trade routes, and important cities of the region, students collaborate to create a large map of West Africa.

title: African Sculpture and Textiles
description: Students view, analyze, and discuss African sculpture and textiles.

title: African Mud Cloth
description: Students make African mud-cloth designs on textiles or paper.

title: African Dance, Chanting, and Udu Drums
description: After viewing and experiencing African dance and chanting, students study the role of drumming in the African oral tradition to create and perform on Udu drums.

title: Self-Portrait
description: At the beginning of Unit 1 Visual Arts, each student draws a self-portrait in his or her sketchbook that is then revisited at the end of Unit 3 as a part of the year’s summative assessment.

title: Sketchbooks
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. The sketchbook is reviewed at the end of each learning experience to monitor student progress, challenges, and accomplishments, and is a part of the unit summative assessment.

title: Origins of Clay
description: Students learn about the origins of clay and begin to understand clay as an art medium by exploring clay in different forms, including wet, air-dry, bisque-fired, and glazed. Students compare these forms of clay to their prior experiences with play dough and salt dough and rethink their previous conceptions about the origins of clay.

title: Clay Explorations
description: Students explore the properties of the clay by rolling, coiling, and flattening it without focusing on the creation of a final work of art. After the exploration with clay, students brainstorm words to describe the clay using their senses and create a chart of these describing words.

title: Create a Planting Vessel
description: In conjunction with their studies of seed germination in science, the teacher reads aloudThe Pot That Juan Built to prepare students to craft a planting vessel. Then students make a pinch pot out of clay, using the most basic methodology for shaping a pot.

title: Clay Reflection
description: Students reflect on their new clay-working skills in a conference with the teacher. They discuss the transformation of their work from an amorphous shape of wet clay to a purposeful object created by hand rolling and molding the clay medium.

title: Ink Blot Organisms
description: Students explore symmetry and color. They mix primary colors to create secondary colors. They explore symmetry by dripping colors on half of a sheet of paper, then folding the other half over and creating a mirror image. Students look for recognizable animals in their inkblots, and then use water-based markers to complete them.

title: Role of Symmetry
description: Students identify and draw classroom objects that have vertical and horizontal lines of symmetry. They review and reflect on their understanding of symmetry in a conference with the teacher.

title: Origins of Insects
description: Students study and take inspiration from the work of Maria Sibylla Merian. Students listen to the story Summer Birds: The Butterflies of Maria Merian, and view the website from the J. Paul Getty Museum that describes Merian’s significant contributions to science and art in the late 1600s.

title: Observational Drawings of Insects
description: Students create their own observational drawings of insects in the spirit of Merian’s work. Students explore the natural areas on campus and collect insects as they explore. Afterward, students make observational drawings of the insects in their sketchbooks.

title: Clay Insects
description: Students use their observational drawings of insects to create an insect from clay. Students are challenged to apply their understanding of shape and symmetry as they use two-dimensional drawings to create a three-dimensional clay sculpture.

title: Reading of The Fire Children: A West African Creation Tale
description: Students listen to the story The Fire Children: A West African Creation Tale. After the reading, students discuss how the story describes the creation and beginnings of humans, and compare the story to other creation myths they are studying in Cultural History.

title: Self-Portraits in Clay
description: Students create a self-portrait in clay as part of the summative assessment for the unit. In a conference with the teacher, each student reflects on his or her work and accomplishments in this final assessment.

title: Creating a Nursery
description: In Cultural History, students make rice-and-stocking babies. To integrate with Cultural History, students use recycled materials to make a nursery and complete the facial details for their rice-and-stocking babies.

title: Sketchbooks
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. The sketchbook is reviewed at the end of each learning experience to monitor student progress, challenges, and accomplishments, and is a part of the unit summative assessment.

title: Warm and Cool Color Centers
description: Students begin to consider the difference between warm and cool colors. They explore how Claude Monet used color to portray various times of days and the four seasons in his many Rouen Cathedral paintings. They continue their investigation of cool and warm colors in scratch paintings and light interaction by overlaying colored acetates on an overhead projector. Students explore mixing primary colors to create secondary colors by constructing a basic color wheel and overlaying primary-colored tissue paper to create secondary colors.

title: Winter and Summer Colors
description: The class discusses the seasons, the colors they associate with each season, and how they feel during the different seasons. Students learn that warm seasons and cool seasons have colors associated with them. Students write winter on one page of their sketchbooks, and summer on another. They classify their colored pencils, crayons, or oil pastels into these two groups, and use them to draw a “summer” design and a “winter” design.

title: Observation of Seasonal Landscapes
description: The class reads the picture book Sky Tree by Thomas Locker. They look at works of art, particularly Monet’s haystack, the Japanese bridge, and the poplar series that show the same landscape in different seasons. After a demonstration of watercolor painting technique, students create four paintings of the same tree, one for each season. As an extension, the class goes for a walk to observe seasonal changes.

title: Seasonal Landscapes
description: Students learn about the important components of a landscape. They compare the colors of their tree paintings from the previous learning experience to Monet’s seasonal paintings, and review warm and cool colors’ descriptive words. Students create their own seasonal landscapes using water-soluble oil pastels, with an emphasis on warm and cool colors.

title: Warm and Cool Squares
description: Students sort precut warm- and cool-colored paper squares, and glue them into their sketchbooks.

title: Winter Trees
description: Students use a new masking tape technique to create a winter landscape using the masking technique, cool colors, and glitter to represent snow. They apply masking tape to brown paper to make a tree, then paint a blue sky and snow over the masked trees. Once dried, they carefully remove the tape to reveal a stunning winter scene. As a final step, students add a dusting of glitter for an icy effect.

title: Imaginary Landscape
description: As a culminating experience and assessment of learning for this unit, students create an imaginary seasonal landscape. Students choose how to portray a season in either a warm or cool color palette and landscape features. They discuss their choices and feelings about their landscapes.

title: Instruments of the Early Maya
description: At the start of this unit, teachers reveal that students will be creating oral presentations with a partner on some aspect of Maya music that interests them. They will be delivering these presentations at the unit’s end. With this fact in mind, students view and listen to the musical instruments that were played in precontact Maya society in a teacher-led, audio-visual presentation. During this presentation, they also practice their note-taking and outlining skills.

title: Vocal Music of the Maya and Music in Maya Life
description: Students begin this learning experience by discussing the forms and functions of music today, as well as the status of musicians today. They then watch a rich, audio-visual presentation about the role of vocal music in precontact Maya society and the status and roles of Maya musicians in precontact Maya civilization while practicing their note-taking and outlining skills. Finally, students select a topic and begin planning for the oral presentations they will develop over the course of the unit.

title: Maya Music in Precontact Maya Society Quiz
description: To monitor their progress so far, students take a quiz on the musical instruments of the early Maya and on the place, form, function, and preservation of music in early Maya society.

title: Xtoles
description: Students listen to a recording of the ancient Maya song “Xtoles.” Then, they learn more about the song’s origins and purpose and discuss how it affected them. Finally, they prepare the vocal selection through a series of rehearsals for a Maya Day celebration performance at the end of the unit.

title: Making an Ocarina
description: Students respond to the sound of the ocarina, recall what they learned about it at the beginning of this unit, make playable ocarinas of their own, and take their first steps in learning to play these instruments.

title: Ocarina Ensemble Rehearsals
description: As students prepare music and work on ocarina technique in ensemble rehearsals, they enhance their ability to prepare pre-written or self-composed music, as well as their ocarina playing technique. Meanwhile, the ensemble is informally assessed on a continuous basis to check for readiness and progress.

title: Maya Music Performance
description: To participate in the festivities of a special Maya Day celebration, students present what they have learned about Maya music in oral presentations that they have been working on all unit long. They also sing the ancient Maya “Xtoles” and perform musical compositions as an ocarina ensemble on the ocarinas they made themselves.

title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Gregorian Chant
description: To acquire background for their activities in this unit, students discover the history behind Gregorian chant, research and present their findings, listen to modern examples of Gregorian chant, and examine the renewed interest in Gregorian chant in the 20th century.

title: Reviewing Key Concepts of Gregorian Chant
description: By writing a paragraph on a chosen topic, students demonstrate their knowledge of Gregorian chant, and then they work in groups to write a concise and informative synopsis to read to the class.

title: Understanding Modes and Neumes
description: Through lecture and a handout, students learn about the notation and modes used in Gregorian chant. They then choose an aspect of Gregorian chant to research for an in-depth presentation in Assessment 7: Chant Performance.

title: Using Modes
description: Through notation and chanting, students demonstrate their understanding of the eight Gregorian church modes.

title: Composing a Chant
description: Students select a text for their chant composition and compose an original melody using one of the church modes. Once the composition draft is complete and any revisions have been made, they create a fair copy to be used in subsequent unit activities.

title: Chant Performance
description: Students perform and critique chants in pairs and present their research findings about Gregorian chants. The teacher meets with students individually to assess their work throughout the unit.

title: Music Is Personal
description: Students listen to a read-aloud of I See a Song by Eric Carle and explore the visualization of music. They discuss how they visualize different shapes, lines, and colors when they hear music and how the author represented water, earth, fire, and air in music and art.

title: Let’s See a Song!
description: Students listen to a piece of classical music while drawing visual interpretations of the music. When finished, they share and discuss their creations with the class.

title: Lullaby and Goodnight
description: Students discuss the question, “What is a lullaby?” and share lullabies that soothed them when they were young.

title: Family Lullabies
description: Students teach their family lullabies to the class. The class sings the lullabies and analyzes similarities and differences between them.

title: Soothing Lullabies
description: Students discuss reasons why people might sing a lullaby to a baby, and come to understand that slower, quiet music is calming. They select a soothing song that they can sing to their rice-and-stocking babies, and illustrate the song.

title: Nursery Rhymes and Lullabies
description: Students learn and move to several nursery rhymes and lullabies, such as “I’m a Little Teapot” and “Itsy Bitsy Spider.” The class discusses why children like to sing these songs, and references and sings these songs throughout the unit.

title: Mandarin Lullaby
description: Students learn the Mandarin lullaby , and sing the song to their rice-and-stocking babies while rocking them to sleep. They come to understand that soothing lullabies are universal.

title: Spanish Lullaby
description: Students learn several Spanish lullabies and sing the song to their rice-and-stocking babies to rock them to sleep. They discuss the English meanings of the songs, which helps them understand that soothing lullabies are sung around the world.

title: The Rice-and-Stocking Baby Shower
description: Students perform three or four nursery rhymes and lullabies for family and friends at a rice-and-stocking baby shower. They show understanding of the power of music to calm and soothe, why lullabies are sung to children, that lullabies are universal, how people can visualize music, and how music helps people express emotions.

title: Mindful Transitions
description: Students learn how to move from free play to the discipline of performance as they create welcome rituals for the beginning of Performing Arts: Theater class.

title: Relaxation and Focus
description: Students practice meditation techniques and movements to learn ways to calm the mind, explore body and breath control, and prepare for the movement, focus, and characterization that are crucial to theater arts. This learning experience happens in conjunction with the Mindful Transitions learning experience.

title: Progress in Theater Arts Studies
description: Throughout this Performing Arts: Theater unit, students learn and practice strategies and exercises that enable them to move from free play to the discipline of performance. Students set personal goals with teacher assistance.

title: Journal and Storytelling
description: Students obtain journals and discuss their use in Performing Arts: Theater class. They tell stories about themselves by drawing a picture in their journal and sharing that story orally as a springboard activity into the theater practice of working together to tell a story.

title: Improvisation
description: Students engage in movement and musical exercises that explore and interpret space, organization, and creative expression. They draw facial expressions from their imaginations, read-alouds, and/or modeling facial expressions with a partner.

title: Seasonal Change
description: After an outdoor walk and sharing books, stories, and online resources, students imagine and create choreographed movements of butterflies and geese.

title: Progress Check
description: Students meet one-on-one with the teacher to review their sketchbooks, discuss their successes and challenges, and explain how their work in Performing Arts: Theater connects with their work in other domains. This assessment may be used multiple times during the course of the unit.

title: Acting and Theatrical Interpretation of Text
description: As they begin to learn artistic discipline, students listen to and act out numerous storybooks with multicultural creation myths and themes.

title: Preparing for Beginnings
description: In response to a read-aloud in each session, students create improvisational skits and dances that examine and portray their understanding of the influence of the elemental forces on the natural world.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: Students meet one-on-one with the teacher at the end of the year to review their journals, discuss their successes and challenges, and explain how their work in Performing Arts: Theater connected with their work in other domains.

title: Explore Rhythm
description: Students explore rhythm through basic body percussion to assess their ability to follow direction and articulate simple rhythmic patterns.

title: Notes and More Notes
description: As visual training and ear training for reading musical notation, students identify musical notes and rhythms, learn about the neutral clef and the single line staff, write down rhythms they hear, and create their own rhythm patterns.

title: Orff Instruments and Percussion Instruments
description: Students discuss instruments and the sounds they make, then experiment with Orff and percussion instruments by playing rhythmic patterns and their own rhythmic compositions.

title: Three Rhythms
description: In this ear-training exercise, students learn to clap out three basic repeating musical rhythms (march, waltz, and cha-cha) to recorded songs, study note syllables and signs, and use dance to express rhythms.

title: Playing Along
description: Students play Orff and percussion instruments to the rhythm of waltz, cha-cha, and march recordings. They read or write the musical notation for each rhythm.

title: Cultural Rhythms
description: In this introduction to world music, students explore rhythmic patterns from a variety of world cultures. After viewing or listening to examples, students clap and speak each rhythmic pattern, then attempt to write it using rhythmic notation.

title: Recycled Instruments
description: In conjunction with Unit 4 Cultural History, students create instruments from recycled materials and play these instruments.

title: Rhythm Performance
description: In small group ensembles, students perform the basic rhythms introduced in this unit before an audience, discuss the performance with the audience, write and draw reflections about the performance in their notebooks, and conduct a final class discussion about the unit.

title: Journal
description: In this two-part assessment, students discuss the usefulness of keeping a journal for their Performing Arts: Theater studies. They learn how to draw physical movement and choreography in their notebooks.

title: Progress in Theater Arts Studies
description: Throughout this Performing Arts: Theater unit, the goal for students is to move from free play to performance. The teacher informally assesses students at any point in the unit, and students set personal goals with teacher assistance.

title: Meditation, Relaxation, and Focus
description: Through the practice of meditation, mindful breathing, and yoga, students learn how to transition from free play to the discipline of theater.

title: Introducing Patterns in Movement
description: Students discover and explore the six basic patterns found in nature: circular patterns (including cycles), linear patterns, branching patterns, tessellations, symmetry, and spirals through theater, rhymes, music, art, and movement.

title: Variations on Space
description: Students explore and express space and develop spatial awareness by practicing variations in breathing and walking with choreographed movement to music.

title: Improvisation
description: Students engage in improvisation, movement, and musical exercises that explore and interpret patterns and cycles.

title: Water Dance
description: In conjunction with their readings about patterns and cycles in World Languages and Literature: English, students create a dance about the water cycle, transforming poems to poetry in motion.

title: Props
description: Students choreograph individual and group dances using props such as scarves to represent the six patterns found in nature.

title: Patterns in Song and Poetry
description: Using poems and songs from around the globe, students discover and recite patterns with rhythm, rhyme, and repetition.

title: Understanding of Unit Goals
description: Students meet one-on-one with the teacher at the end of the year to review their journals, discuss their successes and challenges, and explain how their work in Performing Arts: Theater connected with their work in other domains.

title: Communication Today and Far, Far Back in the Past
description: Working as a class, students discuss different ways in which we communicate today. They theorize how prehistoric societies might have communicated based on the resources they had available and compare the present to the prehistoric.

title: Human Vocal Sounds
description: Students practice making baby, nature, and general human vocal sounds, such as yawning, chirping, and coughing. The class discusses questions, such as “What might have been the first human sounds? What were the purposes for these sounds? How do these sounds make us feel when we make them and when we listen to them?”

title: Early Human Music
description: Students learn about theories of the prehistoric vocalizations of Neanderthals, Homo erectus, Australopithecus africanus, Homo habilis, and Homo sapiens by viewing videos and doing research. The class discusses the idea of music being a “social glue,” that is helping people to bond, group, communicate, and survive, and students draw cartoons that represent music as a social glue.

title: Early Human Music Reflection
description: Students consider their research results from the previous learning experience and reflect on their learning in light of what they already know. This formative assessment guides students’ understanding and assists them to reflect more deeply about early human vocalization.

title: Early Instruments
description: After listening to a read-aloud of Kali’s Song, students experiment with the different sounds and feelings that natural objects can be used to impart and investigate prehistoric cave paintings that show instruments, such as prehistoric drums and flutes.

title: Circle Noises
