description: Students form a circle to create sound compositions, involving rhythm and human vocal sounds. They attempt to communicate a feeling or a message using these rhythms and sounds.

title: Circle Noises Reflection
description: Students reflect on their thoughts and feelings after participating in the Circle Noises learning experience. They write a reflection about their experience.

title: Wax Museum
description: Students consider what they have learned about vocal, non-vocal, and rhythmic sounds to create a final performance for the Wax Museum integrated project. Small groups collaborate to convey a feeling or message of their choosing.

title: Relaxation and Focus
description: Students practice relaxation and focus techniques that prepare them for the demands of theatrical performance and writing.

title: Journal
description: Throughout the year, students use their journals as process journals of their learning, challenges, and accomplishments in Performing Arts: Theater.

title: Oral Storytelling
description: With storytelling and song, students create oral and dramatic stories as a way to explore and express the geological and biological forces that shaped Earth.

title: Meditation, Movement, Dance, and Music
description: After warming up with meditation and movement exercises, students explore and express the origins of life on Earth using music, dance, and song.

title: Characterization, Costume, and Color
description: Students explore characterization, costume, and color as ways to enhance theatrical performance.

title: Curriculum Concepts as Dramatic Stories
description: Students enact dramatic stories that express curriculum concepts such as extinction, growth, and renewal in their study of early human bands.

title: Brainstorming for the Performance of Understanding
description: In preparation for their final Performance of Understanding, “Beginnings,” students brainstorm elements that dramatically express the concepts in this unit best and that will comprise their performance, including movement, music, color, costume, and characterization.

title: Improvisation and Evolving Consciousness
description: Students engage in creative drama and improvisational exercises that examine evolving consciousness in early humans, as well as past learning, such as the evolution of the universe and Earth and the earliest stirrings of life on our planet.

title: Imagine, Create, Decide
description: Students imagine, create, and decide on ideas for their Performance of Understanding.

title: Focus and Rehearsal
description: Students rehearse for their upcoming Performance of Understanding.

title: Assessment
description: Students meet individually with the teacher to review their learning in movement, dance, characterization, improvisation, and dramatic storytelling. As they review their journals, they discuss their successes and challenges in Performing Arts: Theater.

title: Iroquois Music
description: The unit begins with a KWL discussion about Iroquois music. Students view a presentation about Iroquois music, stomp dances, chants, and instruments, and then they take notes and complete the KWL chart.

title: Stomp Dance and Music
description: Students learn an Iroquois chant and stomp dance, and practice with appropriate rhythms on percussion instruments.

title: Stomp Dance, Chant, and Music
description: Students perform instrumental rhythms on percussion instruments, the “Kahawi tha” chant, and a stomp dance.

title: Native American Flute Music
description: After listening to examples of Native American flute music, students transcribe a melody onto staff paper.

title: Researching Native American Music
description: In preparation for a presentation, student groups choose and research topics about Native American music.

title: Native American Music Presentations
description: Groups use their research about Native American music to create and give presentations.

title: Focus and Relaxation
description: Students form the habit of practicing focus and relaxation exercises together at the beginning and conclusion of each session. At the beginning and at the end of the unit, students reflect on these exercises by filling out a worksheet.

title: Performing Arts Journals
description: To record their thoughts, sketches, ideas, and reflections of their challenges and accomplishments in the unit, students start a journal, which they maintain throughout the unit and discuss in conference with the teacher in the final assessment.

title: Improvisation and Creative Expression
description: By performing gestures, dance movements, and nonverbal sounds, students develop and utilize improvisational skills and move toward increased artistic discipline, developing their understanding of themselves individually and collectively as artists.

title: How Does a Theatrical Community Work?
description: To analyze how a theatrical community works, students review the basic elements of community, apply these elements to theater, examine the various jobs involved in a theatrical production, and practice an exercise that emphasizes working together as a community.

title: Consciousness, Spiritual Thought, and Ritual
description: Students recall the sacred beliefs of Paleolithic and Neolithic people and research and recall the sacred beliefs of the Iroquois. They explore how the Iroquois expressed their beliefs through costumes, masks, makeup, buildings, tools, and weapons.

title: Storytelling—The Oral Tradition
description: Students engage in oral storytelling exercises, perform oral stories from the Iroquois tradition, and choose which of these stories to adapt into a theatrical production.

title: Creating Theatrical Elements
description: Students explore how to adapt an Iroquois story into a theatrical production, discuss versions of scripts, and investigate the social structure of the Iroquois through improvisation.

title: Focus and Decide
description: Students break into four groups to design elements for the theatrical performance, participate in a meditation exercise to prepare for the design process, and incorporate the strongest elements of the script versions from the previous learning experience into the final script.

title: Dress Rehearsals
description: Over the course of several classes, students rehearse, and learn to critique and take criticism during the rehearsal process.

title: Summative Assessment
description: To assess their progress in this unit, students review their journals, a video of the performance, and various activities.

title: The Instruments of Ancient Egypt
description: In a beginning ear-training exercise, students listen to examples of ancient Egyptian instruments and take notes of the sounds they hear.

title: Ancient Egyptian Music Discussion
description: The class discusses the sounds of the instruments and connects the sounds to contemporary instruments they know. They view illustrations of the ancient and contemporary instruments.

title: Review of Contemporary and Ancient Egyptian Instruments
description: Students solidify their ear-training of the sounds of ancient and contemporary instruments. They make further connections between the ancient and modern musical world.

title: Sounds of Ancient Egyptian and Contemporary Instruments
description: In a written, assessed review, students listen to and identify the sounds of ancient Egyptian instruments and their contemporary counterparts.

title: Music in Ancient Egypt
description: Students divide into small groups to research topics such as the role of musicians in Egyptian society, the role of music in Egyptian society, the Egyptian gods and goddesses, Egyptian singers and dancers, and the materials and manufacture of the ancient musical instruments. Students use multiple digital and print resources to find information on their topics.

title: Ancient Egyptian Music Presentation
description: Each small group presents their research on their topics to the class along with one visual aid. This culminating event gives the class a well-rounded picture of the many aspects of ancient Egyptian music and culture.

title: Dramatic Storytelling and the Oral Tradition
description: In this two-part assessment, students explore essential elements of theatrical performance, writing, and dramatic storytelling. Part I includes practice and review of relaxation and focus exercises. Part II includes review of the relationship between the oral tradition and dramatic storytelling.

title: Performing Arts Journals
description: Over the course of the unit, students write a series of journal entries as a tool for planning and processing their learning experiences. Then, at the end of each learning experience, students review and discuss their journal entries in order to monitor progress, examine challenges, and assess accomplishments.

title: Improvisation
description: Students compare the qualities of spoken and written word, noting the limitations and advantages of each. They examine prayer, poetry, and recitation as a means to communicate and to pass on cultural beliefs and customs. Students discuss repetition as a mentality and how repetition can be used for expression and emphasis before engaging in improvisational exercises that express aspects of riverine civilizations and cultures.

title: Dance and Movement
description: Students discuss and engage in text interpretation, as well as writing and performing texts that examine and portray civilization as a culture that has attained a degree of complexity. They act out the roles of specialists who arose to cope with economic, social, political, and religious needs of a populous society and create vignettes in dance and movement that portray the invention and consequent explosion of the intellectual breakthroughs of writing, monumental architecture, and art.

title: Character
description: Using improvisation and situation exercises, students explore the different aspects of character and how character is revealed through stance, posture, movement, and facial expression.

title: Monologues and Dialogues
description: Students write and perform short dramatic monologues and dialogues and discuss the different effects and uses of the two forms.

title: Speeches and Public Speaking
description: Students write and give speeches on social issues/concerns. They apply their performance skills as they practice public speaking skills.

title: Motivation of Character
description: Students practice narration of texts and poems that describe Mesopotamia and give evidence of it as the birthplace of civilization. To that end, they explore the dramatic structure of human action, including physical movement and the motivations that lie behind visible behavior.

title: Oral Interpretation
description: In this learning experience, students practice oral language. This includes reciting ancient writings. They come to recognize the differences between physical acting and acting with voice only. This learning experience requires that the actor interpret a script using expressive voice to convey meaning.

title: Body and Voice
description: Using improvisation to write, interpret and perform from a script, students gain an understanding that dramatic dialogue uses many communicative elements in addition to words, including tone of voice, facial expressions, gestures, and body language. They learn to use voice as a way to convey a wide range of emotion and to use body and postural changes to convey the attitude of characters.

title: Ancient Sumer
description: In preparation for the Beginnings integrated project, students brainstorm ideas for dramatic readings, dances, and improvisations based on such myths as Inanna, Gilgamesh, Ashurbanipal, and so on.

title: Egypt
description: Students choreograph dances to express the stories of Isis and Osiris and other Egyptian myths and prepare oral interpretations of dramatic readings about Pharaoh worship and mythopoeic thought.

title: Summative Assessment
description: In the summative assessment, students conference individually with the teacher to review their journals, talk about their strengths, and discuss connections between their work in Performing Arts: Theater and other disciplines.

title: Musical Life in Ancient Greece
description: As they begin the unit, students learn about the ancient Greek musicians and musical instruments and their role in ancient Greek life, including religious festivals, marriages and funerals, and banquet gatherings. They also investigate the nine musical Muses.

title: Ancient Grecian Instruments
description: Students listen to modern instruments and identify them based on their sound. They listen to the instruments of ancient Greece and compare their sounds to those of modern instruments. Students learn about instruments and how they were used and played in ancient Greece and make connections between past and present.

title: Divine Harmony
description: Through reading and discussion of Pythagoras and his views on music, students further understand his role in Greek history and music history, his theories on the manipulative and emotive role of music, and his invention of the octave.

title: Divine Harmony Quiz
description: Students take a quiz based on their reading of the book Divine Harmony: The Life and Teachings of Pythagoras and discussion of Pythagoras. Results help them gauge their understanding of the subject of Pythagoras in Greek music history.

title: Musical Intervals of the Octave
description: Students learn to hear the ascending and descending musical intervals of the octave. They use familiar songs that have the interval in the first two notes. Through this practice, students become familiar with musical intervals and how to identify them.

title: Interval Ear Training
description: In an informal assessment to gauge students’ understanding and ear training of the musical intervals, two teams compete in a simple contest.

title: Relaxation Techniques and Servant-Leader Role Playing
description: Students continue their exploration of relaxation techniques and develop a role-playing activity about the challenges and responsibilities of servant leadership.

title: Performing Arts Journals
description: Throughout the year, students keep journals of their learning experiences in Theater Arts. Students review and discuss their journal work at the end of each learning experience.

title: Improvisation
description: Through improvisation, students practice dramatic techniques, review the art of dramatic storytelling, and explore the physical, social, psychological, and moral aspects of character.

title: Character and Monologue
description: Students explore character by reading, analyzing, and writing a series of monologues.

title: Speeches and Public Speaking
description: Students practice their public speaking skills by viewing and analyzing great speeches, writing original speeches, and delivering them.

title: Taking the Stage
description: Students perform scenes from one-act plays, analyzing the scenes for blocking, character motivation, voice, physical actions, and timing.

title: Visionary Leaders
description: In tribute to and in celebration of the sacrifices and accomplishments of visionary leaders, students create a play they perform before an audience, gaining a deeper understanding of both visionary leadership and acting skills.

title: Greek Tragedies
description: Students study three pivotal Greek tragedies and employ the Aristotelian elements of drama in order to study, rehearse, and perform a Greek tragedy.

title: Unit Evaluation
description: In a two-part summative assessment of the concepts and skills learned throughout the unit, students conference individually with the teacher, assessing both performance applications and individual growth and understanding.

title: Nutrition Then and Now Pre-Quiz
description: To begin the unit, students take a written quiz that assesses their current knowledge regarding Maya food, nutrition, health, agriculture, and the sport of Maya Ball, as well as contemporary nutrition information and sustainable food and agriculture practices. Answers are checked for correctness but the result does not count towards the student’s grade.

title: Maya Food and Agriculture
description: Students explore Maya myths and spiritual practices that involve food and food production, as well as cultural food practices of the Maya. They investigate the roles of corn, chili, and cacao in Maya cuisine and religious beliefs and ceremonies. They analyze food production artifacts that are still used in modern food production to gain a variety of clues about the daily practices and nutrition of the Maya. They also review some of the advanced sustainable agricultural practices and methods developed and utilized by the Maya in food production. The learning experience culminates with a replication of the creation of Maya hot cacao, using traditional tools and ingredients.

title: Today’s Sustainable Nutrition Practices (ROSS Model)
description: Students explore sustainable nutrition and agriculture practices through a review of the ROSS acronym, which stands for regional, organic, seasonal, and sustainable—the tenets behind food procurement and production at Ross School. They learn about the practices that are considered sustainable and unsustainable in modern food production and agriculture. They investigate GMOs; biodiversity; developing healthy soil; crop rotation; working with nature to reduce unwanted pests, weeds, and disease; and why eating local is more sustainable for the planet, farmers, and local economies. They also learn about the environmental benefits of eating lower on the food chain—that is, a predominantly plant based- diet—eating whole foods, avoiding processed and packaged foods, and cooking their own food.

title: Essential Nutrients
description: After reviewing the six classes of nutrients required for proper human nutrition, including their food sources, students narrow their focus to a study of the mineral calcium. They investigate calcium’s role in the human diet, sources of calcium, and the prevalence, significance, and prevention of osteoporosis in United States. Finally, they turn their attention again to the Maya as they discuss calcium in the Maya diet, which came mostly from food preparations, such as grinding food on stones containing calcium.

title: Maya Nutrition and Agriculture
description: Students connect ancient Maya agricultural practices to sustainable agricultural and nutritional practices still prevalent today. They then use their knowledge of nutrition and classical Maya diet to create a healthy, authentic Maya meal, detailing the nutritional content of each item in the meal and showing how the meal as a whole meets what we know today to be the requirements of a healthy, balanced diet.

title: Maya Health and Medicine
description: Students look at evidence of Maya health status, such as reviewing information regarding skulls with anemic lesions and remains that revealed malnutrition in years prior to the Maya migration/disappearance. In addition, students explore traditional Maya healing practices involving spiritual beliefs, the use of food and herbs as medicine, and medical practices and procedures, such as dental and surgical advancements, bloodletting, and drug use. The experience culminates with the creation of a calming Maya tea and a Maya healing balm to soothe skin irritations and inflammation with herbs indigenous to Mesoamerica.

title: Maya Ball
description: To explore and recreate early Mesoamerican Ball, later known as Maya Ball, or Pok-a-Tok, students review myths, rituals, artifacts, and architecture to discover the game’s structure and fully imagine what it felt like to experience it. They learn the basic rules of Maya Ball and recreate the playing court and game right down to playing the positions. Then they practice Pok-a-Tok and prepare for a dramatic reenactment at Maya Day.

title: Nutrition Then and Now Post-Quiz
description: In this assessment, students take a written quiz to demonstrate how much they have learned regarding Maya food, nutrition, health, agriculture, and the sport of Maya Ball, as well as contemporary nutrition information and agricultural practices.

title: Maya Day Celebration
description: As a culmination of the unit, students play the Maya ballgame and dramatize a victors’ ceremony, wearing authentic-looking costumes they have created for the occasion. They also provide Maya-style decorations and food for the school. Students are assessed on their knowledge and execution of Maya Ball rules, skills, and teamwork. They are also graded on their Maya Ball costume idea and execution. In addition, students are evaluated on their ability to educate their peers about nutrition information as it pertains to authentic Maya foods and sustains our own health and well-being.

title: Introduction to the Wellness of the Roman Empire
description: To begin this unit, students complete a worksheet that assesses their basic knowledge about the Roman concept of “Bread and Circuses,” which originated as a means for political gain during the early Roman Empire. They also compare Roman fanaticism with modern fanaticism for sports and games.

title: Roman Food
description: Students learn about how Romans typically acquired their food and what their meals were like based on their social class and where they lived. Students review the features of Roman feasts and banquets and learn about how food was procured and produced for these festive meals, as well as for daily meals.

title: Roman Health, Hygiene, and Medicine
description: Students learn about health and healing practices during the early Roman Empire from the gods of healing to the teachings of Galen and his influence on the development and advancement of “modern” medicine. They study Roman baths and hygiene and make connections between the hygiene needs of the Romans and those of modern adolescents.

title: Roman Sport and Gladiator Culture
description: Through looking at images and making connections, students learn about Roman sport and games and the culture of the Roman gladiator. They explore specific gladiator “positions” and training regimens. Finally, they draw parallels between American football play and culture and the arena sport of gladiator culture by listing similarities and differences.

title: Flag Football
description: As homage to gladiator arena sports, students study the basics of American flag football, learning the basic football positions, from quarterback to kicker. They practice drills, form teams, and play modified flag football games.

title: Roman Tailgate Party
description: Students combine elements of the Roman banquet, bath, snack foods, and arena spectator sporting events into an ancient Roman tailgate. They create Roman snacks and participate in a flag football game, wearing mock Roman gladiator protective gear. Students are assessed on the accuracy and nutrition of the snack, the costume they create for the event, the development of their skills, and their ability to work as a team.

title: Beginner Basketball Skills
description: Students begin the unit by participating in a basketball skills relay to determine their baseline level of skill. The skills of dribbling, passing, shooting, and foul shooting will be assessed, as well as teamwork and communication. This assessment is used to track progress throughout the skills portion of the unit.

title: Health and Wellness in the Gilded Age and the Progressive Era
description: The late 19th and early 20th centuries symbolized the beginning of a new era of fitness leaders in the United States. In this learning experience, students learn about the health and values of Theodore Roosevelt, whose contributions to conservation, outdoor pursuits, and national parks, as well as his commitment to safe and healthy food and labor conditions, made him a wellness champion. Students also learn about the garden movement of the time period by either preparing an existing school garden for spring or volunteering at a local garden or farm.

title: Exercise and Sport in the Gilded Age and the Progressive Era
description: Students discuss the fitness and exercise trends in the United States, focusing on the Public Recreation Movement and its efforts to put playgrounds in urban areas. Students design an ideal playground. Students also study the history, evolution, and rise of basketball as the sport we play today.

title: Fundamental Beginning Basketball Skills and Drills
description: In order to develop a stronger foundation for basketball skills in a variety of areas, students practice drills.

title: Advanced Basketball Skills and Drills
description: Students practice more advanced basketball skills, including principles of offense and man-to-man defense. They work up to playing the traditional game of five-on-five basketball by playing one-on-one, adding players as skills and play develop.

title: Food Trends in the United States During the Gilded Age and the Progressive Era
description: At the turn of the 20th century, companies such as Kellogg, Post, and Quaker emerged with the first boxed cereals. Students create their own versions of healthy cereal box art reflecting the time period. Students also review some of the dangers posed by the emerging corporate food giants, such as Hershey’s, Nabisco, Jell-O, and Kraft.

title: Diet-Related Disease in the United States and Sustainable Nutrition Practices of Today
description: In this learning experience, students examine the role of class as it related to food and health in the United States in the early 20th century. They review diseases caused by poor diet and nutrition and by food contamination. Students read passages from Upton Sinclair’s book The Jungle to comprehend the filthy and dangerous working conditions that led to the formation of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which had its origins in the administration of Theodore Roosevelt. Students further consider nutritional diets and sustainable food practices of today, creating a menu that reflects nutritional value and sustainable food practices.

title: Basketball Game
description: In this assessment, students play a game of basketball, and their skill development and progress over the course of the unit are assessed.

title: History of Archery
description: Students learn about the history of archery. They view images of cave paintings and statues depicting archery and learn about Otzi the Iceman’s equipment. They also analyze the different types of bows used throughout history.

title: Exploring Archery Equipment
description: Students learn the rules of archery, appropriate attire, and the nature of the equipment. They determine if they are right- or left-eyed, which determines if they use a right or left bow. They learn rules of firing a bow and analyze the height of the bow, the length of arrows needed, and share ideas about why archery is a useful sport for wellness.

title: Safety First
description: Students learn safety rules and demonstrate their learning as they respond to whistle blows and different scenarios set up by the teacher.

title: Individual Skill and Technique
description: Students learn the different skills necessary for safe archery practices. They review safety rules and equipment. They learn stance, nock arrow, drawing hand set, bow hand set, pre-draw, draw, anchor, aim, shot set-up, release, and follow through/reflect.

title: Creating a Bow
description: Students continue to explore the history of archery by learning how to make life-size models of early bows, which allows them to apply their understanding of ballistics design. An archery expert from a local Native American tribe or archery organization is invited to demonstrate what goes into making a bow and explain the symbolic significance of the bow to archery.

title: The King Commands
description: Students compare methods of modern competitive archery as they are educated on the evolution of the sport. They examine archery as a survival skill and learn the reasons archery became a competitive sport, particularly in England. Each student chooses an era, culture, archer, legend/myth, or artwork to research for a presentation at the end of the unit.

title: From Archery to Firearms
description: Students learn about the development of gunpowder and how the armor-piercing ability of firearms changed warfare. They investigate the physics and mathematics of projectile motion.

title: Practice Skills
description: Students continue refining their archery skills in practice. The teacher monitors students’ progress (six to eight classes).

title: Archery Competition
description: Students participate in modified competitions. In conjunction with the competition, they read aloud literary selections or poems pertaining to archery that have inspired them.

title: Archery
description: Students display learned archery skills and safety rules, and present their research on the evolution of archery in various cultures as depicted in art and literature (The King Commands Learning Experience 6) as part of a final presentation. Students write a reflection to assess their archery knowledge.

title: Tai Chi Background and Opening Qigong Exercises
description: As an introduction, students learn the background philosophy and history of Tai Chi and the evolution of different styles and forms, specifically the “Simplified 24 Taijiquan (Tai Chi Chuan) Form in the Yang style.” They learn and practice some basic Qigong exercises as warm-ups, and learn the opening stance of the 24 Form and the “horse stance,” coordinating the opening movement with the breath.

title: Tai Chi, the Opening Forms: Some Key Points
description: To establish a sense of the basic Tai Chi movements and stances, students learn the first movements, from “horse stance” into the next four movements.

title: Basic Qigong and Tai Chi Movement Drills
description: Students informally demonstrate their level of competency in Tai Chi movement qualities: shifting the weight, distinguishing between the “empty” and the “full” leg, moving from the waist, and coordinated soft and fluid motion from a strong and grounded center of gravity.

title: Movement #10 “Waving Hands Through Clouds”
description: After having learned the opening forward-stepping and backward-stepping movements, students now learn and practice the side-stepping movement “waving hands through clouds.”

title: The Essential Elements
description: Students cultivate the essential characteristics of softness, gentleness, and slowness, maintaining continuity and evenness, the circular nature of the movements, and the sense of wholeness and harmony. They synthesize the sense of fluid motion with the quality of feeling strong and being grounded. They practice the first 10 movements of the form up through “waving hands through clouds.”

title: Techniques Based on the Concepts of Yin and Yang
description: Students continue their exploration of the principles of traditional Chinese philosophy through contemplating the concept of yin and yang in relation to Tai Chi practice.

title: Review of the First Parts of the Tai Chi 24 Form
description: Students demonstrate and self-assess their competency with the range of Tai Chi movements and stances in the 24 Form they have learned so far, as well as the principles underlying the practice.

title: Elementary Self-Defense Applications of Tai Chi Movements
description: Students begin to understand the application of some Tai Chi movements in self-defense. In this way, the foundational principles of Tai Chi are given practical meaning. They begin to contemplate what is meant when it is said in the classic texts that the mind moves the chi and the chi moves the body.

title: Putting It All Together
description: Students learn the final movements of the form and practice the whole 24 Form from beginning to end. They practice maintaining an even flow of speed and energy as well as height.

title: Self-Evaluation and Reflections
description: Students perform and video-record the whole 24 Form from beginning to end. They conduct a self-evaluation and receive feedback from the teacher.

title: Basic Modern Dance Exercises
description: Students learn and practice some basic Modern Dance exercises and warm-up routines. Students begin to understand effective body placement and alignment. Throughout these exercises, students synthesize the sense of rhythm.

title: Modern Dance Exercises and Understanding Alignment
description: Students demonstrate their level of competency to get a feel for the basic Modern Dance movements as well as principles of body placement and alignment.

title: Modern Dance Technique: Center Standing Exercises
description: Students explore center standing exercises, standing balances, positions of stillness, and isolations. They further learn the anatomy of dance to understand proper alignment for these movements and stances.

title: The Essential Elements of Modern Dance
description: Students become familiar with various dance rhythms. They are introduced to the essential elements of modern dance shapes, lines, and movement energies while developing coordination and spatial awareness. They begin to garner an understanding of combinations from classic Modern Dance technique.

title: Modern Dance Technique: Jumps, Prances, and Center Exercises
description: Students continue their exploration of Modern Dance technique by learning jumps, prances, and center movements. They learn the anatomy of hips, knees and ankles and their proper alignment in dance movements as well as the use of feet in jumps and prances.

title: Modern Dance Technique: Moving Center Combinations
description: Students continue their exploration of Modern Dance technique by learning moving center combinations with an emphasis on rhythm and spatial awareness and variations of walks and drag cuts with an emphasis on direction and focus.

title: Modern Dance Technique: Across the Floor
description: Students learn and practice combinations in which they move across the floor with various techniques and patterns and learn to put into practice the technical aspects of basic turns.

title: Review of Exercises, Combinations, Alignment, Placement, and Technique
description: Students demonstrate and assess their competency with the range of modern dance exercises and combinations studied so far. In written reflections, they compare their self-assessment with the teacher’s feedback. Students demonstrate their knowledge and assimilation of the various combinations and elements of choreography studied so far.

title: Choreography for Performance
description: Students now develop choreography for performance. They study excerpts from the choreography of dance masters in order to perform dances based on these excerpts. They explore the elements of the techniques that give them the artistic language to create their own relationship with the material. Students have a chance to experience movement exploration and self-expression as dancers.

title: Performance of Modern Dance Choreography
description: This summative assessment coincides with performance of students’ choreography. Students receive summative feedback through the use of recorded performances, self-evaluation reflections on personal experience, and a teacher’s evaluation rubric.

title: The Key Elements of Yoga
description: Students examine the key elements universal to most forms of yoga and familiarize themselves with basic poses. They discuss the benefits of yoga in the context of lifelong health practices.

title: Basic Guidelines on the Physical Practice of Yoga
description: Students review basic physical anatomy as it relates to yogic exercise, with a focus on the structure and function of the spine and joints and the nature of their range of motion. Students begin to understand the principles of correct alignment.

title: Principles of a Safe and Effective Yoga Practice
description: Students discuss how to develop self-awareness of their own physical state and discern certain sensations as either part of the practice or as signals indicating a need to perform the pose with attention to proper alignment. Students learn to modify poses in various ways as needed.

title: Historical Roots of the Practice of Yoga and Meditation
description: Students explore the historical roots of yoga through classic and contemporary texts. They also discuss current perspectives on how yoga practices have evolved from their roots in the East and were adapted in the Western world.

title: Yoga Practice and Sequence
description: Students review basic yoga poses and create their own sets of cards detailing poses and their benefits and variations. They then organize the cards into categories and use them to begin to understand sequencing.

title: Self-Awareness and Progress in Yoga Practice
description: Students review what they have learned so far and examine their personal experience of yoga by writing a reflection on their progress in relation to the goals they set at the beginning of the term.

title: The Breath of Life
description: Students learn about the process of breathing. They understand the physiology of the diaphragm and supporting muscles and practice various breathing techniques during yoga practice.

title: Meditation
description: Students explore ways to adopt good sitting posture and then practice meditation, one of the most universal practices across time and culture. They explore the use of silent meditation, stilling the activity of the mind and following the breath, as well as the practice of mantras and mudras.

title: Designing and Leading Others in a Yoga Sequence
description: Students each lead the class in a yoga sequence they have designed based on their knowledge of poses and philosophy of the practice.

title: Developing a Personal Yoga Practice
description: Students review basic yoga poses. They consider the benefits of a personal yoga practice and devise a plan for future yoga work at home.

title: Riverine Art and Artifacts Sketchbook
description: In Unit 4, students continue to use their sketchbooks as a process journal for their learning experiences. They conduct a search of riverine civilization art on a museum website and choose four artworks to draw in their sketchbooks.

title: Minoan Wall Painting
description: Working together, students create original images based on their research of ancient wall paintings done by the Minoans of Crete. Then, in activities complementing their Mathematics work with fractions, they plot their designs on a grid and transfer them to another, larger grid to create an accurate, larger-scale version of their image on canvas. Finally, by painting each square of their gridded image, students produce their own Minoan-style wall paintings.

title: Empty Bowls Project
description: Students study Minoan pottery shapes, functions, and designs and learn how to throw and form a pot on a potter’s wheel. Then, using the wheel, students create their own Minoan-style bowls. Students use these bowls in conjunction with the Cultural History Empty Bowls Integrated Project, a community outreach hunger awareness program.

title: Understanding Unit Goals
description: Students write and share a reflection about their riverine civilization artwork and learning. They discuss their sketchbooks, projects, and class participation with the teacher. Each student also creates a self-portrait and list of artistic accomplishments to help evaluate the progress they’ve made as artists over the course of the year.

title: Sketchbook
description: Throughout the year, students use their sketchbook as a process journal for their learning experiences in Visual Arts. Students review and discuss their sketchbook work at the end of each learning experience to monitor their own progress, challenges, and accomplishments.

title: The Sun Classroom Experience
description: As a connection to their studies of seasonal changes in Cultural History and to bridge into their studies of the elemental forces, students create a giant paper Sun as a representation of the elemental force of fire.

title: Air in Art
description: Students view a presentation of how artists portray air in art. They listen to a read-aloud of the book Painting the Wind by Patricia and Emily MacLachlan and apply what they learn to drawing a picture that shows air movement.

title: Windsocks
description: In support of their study of the elemental force of air, students create colorful windsocks as a work of art that engages with the elemental force of air.

title: Recycled Pinwheel
description: Students investigate the elemental force of air with wind-powered pinwheels. Students paint, cut, and fold paper squares to create colorful pinwheel forms attached to dowels. Students investigate how the pinwheels catch the air and spin.

title: The Great Wave
description: Students study the image of The Great Wave by Hokusai and make observations about the artist’s style and technique to show the force of the water. Students observe videos of ocean waves, and from their observations they create their own wave paintings.

title: Monet’s Lily Pond
description: Students explore the work of impressionist painter Claude Monet, and discuss how this artist portrayed the elemental force of water in his art. Students then use water-soluble oil pastels to create lily pond paintings inspired by the style of Monet’s work.

title: Underwater Paradise
description: In further study of the elemental force of water, students connect their studies of the elemental force of water to their investigations of freshwater and saltwater habitats by creating an underwater scenic mural for each habitat.

title: Revisiting Clay and the Connection to the Elemental Forces
description: Students revisit the medium of clay and its origins as it relates to and is dependent upon the elemental forces of air, fire, water, and earth. They visit a potter’s studio and create a large coil pot as a collaborative work of art.

title: Self-Portraits and Unit Review
description: Each student conferences with the teacher to review his or her participation, sketchbooks, and works of art from the unit. During the conference, each student is encouraged to share his or her ability to meet goals and to discuss some of their accomplishments and artistic challenges during the unit. Then, to compare their artistic development during the school year, students draw an end-of-year self-portrait. They note their accomplishments as an artist over the school year and compare the new self-portrait to the one they created in Unit 1.

title: Beginnings
description: For this end-of-year theatrical Integrated Project, the class works to create costumes and/or backdrops for their grade-level thematic presentation.

title: Origins and Evidence of Early Ball Sports
description: To begin their study of early ball games and the roots of soccer, students explore early evidence of ball and foot-related games found within cave paintings, writings, images, and oral traditions of riverine cultures. They then begin to formulate an understanding of how the modern game may have originated and evolved.

title: Replication of Early Games
description: Students create and participate in a makeshift version of a possible early ball game based on extrapolations from evidence in artifacts of various riverine cultures. They use guidelines for what their early ball game should include and work as a group to design and perform the basic game.

title: The Evolution of Soccer and Global Variations
description: Students explore the evolution of soccer/football, from the earliest evidence of the game (explored earlier in the unit) to the game as it is played today. Students also learn about variations in the modern game as well as how the social impact of the game varies from culture to culture.

title: Basic Soccer Skill Drills: Footwork and Dribbling
description: Through drills, students begin to explore the basics of ground juggling and then practice toe-touch dribbling and ground juggling in increasingly competitive dribbling drills.

title: One vs. One Dribbling Drills
description: In this assessment of their progress in learning soccer skills, students demonstrate their dribbling skills around a variety of obstacles individually and while competing with a peer in three different dribbling drills of increasing difficulty.

title: Soccer Skill Drills: Passing
description: Students engage in soccer drills that involve passing the ball to one another. They then explore these techniques through one vs. one and two vs. two games, noticing how the game changes with passing.

title: Soccer Skill Drills: Shooting and Scoring
description: Students practice the skills and techniques needed to shoot and score successfully in a soccer game.

title: Developing Soccer Play
description: In this learning experience, students develop an understanding of the basic structure, field positions, rules, and safety considerations related to the game of soccer. They learn game strategies, teamwork skills, and penalty-kick strategies. Through play, they practice their passing and ball-control skills.

title: The Game of Soccer
description: By participating in a Fifth-Grade World Cup tournament, students demonstrate their soccer skills and understanding of teamwork and soccer strategy. Additionally, they complete a written quiz to demonstrate their knowledge of soccer rules.

title: Soccer Across the Globe Presentations
description: To complete the unit, students conduct research and create a presentation about the role of soccer in a modern country. Students trace the evolution of early ball games and the modern sport of soccer in their assigned country and soccer’s role in the country’s culture. They also explore the connection between physical fitness and nutrition in examining the career of a well-known soccer player before analyzing the development of their own physical fitness in this unit.

title: Introduction to Ayurveda
description: Through this learning experience, students explore the earliest system of Hindu traditional medicine, with roots in Ancient Vedic traditions. Emphasis is placed on the history of early Hinduism, including the dietary and philosophical principles of the medical doshas, or three body humors/classifications. Students begin learning about the earliest cultures of the Indus Valley (Harappa and Mohenjo Daro) and the basic premise behind determining one’s personal dosha balance.

title: Vata Lifestyle
description: Students identify the qualities of a person who classifies as “vata dominant” and the most beneficial dietary eating habits, food sources, and yoga exercises for this body type. They also get a basic overview of yoga history and terminology and practice yoga postures that are specifically beneficial to vata-dominant types.

title: Vata
description: In this assessment, students begin to create the pages for the culminating summative assessment, the Ayurvedic Wellness Book. Working together in groups, they compile what they know about either the vata body type and characteristics, vata diet, or the best exercise for vata types. Then each student creates one or more annotated illustration(s) to convey the most essential information on his or her group’s topic.

title: Pitta Lifestyle
description: Students investigate the qualities of a person who classifies as “pitta dominant” and determine the most beneficial dietary patterns, food sources, and types of exercise for such a person. After discovering that heat-releasing activities and low-competitive sports and exercise are ideal for balancing pitta energy, students then identify some of these types of exercises and engage in them.

title: Pitta
description: In this assessment, students begin to create the pages for the culminating summative assessment, the Ayurvedic Wellness Book. Working in small groups, they compile what they know about the pitta body type and characteristics, the pitta diet, or the best exercises for pitta-dominant types. Then each student creates one or more annotated illustration(s) to convey the most essential information on his or her group’s topic.

title: Kapha Lifestyle
description: Students identify the qualities of a person who classifies as “kapha dominant” and explore the most beneficial dietary patterns, food sources, and types of exercise for this type of person. Then, after discovering that the most beneficial exercises for kapha-dominant people are endurance exercises that gradually increase in intensity, students engage in these types of exercise.

title: Kapha
description: In this assessment, student's begin to create the kapha pages for the culminating summative assessment, the Ayurvedic Wellness Book. Continuing to work in the same group they were placed in during the Vata Assessment, they now tackle—for the kapha-dominant person—the one area they have not yet focused on among the following three: diet/food choices, body type and characteristics, or exercise.

title: Yoga Olympics
description: Through this summative assessment, students compete at vata, pitta, and kapha yoga exercises. A victor is honored in each category.

title: Ayurvedic Wellness Book
description: In this summative assessment, students combine the most distinguished visuals they created in the formative assessments of vata, pitta, and kapha doshas with writing they produce now to serve as the basic text for an Ayurvedic Wellness Book.

title: Colonial Games
description: To start this unit, students learn about early colonial games and the pastimes of children living in colonial America. They also investigate the various games that gave rise to baseball.

title: Recreating Colonial Games
description: Students recreate and instruct their classmates in early colonial games, such as marbles, hopscotch, stickball, and tag.

title: Evolution of Baseball
description: In this learning experience, students explore the evolution of baseball from its earliest roots to modern American baseball today.

title: Baseball Skills and Techniques
description: Over the course of several class meetings, students participate in drills and activities in order to develop sport-specific baseball skills. Students develop their catching, throwing, pitching, batting, base-running, and fielding skills and review the rules of the game of baseball.

title: Baseball Game
description: In this assessment, students participate as a team in a game of baseball, applying the skills and rules they have learned throughout the unit.

title: Colonial American Food and Medicine
description: Students learn about the eating habits and food procurement practices of the early colonial Americans. They also discuss early colonial medicine and some of the medical and health challenges faced by colonists.

title: Baseball Report
description: For the final activity in this unit, students write reports reflecting their understanding of the evolution and nature of American baseball. They also create a baseball card for a baseball great of their choice.

title: The Anthropocene Epoch?
description: After viewing two videos that make an argument that humans should be considered a geological force, students partner with classmates and discuss the merits and appropriateness of designating the current time period as the “Anthropocene Epoch.” The pairs then share their analyses with the larger class.

title: Fortune as a River: Understanding the Many Aspects of Flooding
description: Students complete a series of short experiments determining the porosity of various soil combinations and simulate the effects of a number of variables on flooding events. They apply what they have learned to assessment of the impact sea level rise and flooding may have on their local environment.

title: Dwellings Project
description: Incorporating studies in cultural history and science, students find and create examples of early human dwellings. As a class, they create a life-size model shelter.

title: Energy in the Modern World
description: After an overview of types of energy used in the modern period, students discuss the pitfalls of these energy sources and explore alternative sources in small groups, analyzing the sources for efficacy and sustainability, and presenting the groups’ finding to their classmates. The presentation may involve various types of media components.
